HEADLINE: F.D.I.C.'S CHAIRMAN EXPECTS 1990 LOSS ON BANK INSURANCE

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Giving one of his bleakest forecasts to date, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that ever-weakening real estate markets and a near-record number of bank failures were likely to produce the third consecutive annual loss for the fund that insures deposits at commercial banks.
The chairman, L. William Seidman, said the Bank Insurance Fund could lose as much as $2 billion this year, leaving it only $11 billion in assets. That would be the lowest level by far in the 57-year history of the fund, which is separate from the fund that insures deposits at savings and loan associations, and it would be half the level of reserves that regulators and banking experts say is prudent.
''The insurance fund is under considerable stress, and it is at the lowest point at any time in modern history,'' Mr. Seidman said in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee.
 
Previous Warnings
Although the F.D.I.C. chairman has been warning for some months that the fund, which insures $2.7 trillion in deposits at commercial banks, is strained, today's remarks were his first that indicate the losses of the previous two years will continue. 
Moreover, they underscore the strains that have gone beyond the savings and loan industry from excessive real estate lending and are now the main preoccupation of the banking industry.
The F.D.I.C.'s Bank Insurance Fund is one of three funds established by the Government to insure deposits up to $100,000 for each account at commercial banks, savings banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions. Banks and other institutions pay annual premiums for deposit insurance into the funds, which are then used when institutions fail, either to pay off insured depositors or to pay acquirers to cover any losses in taking over the failed institutions.
 
Savings Fund Depleted
The fund that insures the nation's savings and loans is depleted because of the losses in the savings and loan industry. Deposit insurance for failed savings institutions is being covered now by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created last year to oversee the industry's bailout.
The third fund, covering deposits at credit unions, is generally considered to be healthy.
In the case of the F.D.I.C.'s bank fund, to sustain a $2 billion drain on its reserves this year, which are currently at $13.2 billion, it would have to suffer losses on failed banks of almost $6 billion, since it will receive $3 billion in insurance premiums from banks and $1 billion in interest income on its cash reserves.
So far, 112 banks have failed this year, nearly the pace set in both 1988 and 1989. In each of those years, a total of 200 or more banks collapsed.
Mr. Seidman specifically attributed the drain on the fund to the toll that the fast weakening of commercial real estate markets was having on the banking system. What began as a regional downturn in Northeast real estate prices has now spread to most parts of the country, Mr. Seidman said.
A $2 billion loss would mean that by the end of the year, the fund would have between 50 cents and 60 cents for every $100 of deposits it insures, Mr. Seidman said. That is less than half the $1.25 for each $100 of deposits that regulators and industry experts say is an adequate level of reserves. The assets that support the insured deposits fell from $1.10 for each $100 of deposits in 1987 to 80 cents in 1988 and to 70 cents last year.
 
Worries About Bailout
Mr. Seidman's comments immediately raised concerns among banking committee members over whether a bailout by taxpayers, akin to the savings and loan rescue, would be needed. ''Are the resources of the F.D.I.C. adequate?'' asked Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is the chairman of the banking committee.
Mr. Seidman, who has earned a reputation for plain and credible talk, said he did not see the need at this time for taxpayer funds to buttress the fund. ''At this point, we believe we can handle anything we can see,'' he said.
But people in the banking industry said the remarks by Mr. Seidman today and similar remarks he has made in recent weeks have rankled the Adminstration, which has been assailed repeatedly by Democrats in recent weeks over what they say is its slow handling of the savings and loan bailout.
The White House has also been stung by the scrutiny being given the involvement of President Bush's son Neil in the collapsed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver. Mr. Seidman has said that the F.D.I.C. would decide within several weeks whether to bring a negligence suit against Mr. Bush and other Silverado directors.
 
Concern on Confidence Loss
Industry experts say the White House and the Treasury Department are concerned that statements about the weakness of the bank fund could cause a loss of confidence in the Government's deposit insurance program and add to their political troubles as elections approach.
Mr. Seidman's comments underscore, however, the seriousness with which the Treasury is looking at revamping deposit insurance, searching for ways to both restrict the financial exposure of the Government and impose discipline from the marketplace on bankers to reduce the risks they take. Last week, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the Administration was leaning toward limiting the insurance to $100,000 for each depositor, from $100,000 for each account, but would not consider cutting the $100,000 level.
For his part, Mr. Seidman seems to be intent on a public relations campaign meant to gradually educate the public about the precariousness of the financial system, without sparking a panic. He said the loss to the fund would not be the result of one large bank failing, but simply the accumulated cost of bank failures caused by the depressed real estate markets.
 
Change From Earlier in Year
His comments today were a change from earlier in the year, when he predicted that the fund, which rose to peak of $18.3 billion in 1987, was likely to break even for 1990, after losing $4.2 billion in 1988, when there were a number of large bank failures in Texas, and $850 million in 1989.
The disclosure and candor by Mr. Seidman is a stark departure from the approach by regulators several years ago. At that point, regulators were concerned that such public discourse would quickly erode depositor confidence in the banking system, sparking runs. So far, Mr. Seidman has proved that belief wrong.
Some experts said one reason for the continued public confidence is that Congress, in the savings and loan bailout, unequivocally demonstrated that the Government's full borrowing powers still stood behind deposit insurance.
''I think we are living in a different world than the world in which bank regulators were very circumspect about the health of the deposit insurance funds,'' said Stephen Verdier, a lobbyist for the Independent Bankers Association. ''Politicians and the people they represent are demanding to know what the exact status of the funds is. And I think that while before there was some residual uncertainty about whether the Government would step in, there is no doubt now. Deposit insurance is as good as the Treasury. I expect absolutely no panic.''

HEADLINE: REBELS IN TRINIDAD SET PREMIER FREE; 40 ARE STILL HELD

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, July 31

 BODY:
Gunmen from a militant Muslim group released the wounded Prime Minister of this Caribbean island nation today, but they continue to hold other members of the Government who were taken hostage four days ago.
The release of the 63-year-old Prime Minister, Arthur N. R. Robinson, who was sent to a hospital, is the first break in a standoff between the insurgents and the Trinidad Army, which is surrounding the rebel gunmen.
Though some hopes for a peaceful end to the crisis were raised by word that the Prime Minister was free, there is a sense among many here that military action is still under consideration.
 
Caribbean Force Stands By
''This crisis is far from over,'' Anthony Smart, Trinidad's Attorney General, said tonight. ''We are praying for the safety'' of the remaining 40 hostages, he added, including 11 Cabinet officers who are being held in the Parliament building and the offices of the state television. 
Eight other hostages have been freed by the Muslims since Friday.
Diplomats here, including the American Ambassador, Charles A. Gargano, said 200 troops from Jamaica, Barbados and elsewhere in the Caribbean were assembled on Barbados for possible duty in Trinidad, although the Government insists that it has the situation in hand. [Page A6.] Bullet Wound in Leg At the same time, Ambassador Gargano denied that any American troops or hostage specialists had been flown to Trinidad despite rumors that hundreds of marines had been seen in this seaside capital and that American warships had moved off the coast.
Tonight, Mr. Smart refused to say whether Mr. Robinson had acceded to rebel demands that he resign as a condition of his release, adding that the leader had been hospitalized and was in no state to resume his role as head of government, let alone assist in negotiations to free the remaining hostages.
Mr. Smart said Prime Minister Robinson suffered a superficial bullet wound in the leg, which was treated by a fellow hostage, Health Minister Emmanuel Hosein, who is a physician. Mr. Robinson was also said to be suffering from fatigue and glaucoma.
Although Mr. Smart said that the Government was ''continuing its efforts to secure the release of all those still held hostage,'' he indicated that the situation remained explosive. He brushed aside questions about reports that an agreement had been reached and then somehow scuttled on Monday night. ''These discussions are at a very delicate stage and we want lives to be saved,'' he said.
Late today, 15 hostages remained at gunpoint in the Parliament building, 7 of them members of Trinidad's 19-member Cabinet, while 25 other captives, mostly employees of the state television, were being held in the television offices, across town.
 
Wave of Looting
Although water and electricity were being maintained, troops surrounding the buildings have refused to allow food, and the rebel leader complained today that the Government had cut telephone links to his followers in the Parliament house, complicating negotiations.
The hostage siege, which began with a series of armed attacks on the capital early Friday evening, touched off a wave of looting that left Port of Spain's commercial center and much of the surrounding suburbs in smoldering ruins, raising fears that shortages of food, medicine and fuel could set off further unrest in a matter of days. To compound matters, workers due to receive their monthly paychecks were not paid today because of the disruptions.
Late Monday night, while he was a prisoner of the rebels, Mr. Robinson told a reporter for the Caribbean News Agency by telephone that he had agreed to step down as part of an overall agreement that included amnesty for the members of the militant sect holding the hostages, the creation of an interim government and new elections in three months. But his statement was disavowed by a group of politicians who were not seized in the takeover.
 
Rebel Leader Interviewed
This morning, the leader of the rebels, who calls himself Imam Yasin Abu Bakr, asserted in a telephone interview that the Prime Minister's agreement to quit had been undermined by members of a faction within the ruling coalition who were seeking to gain political advantage. Mr. Abu Bakr accused the faction of sabotaging a settlement despite efforts by an Anglican churchman to make a deal with the rebels.
''If God wills - and God don't will wrong - then they'll move in and kill everybody, because then they'll have an excuse,'' said Mr. Abu Bakr, a former Trinidad policeman whose name was Lennox Phillip before his conversion to Islam.
There were also reports that the 5,000-member police force, which may have lost 37 men when its headquarters were attacked by Muslims from the Abu Bakr group on Friday night, was outraged that the Government might agree to an amnesty for the rebel group, known as Jamaat al-Muslimeen, or Society of Muslims.
Since their conversion to Islam, experts say, the group's leaders have remained distant from the mainstream Muslims of Trinidad. Those Muslims are primarily ethnic East Indians, descendants of indentured laborers brought from what are now India and Pakistan to work in the sugar cane fields in the 19th century.
The Government has given no estimate of overall casualty figures, although journalists here have put the the number dead as high as 60, including policemen and soldiers, and more than 300 wounded. Most of the civilians are thought to have been shot by security forces for looting or for violating curfew since Friday night. A 22-hour curfew is in effect around the hostage sites, while all people elsewhere in the country must remain indoors except between noon and 6 P.M.
Maj. Dave Williams, a spokesman for the 1,500-member armed forces, said the Muslims, whose number has been put as about 50 gunmen in each building, seemed to ''operate like a trained military force'' in tactics and in their use of automatic weapons and small arms. He would not comment on reports that the rebels have mortars and rocket-propelled grenades.
Whatever the case, there seems to be wide agreement among Trinidadians that the episode is a calamity for this petroleum-producing country, which has been reeling from a series of economic setbacks that began five years ago with the collapse of oil prices.
At Independence Square, a 10-block shopping center in the heart of Port of Spain, virtually every business, from supermarkets and electronics stores to dress shops and hardware outlets, had been looted and in some cases burned.
On the East-West Corridor, the main highway between the capital and the northeast coast, shopping centers and huge warehouses once brimming with everything from frozen meat to automobile tires had been devastated. Trinidadians said many looted goods were available at bargain prices in the streets over the weekend.
''I have enough to feed my family for now, but I'm afraid what will happen later,'' said Evonne Thornhill, a 54-year-old worker in a paper-bag factory.

HEADLINE: Reorganizing the Yankees;
Other Owners Either Silent Or Still Quietly Surprised

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
A day after George Steinbrenner was stripped of control of the Yankees, his fellow owners generally maintained their sedate postures.
Some, like Bill Giles, the owner and president of the Philadelphia Phillies, expressed surprise at the severity of the sanction imposed by Commissioner Fay Vincent, but did not question it. Others, like Larry Lucchino, the president of the Baltimore Orioles, issued brief noncommittal statements looking to the future. 
Most were simply noncommittal, either withholding or reserving comment or not returning phone calls seeking their opinions.
 
No Comment From Mets
Nelson Doubleday, the chairman of the Mets, was traveling yesterday, and Fred Wilpon, the club's president, was occupied in meetings. Neither returned messages left with their offices.
Few executives were as loquacious as Giles. ''It is very unfortunate when any owner is penalized by the commissioner of baseball,'' Giles said. ''I was surprised by the severity of Commissioner Vincent's decision, but I had no knowledge of the case other than what I learned through the news media.''
Lucchino was even less outspoken, declining to elaborate on a two-sentence statement issued by his office.
''Baseball has a proven process for the resolution of these matters.'' it began. ''That process has now been completed, and it's time to turn our attention back to the game on the field,'' it ended.
Jerry Reinsdorf, chairman of the Chicago White Sox, took a similar tack. ''I am pleased the matter has finally been resolved,'' he said.
In Milwaukee, Bud Selig, the president of the Brewers, said he would have no comment until he had read the commissioner's report, and in Los Angeles, Gene Autry, the owner of the California Angels, said he would have no comment at all.
One baseball man who was a bit more forthcoming was Dallas Green, a former Yankee manager. ''I was surprised by the severity of the penalty. But Fay apparently knows a little bit more about it than we do,'' Green said. ''It's tough to hit a guy when he is down, but George has always been his own worst enemy.''
Green expressed reservations about Steinbrenner's plans to turn operation of the team over to his son Hank. ''I don't think he's the kind of person they need,'' Green said. ''The Yankees desperately need a baseball person, a strong baseball person.'' Someone, perhaps, like Green? ''I'm unemployed,'' he said, ''but I'm not available for that. There's still too much Steinbrenner influence in that situation. You'll find somebody to take that job, but you won't find a Dave Winfield or a Dallas Green or a Yogi Berra.''

LENGTH: 421 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Helps Underwrite Guatemala Terror

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I want to commend your articles (most recently, July 5) about the increasing violence in Guatemala. Your contribution is vital because so few Americans know that Guatemala has one of the most repressive regimes in Central America.
I learned about this country during a Witness for Peace trip this year. We spent five days meeting with religious leaders, educators, peasants, women's groups and the military. We learned rapidly how dangerous the situation is for dissenters. Students, union leaders, health agents and church workers are targets because they threaten the Government with ideas of social, political and economic reform. Few who know the situation deny that the so-called democratic Government is a facade for the military, who retain control by intimidation and murder. Amnesty International has reported that human rights crimes in Guatemala account for nearly half of all human rights violations in Central America. 
In Guatemala City, we interviewed a member of an organization started by mothers of the ''disappeared,'' that is, people kidnapped by the police or military and never heard from again. If they are discovered, it is as corpses with evidence of torture.
The woman said they had always been a close-knit family. Then one of her daughters disappeared as she walked home from the university. Her other daughter fled in fear to Canada, broke down in her isolation and is now in a mental hospital. Her remaining children, two sons, have been threatened. One has sought asylum in California; the other has quit the university out of fear and is torn about leaving his mother alone or escaping to another country.
These mothers and members of their families risk their lives by organizing demonstrations, carrying pictures of their loved ones, searching prisons and appealing to the world for help. The woman we interviewed spoke to us hoping we would go back to the United States and let others know what is happening.
Her case is but one example of the injustices Guatemalans suffer from a regime supported with our tax dollars. Most sources agree that in the last 20 years more than 100,000 people have been murdered by the military; 40,000 have disappeared, and 100,000 have been forced into exile.
We must let our representatives know that we oppose the use of our tax dollars where people are not free to dissent and where opposition to the Government is suppressed by murder, by torture and by ''disappearances.''
 
YOLANDA T. WESELY
Scarsdale, N.Y., July 9, 1990

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Enemies List Getting Shorter: Some Hate It

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
Now hatred is by far the longest pleasure; Men love in haste, but they detest at leisure. - Lord Byron
$/
One New Yorker said yesterday that he felt as good as he had on the day Richard M. Nixon resigned. Yet not having George Steinbrenner to kick around anymore poses a risk: whom do we have to hate?
Within less than a year, several of New York's most ubiquitous targets of antipathy fell from grace and were transformed, against their will, naturally, into almost pitiable figures: Edward I. Koch lost the mayoralty; Leona Helmsley was sentenced to prison, and Donald J. Trump was placed on a monthly allowance. This week, the source of public enmity No. 1, Mr. Steinbrenner, was ordered by the commissioner of baseball, Fay Vincent, to yield control of the Yankees. 
His perceived villainy could never be considered in the same league as Walter O'Malley's. But during most of Mr. Steinbrenner's 17 seasons of discontent as principal owner of the Yankees, a team some New Yorkers loved to hate anyway, he has consistently been the best target in town.
If this were merely a local phenomenon, even in a city with as many would-be opinion makers as New York, it would be serious enough. But attrition has shrunk the nation's enemies list, too. The form of Communism that Americans comfortably feared is collapsing and the number of reviled dictators has shriveled to just a few. If people are known by their enemies, our definition is unraveling.
Fear plus hate equal power, Eugene Burdick once wrote. Today, power has become so diffuse that billions of dollars can be diverted in a savings-and-loan scandal without anyone being singled out for blame. Television - by contributing to the crowd-pleasing blanding of America and by stifling conversation - has sapped our national venom. Potential targets are faceless behind a corporate veil.
Many government figures no longer loom large enough to hate. Can anyone really get into a lather over the villainy of Stanley Simon, the former Borough President of the Bronx.
Roy Cohn died. Rupert Murdoch sold The New York Post. Jimmy Breslin stopped writing his annual list of people he isn't talking to. And Richard Nixon keeps edging closer to rehabilitation, although that prospect alone gives some people still another reason to hate him.
For some haters in this city, the best hope might be the Rev. Al Sharpton. If he is sidelined with a sore throat, New Yorkers would be left empty-handed.
Might not the absence of hate be a positive development, ushering in an era of good will? It might, except that what has dissipated is not hate, but handy targets. All the talk or a mellower America and all the blue unity ribbons notwithstanding, some deep thinkers consider hatred to be a healthy emotion, properly directed.
''We have to have certain targets,'' Dr. Vamik Volkan, a psychiatrist at the University of Virginia, said yesterday, elaborating on the thesis of his book, ''The Need to Have Enemies and Allies,'' published by Jason Aronson.
''We also need to feel secure and cohesive in our identities as a group,'' Dr. Volkan said. ''There's something about yourself that you do not like, so you say it doesn't belong to me, it belongs to someone else.''
''The whole idea,'' he said, ''is to keep your self-esteem. I call it in-projection-projection-relatedness.''
Mr. Steinbrenner, Dr. Volkan said, represents ''a transference figure - one of those people, like Presidents and sports figures, who absorb many of our wishes as well as our defenses against what we're not.''
Will an absence of transference figures manifest itself in an era of good feeling, a frantic search for new targets or a period of self-hate? ''All of the above,'' Dr. Volkan replied. He suggested that the absence of popular villains - and, with the possible exception of such distant figures as Nelson Mandela, of heroes, too - is only transitory because people in stressful cities, with so many different ethnic and economic groups, also abhor a vacuum.
His optimism was echoed by another interpreter of popular culture, Jerry Della Femina, the advertising executive.
''We need people to hate because it brings New York together,'' Mr. Della Femina said. ''I see a big Dinkins hate coming.'' Mr. Della Femina recalled that even Mr. Steinbrenner was once, many seasons ago, a hero to some people. ''Let's not lose hope,'' he said. ''There are people we still admire who we could learn to hate.''

HEADLINE: Minority Role in Broadcasting Yields Far Bigger Effect on Radio Than TV

BYLINE: By JEREMY GERARD

 BODY:
After Federal and local law-enforcement officials arrested Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington on drug charges in January, Cathy Hughes devoted a week of her morning radio talk show on WOL-AM to issues raised by the arrest.
Hers was not the only call-in radio show in the capital to explore Mr. Barry's troubles. Indeed, the Mayor made himself prominently available to WOL and other stations that specifically serve minority audiences. But many listeners said WOL's programs addressed issues in the case, including the role of race, that were of particular concern to the station's largely black audience. 
Executives and experts in broadcasting say this kind of programming, directed at audiences not regularly addressed by mainstream radio and television, is precisely what the Federal Communications Commission was seeking in 1978, when it instituted policies that give preference to minority applicants for broadcast licenses.
But they also say such programming is usually found only on AM radio stations like WOL, and is still greatly underrepresented on television despite a modest increase in the ownership of television stations by minority members.
 
'Stayed With the Same Style'
''I would say there has been no change at all in our programming,'' said Sean Bradley, the station manager at KTBY-TV in Anchorage, a Fox affiliate that changed to minority ownership in 1985 with help from the F.C.C. ''We've stayed with the same style,'' Mr. Bradley said. The commission's policies, which were upheld by the Supreme Court in June, give preference to qualified minority applicants for broadcast licenses and allow a station owner in danger of losing a license for financial or other reasons to sell it to a qualified minority applicant. Both policies give tax advantages to owners and minority buyers.
The commission says the policies have increased the minority ownership of radio and television stations from about 1 percent in 1978 to about 3.5 percent today. Among the nation's 12,000 radio licenses and 1,200 television licenses, 182 radio stations and 17 television stations are licensed to 110 companies owned by blacks, according to the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters, a Washington trade group. Other minorities are considerably less represented among owners, the F.C.C. says.
''I'm not sure there is any special responsibility to do increased minority programming,'' said James S. Winston, executive director and general counsel to the black broadcasters' group. ''However, the vast majority of owners do that. The greatest change by far is in radio, which goes to a smaller and more targeted audience than television.''
WTNH-TV in New Haven is the rare example of a television station whose programming has been affected by its transfer to minority ownership.
 
Community Affairs Programming
''We've changed a certain focus in community affairs programming,'' said Lew Freifeld, vice president and general manager of the station. WTNH, an ABC affiliate, was sold in 1985 by Capital Cities Inc. to the Cook Inlet Communications Corporation, an Aleut and Eskimo company whose headquarters are in Anchorage.
''We took a story line or an issue -last year we did 'For a Drug-Free Generation' - and allocated all of our resources toward that,'' Mr. Freifeld said. ''We pre-empted prime time. In the past that wasn't true.''
He attributed the changes to WTNH's new owner. Under the F.C.C. policies, Cook Inlet, owned by 6,500 Aleut and Eskimo shareholders, has purchased 11 radio stations and WSMV-TV in Nashville, in addition to WTNH. Both television stations have won awards for public service programs, said George V. Kriste, a Cook Inlet executive.
Minority owners, like their white colleagues, face the task of making their stations successful businesses. Increasing the number of voices, they said, is a goal that can be met only with more minority owners in the broadcasting marketplace.
 
No Plans to 'Narrowcast'
Two years ago W. Don Cornwell, who is black, left Wall Street to form the Granite Broadcasting Corporation, which now owns two ABC and two NBC affiliates and plans to buy more. Mr. Cornwell said he did not buy those stations to serve a small audience. ''You don't buy it to narrow-cast,'' he said. ''Unlike a radio station, there's a broader perspective.''
At the affiliates, the executives said, the commission's policies have had less effect on programming. Managers at affiliate stations said that while they adhered to the network schedule, minority ownership had increased their sensitivity to concerns of minorities in local news and public affairs.
Minority owners, as well as civic leaders, also scrutinize the stations' hiring practices, they added.
''You do have a high interest in happenings in the minority community,'' said Stephen H. Kimatian, president and general manager of WKBW-TV in Buffalo. WKBW, an ABC affiliate, became the nation's largest black-owned television station in 1986 when it was bought from Capital Cities by Queen City Broadcasting Inc. The chairman and majority stockholder of Queen City is J. Bruce Llewellyn, a soft-drink executive from Philadelphia who is black.
 
'Accent and Emphasize'
While WKBW fills prime time and much of the daytime schedule with ABC programs, the station, like other affiliates, draws from syndicated shows for some hours of the day, including those immediately before and after the evening news.
''You select programs with a value to minorities; you do accent and emphasize,'' Mr. Kimatian said. He added that under the new owner, ''Buffalo Beat,'' a locally produced community affairs program, had increased reporting on subjects like unemployment, racism and drug abuse, which are of great concern in Buffalo, whose population is 28 percent minority.
The minority ownership policies enabled Ms. Hughes to buy WOL in 1980, when she changed the Washington station's format from music to a combination of talk and music. She later moved the station from Georgetown to a ground-floor studio in downtown Washington, where passers-by can watch the announcers. WOL is much like the community bulletin board station in Spike Lee's film ''Do the Right Thing.''
In New York, WLIB-AM, another black-owned radio station that was bought with help from the F.C.C. policies, also features talk shows that address current issues from a distinctly black perspective, and there are others in major cities around the country.
But most executives said greater diversity in programming, especially on television, would not come until there were more minority owners.
''As so often is the case with minorities,'' said Gerald D. Smith, an executive at WOL, ''until you get in the front door you can't move around the house.''

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
A Plan Aimed at Improving Schools

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

DATELINE: MOBILE, Ala., July 31

 BODY:
The nation's governors today approved plans intended to give backbone to their national education policies, but the package was greeted with skepticism by some education groups.
The proposals, which could run into trouble with voters because of the costs, was the clearest indication yet of who will assume the lead in establishing, financing and accepting responsibility for programs to meet the six ambitious goals set forth earlier this year by President Bush and the governors as a way to overhaul American schools by the year 2000.
''The time for excuses is running out if we're going to remain a first-world country,'' Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington said in an interview at the summer meeting of the National Governors' Association, which elected him its next chairman. ''We have to do with the resources we have. In my state I'm ultimately accountable.'' 
The issues of accountability and financing had been unclear since the first announcement of the goals. But today the governors approved the creation of a 14-member committee that will include six governors, equally divided between the political parties, and four Administration appointees. That will put the bulk of responsibility in the hands of the Governors.
Two senators and two representatives, also from from both parties, will also join the panel, but only as advisers.
 
Strategies for Meeting Goals
In addition to establishing the committee, the governors approved a long list of strategies to provide guidance on meeting the six general goals. Strategies at the state level include things like reducing red tape in local school systems and holding students more accountable for their performance. Strategies at the national level include easing restrictions on how some Federal money is spent.
The committee will issue an annual report evaluating each state's progress on the strategies and the six larger goals.
Although both the Administration and Congressional leaders have roles in putting the goals in place, some governors said it made sense for the states to take the lead, because the proposals were largely a result of their work. In addition, they said states on average pay for about 50 percent of education expenses, as against the Federal Government's 8 percent.
Governors face significant hurdles in trying to meet the goals. Many state budgets have been hobbled by soft economies that leave little room for more education money. Proposals for more taxes to pay for school improvements are likely to run into hostile voters, many of whom are increasingly weary of paying for inadequate schools.
 
Governor Pays With His Job
Moreover, even changes aimed at improvement can carry risks. In 1986, for example, Gov. Mark White of Texas was defeated after he proposed teacher competency testing and a requirement that students have passing grades before they could participate in extracurricular activities. In what could be their sternest test, governors may face resistance from some educators who already feel beleaguered and blamed for the faults of American schools.
Although some governors, like Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, complained about inadequate Federal financing and argued that some savings from military budget cuts should go to education, many more of the state chiefs here said the largest share of financing was the responsibility of states.
''The reality is there is finite money,'' said Governor Gardner of Washington, a Democrat.
In many states, educational revisions are already under way or soon will be, and the increases in spending came at the expense of other state programs. Since their efforts are in line with the national goals, officials in those states have urged the others to go along with assuming most of the responsibility at the state level.
''Everybody has enough money to pay for education if that's their priority,'' said Gov. Ray Mabus of Mississippi. Mississippi, for instance, in 1988 raised teachers' annual average pay to $24,500, moving the state to 42d from last in teacher salaries.
 
Questions on Accountability
Officials of education groups said they had hoped for more clarity on the issues of accountability and finances. The said they were afraid that the absence of a definitive statement on those issues would leave their members open to further blame for the decline of education and render the goals unworkable.
''They set up a system for everyone to be held accountable, but the committee isn't responsible to anyone,'' said Samuel B. Husk, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, an association of 45 urban districts with 5 million students representing about 10 percent of the national school enrollment. ''They completely ignored funding,'' he added.
Martha C. Fricke, president of the National School Boards Association, said she was afraid that without more definitive language over responsibility and finances, local boards would become scapegoats. ''We've been burned before,'' she said.
Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, a Denver organization that helps states coordinate education policy, said schools would be held more accountable under the governors' plan.
But Mr. Newman, who served on an advisory committee that assisted in formulating the goals, disputed assertions by some members of education groups that the burden of accountability would unfairly fall on them instead of the politicans.
''This is not public posturing'' by the governors, he said. ''They've stuck with the idea and have said that they're going to be accountable.''

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
About Education

BYLINE: Fred M. Hechinger

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
In a contest between child care in France and the United States, American children are the losers.
''Why don't you change it? It is incredible for a large rich country to accept the terrible infant-mortality rate. It's crazy.''
That was how a woman who helps oversee child-care and preschool education in France reacted to the way America treats its infants and children. The official, Solange Passaris, special counselor on early childhood and motherhood to the Ministry of Health and Social Protection, said in an interview that because Europe was no longer in economic crisis it could now deal with children's welfare as part of a country's economic well-being. 
She said she did not understand how the United States could accept ranking 19th in the world in the prevention of infant deaths while France ranked fourth.
National commitment may be at the heart of the matter. Even discounting the French passion for dramatic style, there is a political message in President Francois Mitterrand's statement that ''France will blossom in its children.'' Or, as the president of the French-American Foundation, Edward H. Tuck, said more prosaically in a recent report by the foundation, ''A Welcome for Every Child,'' France's success is attributable to ''national policies focused on children, highly trained staffs, clearly defined responsibilities among agencies and a committed leadership at all levels of government.''
Child care in France enjoys strong support from business and industry. ''We try to create a partnership between business, the unions and government,'' Mrs. Passaris said.
Maternal leaves with pay begin six weeks before birth and continue for 10 weeks after delivery. Corporate leaders do not appear to be concerned over any possible negative effect on productivity and profits.
By contrast, American business interests lobbied so successfully against legislation that would have provided 10 weeks of unpaid maternity leaves that President Bush vetoed it.
To strengthen the family, French parents may take off two years without pay after a child's birth, knowing that their jobs remain protected.
On major issues, this is truly a tale of two countries.
Pre- and postnatal health care, lacking for so many poor women and their babies in the United States, is firmly anchored in French national policy. So is immunization, which in the United States has become increasingly erratic, leading to the revival of children's diseases that had been considered virtually extinct.
French eductors, health experts and politicians appreciate the close link between preventive health care and children's future success in school and life.
In the United States, millions of children are exposed to unlicensed day care. In high-quality centers, the cost is high. That creates great disparities in the lives of rich and poor children.
In France, the cost of care for children up to the age of 3 ranges from $195 a year for the poorest families to a maximum of $4,700 for the wealthiest.
Preschool for 3-to-5-year-olds is free, and 98 percent of the children attend it, more than three times the American percentage. Safe and nurturing places for young children of working parents are available from early morning to late afternoon.
In the United States, low pay and low status severely hamper the staffing of child-care centers. According to a recent report by the General Accounting Office, 40 percent of the workers in child-care centers in the United States leave each year.
French preschool teachers hold the equivalent of a master's degree in early childhood and elementary education. The directors of child-care centers are pediatric nurses, with additional training in public health and child development. Staff members have the equivalent of two years of college plus a two-year course in child development and early childhood education.
As an incentive, France offers students of preschool education free college tuition plus a stipend in return for a pledge to work in the field for at least five years after graduation.
Home care, which allows families to take in three children in addition to their own, is also licensed. In addition to daily compensation, family day-care providers are covered by Social Security, disability and unemployment insurance.
The home-care system is augmented with small-group centers to allow the children to mingle with others once a week.
A look at child care in industrial societies suggests that under regulated capitalism, as in France, or in social democracies, as in Scandinavia, children's welfare is protected because it is viewed as crucial to the children's and the nations' futures.
By contrast, leaving child care exposed to the uncertainties of a largely unregulated free market, as in the United States and Britain, has created conditions that Mrs. Passaris calls crazy. The practice leaves many children with inadequate care and permanently damaged, a costly liability to society.

LENGTH: 1617 words

HEADLINE: A Girl Trout Needs a Boy Trout The Way a Fish Needs a Bicycle

BYLINE: By DENA KLEIMAN

DATELINE: UHL, Idaho

 BODY:
THEY call this stark, spectacular crevice of Idaho the Magic Valley after a trick of nature that sends more than a million gallons of water a minute down its vast canyon walls.
But that is not the only trick of nature going on here at the Clear Springs Trout Company, 120 miles south of Boise. There is another, human trick that now makes it possible for a business executive to orchestrate the production of a fish egg, fertilize it, dictate its sex, hatch it and manipulate its growth rate to produce the ''fresh'' rainbow trout that most people find on their dinner plates - and in far less time than nature intended.
Clear Springs, amid the lava rock along the Snake River here, is one of the largest and most advanced trout farms in the world. And the work it has done here - domesticating wild animals and turning them into the underwater equivalent of the modern farm-raised chicken - reflects a transformation of the entire seafood industry, as aquaculture spreads and techniques improve. 
Fish farming has soared in the United States in recent years as pollution, over-fishing and other environmental problems have depleted supplies of fish in the wild. In 1980, farms provided only about 1 percent of all the fish consumed; today they provide more than 10 percent, according to the Commerce Department, which predicted that the figure would rise to 20 percent by the turn of the century.
Species being farmed today include striped bass, shrimp, tilapia, salmon, sturgeon, redfish, oysters, clams, crayfish and catfish. But none have been farmed as long as trout, nor with such technical sophistication.
The trout was once exclusively wild, and it still evokes images of clear rushing mountain streams and fishermen in rubber boots. But today almost none of the trout eaten by Americans come from the wild. The Agriculture Department said more than 99 percent of the 57 million pounds of trout now consumed each year in this country are farmed. Nearly 60 percent of the trout farmed in the United States are raised in Idaho (the other states include North Carolina and California), and more than half of the Idaho fish come from Clear Springs.
Less than 15 years ago, it took 18 months to grow an edible trout on a farm. (In the wild, it can take up to three years.) Today it takes less than 12 months, and scientists at Clear Springs hope, over the next 15 years, to cut that time in half.
''What we're seeking is a more efficient animal,'' said Larry Cope, the president of Clear Springs. He pointed out that it takes only six weeks to grow a chicken. The secret: female trout. Officials of the company said they hoped to eliminate all males from their stock and breed a super race of trout - all female - because females are better than males in appearance, texture, growth rate and taste. The problem with male trout is that they become unattractive and their texture gets ''mushy'' as they age. They also become combative and waste energy chasing each other.
''They develop a skinny appearance and dark, unattractive skin,'' said Dave Erickson, the director of technical services for Clear Springs.
''They become mushy and the yield goes down,'' said Jim Parsons, a research scientist at the company.
As of mid-July, 62.5 percent of the 22 million trout at Clear Springs were female. The goal over the next three years is to raise that to 100 percent, using genetic tricks and male hormones.
Other companies are also using genetic engineering to make fish farming more efficient. Dr. James P. McVey, an associate program director at the National Sea Grant College Program, which finances aquaculture research for the Commerce Department, said that some 40 percent of all the oysters now being consumed in the United States are sterile oysters that have been altered to channel all their energy into growth rather than reproduction. Other changes are also becoming increasingly widespread, prompting some critics to condemn such genetic manipulation.
''It is a violation of a species' integrity,'' said Jeremy Rifkin, the president of the Foundation on Economic Trends in Washington and an outspoken critic of genetic engineering.
And as more and more species are being bred on farms, some wildlife organizations are voicing concern that domesticated and genetically engineered animals could weaken species that are surviving in the wild.
''I've been afraid of this happening,'' said Bill Bakke, the executive director of Oregon Trout, a conservation organization in Portland, when told of Clear Springs's decision to grow nothing but female fish. Mr. Bakke said he feared that genetically altered fish could end up intermingling with wild fish, which must survive under totally different conditions.
In response, Clear Springs said that there was only a remote chance that one of its trout would escape, and that even if one did escape it was unlikely to cause significant damage.
The company's attempts to grow the most trout in the shortest time with the least food in the smallest amount of water are considered the standard for the industry by the National Fisheries Institute, a trade organization for processors. Other companies frequently send observers to Clear Springs for a glimpse, perhaps, of the future.
The company has four farms, which get most of their fertilized eggs from a spawning station 200 miles away in Soda Springs, Idaho. That is where the genetic destiny of male trout is rerouted, and this is how it works:
Mature eggs are removed by hand from specially selected females that have been bred for speed of growth as well as texture, flavor and resistance to disease. Other, similarly selected, females are fed testosterone, a male hormone that causes them to grow male sex organs and enables them to produce sperm.
But while male sperm typically contains an X chromosome and a Y chromosome, these fish remain genetically female, and their sperm contains only X chromosomes. When this sperm is used to fertilize the eggs, which also contain only X chromosomes, the offspring are all female. (The company decided to use this procedure rather than to feed female hormones to male fish because, a Clear Springs spokesman said, it did not want to feed hormones directly to fish that people would eat.) The fertilized eggs are then shipped from Soda Springs to Buhl, where they go to the four farms. Separate farms are maintained to guard against catastrophe; in 1974 the company was almost wiped out when it lost 840,000 pounds of fish in a single night when a wall collapsed and drained an entire farm of water.
Each farm is on about eight acres of land. Each has a ''hatch house,'' a vast greenhouse-like structure that houses the fertilized eggs and youngest fish. At the Box Canyon farm, 20 three-foot high cylinders of circulating water are lined up along one wall in the hatch house. Each holds about 150,000 eggs for 12 days, until they hatch.
Then the eggs are siphoned into 60-foot-long concrete ''ponds'' where they remain for 35 to 40 days, growing to a length of several inches. In the ponds, they are fed a high-calorie mixture of anchovies, herring, wheat germ, molasses and fish oil, mashed to the consistency of moist flour.
There was a time when trout spawned only in the spring. But now through selective breeding and tricks of lighting developed at the company, they can be made to spawn for 10 months of the year. The fish are held in tanks where artifical lighting simulates daylight and the lengthening of the days, tricking them into thinking it is time to spawn.
At the age of about 3 months, the trout are transferred outdoors at each farm to a complex of 180 outdoor raceways, each 18 feet wide and 150 feet long and filled with swiftly moving water that simulates a natural stream. Their growth is monitored by computer and controlled by the amount of feed, which is also developed and manufactured at Clear Springs.
Only a few years ago, trout required three pounds of food to gain one pound in weight, but now they need only about 1.3 pounds of food to gain a pound, in part because of selective breeding and in part because of better understanding of trout digestion.
''Trout are carnivores,'' said Mr. Erickson, the director of technical services. To keep smaller trout from being eaten by bigger trout, a series of gates separate the larger fish from the small. Even though several hundred thousand fish swim around at close quarters, there is no odor at the farm. The only sound is that of rushing water.
Indeed it is the steady supply of water that lures fish farmers to Magic Valley. Not only is the water fresh, clean and constant, its temperature is exactly 58 degrees year round. That means it is always spring - spawning time - for the trout. The water source is a 100-mile-long aquifer that is fed from melting mountain snows to the north.
Six strains of fish that have been bred for rapid growth, superiority of taste and resistance to disease produce the millions of fish at Clear Springs.
These trout remain in their outdoor raceways for 8 to 10 months. Their runways are periodically cleaned of waste, which is donated to local farmers for fertilizer.
As the company receives orders, the fish are taken by truck to a processing plant, where they are cleaned and prepared for sale in a variety of forms: dressed, filleted, frozen and stuffed (the recipe for the stuffing is the company's own). On average, 75,000 pounds of trout are processed each day and are sent in the company's trucks to chains like Shop Rite, Grand Union, Ponderosa and Red Lobster.
''We're not different from other animal industries,'' said Mr. Cope, the Clear Springs president. ''Our animal just lives in the water.''

HEADLINE: Currency Markets;
Tumbling U.S. Dollar Could Hit New Lows

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Weakened by a sluggish economy and the expectation of lower interest rates, the American dollar is tumbling, and many economists expect it to reach or come close to all-time lows against several leading currencies.
The dollar has fallen 3.2 percent against the West German mark over the last three weeks, declining yesterday to 1.5888 against the West German mark, just above its post-World War II low of 1.57. It continued to slide against the Swiss franc, the British pound and many other currencies.
The Japanese yen is the only exception to the trend. While the dollar fell yesterday against the yen, it is still stronger than it was at the beginning of the year, partly because of political problems in Japan and continued uncertainity about economic policy there. 
American corporations with operations in Europe are already benefiting from the fall because their earnings from abroad, when they are translated back into dollars, are worth more. But the declining dollar shrinks the spending power of American tourists abroad.
If the dollar stays at these low levels for several months, American exporters will benefit because the lower dollar makes their products more competitive abroad. It would also make imports more expensive and less attractive to American consumers.
 
Importers Feel the Pinch
Some importers are already feeling the pinch. ''I'm beginning to see substantial increases in the prices of champagne and cognac,'' said Michael Kapon, president of Acker, Merrill and Condit, a liquor store in Manhattan.
Rising import prices here could increase inflation but some economists feel that with a slowing economy and declining demand the impact will be much less than might be expected.
Many analysts have been predicting for much of the year that the dollar would move lower because of rising interest rates abroad and declining rates in the United States. This makes investment in dollar-denominated securities less attractive.
But it took several events in the last three weeks to solidify the bias toward a lower dollar. The Federal Reserve eased credit slightly in mid-July and Alan Greenspan, its chairman, expressed concern about the weakening economy.
Friday's report on the gross national product, which showed that the economy grew more slowly in the second quarter than had been expected and that it is not far from a recession, added further downward pressure on the dollar.
''I don't care what the level of the dollar is, whether it's at its all time low or not,'' said Liliana Nealon, vice president for foreign exchange sales at Union Bank of Switzerland. ''The way to be is short on the dollar.''
This is the first time since 1985 that the dollar has moved significantly without the direct encouragement or obvious objections of the Group of Seven, which includes the United States and its chief economic allies: Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada.
From 1985 to 1987, the Group of Seven worked with interest rate moves and aggressive market intervention to push the dollar from record highs as a way to reduce the United States trade deficit, which was then at record highs. Since last fall, the Group of Seven has worked to keep the dollar from rebounding again.
The Group of Seven has not raised any objections to the dollar's levels, an indication, analysts said, of its general approval and that member nations are concentrating on domestic economic politics.
Both the Germans and the Japanese want their currencies to be stronger to help fight inflation at home. In the United States, the Federal Reserve is more worried about a recession than the inflationary impact of a lower dollar. And a lower dollar could also help further reduce the American trade deficit by making American exports more competitive and imports more expensive.
So many traders and analysts do not think the Group of Seven will object to the new lows, although they intervened in the market at the beginning of 1987 to keep the dollar from falling below its all-time low of 1.57 marks.
''I don't think that in the given circumstances the U.S. Treasury will fight this,'' said David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services.
In trading yesterday, the dollar closed at 1.5888 marks, which is just above the second-lowest level of 1.5880 reached on Jan. 4, 1988. The dollar hit its record low against the mark, which was created in 1948, on Dec. 31, 1987. Including yesterday's spurt, the German mark has risen 3.3 percent in the last two weeks, while the yen has picked up only 1 percent. It closed at 145.84 to the dollar in late New York trading, up in value from 147.83 late Monday.
The dollar also moved closer to a record low against the Swiss franc, closing at 1.3455 yesterday, the lowest since Jan 20, 1988. Its slide against the British pound to $1.8639 pushed it near a 20-month low, but still far above its all time low, while the drop against the French franc to 5.3255 reached a two and a half year low.
Analysts expect the dollar to fall even further because interest rates are rising abroad. But they generally agree that the dollar will continue to be much stronger against the yen than against European currencies.
Both short and long-term interest rates in Japan have been rising since the end of June and many analysts now expect the Bank of Japan soon to raise its official discount rate, which is now 5.25 percent. In West Germany, rates should remain high and some economists expect the Bundesbank to push interest rates higher to help curb inflation as the two Germanys merge.
In the United States, the Federal Reserve surprised the market with its easing of interest rates on July 13. More easing is expected, but the timing is uncertain.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid to Farmers Unchanged in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
The prices farmers get for raw products were unchanged from June to July, but the overall commodity price index was still 2.7 percent above a year before, the Agriculture Department said today.
Prices were higher in the month for lettuce, apples and milk, but declines were reported for cattle, wheat and eggs, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report.
Most prices are mid-July averages that will be revised next month. For example, the latest report showed June prices dropped 2 percent instead of the 1.3 percent decline indicated a month ago. 
The report also showed prices farmers pay to meet expenses were up five-tenths of a percent from April, when the previous estimate was made, and 3.4 percent above July, 1989. The prices paid index is computed quarterly.
Department economists say consumer food prices are going up much faster this year than the earlier prediction of 3 to 5 percent.
Ralph L. Parlett Jr. of the department's Economic Research Service said in a telephone interview that a 1990 forecast due in August will ''put us right back to the early 1980's'' when retail food prices were climbing steeply. Annual food price increases were 8.6 percent in 1980 and 7.9 percent in 1981 before slowing in the next few years.
Mr. Parlett did not disclose the new forecast but indicated the 1990 increase would probably exceed 6 percent. Food prices rose 5.8 percent in 1989, the most since 1981.
''It's obvious that 3 to 5 percent forecast is out in left field,'' he said. ''Beef and pork, that's what's doing it - pork, particularly.''
Recent forecasts show the net cash income of farmers in the range of $55 billion to $59 billion, compared with about $54 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988.
Based on the preliminary figures, the July price index for livestock and poultry dropped 1.2 percent from June but still averaged 8.9 percent more than a year earlier. Meat animals were down 1.5 percent from June but averaged 11 percent more than a year before.
Milk prices rose 30 cents in July to an average of $14.10 for l00 pounds. That was up $1.50 from July 1989. The farm price of milk rose to a record $16 a hundredweight in December before easing down.
Crop prices, over all, rose 1.6 percent from June but averaged 4.4 percent below the year-earlier level.

HEADLINE: Sales of New Houses Up 3>8%; Some Predict a Turnaround

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Sales of new homes surged 8 percent in June, the sharpest increase since November, the Government said today.
Many analysts saw the rise as an indication that the sluggish housing industry had bottomed out. ''We believe that the second quarter was the low point,'' said David Seiders, the chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. 
He and other analysts said they expected continued but subdued growth in both new and existing single-family home sales for the rest of the year.
 
May Data Revised
The Commerce Department said new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 581,000 units after posting a revised 2.3 percent gain in May. May sales were reported last month to have risen just four-tenths of a percent, the first advance in five months.
The June increase was the sharpest since an 8 percent gain in November. Analysts attributed the increase to lower mortgage rates, which they said should renew interest in home sales.
''We expect mortgage rates to trend downward in the weeks ahead, which should boost sales of new homes as well as existing homes,'' said John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors.
The group reported last week that sales of existing homes rose 1.2 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.34 million units. It was the first increase since a 3.2 percent gain in November.
The average rate for 30-year, conventional fixed-rate mortgages ranged from 10.10 percent to 10.29 percent in June, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The rate had dropped to 9.98 percent by Friday.
Mark Obrinksy, an economist with Freddie Mac, and other analysts said they did not expect rates to fall much more. They predicted only a gradual increase in future sales.
 
Favorable Weather
Richard Peach, the deputy chief economist with the Mortgage Bankers of America, said favorable weather had attracted buyers in June.
''We had a very soggy April and May, particularly in the eastern part of the country,'' Mr. Peach said. ''When it's cold and damp, people don't like to go out and shop around for new houses.''
Sales in the Northeast, which had been sluggish for more than a year, jumped 36 percent, to an annual rate of 102,000 units. Sales also rose in the South, up 13.6 percent, to an annual rate of 243,000 units.
But they dropped elsewhere. In the West, sales were down 5.8 percent, to an annual rate of 146,000 units; in the Midwest, they were off 4.3 percent, to an annual rate of 90,000 units.
The Commerce Department said the median price of a new home rose 1.6 percent, to $129,900. The median price means half of the homes cost more and half less. The average price advanced 2.1 percent, to $152,900.

HEADLINE: Company News;
New California Park Is Proposed by Disney

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 31

 BODY:
Intent on creating a second significant attraction in Southern California, home of Disneyland, the Walt Disney Company disclosed plans today for a big park and resort with an ocean theme in Long Beach, Calif., about 20 miles west of Disneyland.
The $2 billion waterfront project, to be called Port Disney, would include five hotels, shopping areas, restaurants and a cruise-ship terminal. The accompanying theme park, tentatively called DisneySea, would feature rides, shows, an aquarium and marine research operations.
Disney has been considering building a new attraction here for several years. At one point, the company considered developing a Hollywood-theme entertainment complex in Burbank, where the company is based, but it abandoned that plan.
Now, Disney says it wants to proceed either at Long Beach or in Anaheim, on land next to Disneyland. The company is pitting Anaheim and Long Beach against each other to see which city will offer the best inducements.
Disney, which has set no completion date for its proposed project, said it would decide on its plans next year.
''A final decision will be based on a number of factors including community support, government approvals, public sector participation and theme park and resort economics,'' said Alan Epstein, vice president of the Disney Development Company.
Industry analysts said it was important to Disney, which has reported record sales and earnings for 22 straight quarters, to continue developing projects to assure strong growth.
The Port Disney proposal encompasses 350 acres, including 250 underwater acres that would be filled. Disneyland is about 180 acres. Two other Disney-owned attractions already on the Long Beach site, the Queen Mary and the Spruce Goose airplane, may be repositioned or moved.
Disney's stock slipped 25 cents today, to $117.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 2, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Company News page in Business Day yesterday about the Walt Disney Company's plans for a theme park in Long Beach, Calif., misstated the company's business relationship with two attractions on the site in some copies. Disney leases and operates the Queen Mary ocean liner and the Spruce Goose airplane; it does not own them.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices on Treasury Bonds Ease

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds eased yesterday in lackluster trading, causing rates to edge up. Dealers described the market's mood as indecisive. Some dealers said a pause was normal after two sessions of sharp advances, but others described the market as confused and contended that the recent price gains had left the market vulnerable to any determined selling.
Few professional traders and speculators, who provide much of the bond market's liquidity, have sold Treasury securities short, and that makes the market vulnerable by reducing a potential reservoir of buying power - those who sell securities short eventually have to buy out of their positions. 
The Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, were offered late in the day at 103 22/32, off 2/32. This caused the long bond's yield to inch up a basis point, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 8.41 percent.
''It is surprising that the long end of the Treasury bond market held up as well as it did today, given the day's burden of negative news,'' said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. ''The shorter Treasury maturities, which are more influenced by the overnight interbank lending rate as well as Federal Reserve operations, showed the best gains.''
 
Chicago Purchasing Managers
Mr. Kellner noted that about the only positive news for the bond market, which generally reacts positively to bearish economic news, was a report by the Chicago purchasing managers indicating that business was terrible in July. The influential report by the National Association of Purchasing Managers is due out today and is expected to mirror the Chicago data.
The reason negative economic news is positive for investors in fixed-income securities is that it is perceived to lessen inflationary pressures and keep interest rates on competitive investment instruments from rising.
An important element of the day's economic news - a further drop in the dollar's value against key foreign currencies - was decidedly bearish for the fixed-income market because it made dollar-denominated investments less attractive to foreigners.
 
Single-Family Home Sales Up
Also negative was the Government's report of an unexpectedly strong rise of 8 percent in June sales of single-family homes. Moreover, May sales were revised upward to 2.3 percent from a previously reported increase of four-tenths of 1 percent.
The other news from Washington was equally bleak for bondholders. The Congressional Budget Office increased its estimate for the Federal deficit in the current fiscal year to $195 billion, or $60 billion more than its previous estimate six months ago. Mr. Kellner noted that the latest deficit figure was equivalent to 3.6 percent of the Gross National Product, compared with 2.9 percent six months ago.
''While the vote by the House to raise the national debt ceiling by $322 billion, to $3.4 trillion, was expected,'' he said, the market does not know how all these deficit numbers will affect next week's record Treasury refunding auctions. But we do know it will add to the supply of Treasury paper.''
Today, the Treasury will announce the terms of its auctions of three and 10-year notes as well as 30-year bonds that will be sold next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. After the terms are announced late today, the three issues will then be traded on a when-issued basis and provide some estimate of investor interest in the auctions.
The long notes, the 8 7/8's of the year 2000, were unchanged in price and yield at 103 17/32 and 8.34 pecent, respectively.
Among some representative shorter Treasury maturities, the 8.5 percent notes of 1997 rose 3/32, to 101 8/32, for a yield of 8.26 perent; the 8's of 1992 gained 4/32, at 100 8/32, to yield 7.86 percent.
Demand for Treasury bills caused discount rates to decline. While the 90-day rate dipped a basis point, to 7.49 percent, the six-month bills fell 5 basis points, to 7.32 percent, and the one-year bills also lost 5 basis points, at 7.19 percent.
The Treasury announced that it would auction $4 billion of 44-day cash management bills tomorrow. As usual the bills are denominated in units of $1 million.
The Federal Reserve intervened in the credit markets, adding $2 billion to banking reserves through customer repurchase agreements. Federal funds, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, were at 8 percent at the time and continued to trade at that level for the rest of the session.

HEADLINE: Media Business;
Editor Leaving Philadelphia Inquirer

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The executive editor and president of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Eugene L. Roberts Jr., announced unexpectedly yesterday that he would retire on Sept. 1.
Mr. Roberts, 58 years old, is one of the nation's most respected newspapermen. In his 18 years as the top editor of The Inquirer, the paper won 17 Pulitzer Prizes and became a prestigious daily.
His successor is Maxwell E. P. King, currently a senior vice president of The Inquirer. 
 
To Travel and Teach
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Roberts said he had decided to retire to travel and teach, and to clear the way for younger editors at the paper.
But Mr. Roberts has made no secret of his unhappiness with what he regards as the increasingly bureaucratic and profit-oriented management of Knight-Ridder Inc., the Miami-based newspaper chain that owns The Inquirer.
At many newspapers, editors are feeling heavy pressure to trim expenses and increase circulation, as declining advertising sales have cut heavily into profits.
The Inquirer has been highly profitable, but it too is suffering from a weak advertising market in the Northeast. In addition, circulation has been relatively flat for several years, with The Inquirer selling about 500,000 copies daily and about one million on Sundays.
 
Struggle Over Budget
A year ago, Mr. Roberts described the struggle to reach an agreement with Knight-Ridder on a five-year budget plan as a ''brass-knuckle, white-knuckle debate,'' and he has been critical of the emphasis on quarterly earnings among publicly owned newspaper companies.
Yesterday, Mr. Roberts said budget differences were not a factor in his decision to retire. He added that Knight-Ridder, which has a reputation for operating well-regarded newspapers like The Inquirer and The Miami Herald, had been more restrained in its profit expectations than most newspaper groups.
''There haven't been any arteries hit,'' said Mr. Roberts, who will remain with Knight-Ridder as a consultant.
Mr. Roberts also said that his decision was not related to the appointment in March of a publisher at The Inquirer with overall responsibility for both news and business operations. Mr. Roberts had long resisted such a management structure, preferring to report directly to a Knight-Ridder executive in charge of news operations at all of the papers.
 
Tribute From Chairman
James K. Batten, Knight-Ridder's chairman and chief executive, praised Mr. Roberts as ''an inspiration'' to other editors and said his budget disagreements with Knight-Ridder had always been resolved amicably.
Mr. Roberts's successor, Mr. King, is a former editor at The Inquirer who switched to the business side of the paper in 1988. He will have the title of editor of The Inquirer and will become executive vice president of Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., which also publishes The Philadelphia Daily News.
Mr. King, who is 46 and the grandson of Maxwell Perkins, a renowned book editor, currently oversees circulation. Gene Foreman, the managing editor, will become executive editor, reporting to Mr. King.
 
Prickly Independence
Mr. Roberts had a reputation for stubborn, prickly independence that belied his shy manner and eccentricities, like lapsing into prolonged silences in mid-conversation.
Mr. Roberts came to The Inquirer in 1972 from The New York Times, where he had been national editor.
Reporters at The Inquirer said yesterday that much of the paper's news staff regarded Mr. Roberts with awe because of his aggressive news coverage and willingness to underwrite expensive projects.
For instance, Mr. Roberts approved a painstaking 15-month inquiry into who benefited from special provisions of the 1986 Tax Reform Act. The series resulted in a seven-part series that won a Pulitzer Prize.
Donald L. Barlett, a reporter on the tax inquiry, said that the staff feared that without Mr. Roberts, such projects would be considered too expensive.
Mr. King said that he was committed to the values Mr. Roberts had instilled at the paper and felt strongly that Knight-Ridder was similarly committed, but that he was concerned that underlying newspaper economics threatened high-quality journalism at all newspapers.
''I'm no Gene Roberts and I don't think of myself as replacing Gene Roberts,'' Mr. King said. ''But I do think of myself as leading a group of journalists who are dedicated to carrying on his work.''
