HEADLINE: Pentagon Drafts Strategy for Post-Cold War World

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The Pentagon has drafted a blueprint for United States military strategy in the 1990's with the assumption that once Soviet forces withdraw from Eastern Europe it would take Moscow up to two years to mobilize for a major invasion.
The plan marks a striking change from the assumption underlying American military strategy during the cold war, that Washington might have as little as two weeks to reinforce NATO forces if Moscow appeared to be marshaling troops and weapons for an attack on Western Europe.
The confidential plan, the details of which unfolded in interviews with several senior Pentagon officials, was presented to President Bush in late June by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. It envisions, by about the mid-1990's, cutting the armed forces by 500,000 troops from the current level of 2.1 million, reducing overseas deployments and establishing a new organizational framework for the military.
The plan would also take advantage of the longer warning time of a possible Soviet attack on Europe by creating new Army reserve divisions that could be brought up to full strength only if needed for a prolonged crisis. These ''reconstitutable'' units would be partly manned and their equipment would be held in storage. 
Some senior military officers have criticized the plan, arguing that the cuts go too far. But while it is still being refined by the Pentagon, Bush Administration officials say the main thrust of the blueprint has been favorably received by the President, who is expected to draw on some of the Pentagon's latest planning in a speech on military policy in Aspen, Colo., on Thursday.
The new blueprint represents the first comprehensive effort by senior Pentagon officials, under heavy pressure from Congress to reduce spending, to adapt American strategy and forces to the political and military sea change that has taken place in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
 
Nuclear Forces Will Continue
The changes in the Defense Department's thinking deals more with conventional than with nuclear weapons. Pentagon officials believe the Soviet Union will continue to have a formidable force of long-range nuclear weapons so it can maintain its status as a superpower. Thus, the United States will have to keep a large strategic nuclear force as well.
Until now, the Pentagon has presented only fragmentary suggestions of how it would adjust to receding Soviet tensions, mostly dwelling on budget cutting. This has drawn sharp criticism from members of Congress, who have assailed the Defense Department for failing to articulate a broader vision.
The Pentagon told Congress in June, for example, that it was considering a 25 percent cut in forces over five years and offered a breakdown to illustrate how such a reduction might be accomplished. But that report made no mention of strategy, did not explain the projected cuts in detail and was cast primarily as an exercise to explain the fiscal consequences of force reductions.
 
In Line With Budget Plans
Pentagon officials said the new strategic plan reflected an acceptance that the military budget is in decline. It is generally consistent with current Administration plans to cut military spending, after taking account of inflation, by 10 percent over five years. Somewhat greater savings could be achieved if the pace of the reductions in forces were accelerated.
But at the same time, the plan is intended to help the Pentagon hold the line against more severe budget cuts, by arguing that there is a ''base force'' that the nation cannot go below.
The blueprint is the result of more than five months of planning and meetings, encouraged by Mr. Cheney, and is based on the work of General Powell and Paul Wolfowitz, the Undersecretary of Defense for Policy, who oversaw separate efforts to update military planning. General Powell and Mr. Wolfowitz reached similar conclusions about the size of forces needed.
 
Four Basic Components
The new plan, in keeping with the thinking of General Powell, organizes the military into four basic components. It would establish an Atlantic Force that would include armored units and sizable Army and Air Force reserves to guard against a renewed Soviet threat, and to meet threats in the Persian Gulf. There would also be a Pacific Force that would emphasize naval and tactical air units to defend South Korea and other American allies in Asia.
Additionally, the military would have a Contingency Force for rapid response to smaller conflicts in the Third World and to be the leading edge if a major military action became necessary. There would also be the Strategic Force of long-range nuclear weapons.
Based on the revised forecast of the Soviet military threat, the blueprint calls for cutting Army and Air Force units oriented toward the defense of Western Europe.
The United States has already proposed shrinking its force of 305,000 Army and Air Force troops in Europe to 225,000. Pentagon officials say the new plan does not explicitly say what further cuts might be possible there if Moscow completely withdrew its forces from Eastern Europe, as projected by the Defense Department.
But these officials add that the plan implies there would be such further reductions. In fact, senior Pentagon officials are now weighing plans to cut to the level of 100,000 to 125,000 or so if Moscow should withdraw from Eastern Europe.
 
'Reconstitutable' Divisions
The new ''reconstitutable'' Army reserve divisions suggested in the plan are sometimes known as ''cadre'' divisions. The idea is part of a larger proposal advanced by Mr. Wolfowitz for building up forces in a crisis. The broader plan calls for storing equipment from dismantled units, but retaining officers who could provide training and leadership if reconstituting became necessary.
Some elements of the new blueprint have drawn sharp criticism from the services. Pentagon officials said final decisions will not be reached by Mr. Cheney until the commanders in the field and the Joint Chiefs of Staff meet later this month and further studies are completed.
One point of contention revolves around the possibility, raised in deliberations on the plan, that the United States would modify its longstanding policy of keeping some aircraft carriers constantly stationed near areas of potential conflict.
Mr. Wolfowitz and General Powell have reportedly raised the question of reducing the Navy to 11 deployable aircraft carriers as part of a minimal Navy force.
The Navy, which now has 14 deployable carriers, has complained that such a force is not sufficient to keep carriers in the Mediterranean Sea and the Western Pacific constantly, while also maintaining a presence in the Indian Ocean six months of the year. The service says 12 are needed.
An aide to Mr. Cheney said that the Secretary currently favors retaining a force of 12 carriers but that the matter is under review.
 
Marine Corps Objections
The Marine Corps objects to the blueprint's proposal to reduce the service to about 150,000 men, a 25 percent cut. Gen. Alfred M. Gray, the Marine commander, has argued that the 196,000-member corps should not be reduced below 180,000. The Marines argue that the corps is needed more than ever to deal with conflicts in the third world.
Top Army officials appear reconciled to the proposal to cut the service to 12 active divisions from 18. But Army officials are cautious about the idea of creating two ''reconstitutable'' reserve divisions, expressing concern that it could lead to even sharper cuts. In addition to the two ''reconstitutable'' units, the blueprint would keep six other reserve divisions.
Senior Air Force officials have said the service needs more than the roughly 25 active and reserve tactical air wings suggested by the new blueprint. The Air Force currently has about 36 air wings and has proposed shrinking that to 28.
Pentagon officials say the new plan assumes that Soviet forces will be withdrawn from Europe by the mid-1990's, that a new East-West conventional arms agreement will be reached and that the Western alliance will be intact.
Following such developments, Moscow would still able to launch limited attacks on the northern and southern flanks of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization or even in central Europe. But the Soviet Union would need a year or two of preparation to fight a conventional war involving a multifront attack on Western Europe.
The study also assumes that third world powers like Iraq, which is already regarded as a formidable opponent, will become more powerful. The growth of regional powers in the Middle East is leading to some important modifications in military planning.
Because a nation like Iraq could attack on short notice, the warning is likely to be less than it would be for a Soviet invasion, Pentagon planners say. To cope with such regional threats, planners are emphasizing tactical air forces, instead of ground troops, and might draw on forces from the Pacific as well as from the Atlantic.

HEADLINE: Afghan on a Sudden Trip to Moscow

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 1

 BODY:
As Afghan rebel leaders and Pakistani officials await the results of talks on Afghanistan between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, attention here and in Kabul is riveted on the sudden and mysterious trip to Moscow by the Afghan leader, Najibullah.
An embassy in Kabul, reached by radiophone today, reported that President Najibullah had taken several high-ranking military officers and the Soviet Ambassador to Afghanistan with him to the Soviet Union on the eve of the Baker-Shevardnadze meeting in Irkutsk in Siberia, which began today. The Afghan leader was also accompanied on the trip by his immediate family, it was reported here.
President Najibullah has been giving mixed signals over the last few weeks about his willingness to cooperate in a Soviet-American plan, still under discussion, that would end outside arms supplies to the warring Afghan factions and set up an impartial electoral process. Mr. Najibullah is sustained by at least 20 Soviet flights a day, costing Moscow billions of dollars a year. 
In recent days, the Afghan leader appeared to be reneging on promises to give up much of his power to speed the transition to a new political order. This concession would be crucial to American acceptance of his continued presence in an interim government.
 
An Unannounced Trip
After President Najibullah left on an unannounced trip to Moscow on Saturday, the official Kabul radio said he was going for a ''medical checkup.'' Soviet officials called it a vacation. Kabul radio has not commented since.
It is considered significant that an Acting President was named in Mr. Najibullah's absence. He is Abdul Rahim Hatif, who formerly served the exiled King, Zahir Shah. Mr. Hatif, who is considered a moderate in Afghan terms, is not a Communist. The former King recently met Peter Tomsen, the United States envoy to the Afghan insurgents.
While Western diplomats and Pakistani officials say that no major breakthroughs are expected in the Siberian talks, they acknowledge that the Afghan issue has become the almost total preserve of Washington and Moscow and that even information is scarce here. The increasing cooperation between Soviet and American officials has made a palpable difference in the Pakistani capital, which feels for the first time in years like a diplomatic and strategic backwater.
 
U.S.-Soviet Meeting
IRKUTSK, U.S.S.R., Thursday, Aug. 2 (Special to The New York Times) -Foreign Minister Shevardnadze said at a joint news conference today that the Soviet Union had agreed to suspend production of the SS-24 rail mobile system. But American officials said they were not certain how significant the Soviet concession is, because it is unclear how many more of these intercontinental missiles the Soviets had intended to produce.
Secretary of State Baker and Foreign Minister Shevardnadze went fishing in Siberia on Wednesday as they discussed Afghanistan, arms control and a possible summit meeting before the end of the year.
Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze spent the day on Lake Baikal, first on a hydroplane and then on a fishing boat. Neither had much success as anglers, with the Soviet Foreign Minister managing to catch the only fish of the day -an omul, a type of trout.
As the two were about to leave from the dock on the Angara River, Mr. Shevardnadze said it was a coincidence that the two would discuss Afghanistan today and Thursday as President Najibullah is visiting the Soviet Union.
Soviet journalists covering the Baker-Shevardnadze meeting said they understood that President Najibullah would meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to discuss his possible removal from office in preparation for elections - an approach endorsed by the Bush Administration.
Neither Mr. Baker nor Mr. Shevardnadze would discuss details of their Afghanistan discussions. ''We have things to discuss about Afghanistan,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said. ''I'll not call those new ideas, but we'll see.''
Mr. Baker said, ''We are moving closer together on Afghanistan,'' but he cautioned that it did not mean that ''the people that we've been aligned with have come any closer to a settlement.''
Without going into details, the two Foreign Ministers said they were discussing scheduling for a future meeting between President Bush and President Gorbachev, arms control in Europe and future American technical aid to help the Soviets develop a market economy.

HEADLINE: Dukakis Signs His State's Disputed Budget

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today signed the $13.4 billion budget the Legislature sent to him on Saturday, ending seven months of bitter negotiations.
Mr. Dukakis also signed a separate measure, a $1.4 billion financing bill, that will allow the state to issue bonds to pay bills that current tax revenues are insufficient to cover. The Governor said the budget and the borrowing authorization ''will finally restore our fiscal stability and set the stage for economic recovery.''
State leaders have been struggling with budget deficits since 1988, when the economy began to slow down after years of steady growth.
Legislators had been unable to agree on a balanced budget for the current fiscal year, which began July 1, until last Saturday, when they approved 4 percent across-the-board cuts in several categories of spending. Human services, higher education and aid to municipalities were the hardest hit.
The new budget relies on revenue from a $1.8 billion tax increase that became law on July 18. The increase comes from higher levies on income and gasoline and an expansion of the sales tax to nearly 600 services not previously covered, including, for example, legal and accounting services,

HEADLINE: America's Neck and a New Noose

 BODY:
Even before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, America's energy situation was looking increasingly ominous. Fact one: Imports accounted for a record 50 percent of the oil consumed by the U.S. during the first half of 1990. Fact two: The oil cartel, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, this week raised its target price for oil by 17 percent.
This combination of increasing dependence and price was cause for concern by itself. Now add the possibility of military upheaval, and there are all the ingredients of a new energy noose, like the one that caused Americans to choke in the 1970's. 
The U.S. can't do much about its declining oil production or OPEC's prices. But it can curb its voracious appetite for oil by imposing higher energy taxes. And, by enlarging the Strategic Reserve, it can protect itself against the temporary supply crises that might follow from Iraq's action.
The 1980's were kind to oil importers. Mexico, the North Sea and other non-OPEC sources blossomed. OPEC's ability to enforce high prices waned, even among its members.
That's not surprising; cartels are inherently unstable. At first, OPEC members embraced strict production quotas in order to create artificial scarcity. That jacked up prices tenfold. But the exorbitant prices created an irresistible desire by some members to sell more than their assigned quotas. In time, they cheated - and prices plummeted.
Oil-importing countries helped their own cause by cutting back demand. The U.S. now uses a third less oil, compared with the size of the economy, than in 1973. That's progress.
The 90's look less kind to importing countries. Britain's North Sea oil and America's production from the North Slope are petering out. And now Iraq's aggression against Kuwait adds more uncertainty. By threatening Kuwait last week, Iraq delivered a stern warning to all OPEC members to stop cheating. Judging from the quick bargain struck at this week's OPEC meeting, the warning was heeded. But now the possibility looms of a disruption in oil shipments from the Middle East.
Before Iraq's move these developments were troubling but not alarming. Non-OPEC oil exporters are numerous. Supplies of natural gas outside the Middle East are large. And the U.S. has effective ways to counter the OPEC oil cartel:
Store more oil for an emergency. America created its Strategic Petroleum Reserve in 1975 after the 1973 oil crisis. But the reserve holds only slightly more than half the original target of a billion barrels. Morris Adelman, an energy economist at M.I.T., urges an increase to at least 750 million barrels - enough to offset a 10 percent loss of imports for two years.
Such a loss would be far worse than the crises of 1973 and 1979, when imports fell less than 5 percent. Yet these disruptions became catastrophes because panicky consumers and suppliers hoarded every barrel in sight. By guaranteeing ready access to oil, an ample Strategic Reserve would calm nerves and ward off panic. Mr. Adelman warns, however, that administrative procedures must be changed so that the oil would be immediately available.
Enhance conservation with energy taxes. Another ingredient of a sound energy policy is lower demand. A sizable energy tax, phased in over time and with offsets for the poor, would lower demand for oil imports and reduce the Federal deficit and clean up the environment.
OPEC is unlikely ever again to voluntarily sock oil-importing countries with precipitous price hikes. That would drive customers into the welcoming arms of non-OPEC oil exporters, hasten conversion to natural gas and other fuels, and promote conservation. But even if the noose is not pulled to the point of strangulation, it can hurt. The U.S. needs to cut itself a bit more slack.

HEADLINE: Don't Let Congress Hobble the Cable Industry;
Fiber Optic Highway

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 22 editorial ''Furious About Cable'' makes a point, but misses the target.
Yes, viewers are angry, and the Cable Act of 1984 is not working. But the goal should not be a country of happy cable watchers, tranquilized by movies at home. The goal should be the development of diverse technologies that will serve the broader public interests of home education, health care delivery, telecommuting and international competitiveness.
That goal requires a broad-band fiber optic network - an information highway, really - to every home, school and business in America. Spurring that network will take more than ''light-touch reregulation.''
Night's courage may be day's timidity. Your ''no rush'' policy is too cautious. Rand studies notwithstanding, the United States needs to create opportunity, not just satisfy demand. There is enough daylight now for us to move as a country toward telecommunications excellence.
The people may be ''furious about cable,'' but they are curious about much more. The Information Age is already here. Let's not lose the opportunity to build, for all of us, a truly global economy.
 
JOHN EGER
Washington, July 26, 1990
 The writer heads Opt in America, a public interest organization.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Has Earned No Environmental Role

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Whether the motives that Robert Bazell attributes to Senator Sam Nunn for proposing a strategic environmental research program are true or not (''Rapid Employment Force,'' Op-Ed, July 12), the Senator is correct in his assessment that the military, which now absorbs nearly 70 percent of all Federal research and development funds, will not continue to require all these resources in the future.
Senator Nunn's suggestion that some of these research resources be redeployed to deal with the country's urgent environmental, energy and competitiveness problems is a wise one; but his plan for doing so is seriously flawed for a number of reasons. Among others:
* Government departments with internally competing interests and tasks are doomed to immobilizing inefficiency and hopeless tangling in Congressional committees. Environmental research that competes for funds and attention with military projects within the Department of Defense and Department of Energy is destined for wasteful atrophy. 
* Pentagon-led research and development has been marked by chronic cost overruns and often produces costly, complicated, unreliable or unworkable systems. There is no reason to believe that the Pentagon can develop cost-effective civilian products that would succeed in the competitive international marketplace as the Senator hopes.
* The Federal Government must maintain an ''even field'' and not favor weapons research facilities over private industry that not only pays taxes and has to survive in a competitive environment, but also knows best how to operate in it. To provide environmental research and development funds to military research and developing installations preferentially would be choosing winners and losers, at best a dubious proposition in a market economy such as ours.
* Exclusively military research and development facilities were established and maintained to provide the necessary secrecy that must surround weapons development. Secrecy is not needed for environmental research, and therefore such facilities and their research can be safely removed from military controls.
There is no nationally rational reason for the military to become involved in research and development that addresses the problems of the society's metabolism - that is, the process of energy extraction, use and waste disposal that sustains the myriad activities of society. The United States needs a broad, well-coordinated national environmental-energy-competitiveness technical policy that cannot be implemented into the needed civilian technology base as a sideshow of the country's military oligarchy.
 
KOSTA TSIPIS
Cambridge, Mass., July 17, 1990
 The writer is director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology program in science and technology for international security.

HEADLINE: To Expand Javits Center, Reopen the Coliseum

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The proposal that New York City's Jacob K. Javits Convention Center be enlarged (news article, July 18) at the same time recognizes a need and neglects simpler and less expensive means of solving the problem and doing so immediately.
For the four years since the opening of the Javits Center, the New York Coliseum in Columbus Circle has remained dark. While by no means a perfect exposition facility, it served its purpose well, and could do so again. From being a burden to the city it could become highly profitable, producing revenue, directly and indirectly, for the city's economy.
The Coliseum could house expositions that can find no home in New York because of the Javits's crowded schedule. Although some of the shows implicitly indicated as shunning New York because of the Javits's inadequate space would not come here because of high costs and more sinister causes, other large shows could, by using both the Javits and the Coliseum. While division of a large exposition is not ideal, it has precedents in other cities. The separation between the two is only a mile and a half, an easy link by bus.
Reopening the Coliseum, perhaps under Javits administration, could achieve the proposed expansion painlessly at great savings and restore a litigation-plagued building to its role as an asset.
 
SAUL POLIAK
New York, July 19, 1990

HEADLINE: Who Robbed the S.&L.'s? Congress.

BYLINE: By Jim Leach; Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, is a member of the House Banking Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The most captivating news story in my home state last year concerned an attempted robbery of tragicomic proportions.
At the end of the basketball season, a star forward on the Iowa State University team walked into the campus Burger King, without a mask, carrying a rifle. He asked the high school sophomore at the counter to hand over the money in the cash register. The team's picture featuring this strapping athlete was on the wall. The teen-ager recognized him with a ''Hi, Sam.'' He looked up and responded, ''It's not me!'' 
The savings and loan scandal is another kind of robbery, the biggest bank heist in history - one that goes beyond the bank vaults to pick the pocket of every American. And the picture of another pin-striped team is on the wall: It is the biannual official photograph of Congress.
The savings and loan debacle symbolizes the breakdown in discipline in legislative bodies, especially at the committee level, where interest groups target their attention and dollars. Committees are designed to be delegated centers of legislative expertise. Too often they have become advocacy rather than oversight oriented, failing to provide stop signals for the inevitable train wrecks.
In modern politics, legislative reputations are generally made by extremists, those who push the biggest programs or tax cuts, or who advocate the greatest new powers for Government or the private sector.
With savings and loans, the committees of jurisdiction in Congress failed to rein in the powers that regulators had allowed the thrifts - to over-leverage capital, buy junk bonds and make speculative investments. They chose instead to encourage the continuation of patently imprudent practices.
During the 1980's, the two costliest code words in the legislative lexicon became ''direct investments.'' Thrifts were released from their social contract to make home loans -the historical quid pro quo for receipt of Federal deposit insurance - and given license to speculate in commercial real estate and leveraged buyouts. Instead of following the Wall Street precept that ''first loss is best loss,'' gullible legislators bought the claim of Charles Keating and other industry insiders that inflation-ravaged thrifts could beat insolvency by gambling with other people's money.
From a Sun Belt perspective the gamble worked: The wealth of the Midwest and Northeast was transferred on a one-shot basis to the Southwest and West. While graft was rampant, not all of the deposits were frittered away. A localized infrastructure of homes and modern offices was built that will stand for a generation as a government-induced incentive for migration to those states with the most lax regulation.
This criminal transfer of wealth from one region to another, from middle-class taxpayers to lubricious high rollers, occurred because legislative bodies abandoned the national interest and represented regional and industry concerns. Once an innumerate Congress ceased to require prudent capital ratios and sanctioned phony accounting and capricious powers, the Government's gold could be stolen without breaking into Fort Knox.
Ironically, it was the alleged defenders of the little guy in American politics who led the charge to transform an industry created under Franklin Roosevelt to serve small savers and average homeowners into a privileged preserve for the moneyed elite.
The only honor that can be salvaged from this fiscal Vietnam - the chance to hold the ''ins'' accountable for privatizing profit and socializing loss - must be a demand for campaign reform, for fair rules, for competitive opportunity in American political as well as economic life. The $20 a month that the average American family must pay Uncle Sam for the next 30 years amounts to a Congressional Watergate, depriving Congress, particularly its majority party, of the moral authority to defend the political status quo.
In Chinese history there is a theory of revolution based upon a ''mandate of heaven.'' A government may be overthrown when a catastrophe - a drought, flood or earthquake - signals the necessity. The question of the 1990's is whether the American people are concluding that the conflicts of interests that cost real people real money are of such earthquake proportions that the mandate of governance ought to be removed from the Democratic political establishment, which has controlled Congress and the majority of state legislatures during the past half-century.
The challenge to Republicans is to stake out the position as the party of reform. The future belongs to the political party that puts the S.& L. crooks in jail and removes America's legislative bodies from the control of moneyed influence peddlers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Former Associate Sues Rinfret Over Business

 BODY:
A former business associate of Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor, has filed a lawsuit charging that Mr. Rinfret went back on a promise to give him a share in his investment businesses.
In the suit, Arthur E. Greco also contends that Mr. Rinfret lost a substantial amount of his clients' money in the October 1987 stock market plunge. In an interview, Mr. Greco's lawyer, Donald Chase, asserted that some clients of the investment company, Rinfret Inc., lost 80 percent of their money in the stock collapse.
The suit also accuses Mr. Rinfret, an economic consultant, of making personal investments that ran counter to those he made for his clients.
Mr. Rinfret's son and business partner, Peter Alan Rinfret, said they would not comment on the suit.
The lawsuit said the Rinfrets persuaded Mr. Greco in February 1987 to leave his job at J. P. Morgan Securities by promising a $75,000 annual salary and 16 percent of their investment business. The suit seeks money equal to this share and punitive damages.

HEADLINE: Phil D. Fine, Lawyer, Dies at 64; Key Force in Boston Development

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Phil David Fine, a lawyer who played an important role in several major development projects in Massachusetts, died Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 64 years old and lived in Boston.
His family said the cause of death was heart failure. 
In the early 1970's, Mr. Fine assembled the investment group that built Schaefer Stadium, now Foxboro Stadium, outside Boston for the New England Patriots football team. The stadium was the first since the 1920's to be built solely with private financing.
 
Revival of Languishing Plan
He was also instrumental in the redevelopment of Faneuil Hall Marketplace in Boston, the first of several projects in historic areas of Eastern cities undertaken by the Rouse Company of Maryland. The proposal had been languishing for a decade when he won approval in 1973 for Rouse to restore Faneuil Hall, then a decaying property in the heart of Boston that dated to Revolutionary times. The exteriors of the market buildings were preserved, and shops, restaurants and other services were housed inside.
To clear the way for the construction of Exchange Place, a 40-story skyscraper using the facade of the old Boston Stock Exchange, Mr. Fine worked out design compromises with city officials and preservation interests permitting his client, Olympia & York of Toronto, to start the project.
In recent years he was a consultant to the Government of Israel and the City of Jerusalem on construction of the Mamilla project, the largest urban development effort in that country.
Mr. Fine, who was born in Brookline, Mass., was a graduate of Northeastern University and the Boston University School of Law. He was a founding partner of the law firm of Fine & Ambrogne in Boston and later of White, Fine & Verville in Washington.
In 1961 and 1962, he was Deputy Administrator of the Small Business Administration in the Kennedy Administration. He was a founder of the Commonwealth Bank of Boston in 1964.
Mr. Fine was an overseer and trustee of Northeastern University. He was president of the American Jewish Historical Society for two years before becoming its chairman last May.
He is survived by his wife, the former Norma Loew; three daughters, Susan and Debra, both of Manhattan, and Lauri Friedman of Haifa, Israel; two sisters, Tina Mintz of Norwood, Mass., and Leona Vetstein of Newton, Mass.; a brother, Ralph, of Boston, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A Legal Leg for Designers

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
AFTER years of legal wrangling, the design field in New York state has taken a step toward professional legitimacy with the signing by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of a bill that provides for state certification of interior designers.
The bill, the LaValle-Koppell bill, resulted from an agreement between the architectural profession and interior designers on the scope of designers' work. Architects initially opposed the bill, which establishes for the first time legal definition of interior design in the state that is widely considered the nation's design capital. The Governor's office announced yesterday that the bill was signed Monday.
The law is intended to set a higher standard for the profession and to give designers higher status by establishing a category of certified interior designers. Those who wish to be certified must have a minimum of seven years of education and professional training, and must pass two examinations. The law goes into effect next June 1. 
Theoretically the law will help clarify who's who in a field where people arbitrarily call themselves interior decorators and interior designers, a distinction that has been virtually meaningless until now. In New York State, people will still be able to practice as interior decorators, space planners, home fashion consultants and even as the so-called housewife decorators as long as they do not use the title certified interior designer.
In a move led by architects - and one that may cause widespread chagrin - the bill contains no grandfather clause exempting established designers from its provisions. To call themselves certified, even seasoned professionals with academic training will be required within two years to take two comprehensive examinations, one a design qualifying exam and the other on city and state fire, safety and building codes.
This has already created some angst as famous designers contemplate being trapped in a room with pencil and paper. ''I'll probably fail,'' said Mario Buatta, the maestro of chintz.
New York is the eighth state, plus Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia, to recognize interior designers legally. Alabama, Connecticut, Florida, Louisiana, Virginia, New Mexico and California have passed laws with varying degrees of strictness; in Illinois a bill is pending.
For the designers, who have lobbied vigorously for five years in Albany in a protracted territorial feud with architects, the bill's passage may go a long way toward improving a longstanding image problem. It will legally distinguish the work of interior designers, who may become involved in reorganizing space by moving certain nonstructural partitions, from the work of architects, who are legally authorized to make decisions about the physical structure and systems in a building.
''There's been a lack of credibility,'' said Noel Jeffrey, an interior designer in Manhattan who has supported the bill. ''A segment of the population still thinks of us as glorified shoppers.''
Until the act, an amendment to the education law governing the use of the title certified interior designer, there was no official body to monitor professional qualifications among interior designers. Membership in organizations like the American Society of Interior Designers, which has 32,000 members nationwide representing but a small percentage of the estimated 200,000 interior designers in the country, is strictly voluntary; the society has no means to regulate competence.
Nor was there any consumer protection. The new law is meant to protect consumers by creating a state board for interior design to monitor certification and professional conduct. Its members will be appointed by the Board of Regents.
''Up until now anyone could go hang a shingle and call themselves an interior designer, whether they were the owner of a paint store or a graduate of F.I.T.,'' said Susan Forbes, a partner in Forbes-Ergas Design Associates in Manhattan and a board member of Interior Designers for Legislation, a coalition of six organizations that has been lobbying for a certification law since 1984.
''We feel very good about the strength of the bill,'' said Ruth Lynford, a partner in Lynford Mayo Associates Inc. and president of the designers' lobbying coalition. ''No other state has passed a law with two exams, including one on codes. We feel the bill shows seriousness of purpose and a willingness to take on responsibility and accountability.''
The law does not go so far as to prohibit anyone else from operating in the domain of interior design. (State law does restrict the practice of architecture to registered architects.) The laws on interior design in the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico are ''practice acts,'' meaning that ''unless you have the qualifications, you cannot call yourself an interior designer nor can you practice interior design,'' said Jean Richmond, director of government and public affairs for the American Society of Interior Designers.
The New York law is expected to create a demand for certified designers. ''I think it's a very good thing,'' said Georgina Fairholme, a Manhattan designer. ''This will divide the real workers from the 'social' workers.''
Interior decorators and designers and architects have long been involved in a tug of war over turf. In New York, where the New York State Association of Architects lobbied against state certification for designers until an agreement was reached at the 11th hour, the architects' most strenuous disagreements were over which aspects of interior construction constituted the architect's domain and which the interior designer's.
The architects argued that construction of even non-load-bearing interior walls, for example, significantly affects a building and is therefore the architect's responsibility. They also objected to an earlier version of the bill, which had a provision enabling designers to stamp drawings that would be accepted by municipal building departments without full review by an architect or engineer.
''You would have had interior designers involved in issues of public health, safety and construction technology, for which they do not have educational and training experience,'' said Randolph R. Croxton, a New York architect who is a director of the architects' association.
Lee Bearsch, a Binghamton, N.Y., architect who is president of the state association, said, ''We were concerned that certification would confuse the public into thinking a person who'd picked out curtains and colors could do the equivalent of architecture.''
The new law defines the type of interior construction designers can perform as ''not materially related to or materially affecting the building systems''; according to several designers, details are open to interpretation. Passage of the bill demonstrates official recognition that what designers do goes beyond comfort and esthetics to affect the public health, safety and welfare.
The bill, named for its legislative sponsors, State Senator Kenneth P. LaValle, Republican of Suffolk County, and Assemblyman G. Oliver Koppell, Democrat of the Bronx, is also an acknowledgment of the growth of the profession. From its origins early in the century, when self-taught decorators like Elsie de Wolfe - a woman with good taste and a business card - pioneered the field, Interior Design magazine estimates that interior design in the United States has grown into a $31 billion industry, $7 billion of that in New York State.
Most designers were called decorators until the 1950's. But in the last two decades, there has been a demand for services that go beyond decorating and furniture arrangement to involve knowledge of space planning, flammability and toxicity of materials, and building codes.
Robert Gutman, a professor of architecture at Princeton University who has written extensively on the architectural profession, said that among architects, interior design ''tends to be regarded as a less important subject,'' even though some of the world's greatest interior spaces have been designed by architects. In architecture, traditionally a male-dominated profession, interior design ''has also suffered from the fact it has historically been associated with female roles,'' he said.
In recent years competition and a growing demand for interior design services resulted in many large architectural firms forming interior design departments.
''What's generally creating the current brouhaha is the market growth in interior work environments,'' Professor Gutman said. ''The issue is, whose turf is it? Especially in times of economic anxiety, the architectural profession is anxious to maintain its hold on the market.''
Mr. Croxton, for one, thinks the lines between the two professions are blurring. ''The notion of architecture as a box and someone coming along to decorate it later is outdated,'' he said. ''Some of the best work today is being done in a collaborative environment in which the two disciplines are being merged.''
Professor Gutman said: ''The bill gives interior designers a greater degree of legitimacy than they have had historically, and establishes a legal umbrella through which disputes can be resolved. But whether or not it will result in a better built environment is hard to say.''
Many decorators and designers welcomed the certification as a necessary fact of modern life. ''Although we are all reluctant for government intervention, the nature of the work has become much more taxing and demanding than it used to be,'' the designer Mark Hampton said.
''Sixty-four years ago, when I started, there wasn't even such a thing as a decorating school,'' said Sister Parish, a grand dame of decorating. She heartily approves of the bill. But, citing her age - 80 - she said she would not be taking the exams.

HEADLINE: From Honda, an Exotic Challenge

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., July 31

 BODY:
The Acura NSX sports car that will be roaring down American roads later in August has swooping lines, a heart-stopping 168-mile-an-hour top speed and a long list of other characteristics that the Honda Motor Company says a competitive ''super car'' should have.
Still, at $60,000 for two seats, the car will appeal to only a few thousand buyers. But beyond the exotic looks and near race-car performance, the NSX represents a clear technical leap forward that could mean stronger sales for all Honda luxury cars.
''The true significance of this car is the way it enhances Acura's high-performance image,'' said Christopher Cedergren of J. D. Power & Associates, an automotive-marketing consulting firm in Westlake Village, Calif. ''With the NSX, you can have a sexy, exotic performance car with the maintenance cost of a Honda Accord.'' 
The NSX, shown to reporters at a race track here this week, also symbolizes the Japanese auto industry's determination to place challengers into every marketing niche of the industry, no matter how small.
In building the NSX, Honda extensively redesigned outside body parts and inside components to reduce size and weight. It also refined the engine technology to coax enormous power from six cylinders.
The resulting car, due in American showrooms in two weeks, makes Honda the first Japanese auto maker to offer a vehicle that matches the lightning-fast performance characteristics of the super cars from Ferrari, Lamborghini and Porsche that cost $100,000 and more.
Honda engineers say innovations introduced in the NSX will appear in other new models destined for the American market, starting with two new Acura sports luxury models that are to be introduced within nine months.
To show off the NSX's handling and performance characteristics, Honda executives have been inviting automotive journalists and reviewers to race tracks around the country, including the Portland International Raceway, for test drives. Porsche and Ferrari models were provided for comparison.
 
Extremely Glowing Reviews
Suprisingly, the NSX's gears and clutch feel the same as those in regular Hondas. But the power and sound of the engine seem awesome to one accustomed to conventional cars. Just a few seconds after pressing the accelerator, the driver can see the speedometer closing on 110 miles an hour. Despite the high speed, there is little sense of danger or urgency, even in fairly sharp curves.
NSX stands for ''new sports car experimental,'' as it was called internally while it was under development. The car has already been trumpeted on the covers of most car magazines and has received extremely glowing reviews, even by the standards of the sometimes boosterish automotive press.
One important development in the car was the use of aluminum for NSX's body, rather than steel or plastic. Aluminum is 40 percent lighter than steel but also five or six times more expensive and very difficult to bend and weld because it tears easily. Honda engineers said that what they learned about special welding equipment, dies and aluminum alloys could result in more aluminum parts on future cars, especially if energy prices increase and fuel efficiency standards get stricter, requiring lighter-weight vehicles.
 
Multivalve Technology
The NSX's engine is placed in the middle of the car behind the two-seat passenger compartment, which is unusual but not new. The engine derives much of its uncanny power from the four valves on each of the six cylinders, rather than the more common two. The additional valves allow more air in and out of the combustion chambers where the fuel ignites, resulting in more power.
This multivalve technology, found on most Japanese-made cars, normally requires a small sacrifice in power when the engine is operating at low speeds or starting to move from a standing stop.
To overcome that effect, Honda developed special electromechanical valve controls that enable the NSX to accelerate from 0 to 60 miles an hour in less than six seconds, a rare feat. The Nissan Infiniti Q45 luxury sedan is the only other car available in the United States to offer similar technology.
Relentless efforts to cut the size of components to make them fit in the compact NSX left a comparatively large amount of elbow and leg room for driver and passenger and good visibility in all directions - features not found in similar cars.
 
Honda's Sales Goal
If the three new Acura models are as successful as the current two, they will probably vault Honda well past the Chrysler Corporation as the nation's third-best selling car company, after the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.
''If this puts us ahead of Chrysler, then it does,'' said Thomas Elliott, executive vice president of Honda's American sales organization. ''Frankly, our goal is to sell a million cars a year'' within the next five years.
Currently, Honda and Acura sell about 840,000 cars a year; the auto maker was selling 552,000 cars in 1985, before the Acura was introduced. Meanwhile, Chrysler, which once sold about a million cars a year, has seen its sales slide to a level just slightly higher than Honda's.
By itself, the NSX will have only a marginal effect on the American car market. Honda hopes to sell 3,000, just a drop in the sea of 14 million to 15 million vehicles of all kinds sold annually.
So far this year, Japanese car brands have captured a 28.4 percent share of the American market, up from 24.3 percent a year earlier.
 
Psychological Effect
But the greatest effect of Honda's new sports car could be psychological. Honda is hoping that attention to the NSX will spill over Acura's entirely redesigned Legend sedan, scheduled to make its debut this fall, as well as a second new Acura sedan, equipped with a five-cylinder engine, that will be smaller than the Legend but larger than the sporty Integra compact.
The expanded array of Acura vehicles is primarily aimed at customers of sporty European luxury cars like some Mercedes-Benz and BMW models, at current Honda owners and at owners of Toyota's Lexus and Nissan's Infiniti brands.
Honda, whose racing engines have dominated the Formula One car racing circuit for several years, began developing the Acura NSX five years ago. The concept meshed with the auto maker's overall American marketing strategy, which was to create a separate line of sports luxury vehicles in 1986. In its first year, Acura sold 52,869 cars; last year that number had grown to 142,061, surpassing BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Volvo.

The Economy
The purchasing managers' index showed a sharp decline for the economy in July, reversing a three-month growth trend. Economists said the survey gave more credence to assessments that the economy is slowing, perhaps slipping into a recession. [Page D1.] 
The index of leading indicators was unchanged in June from May, the Commerce Department said, in a report that analysts said was a sign of a listless economy in the months ahead. [D5.]
Construction spending was flat in June after falling for two straight months, the Government reported. [D5.]
The Government will sell 130 more failed S.& L.'s and about $50 billion in securities and real estate properties by the end of the year, it said. [D1.]
Accountants will be allowed to organize their practices as corporations, the profession's leading oversight body voted, in a sharp break with tradition. [D1.]
 
Companies
Nynex plans to build a second cellular telephone network in Manhattan by Christmas of next year for use by pedestrians, company officials said. [D1.]
Beyond the exotic looks and near race-car performance, the NSX represents a clear technical leap forward that could mean stronger sales for all Honda luxury cars. [D1.]
On his first day as G.M. chairman, Robert C. Stempel vowed that the auto maker would not pursue a strategy of reorganization like the one that caused turmoil in the world's biggest auto maker in the 1980's. [D3.]
I.B.M. confirmed that it would spin off its low-technology businesses - typewriters, keyboards and personal printers - into a new subsidiary. Clayton & Dubilier is to become the primary owner of the new unit. [D3.]
 
International
Gorbachev and Yeltsin joined to create a commission to produce a program of economic change for the Soviet Union by Sept. 1, signalling a shift by Gorbachev toward his rival's market-oriented policies. [A1.]
Japan agreed to open up its telecommunications market further to foreign companies, meeting an Aug. 1 deadline for possible American retaliation. [D2.]
 
Markets
The chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade resigned, a day after Federal regulators charged an affiliate of his commodities firm with misusing customer funds. [D1.]
Japanese stock prices fell sharply today and the yen fluctuated wildly against the dollar after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Crude oil prices, meanwhile, rose sharply in Asian trading. [D15.]
Stocks fell slightly, with the Dow dipping 5.94, to 2,899.26, despite heavy program buying. [D8.] Bank stock prices fell sharply after a Stanford economist said on a television program that several large banks were ''very close to true insolvency.'' [D8.]
Interest rates resumed their decline as prices of Treasury securities rallied on new evidence of a weakening economy. [D14.]
The dollar regained some ground in New York, but traders warned that the currency remained weak. [D15.]

Chiat/Day/Mojo laid off 30 employees in its 150-person New York office, which has lost three big accounts this year. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: U.S. and Japan Agree On Telecommunications

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Japan agreed today to open up its telecommunications market further to foreign companies, meeting an Aug. 1 deadline for possible American retaliation, United States officials said.
The tentative agreement, expected to be signed in Tokyo Thursday, should pave the way for American companies to win hundreds of millions of dollars of sales in Japan, they said.
''This agreement represents an important step toward giving U.S. firms in Japan access comparable to the access Japanese firms enjoy in the United States,'' the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said. 
 
What the Agreement Covers
The agreement, reached in Tokyo after 13 days of talks, covers both telecommunications equipment and services.
Mrs. Hills said Japan agreed to liberalize its large and fast-growing market for such advanced telecommunications services as voice mail and electronic banking.
The Japanese market in such services is estimated at about $700 million per year now and American officials estimate that it could grow to close to $2.5 billion by 1994.
Tokyo pledged to simplify regulations so that it would be easier for foreign companies to enter the market, United States officials said.
American companies will be able to communicate electronically - internally, among affiliates and with regular customers and suppliers - essentially free of regulation.
''As a result, U.S. manufacturing, financial and other firms that do business with Japan should be able to run those operations more easily and economically,'' Mrs. Hills said.
Also under the agreement, American companies will be able to sell network channel terminating equipment directly in Japan, rather than having to go through Japanese companies like the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation.
Network channel terminating equipment acts like a modem to connect computers to digital telephone networks. $150 Million Market ''Industry sources estimate that the U.S. share of Japan's market could be at least $150 million annually,'' Mrs. Hills said.
She said Japan also promised to enact safeguards against anticompetitive conduct in the telecommunications services sector.
''These agreements will play a growing role in maintaining the competitiveness of American firms in providing benefits for consumers worldwide,'' Mrs. Hills said.

HEADLINE: Kodak Profits Rise Sharply

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 1

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company said today that its earnings had risen nearly fivefold in the second quarter from results that were depressed by a large restructuring charge a year ago.
The photographic giant earned $384 million, or $1.19 a share, for the second quarter, compared with $77 million, or 24 cents a share, in the 1989 period, when results were reduced by $227 million because of restructuring costs. The company said that excluding that charge, its profit was up 26 percent, from $304 million, or 94 cents a share, in 1989.
It was the first quarterly earnings increase for the company since 1988.
Sales for the quarter rose 2 percent, to $4.87 billion, from a restated $4.77 billion in 1989.
Kodak, the most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange, rose $4.25, to $42.375.
''Barring unexpected developments in the general economy or dramatic changes in currency valuations, we look forward to continued recovery in Kodak earnings and to a strong second-half performance,'' said Kay R. Whitmore, Kodak's chairman and chief executive.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Remain Level

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The Government's main gauge for forecasting the direction of the economy did not budge in June, the Commerce Department said today in a report that analysts said was a sign of a listless economy in the months ahead.
The index of leading indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, was unchanged from the month before for the second time this year. It had risen in March and May and fallen in February and April. 
Many economists had expected a small increase in June. If the index were to fall for three straight months, it could signal a forthcoming recession.
 
A Consistent Pattern
''This meandering is consistent with what is happening in the economy,'' said Darryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass. ''It all nets out to basically nothing.''
But other analysts, including David Jones, an economist with the New York securities dealer Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, expressed deeper concern.
''What we have got is an economy that is slowly sinking into possibly a mild recession by either late this year or early next,'' Mr. Jones said.
The Bush Administration has predicted that the economy would grow by 2 percent this year.
But the growth rate as measured by the gross national product was just 1.7 percent in the first quarter and 1.2 percent in the second, meaning the economy would have to expand at an annual rate of 2.9 percent in the second half to meet the Administration's prediction.
 
Slump in Manufacturing
Few economists expect that amount of growth. Indeed, the National Association of Purchasing Management released its latest survey today showing that the manufacturing economy slumped in July for the first time in three months.
And the Commerce Department, in another report today, said construction spending in June was flat after falling in the previous two months.
Both the building and manufacturing sectors have borne the brunt of high interest rates under the Federal Reserve Board's policy of stemming inflation by slowing the economy.
''The June leading indicators report dashes almost all hope that the economy will pick up steam later this year,'' said Richard W. Rahn, chief economist with the United States Chamber of Commerce.
''The weak industrial sector will get even weaker by year's end as manufacturers' new orders fall and growth in unfilled orders wanes,'' Mr. Rahn added. ''It would take only a mild amount of order cancellations to stop growth in industrial production and turn a weak economy into recession.''
 
Many Negative Statistics
Both manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and unfilled orders were among the negative statistics in the June indicators report. Others were a decline in the money supply, a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence, a decrease in orders for new plants and equipment and an increase in weekly unemployment claims.
The consumer confidence index also was negative in May, leading some analysts to fear that consumers, whose spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, were retrenching.
But a Commerce Department report issued Monday eased these fears when it showed that personal consumption jumped 1 percent in June, suggesting consumers would keep the weak economy alive.
Nevertheless, only four of June's leading indicators were positive: an increase in the price of raw materials, higher stock prices, an increase in building permits and slower business delivery times. The length of the average workweek was unchanged.
The various changes left the index at 146 percent of its 1982 base of 100 and up 1.4 percent from its level a year earlier.

INDUSTRY: SIC6211 SECURITY BROKERS, DEALERS, & FLOTATION COMPANIES (69%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: MASSACHUSETTS, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Was Unchanged in June

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Construction spending, which fell for two straight months, was flat in June, the Government reported today.
The Commerce Department said that spending on residential, nonresidential and Government projects totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $447.5 billion, after dropping 1.9 percent in April and three-tenths of 1 percent in May.
The April and May declines were not as severe as first reported. The April figure was revised from 2.2 percent while the May number improved from four-tenths of 1 percent. 
Residential spending was down 2.2 percent in June for the second consecutive month, to an annual rate of $196.1 billion.
 
Single-Family Building Is Off
Single-family building was off 3.5 percent, after a 4 percent drop in May. Apartment spending was unchanged, after rising 1.5 percent in May.
Some analysts said they expect a slight pickup in residential building but suggested other areas of the construction industry would remain sluggish.
David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said residential activity was still feeling the effects of higher mortgage rates earlier this year.
The rates, he said, caused sales to drop and builders to put off projects.
The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, which had been in the double digits for most of the year, dropped to the 9.98 percent level by last Friday.
Nonresidential spending surged 3.9 percent, to $107.1 billion at an annual rate, paced by a huge 10.2 percent gain in construction of office buildings. The nonresidential segment had fallen nine-tenths of 1 percent in May.
 
Widespread Vacancies
Both Mr. Berson and Darryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., expressed surprise at the spending on office buildings and suggested the pace could not be sustained because of widespread vacancies throughout much of the nation.
The often-volatile Government sector was off one-tenth of 1 percent to $108.4 billion, after a 3.8 percent advance in May.
In another report on construction spending this week, F. W. Dodge, a financial information division of McGraw-Hill Inc., said its index of new construction contracts fell in June, to 153, from 156 in May. The report said spending for new construction totaled $240.7 billion in June, compared with $245.7 billion in May.
Dodge said contracts for new nonresidential construction increased 5 percent, while residential construction spending fell 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Index Is Steady On Confidence

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Confidence in the nation's economy among consumers was about the same in July as in June, according to a monthly study.
Consumers were slightly more positive about current conditions than in June but a little less positive about their expectations for the months ahead, the Conference Board reported this week. 
The conclusions were based on a monthly survey of 5,000 households nationwide conducted by the Board of Family Opinion Inc. in Toledo, Ohio.
Confidence was sharply lower in New England in the second quarter of 1990 compared with the corresponding period a year earlier. Expectations in the Middle Atlantic and Pacific states were also lower, while consumer confidence was up in the West Central and mountain regions.
Of those surveyed, 23.2 percent said business conditions were good in July, up from 22.6 percent the previous month.
But more respondents - 11.7 percent in July, compared with 10.4 percent in June - said they expected business conditions to worsen.

HEADLINE: Consumer Rates;
Fund Yields Are Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday.
The decline is expected to continue as further signs of a weakening economy emerge and the Federal Reserve Board comes under increasing pressure to push down rates, analysts at Donoghue's said.
''So far, short-term rates are down sharper than long-term rates, which have resisted the pressures to some extent because of the upcoming quarterly refunding by the U.S. Government and a weak dollar overseas,'' said Walter S. Frank, Donohgue's chief economist. 
The average number of days that securities are held by tax-exempt money funds remained unchanged this week at 51.
 
Tax-Exempt Assets Drop
Assets of tax-exempt funds declined by $67 million, to total $78.7 billion. The average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield was unchanged at 5.21 percent, while the 30-day average yield was down by 5 basis points, to 5.26 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The equivalent taxable seven-day compounded yield would be 7.23 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 7.76 percent for investors in the 33 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets exceeding $100 million surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund again showed the best return, with a yield of 6.13 percent. The fund is distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee.
Assets of taxable money funds increased by $600 million, to total $385.4 billion, a new high. About $300 million of the gain was in Treasury-only funds as investors uneasy with deposit insurance at banks sought refuge in those funds, analysts said. #44 Days to Maturity Institutional assets fell by $90 million, to $82.5 billion, while consumer assets rose $700 million, to total $302.9 billion.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios remained at 44. The level is considered high, Donoghue's said.
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for taxable money market funds fell by 4 basis points, to 7.84 percent, while the 30-day average yield fell 3 basis points, to 7.91 percent.
Of the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million, the Alger Money Market Portfolio, distributed by Fred Alger & Company, Jersey City, showed the best return for the fifth consecutive week, with a yield of 8.78 percent.

HEADLINE: The Media Business;
Chargeurs Buys Pathe

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 1

 BODY:
A French industrial group, Chargeurs S.A., today bought Pathe-Cinema S.A., the film company that the Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti tried to buy earlier this year.
The acquisition, costing an estimated one billion francs, or $180 million, was announced in two stages. 
First, French stock exchange officials said Chargeurs had bought 52.3 percent of Pathe-Cinema for 517 million francs, or $93 million, from four companies within the Rivaud investment group.
Later, Mr. Parretti's Pathe France Holding, which owned 46.5 percent of Pathe-Cinema, said it was also selling its shares to Chargeurs. The sale price was not disclosed.
It could not be immediately determined whether the sale of Pathe-Cinema would affect Mr. Parretti's efforts to buy the MGM-UA Communications Corporation in the United States.
The Chargeurs deal follows a decision in June by the Economics Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, to block Mr. Parretti's acquisition of Pathe. Mr. Beregovoy questioned the source of Mr. Parretti's financing, which was linked to a Swiss company, Sasea Holding. If this were the case, he contended, Mr. Parretti's group should have sought prior approval from the Government because Switzerland is not in the European Community.

HEADLINE: The Media Business;
TV Ratings Spying Case

 BODY:
A former employee of the Arbitron Company attempted to give confidential information about the company's television ratings to its principal rival, the A. C. Nielsen Company, the Department of Justice charged yesterday. 
In a one-count criminal indictment filed by the United States Attorney for the District of Maryland, the Arbitron employee, Barry D. Glick, was accused of interstate transportation of stolen property.
Mr. Glick, a 45-year-old former Washington policeman, is charged with mailing to Nielsen internal Arbitron memoranda, a company manual and a ''remote-control device and related technology'' having a value of more than $200,000.
The criminal count carries a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment and a $250,000 fine.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Chiat/Day Lays Off 30 In New York

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
CHIAT/DAY/MOJO, the Venice, Calif., agency that seemed to have the golden touch in the last decade, announced yesterday that it had laid off 30 employees in its 150-person New York office, which has lost three major accounts this year.
Chiat/Day employees, aware of the financial pressures on the agency, which built its reputation on its Nike and Apple Computer ads, said that the number of layoffs could go as high as 50 this month.
Jane Newman, the president of the New York office, said the layoffs were necessary because one of the office's biggest clients, Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines, had decided to put its $35 million account into review. ''We aren't sure that we are going to re-pitch the account,'' she said. ''This is the prudent thing to do.'' 
If, as expected, the agency loses the Royal Caribbean account, it will be the fourth big loss this year for the New York office. It lost the $7 million Sara Lee bakery account; the $5 million to $10 million Bissel account and the $30 million Reebok account. American Express and the New York Life Insurance Company have also cut back substantially on their advertising spending with the Chiat/Day New York office, which currently has billings of about $130 million.
The loss of the Royal Caribbean account would mean billings at the New York office would fall below the critical $100 million mark. It is generally believed in the industry that agencies with billings of less than $100 million would not be considered by national clients for their large accounts.
The recent problems at the New York office have sparked rumors that there will be a management shake-up there, with several of the office's top executives leaving, including at least one senior creative executive.
''We are very concerned about what is happening in New York, and we plan to fix it,'' said Bob Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of Chiat/Day's North American operations. But he would not comment on what, if any, changes would be made in light of the loss of accounts.
Mr. Wolf said that the agency had no plans to cut back further in the New York office or to close it. ''We are still very committed to it,'' he said. ''New York is an important part of our future.''
Some advertising executives said a primary reason for the problems at the New York office was the frequent absences of Jay Chiat, the agency's founder, who moved his office to Manhattan when the New York branch was opened in 1981. He recently has been spending increasing amounts of time at the agency's other offices in the United States and abroad.
Recently, Chiat/Day/Mojo, which has total billings of about $1 billion, has sold several of its smaller businesses. Last week, the agency announced it had reached an agreement to sell its public relations subsidiary, Jessica Dee Communications, for an undisclosed amount to the firm's management. In June, Chiat/Day sold most of its San Francisco operation to that agency's management.
The agency's plans to establish itself as a big international advertising power seem to have stalled. Last year, Chiat/Day acquired Mojo MDA, an Australian agency, for about $68 million. The acquisition gave Chiat/ Day a valuable foothold in the Pacific Rim and also an office in London, which it could use as a jumping-off point to begin an assault on Europe.
But its Australian operations have faltered lately. The agency is suffering primarily because of Australia's depressed economy. One of the agency's primary clients is the Australian tourism account, which has cut spending drastically. In addition, one of the agency's biggest clients, the Bond Corporation Holdings' brewing interests in Australia, filed for bankruptcy protection.
The one bright spot, Mr. Wolf said, is the agency's flagship office in California. In the last 12 months, he said, that office has won about $30 million in new accounts.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Bond Investors Gain Overseas

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to global bond investing, sometimes all that matters is getting the currency right. In July, the principal determinant of profit was investing in bonds denominated in almost any currency other than the dollar.
The fall of the dollar, which is near its lowest level ever against the German mark, was the principal reason that European bond markets, measured in dollars, produced monthly returns of at least 6 percent.
But the dollar was not the only factor. Interest rates have turned lower in most major countries, with the dramatic exception of Japan. That downturn, coming after a rapid increase in rates early in the year, may help to stimulate economies around the world, thus reducing the chances of a recession in this country. 
For American money managers, the recent returns have been extraordinary, but some doubt whether that can continue. They worry that foreign interest rates could turn higher, particularly in Europe, as the cost of German reunification is felt.
According to the J. P. Morgan government bond index, 10 of the 11 bond markets it follows produced a positive return for local investors in July. The exception was in Japan, where bond investors lost 1.06 percent. But after factoring in the dollar's slide against every currency, the United States bond market, with a return of 1.29 percent, was the poorest performer. Japan showed a gain of 3.18 percent in dollars.
The star bond market for the month, and for the previous three months, was the one in Britain. In dollars, a portfolio of British government bonds, known as gilts, produced a stunning return of 6.86 percent in July, raising the three-month return to 24.81 percent, according to Morgan's figures.
Yields on British gilts now average about 11.6 percent a year, high by international standards but down significantly from earlier this year, as a slowing economy has led to recession talk. The rise of the pound has been related in part to speculation about Britain's joining the European Monetary System of fixed exchange rates.
Early this year, as interest rates were soaring in many markets, stock markets also suffered. But the general downturn in interest rates has provided some support for stock markets around the world, which, with the notable exception of Japan, generally rose last month. The United States market had a small decline, as the Standard & Poor's 500 average dipped 52-hundredths of 1 percent.
The recent rally in bonds has more than wiped out the losses early in the year, and holders of government bonds are showing a profit in local currencies for 1990 in 9 of the 11 countries, the exceptions being Germany, which is down 39-hundredths of 1 percent, and Japan, off 4.2 percent. For the year, the dollar is down against every currency except the yen, so in dollars there are profits for bondholders in every currency.
The J. P. Morgan figures for various bond markets are not strictly comparable, because they are based on the overall return of all outstanding government bonds. Countries that have more long bonds outstanding, like Britain and the United States, generally have more volatile returns. But the figures broadly reflect the profits, and losses, of investors in each market.
In the United Sates, the year began with a general - and incorrect - consensus that rates were headed lower, and that bond prices would rally. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, at 7.97 percent as the year began, rose to above 9 percent by the end of April. It has since fallen to 8.34 percent, which means bonds sell for less than they did at the beginning of the year. But coupon payments in the interim have more than made up the difference.
Now, while many expect the Federal Reserve to push short-term interest rates lower to combat a weak economy, the slide of the dollar makes that forecast less certain for longer bonds. Some analysts think those rates will have to rise to draw in foreign cash worried about possible further declines in the dollar.
In Japan, the general consensus is that rates will remain under upward pressure, ''simply due to over-full employment and pressures from higher energy prices,'' as Kenneth Oberman, a money manager with Oppenheimer Capital Management, put it yesterday.
In Germany, where rates are close to as high as they have ever been, and are close to United States levels, foreign money has poured into the markets in recent months. That has helped to push bond prices up a bit, and to strengthen the mark. But some American money managers are growing more cautious. ''We are starting to see the costs of the German reunification coming through, and they are higher than people expected,'' said John Hickling, the manager of Fidelity Investment's International Growth and Income Fund. He said he had been reducing the fund's holding of German bonds.
