HEADLINE: Dow Drops 5.94; Bank Stocks Off Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks fell slightly yesterday, with bank shares giving ground amid fears that the industry could be facing difficult times.
The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 5.94 points, to 2,899.26, despite heavy program buying.
Volume rose to 176.8 million shares, from 173.8 million the day before. Declines totaling 777 outnumbered 733 advances, with 84 stocks setting new lows. 
Particularly disturbing, analysts said, were remarks on national television Tuesday evening by a Stanford University economist, R. Dan Brumbaugh Jr., who said he believed that several big banks were ''close to true insolvency.''
Speaking with Ted Koppel on the ABC News program ''Nightline,'' Mr. Brumbaugh said the banks included Chase, Chemical, Manufacturers Hanover, Bankers Trust ''and even Citibank and Bank of America.''
 
Reaction of Seidman
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, who also took part in the program, called the remark ''irresponsible.'' The economist ''has been saying things like this for the last three or four years,'' Mr. Seidman said. He argued that investors ''say the banks aren't broke, or they wouldn't be buying and selling their stocks.''
A spokesman for one of the six banks, commenting on the condition that he would not be identified, said: ''All the banks he mentioned are turning in profits; they're all paying dividends and in most cases their capital requirements are higher than Federal guidelines. So he's flat wrong.''
Chase, the Big Board's second-most-active stock yesterday, fell 1/4, to 18 7/8, with nearly three million shares changing hands. Citicorp, the third-most-active, slumped 3/4, to 19 3/8, on 2.5 million shares, after hitting a new low of 19. BankAmerica, the fourth-most-active, slid 3/4, to 24, on 2.4 million shares, and also dipped to a new low, 23 5/8.
Chemical fell 1, to 22, hitting a new low of 21 3/8; Manufacturers Hanover fell 1, to 29 1/2, and Bankers Trust dropped 1, to 37. Wells Fargo, which was not mentioned by Mr. Brumbaugh, fell 2 5/8, to 65 7/8, after tumbling 3 3/8 on Tuesday in the wake of growing wariness over real estate loans in California. It also hit a new low yesterday, 63.
 
Weak Economic Reports
Three economic reports released yesterday gave further signs that the economy continues to weaken. The purchasing managers index, indicating conditions in the manufacturing sector, fell to 47.4 percent in July, its lowest level since January and its sharpest decline since 1984. And the Government's index of leading indicators, designed to predict the course of the economy, and its report on the level of construction spending were both unchanged in June. The news helped bond prices advance, but stocks did not follow.
David B. Bostian, chief economist for Jesup, Josepthal & Company, said the news meant ''recession is coming'' but that stocks did not rise in expectation of lower interest rates because of the ''negative impact of recession'' on corporate profits.
''There's still hope,'' he said, ''that the Fed will ease further but I don't think the Fed's easing will be rapid enough to help corporate profits -and that's what the market pays attention to.''
 
Kodak Is Most Active
Kodak, which reported an exceptionally sharp rise in second-quarter profits, jumped 4 1/4, to 42 3/8, leading the Big Board's active list on 3.85 million shares.
The Dow transportation index, which fell 31.57 points on Tuesday, fell an additional 2.55, to 1,090.88. UAL, which touched off Tuesday's decline with a 16 7/8 drop, lost 4 1/8 more, to 135 7/8, on doubts over the financing for a buyout of the airline by its union.
Oil stocks gained, responding to rising crude prices and new Middle East tensions. Arco was up 1 1/8, to 130 1/2; Texaco up 3/4, to 64, and Exxon rose 1/4, to 52 1/8, with two million shares traded.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 0.63, to 355.52. The Nasdaq composite, where technology stocks weakened, fell 2.33, to 435.91, and the Amex market value index fell 0.30, to 353.30.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Post More Gains

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Interest rates resumed their decline yesterday as prices of Treasury securities rallied on new evidence of a weakening economy.
Dealers said the latest spate of buying was touched off by an unexpectedly sharp drop in the closely watched economic index compiled by the National Association of Purchasing Management. The Government, meanwhile, reported no change in its June index of leading economic indicators.
Dealers said the purchasing managers' July index stunned the market because it plunged to 47.4 percent from 51.1 percent in June. Many economists had expected a neutral reading of 50 percent - much as they had expected the Government's index of leading indicators to show little change. 
 
Report 'Somewhat Shocking'
''Although the Chicago purchasers' report on Tuesday more or less told the market what the national data would show, the index was still somewhat shocking,'' said Peter D. Mayers, Treasury securities trader at the New York office of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich. ''And once again investors rushed to lock in declining yields, which led many of them to the longer Treasury maturities.''
Late in the session and after some profit taking, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, were offered at 104 13/32, up 22/32 on the day, as the yield dropped to a six-week low of 8.34 percent from 8.41 percent the day before and 8.47 percent on Friday.
Those investors fearing to venture that far out were aggressively buying the long notes, the 8 7/8's of 2000, which caused the price to climb 14/32, to 103 31/32, and the yield to fall to 8.27 percent from 8.34 percent the day before and 8.41 percent on Friday.
Demand was also strong for the 8.5's of 1997, which climbed 13/32, to 101 20/32, as the yield fell to 8.19 percent from 8.26 percent the day before and 8.35 percent at the end of last week.
But Mr. Mayers noted that while the shortest notes, the 8's of 1992, rose only 2/32, to 100 10/32, to yield 7.83 percent, this issue has become pivotal to the interest-rate structure.
 
What Short Notes Tell
The reason, he explained, is that either the short notes have been overbought and their price is due for a correction, or more likely, their price is telling the market that the Federal Reserve will have to lower interest rates.
Except for Treasury bills, the two-year notes are the most sensitive of the Treasury coupon issues to the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for temporary loans. And the funds rate is the most easily controlled by the Fed. Despite a further infusion of $2.5 billion of reserves by the Fed, the funds rate moved up to 8 1/16 percent from 8 percent, which is well above the yield on the short notes.
''We can't see the yield on the short notes remaining much longer at so low a discount to what investment professionals can get on similar or shorter maturities such as commercial paper,'' Mr. Mayers said. ''We think it won't be long before the Fed eases.''
The discount rate of Treasury bills continued to decline. The 90-day rate fell 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.43 percent; six-month bills lost 6 basis points, at 7.26 percent, and one-year bills fell 7 basis points, to 7.12 percent.
Late in the day, the Treasury announced its terms for the midquarter refunding auctions, which it said were tentatively scheduled for next week because Congress has yet to complete legislation raising the debt ceiling. If the debt ceiling is not raised by Monday, the sales set for the following three days will have to be rescheduled.
 
Auction Dates Set
The Treasury tentatively plans to auction $11.5 billion of three-year notes on Tuesday; $10.5 billion of 10-year notes the next day, and $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds next Thursday.
Today, the Treasury plans to auction $4 billion of 44-day cash management bills in the usual denomination of $1 million each. Next Thursday, the Treasury said it planned to auction $10 billion of 36-day cash management bills. The proceeds of cash management bills are often used by the Treasury to redeem maturing debt normally covered by the refundings.
Dealers said that because of the uncertainty over what would be a record $32.25 billion refunding auction, there would be no when-issued trading on the 3- and 10-year notes as well as the 30-year bonds originally scheduled for sale next week. Trading in such issues on a when-issued basis enables bidders and investors to measure market sentiment as well as hedge potential purchases against adverse price moves after the sales.

HEADLINE: Currency Markets;
Dollar Makes Some Gains, But Traders Remain Wary

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar regained some ground in foreign exchange trading yesterday, but traders warned that the United States currency remained weak.
Analysts said the dollar's advance appeared to be a technical correction as traders took profits on foreign currencies that have surged against the dollar in the past week. 
The dollar has fallen sharply amid increasing signs that the United States economy is weakening and amid speculation that the Federal Reserve Board will be forced to lower interest rates to stimulate business activity.
The dollar is supported by higher rates, so a move by the Fed to push rates down would also bring the currency lower.
Further evidence of an economic slowdown came today from the monthly index issued by the National Association of Purchasing Management, which fell to 47.4 in July from 51.1 in June. The decline indicated a slowing in the manufacturing sector.
Analysts said currencies of countries with higher interest rates -especially those in Europe - remain strong against the dollar, and they are not expected to decline in the near future.
The dollar recovered some ground against the British pound today. Sterling fell to $1.8552 in New York, from $1.8635 late Tuesday.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose in New York trading to 1.58885 marks, from 1.58555 Tuesday.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar rose in New York by nearly a yen and a half, to 147.30, from 145.84 Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.3540 Swiss francs, up from 1.34475; 5.3240 French francs, up from 5.3195; 1,162.75 Italian lire, up from 1,162.00, and 1.15275 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15165.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks and Yen Fall After Iraqi Invasion

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Japanese stock prices fell sharply in afternoon trading today and the yen fluctuated wildly against the dollar after Iraq invaded Kuwait.
Spot crude oil prices, meanwhile, rose sharply in Far East trading. The price of the widely traded Middle Eastern Dubai crude jumped at least 30 cents a barrel after the invasion was reported. Price levels were not clear as buyers and sellers backed off from the market, oil traders said. 
Japan is hugely dependent on Persian Gulf oil supplies.
''The conflict, if further aggravated and prolonged, would have significant impact on Japan in various forms, especially in terms of oil supplies,'' an official of the Foreign Ministry said.
On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei stock index - which had fallen 255 points in the morning session - plunged almost another 400 points in the first 25 minutes of afternoon trading.
Shortly before the close, the Nikkei was down 673.22 points, or 2.18 percent, to 30,164.77. At one point, it was down more than 900 points.
News of the fighting pushed the dollar up by nearly a yen.
The dollar fluctuated violently between its morning low of 146.50 yen and high of 148.15, reached after frenzied buying after a Japanese translation of the news appeared.
''It was incredible,'' said Yuko Fukakusa, assistant manager at Tokai Bank. ''The market was thin, but it just went wild.''
The dollar was at 147.70 yen at midday.
Japan, the world's second largest oil importer, depends on Middle Eastern crude oil to meet about 70 percent of its needs.
Kuwait supplied 5.9 percent of Japanese crude imports of about three million barrels a day in June, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry reported. Iraq exported some 100,000 barrels a day, or 7.7 percent of Japan's needs.
 
Oil Rises in New York
By The Associated Press - Petroleum and gold prices rose yesterday in New York as the growing tensions between Iraq and Kuwait sent fears of a crude-oil supply disruption through the trading pits.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 32 cents to 85 cents higher, with the contract for September delivery up 85 cents, to $21.54 a barrel. Wholesale heating oil was 1.85 cents to 2.84 cents higher, with September at 61.19 cents a gallon, and wholesale unleaded gasoline was 1.81 cents to 2 cents higher, with September at 64.27 cents a gallon.
Gold and silver futures also rose on the Iraq-Kuwait news, partly to hedge against the inflationary effects of higher oil prices and partly because of the tendency among investors to seek the safety of precious metals during times of international conflict.
Gold futures settled $3.30 to $3.40 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with August at $373.30 an ounce. Silver was 3.2 cents to 3.5 cents higher, with August at $4.822 an ounce.

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion: Global Reverberations

 BODY:

OIL PRICES Spot market prices surged, with the American benchmark crude rising to $23.11 a barrel, up $1.57. The invasion stirred fears of slower economic growth, higher inflation and OPEC domination of the world oil market. But price increases should be limited by a near-record stockpile worldwide. Page A9.
 
FINANCIAL MARKETS The dollar rose, gold prices jumped and most stock markets fell. Japan, dependent on imported oil, was hard hit. As of today's close in Tokyo, its stock market had fallen 4.3 percent since the invasion took place. Page D1.
 
THE SOVIET UNION Moscow announced a suspension in the delivery of arms and military hardware to Iraq. The move interrupted Moscow's longtime role as Baghdad's chief arms supplier. Page A10.
 
UNITED NATIONS With Moscow and Washington in agreement, the Security Council voted 14 to 0 to condemn the invasion and demand an Iraqi withdrawal. Page A10.
 
DIPLOMACY Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d cut short a visit to Mongolia and plans to issue a joint statement about the crisis in Moscow today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Syria condemned the invasion and called for an emergency Arab summit conference.

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion: A New Gulf Alignment;
Iraqis, Bargaining on Anti-U.S. Sentiment, May Profit by Intimidating the Monarchies

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ushers in a new alignment in which Iraqis, Iranians and Palestinian hard-liners appear to share an interest in subduing the oil-rich monarchies of the region and challenging United States influence in the Arab world.
In ordering his forces to attack Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq calculated that the odds were largely in his favor.
Arab diplomats and military experts said the only serious risk for Iraq was swift retaliation from the United States military forces. But that is a move that Washington may not be ready to take, given that the Iraqi armed forces are widely considered the most tested and best equipped in the Gulf region.
The Iraqis have much to gain from their invasion of Kuwait. A successful offensive could establish Baghdad as the dominant power in the Middle East, giving it a much greater say in decisions on oil production and prices. 
Beyond that, the attack could become a rallying point for those in the Arab world who resent United States influence in world affairs and who feel that some Middle Eastern nations like Egypt have gone too far in accommodating Washington. Lastly, it could finally settle Iraq's longstanding border disputes with Kuwait.
The prospects for an effective counter to the attack appear slimmer in view of evidence that the Iraqis coordinated their move with Iran, which helped exert diplomatic pressure on Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates to raise prices last month at a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
Iran officially condemned the Iraqi move late today, but the suspicion remained that it had at the very least not discouraged Baghdad's action.
 
Sense of Powerlessness
In the wake of the invasion, the Arab world is discovering how powerless it is in countering an Iraqi attempt to assert its dominance.
Saudi Arabia is Kuwait's closest ally in the region and the founder of the Gulf Cooperation Council, the alliance to which both Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates belong. But it has hardly lifted a finger to halt the Iraqi invasion, giving the impression that it is powerless and ever more dependent on American assistance. Although the Saudis have spent billions of dollars on weapons and equipment in the past decade, they have contented themselves so far with giving refuge to the Kuwaiti Emir and his crown prince.
Saudi Arabia, which signed a nonaggression pact with Iraq last year, has within its territory a major pipeline that carries 1.5 million barrels a day of Iraqi crude to the Red Sea port of Yanbu. The Saudis could shut this outlet down, but such a step could give President Saddam Hussein of Iraq grounds to attack Saudi Arabia as well. Sacrificing Kuwait? ''I am afraid that we may have to sacrifice Kuwait as we knew it, to get out of this one,'' said a senior Arab Cabinet minister from a country friendly to Kuwait, who asked not to be further identified.
Saudi Arabia's main hope now appears to be action by the United States. The Saudis are reported to be discussing the possibility of organizing some kind of diplomatic and economic sanctions, like a boycott of Iraqi exports. Such action would require a guarantee of military protection from the United States.
Bolstering Iraq's resources is the price of oil, which has already soared to a two-year high along with the country's revenue. An oil embargo by the West and Japan against Iraqi or Kuwaiti crude would only push prices higher, hitting Western consumers hardest.
The Iraqi move has already buttressed Baghdad's quest for leadership in the Arab world, diluting the influence of American allies like Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Jordan as their strenuous diplomatic efforts to avert the attack over the last few days failed miserably in the face of Iraqi determination.
 
Iraq and Iran Met Secretly
Iraqi and Iranian officials confirmed in interviews at the OPEC meeting last month in Geneva that their officials had met secretly as recently as late July, days before the OPEC session opened. In a half-day meeting, the officials said, Iran and Iraq crafted their common strategy of squeezing Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates to stop violating their quota ceilings on oil production.
When President Hussein and his top ministers singled out Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates as the main culprits in the weakening of oil prices, he had the open support of Teheran. Iraq and Iran then maneuvered to nudge the rest of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, including Saudi Arabia, to raise the minimum price of oil by $3 a barrel, a policy which had been steadfastly opposed by Kuwait.
Arab officials from Persian Gulf countries said they believed that some Palestinians from among the 400,000 Palestinians who live in Kuwait had lent active support to Iraq, gathering information and giving other assistance to Iraqi troops.
The Iraqi attack comes at a time when Palestine Liberation Organization militants active in the Israeli-occupied territories have been sharply criticizing Egypt, Iraq's main rival for Arab leadership, accusing President Hosni Mubarak of being ''an American puppet.''
 
Atmosphere of Hostility
The Iraqi invasion also comes amid a growing hostility in the Arab world to American policies. Many Arabs were disappointed over the failure of the American dialogue with the P.L.O. to produce tangible progress toward satisfying Palestinian aspirations. They also resent the United States for supporting Israel throughout the two-and-a-half year Palestinian uprising against the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza.
Several Arab officials expressed ambivalence about Kuwait. On the one hand, there is a widespread admiration for its generous help to many an Arab country, including Iraq, which received close to $10 billion in interest-free loans from Kuwait during its eight-year-long war with Iran.
But Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar are also seen as privileged countries that have accumulated wealth far beyond that of other Arab nations and that have done little to help resolve the Palestinian issue.
This view was evident by the late afternoon, when only a handful of Arab nations had spoken out unequivocally in favor of Kuwait. Among them was Syria, Iraq's longtime enemy, which called today for an emergency summit conference of the heads of state of 21 Arab nations to discuss what its official radio station called the ''blatant invasion of sisterly Kuwait by Saddam Hussein's forces.''
Syria was also reported by Arab diplomats to have reinforced its military units on its border with Iraq.
 
Hints of Appeasement
Perhaps in recognition of this sentiment, senior Kuwaiti officials hinted today at an appeasement of the Iraqis, even while calling for help against the invasion. Abdel Rahman al-Awadi, a Kuwaiti minister of state, emerged from a meeting of Arab foreign ministers in Cairo to appeal for a ''brotherly solution'' to the conflict.
Libya warned against any foreign intervention in the conflict, saying it would be considered an aggressive act, according to the official Libyan press agency JANA. Libya also reiterated its thinly disguised criticism of Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates for their policy on oil prices.
Iraqi officials appeared confident of the cards they were holding, reacting firmly to any notion of withdrawing troops until they installed a regime favorable to Baghdad.
''The ruling family system in Kuwait is over for good. The Americans know that,'' said a senior Iraqi official who asked not to be identified.

PUB-DATE: August 3, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1258 words

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
IRAQ'S ADVANTAGE LIMITS U.S. OPTIONS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The Bush Administration faced the sobering reality today that despite a longstanding commitment to defend America's vital interests in the Persian Gulf, there was no easy military means to compel Iraq to withdraw its forces from Kuwait.
 
With the forces of pro-
Western Arab powers like Saudi Arabia no match militarily for Iraq's powerful army, and with only a token American military presence in the area, the Administration's immediate responses included condemning the invasion, freezing Iraqi assets in the United States and calling for international sanctions.
Pentagon officials said that the United States had undertaken some military preparations as a result of the Iraqi attack. One aircraft carrier, the Independence, was under way at high speed from the Indian Ocean toward the Arabian Sea, adjacent to the Persian Gulf. It is expected to reach the area in several days. 
 
A 2d Carrier Is Shifted
Another aircraft carrier, the Eisenhower, was being shifted to the Eastern Mediterranean Sea to put its attack planes within range of Iraq. The modest fleet of American ships in the Persian Gulf was expanded from six to eight. And some Air Force aerial refueling tankers were said to have been dispatched to the Indian Ocean region.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney canceled plans to go with President Bush to Aspen, Colo., for Mr. Bush's speech on military issues and instead monitored the Gulf crisis from the Pentagon. But there was no effort to dispatch Army forces or move Marine Corps supplies based on ships toward the Persian Gulf for a possible ground campaign.
In a morning news conference, Mr. Bush suggested that a military response to Iraq was not imminent, but he did not formally exclude it. Asked if the United States would intervene militarily in response to urgent Kuwaiti calls for assistance, he said, ''I'm not contemplating such action, and I, again, would not discuss it if I were.''
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is head of the Senate Armed Services Committee, expressed the prevailing view on Capitol Hill when he said that the proper response should be economic and political pressure and not military action.
 
'Intensive Diplomatic Activity'
''I don't think we have a military option at the moment, nor do we have a treaty obligation,'' Mr. Nunn said. ''I believe that our primary recourse should be to very intensive diplomatic activity.'' His comments were made on the NBC News program, ''Today.''
Pentagon officials said that the Administration was actively considering a number of military responses but stressed that the first course of action would be to apply political and economic pressure.
The impediments to military action are the simple facts of geography and the phenomenal growth of Iraq's military power.
Pentagon officials said, for example, that it would take close to a month to deploy an Army corps of two ''heavy'' - armored or mechanized - divisions to the gulf, assuming that Saudi Arabia was prepared to receive it.
Smaller forces, like a Marine Expeditionary Brigade, numbering about 16,000 troops, could be dispatched more quickly. It would take about a week to move such a unit and its equipment to the gulf, a Pentagon official said. But such a unit would be no match for Iraq's large, battle tested Army.
 
Concerns About Americans
Further, as Thomas L. McNaugher, a military specialist at the Brookings Institution noted, Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, is holding as virtual hostages the Kuwaiti population and the several thousand Americans living in Kuwait. The Iraqi radio, in an official statement today, warned against intervention, saying ''our armed forces'' would make Iraq and Kuwait ''a graveyard'' if such action were attempted.
For some military officials, a punitive air strike against Iraq did not appear to be an attractive option, though others said it was under consideration. Such an attack could be carried out by Air Force or Navy planes, or by Navy ships in the gulf firing conventionally armed cruise missiles.
But having endured an eight-year war with Iran, Iraq's leadership might calculate that its population would not be shaken by such a blow, some Pentagon officials say. Iraq also has surface-to-air missiles to defend its installations; this raises the prospect that American planes could be shot down and their crews killed or captured.
Beyond that, there is the possibility that Iraq could respond to an American air raid by sending its force beyond Kuwait and into Saudi Arabia. Unless the United States was ready to defend Saudi Arabia, an air raid could be risky, a military official cautioned.
 
Differences in Interpretation
''With warning time, we could move into Saudi Arabia and develop a defensive position. All of this is predicated on warning. We have lost that. What warning we had was ambiguous,'' a military official said, noting that many in the Administration were inclined to interpret Iraqi military moves as merely intimidation.
But one senior Administration official took exception to this analysis, saying that the United States could adequately defend Saudi Arabia.
The obstacles to an immediate American military response, as well as the failure by the Bush Administration to anticipate the Iraqi attack, have raised questions about the Administration's strategy toward Iraq.
When Iraq began making public threats toward Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates and moving forces toward the Kuwaiti border last month, the United States response was to hold a joint air and sea exercise with the United Arab Emirates.
 
Signal to Iraq
The exercise, while very modest in military terms, was intended as a signal to Iraq to abandon any aggressive designs on the gulf states. But when Iraq, in effect, called the Administration's bluff with its lightning attack on Kuwait, many Administration officials were surprised.
Bush Administration officials had been well aware before the attack of the threatening deployment of large numbers of Iraqi troops on the border with Kuwait, and the Central Intelligence Agency had reportedly flagged the possibility of an attack. The force eventually reached 120,000. But many officials fundamentally misjudged the Iraqi leaders' intentions. The prevailing view in the Administration, the military official said, had been that Iraq intended to use its forces to intimidate Kuwait, or perhaps snatch a small piece of territory.
The United States is not devoid of military options, and they remain under consideration.
Mr. Bush and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, after meeting in Colorado, called for economic sanctions against Baghdad under the United Nations Charter, which provides for collective military action to enforce such measures. That raised the possibility that American naval vessels could be deployed to mount a blockade of Iraq, an option under discussion.
The United States could also buttress the defense of Saudi Arabia by moving military supplies and forces toward the gulf country. One option being discussed is to dispatch American tactical aircraft to Saudi Arabia. But the Saudis have not officially requested any military assistance.
The Iraqi attack might influence the debate here about the proper level of military spending and how the Pentagon should reshape its forces. Faced with a declining budget, the Navy no longer keeps an aircraft carrier continuously on station in the Indian Ocean, and no carrier was deployed there when Iraq moved troops last month toward the border with Kuwait.

49 of 925 DOCUMENTS

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 3, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1894 words

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
INVADING IRAQIS SEIZE KUWAIT AND ITS OIL; U.S. CONDEMNS ATTACK, URGES UNITED ACTION

BYLINE: By APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Iraqi troops stormed into the desert sheikdom of Kuwait today, seizing control of its capital city and its rich oilfields, driving its ruler into exile, plunging the strategic Persian Gulf region into crisis and sending tremors of anxiety around the world.
President Bush condemned the invasion as ''naked aggression'' and sought to enlist world leaders in collective action against Iraq.
Faced with a dire threat from the truculent Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, to a region containing much of the world's oil reserves and with world financial markets in turmoil, Mr. Bush banned nearly all imports from Iraq and froze the nation's assets in the United States. At a news conference in Woody Creek, Colo., the President and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain raised the possibility of economic or even military action by the United Nations.
 
Iraq Suspends Payments
In response, Iraq, which had been accusing Kuwait for weeks of stealing its oil and violating production limits set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, suspended debt payments to the United States. Western experts asserted that Iraq had been motivated by a financial squeeze that only more oil dollars could ease and by ambitions for regional dominance. 
Although oil prices rose sharply today, analysts noted that world inventories are unusually high, and they saw no immediate threat to supplies.
Witnesses in Kuwait said that hundreds of people were killed or wounded today as Iraqi ground forces, led by columns of tanks, surged into the desert emirate at the head of the gulf. Other troops came by air.
For Mr. Bush, the invasion posed manifold problems: the difficulty of direct military action despite the huge commitment of money and resources to the gulf in recent years; fear of another surge in oil prices, which could hurt economic growth and rekindle inflation; the potential disruption of the fragile budget negotiations between the White House and the Congress, in which a gasoline tax has been considered, and possible damage to the Republican Party in elections this fall.
Reuters reported that the Kuwaiti forces continued to resist tonight in at least one area of the capital, at the main military barracks. Earlier reports spoke of explosions and gunfire echoing around the steel-and-glass skyscrapers of the city center in fierce fighting at dawn. But the Iraqi Army, the most powerful in the Arab world, vastly outnumbered the Kuwaiti forces, and 12 hours after the invasion began the Iraqis were reported in control of the airport, central bank and all key government buildings.
The State Department reported that Iraqi troops had taken six American oilfield workers into custody near the Kuwait-Iraq border. Officials said their whereabouts were unknown.
The President said he could not confirm that Americans had been seized, but that if it were true, ''it would affect me in a very dramatic way because I view as a fundamental responsibility of my Presidency protecting American citizens.''
Mr. Bush said this morning that American military intervention was not under active consideration, but Lieut. Gen. Howard Graves of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, traveling in Mongolia with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, said the United States was considering ''political, military or economic moves'' against Iraq. And after flying west to meet Mrs. Thatcher and deliver a speech at the Aspen Institute, the President said, ''We're not ruling any options in but we're not ruling any options out.''
 
Warships Head Toward Gulf
An American naval task force, headed by the carrier Independence with 60 fighters and bombers, sailed from the Indian Ocean toward the mouth of the Persian Gulf in a show of strength. The Kuwaiti Ambassador in Washington, a close relative of the Emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who is now in Saudi Arabia, pleaded for immediate American military intervention.
At the United Nations, the Security Council issued a unanimous call for an Iraqi withdrawal despite Iraqi assertions, brushed aside by virtually all nations, that Baghdad had been asked to send troops into Kuwait by rebel elements there and that Iraqi forces would be withdrawn from Kuwait within a few weeks.
Mrs. Thatcher called Mr. Hussein's behavior ''intolerable'' and said that ''a collective and effective will of the nations belonging to the U.N.'' was needed.
United States and British officials referred to Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter, which permits the Security Council to use economic sanctions or military action against any nation that threatens the peace.
Such action was always difficult to take during the cold war because it was very rare to find all five permanent members of the Security Council in agreement on any major dispute.
 
Soviet Shipments Suspended
But the Soviet Union, a principal arms supplier to Iraq, immediately suspended its military shipments to that country, and the United States and the Soviet Union planned a joint statement on Friday after Mr. Baker arrives in Moscow. He hurriedly changed his travel plans after receiving news of the invasion.
Still there seemed to be little practical action that anyone could take in the days immediately ahead to reverse the Iraqi conquest. If Baghdad absorbs Kuwait or sets up a compliant government there, the oil reserves under Iraqi control will be doubled to about 195 billion barrels, making it second only to Saudi Arabia, which has 255 billion barrels.
The invasion appeared to have the potential to shift not only the economic but also the military and political balance in the region.
Moving swiftly today to endorse the President's actions against Iraq, the House voted 416 to 0 to impose trade sanctions and to cut off Export-Import Bank credits.
The Senate unanimously approved a resolution calling for multilateral actions ''involving air, sea and land forces'' under the United Nations charter to restore international peace and security to the region.
Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, called Mr. Hussein ''the Hitler of the Middle East'' and criticized Mr. Bush for not having moved earlier to forestall an invasion. Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, an influential member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, complained that there had been ''a kind of inertia'' to American policy toward Iraq in recent weeks.
 
Fears Over Saudi Arabia
Several lawmakers suggested that Mr. Hussein might now be emboldened to move into neighboring Saudi Arabia. Senator David Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, who was briefed by the Central Intelligence Agency this morning, noted that the primary Saudi oilfields are only 250 miles from Kuwait, with no terrain ''that would impede a rapid movement of forces'' by Iraq.
''We have to understand that our national interests are very much at stake,'' Mr. Boren said. ''I think it would be wrong to underestimate the ultimate aims of Saddam Hussein. He really hopes in the long run to put Iraq on a par with the kind of power he sees the Western powers as having.''
Judith Kipper, a Middle East specialist at the Brookings Institution, described the conflict in Kuwait as ''a war of resources.''
''This is the first post-cold-war crisis in the economically dependent world,'' she said. ''With the end of the East-West game, small countries can act with impunity to rearrange the neighborhood. Iraq is a superpower in its own area, but they need cash to service their debt and rebuild their oil industry. He gets cash from oil; oil prices are going up. Plus, they have historic claims to Kuwait, which Saddam Hussein has chosen to act upon.''
Gary Sick, a Middle East expert in the Ford, Carter and Reagan administrations who now teaches at Columbia University, said that condemnations by nations around the world would have ''no effect at all.''
''Saddam Hussein obviously expected that when he did it,'' Mr. Sick said. ''He can't be surprised by the reaction, and he obviously discounted that in advance. Some tangible steps will have to be taken if in fact Saddam Hussein is to be persuaded that this didn't work out to his benefit.''
 
Washington Is Galvanized
The news of the invasion galvanized Washington on Wednesday night and this morning.
Mr. Bush was told of the invasion at 9 P.M. on Wednesday in the residential quarters of the White House, officials said, and was awakened from time to time during the night for briefings by his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft. He signed his orders on Iraqi assets and trade at 5 A.M., they said.
At 8 this morning, the President met at length with his senior advisers, including the chairman of the Joint Chiefs, Gen. Colin L. Powell.
Michael J. Boskin, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, said that if oil prices rose 25 percent, and he seemed to consider this plausible, it would have ''some deleterious effect on our economy.''
Such a rise in prices would slow growth slightly, he said, but not enough to produce a recession. Growth, though meager, is still running at slightly more than 1 percent.
Later the Department of Energy said the turmoil in the Middle East posed ''no immediate threat'' to American supplies of petroleum products. It estimated that in January to May of this year, Iraq supplied 8 percent of United States oil imports, about 3.6 percent of total United States demand. For Kuwait, the department said, the comparable figures were much smaller -just over 1 percent and less than one-half of 1 percent.
The Energy Secretary, James D. Watkins, said that crude oil stocks in the United States stood at near-record levels and that world inventories were also unusually high at the moment. This country's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a statement by the department said, could offset the amount of oil the United States has been importing from both Iraq and Kuwait - about 730,000 barrels a day - for more than 800 days.
 
Crude Oil Prices Rise
Still, crude oil prices shot up to more than $23 a barrel, and some economists said that gasoline prices would rise by at least a nickel a gallon within a week.
Recalling the Arab oil embargo of the 1970's that forced millions of Americans to wait in long lines, analysts noted that the United States is more dependent on Middle East oil now than it was then. The American Petroleum Institute, which represents United States oil companies, spoke recently of a ''potentially ominous'' trend that has brought oil imports to nearly half of total American consumption.
 
Mediation Efforts Collapse
Arab mediation efforts to head off the crisis broke down Wednesday with the collapse of talks between Iran and Kuwait in the Saudi Arabian port of Jidda on the Red Sea. Mr. Bush said tonight, after talking by phone with a number of Arab leaders, that he was hopeful of a new regional initiative, but there were no reports of concrete plans to bring the two sides together.
Only a few hours after the collapse of the talks, Iraqi armor, led by more than 350 main battle tanks, began racing across the 80-odd miles of desert that separate Kuwait City, a modern enclave on the gulf, from the frontier. It took the Iraqi forces, using weapons supplied largely by the Soviet Union, France and China, little time to overwhelm the Kuwaiti defenders.

PUB-DATE: August 3, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 6, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 922 words

HEADLINE: To Americans Abroad, Paris Isn't All Feast

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Chauffeur-driven cars, drinks by the swimming pool, year-round tans and bottomless expense accounts may not be the happy fate of most American expatriates. But to a good many people back home at least, those are just some of the privileges they think are enjoyed by their fellow Americans abroad.
Not so, many overseas Americans say. Thrown into an environment where language, food and customs are strange, cut off from family and lifelong friends, they say they get little thanks for carrying the country's assorted diplomatic, business and cultural flags around the world. 
Still worse, when it comes to questions of citizenship, taxation, education and social security, many assert that they are victims of discrimination and even human rights violations. ''We are the forgotten Americans,'' said a Chicago-born lawyer now living in Paris.
Yet as different organizations representing Americans overseas begin organizing a lobby to carry their message to Washington, their leaders are fully aware that their golden image is the main obstacle to winning the sympathy of their fellow citizens.
 
Seeking to Persuade Congress
''We Americans have a sort of auto-xenophobia: we don't like ourselves when we move abroad,'' said Andrew P. Sundberg, a consultant who founded the Geneva-based American Citizens Abroad. ''This is due 95 percent to ignorance and 5 percent to envy.''
At what was proclaimed to be the First World Conference of United States Citizens Abroad, held at the American Hospital in Paris in June, expatriate spokesmen from Europe and the Middle East began mobilizing arguments aimed at persuading both Congress and American public opinion that theirs is not such a happy lot.
In speech after speech, it was said that the United States did less for its overseas citizens than any other industrialized power, that it is the only Western nation that taxes its citizens abroad and that it effectively discourages talented business people from taking foreign assignments.
One speaker said that while three million Americans live abroad, as a proportion of their countries' populations, far more Britons, French and Dutch live overseas. And if the United States is to face the challenge of the global economy, he went on, Washington must make it easier to do so.
 
Number of Suggestions
The expatriates suggested these ways to change the situation:
* Legislation should be amended so that American citizenship is given to children born to or adopted by an overseas American married to a foreign national, thus eliminating ''human rights violations'' where these children may be considered stateless.
* Americans working abroad should not be required to pay American taxes on foreign earned income - at present they have a $70,000 annual tax exemption - because they are often subject to double taxation, in their country of residence and in the United States.
* Americans living abroad should be allowed to choose between paying social security in the United States or overseas rather than twice, as frequently the case today.
* The United States should follow the lead of France and other Western countries in supporting American schools abroad since many American business people refuse foreign postings for fear of hurting their children's education.
* Modeled after the special delegates who represent Puerto Rico, Guam and other American territories on Capitol Hill, overseas Americans should be allowed to choose between voting in state elections or electing their own representative to Congress.
 
'A Global Town Meeting'
Democrats and Republicans Abroad, two of the six organizations that co-sponsored what became known as ''a global town meeting,'' did not endorse the idea of a nonvoting special delegate for expatriates on the ground that it would disfranchise overseas Americans from voting in their own states.
But the expatriates are not without friends on Capitol Hill. Mervyn M. Dymally, Democrat of California, who is chairman of the Subcommittee on International Operations of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, called hearings in Washington last October on the plight of Americans abroad and it was at his suggestion that the conference was organized here in June.
He invited nine Congressmen to join him at the Paris meeting and promised hearings in Washington this fall. ''The perception in the United States is that Americans abroad have the good life,'' he said. ''But I have the utmost admiration for our overseas Americans.''
They were warned, though, that they must take their battle to Washington. ''There's not a single person in Washington asking what's happening to you,'' Ben Blaz, the special Congressional delegate from Guam, said. ''The burden on you is to lobby, to keep us posted, to make people realize you're not mercenaries of America but missionaires of our country.''
 
'Important National Asset'
Cheered by a letter from President Bush, who described Americans abroad as ''very important national asset,'' the conference organizers are thinking of creating a permanent Congress of Americans Abroad that could send lobbyists to Washington without waiting for Congress to act on a special delegate. But one Congressman reminded them that victory was not nigh.
''You are taxed because you are citizens of a government that has to be maintained, and you have as great an obligation here as I do in Detroit,'' George W. Crockett, Democrat of Michigan, said. ''You asked me to tell you the reading of the average Congressman? You got it.''

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
Iraqi Invasion, Step by Step

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:

July 17 President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accuses Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of flooding the oil market and driving prices down, asserting that the move cost Iraq $14 billion in lost oil revenue.
 
July 18 Iraq accuses Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from wells along the disputed border with Iraq and of seeking to wreck Iraq's economy by overproducing oil and thus pushing down prices. 
 
July 20 Kuwaiti officials suggest that Iraq's sudden outburst of belligerence is aimed at getting its creditors - including Kuwait - to write off billions of dollars in debts from the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war.
 
July 24 The Pentagon announces that United States Navy warships and aircraft are holding a ''short-notice exercise'' in the Persian Gulf with the United Arab Emirates. Kuwait puts its forces on alert.
 
July 25 The Baghdad Government says it will not be intimidated by United States pressure. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt says Iraq and Kuwait plan to meet in Saudi Arabia in an effort to resolve their dispute.
 
July 26 OPEC ministers in Geneva agree to new, lower production ceilings in an effort to push up the price of crude oil. Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates pledge to abide by the agreement.
 
July 31 Kuwaiti and Iraqi delegations meet in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to negotiate the oil and border dispute. Diplomats say Iraq has massed 100,000 troops on Kuwait's border, more than triple the number originally estimated. That number dwarfs the Kuwaiti Army, which has about 20,000 troops.
 
Aug. 1 Iraq walks out of the Jidda talks after one session.
 
Aug. 2 The Iraqi Army invades Kuwait with tank-led troops, seizing the Emir's palace and other government buildings and strategic installations.

SECTION: Section A; Page 9, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1216 words

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
70's-Style Price Shock Not Likely in This Oil War

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
A new round of economic warfare seemed to be under way yesterday, as the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait resurrected both higher oil prices and fears of OPEC domination of the world oil market. But many ground rules have changed, both for nations that export oil and for those that import it.
The price surges on the spot oil market yesterday recalled the shocks of the 70's and stirred concerns about slower growth and more inflation worldwide. But unless pure fear inflates demand unnecessarily, the world is probably not headed for price run-ups on the scale of the 1979 oil shock, when prices tripled within months.
For now, the world is sitting on a near-record stockpile of crude, and at least some surplus capacity exists inside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. 
But in the years since the oil shocks of 1974 and 1979, OPEC members, including Kuwait and Iraq, have taken far different approaches to economic development, introducing strains into the organization.
 
Uncertainty at the Pump
The effect at the gasoline pump is uncertain. Crude oil prices fell sharply in the early part of this year but gasoline prices were stable. In the longer term, an increase of $7 a barrel in crude, which is what the markets have seen in recent weeks, would come to 17 cents a gallon at the pump.
In contrast to 1974 and 1979, experts point out, it is not clear that Iraq intends any interruption in output.
''Loadings were stopped; that's all we know,'' said Wolfgang G. Luding, head of the oil industry division of the International Energy Agency in Paris. ''They may resume tomorrow.'' Even if they do not, though, and Kuwait does not load a single tanker this month, world inventory on Sept. 1 would be about the same as it was last Sept. 1, according to Joseph Stanislaw, of Cambridge Energy Research Associates.
Confirming the surplus, the Exxon Corporation estimated yesterday that the world inventory is 150 million to 200 million barrels ''in excess of normal commercial needs,'' about 100 to 133 days worth of Kuwaiti production of 1.5 million barrels daily.
 
Other Sources of Oil
Even if Kuwait's production were lost for a longer period, there are other sources. Outside the Persian Gulf, Venezuela has about one million barrels a day of spare capacity, experts say, and other countries could produce an additional one million barrels a day.
On the Gulf, Saudi Arabia alone has two million barrels a day or more of idle capacity, and the United Arab Emirates has about 800,000, Mr. Stanislaw said. But having seen Kuwait invaded by a neighbor bent on enforcing quotas, they may be reluctant to produce much more.
''They've now got a lot of Iraqi tanks a lot closer than they were yesterday,'' said Michael C. Lynch, a political scientist and energy analyst with the Washington International Energy Group, a consulting firm.
Still, Mr. Stanislaw said, there is no immediate reason to believe that Iraq would hobble Kuwaiti production. If Saddam Hussein now effectively owns Kuwait or exacts a tribute from it, he may prefer even higher production.
 
Impulse of the Marketplace
But this logic may never prevail in the marketplace, say some analysts, who point out that the impulse in time of shortage is to buy more, even if huge stocks are on hand. And the price of oil depends on the price of the last barrel purchased. At the Institute for International Economics, Philip K. Verleger, a visiting fellow, estimated that a 10 percent shortfall in world supply would raise prices to about $45 a barrel.
A price that high, however, would bring new supplies to market. In contrast, in 1979, when the fall of the Shah of Iran removed that country's six million barrels a day from world markets, capacity elsewhere was thin. The same was true at the time of the Arab oil embargo of 1974. And after both interruptions, demand from nervous consumers swelled far above normal.
In trading yesterday of contracts for September delivery, West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark crude, closed at $23.11, up $1.57. It closed last week at $20.04.
The Energy Department said late yesterday that for the first five months of this year, the United States imported 610,000 barrels a day from Iraq, less than 8 percent of total imports, and 120,000 barrels from Kuwait, which is less than one-half of 1 percent. Domestic crude oil stocks are 1.1 billion barrels, the highest level in eight years, the department said, and if imports are interrupted, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve of stored oil can be emptied at 3.5 million barrels a day for 170 days.
 
Faster Reaction
There are other differences from the shocks of the 70's. One is that markets are faster now and unregulated. The shouts of a horde of speculators are quantified and transmitted worldwide by computer, and customers will feel them quickly.
Another change is that OPEC has been fundamentally split between countries like Kuwait, which diversified in the oil business so they could profit in a low-price environment, and countries that remained pure producers, like Iraq. If oil prices decline, so does Iraq's income.
The Saudis would also like to keep prices down so that the oil in the ground worldwide - about a quarter of which they own - will be the primary fuel of the next century.
One factor that has not changed is a frustrated desire to retaliate. Most of the responses, including the embargo of Iraq ordered by the White House, constitute the West's biting the hand that oils it.
 
Effects of an Embargo
At best, a Western embargo of oil from Iraq and its new acquisition would leave the world bidding up the price on the remaining OPEC output, say experts, hitting consuming nations with an increase at least as big as the one Iraq is seeking to impose.
As Western governments cast about for levers of economic influence they can exercise over Iraq, experts say there are few.
Some countries could exert immediate influence on Iraq; about a third of the country's exports go through Saudi Arabia, in a pipeline built during the Iran-Iraq war to avoid the Strait of Hormuz. But thus far, they have not chosen to turn the tap.
The United States Navy could also respond. If bombers retaliated against Iraq by attacking its oil export facilities, ''it would add another $5 a barrel in a matter of seconds,'' predicted Marion B. Stewart, an energy expert at National Economic Research Associates, a private consulting group in White Plains, N.Y.
 
Japan and Germany
Presumably, the impact would be bad in Japan, Germany and other trading partners whose dependence on imports exceeds the 50 percent in this country.
''The countries that get hurt the most are the oil-importing countries in the third world, like Morocco, Jordan, countries in Africa and India,'' said Vahan Zanoyan of the Petroleum Finance Company in Washington.
For industrial countries, the impact of an increase is likely to be smaller now, because their economies were fundamentally altered by the earlier oil shocks, and now use less energy for each unit of economic output. Of the energy they do use, a smaller fraction is oil. In the United States in 1973, oil's share of all energy sources was 46.9 percent; last year it was 42.1 percent. The decline in other countries has been steeper.

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
U.N. Condemns the Invasion With Threat to Punish Iraq

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council voted overwhelmingly early this morning to condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, demanding the immediate, unconditional withdrawal of all of Baghdad's forces from the tiny Persian Gulf nation, and threatening to invoke mandatory sanctions if it does not promptly comply.
The Council called on Iraq and Kuwait to begin ''immediate intensive negotiations'' to resolve their differences and gave its backing to Arab League efforts to mediate in the crisis.
Citing Articles 39 and 40 of the United Nations Charter, which gives the Council the authority to impose such sanctions on aggressor nations and to intervene against them with military force, the Council resolved to meet again ''as necessary to consider further steps to insure compliance with this resolution.'' 
 
A Seldom-Issued Threat
This is the language the Security Council traditionally uses when it threatens Charter violators with punitive action. Today's move is believed to be only the fifth time in the organization's 45-year history that the Security Council has issued such a threat.
The four previous occasions were the imposition of arms embargos against South Africa and Rhodesia, the threat of sanctions to obtain a cease fire ending the first Israeli-Arab war in 1948, and and the council's action ordering a cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war in 1987.
The 1948 and 1987 actions preceded cease-fires, and the Rhodesian arms embargo lapsed after that country became Zimbabwe under majority rule in 1980. The South African embargo remains in effect.
Several Council members emphasized that they are deadly serious about the sanctions threat, arguing that at a moment when a more peaceful and cooperative world order is evolving, the United Nations must show itself ready to compel compliance with the principles of its Charter.
 
'The World Is Watching'
''It is a time for peace and diplomacy, not for war and aggression,'' the United States chief delegate, Thomas R. Pickering, told the Council. ''The world is watching what we do and will not be satisfied with vacillation and procrastination.''
Kuwait's United Nations representative, Mohammed A. Abulhassan, called the resolution ''a test of the Council and its ability to preserve the peace and security of all small nations.'' After the vote, the delegate of one third world nation said, ''We have threatened sanctions and we mean it. Our credibility is at stake.''
The 15-member Security Council consists of five permanent members -Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union and the United States - and 10 rotating seats, currently held by Canada, Finland, Colombia, Ethiopia, Malaysia, Ivory Coast, Zaire, Romania, Cuba and Yemen.
Western members of the Council said they will probably delay the next meeting until Monday to give Iraq time to comply and allow the Arab League to pursue its mediation efforts. But if, as they anticipate, Iraqi forces are still occupying Kuwait, they expect to reconvene and start planning a worldwide program of mandatory economic sanctions against Baghdad.
 
Early-Morning Vote
After a night of frenzied negotiations, the Security Council voted just before 6:00 this morning to condemn Iraq's invasion. Fourteen of the Council's 15 members voted in favor of the resolution and none against. Yemen, the only Arab country on the Council, did not participate in the vote because its delegate said he had no instructions from his government.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
The Target of Choice For the G.O.P.: Mitchell

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Move over, Mario Cuomo. George Mitchell, the mild-mannered, sober-minded and rarely quotable Senate majority leader, is emerging as the Democrat the Republicans love to hate.
When House Republicans adopted a resolution two weeks ago declaring their opposition to a budget plan that includes any kind of tax increases, the Democrat they scorned for having ''championed tax increases at every turn'' was Senator Mitchell. True, the Senator's name was inserted at the suggestion of an Administration eager to divert attention from President Bush's position on taxes, but Congressional Republicans liked the idea. 
''House Republicans are mad as hell at Senate Democrats, and at George Mitchell in particular,'' said Representative Vin Weber, a Minnesota Republican. ''He's been in the forefront of getting President Bush to break his pledge on taxes.''
When Senate Republicans found themselves outmaneuvered on the procedures for debating and amending the civil rights bill, the man they accused of playing fast and loose with the rules was Senator Mitchell.
''It has been happening on other bills, and we don't think this is a fair way to run the Senate,'' said Senator John C. Danforth, a Republican from Missouri, who insisted there was no personal animosity toward Mr. Mitchell.
Another Republican, Senator Thad Cochran of Mississippi, said: ''Republicans feel they are being deprived of their right to offer amendments on important legislation. It's been building for several months, and on our side it's developed into a real resentment.''
This was evident when Republican strategists looked for a way to explain high interest rates and a sluggish economy. The cause they cited first was the fact that the capital gains tax rate was not cut last year. And the man they blamed for blocking the cut was Senator Mitchell.
''The Mitchell Recession is more than an article of faith for Republicans: it has entered into our mythology,'' said John Buckley, a former spokesman for the National Republican Campaign Committee. ''George Mitchell's single-handed blocking of the capital gains tax cut in 1989 is the greatest blow this economy has received in the last two years.''
Mr. Mitchell's transformation by Republicans from ''just plain George'' to arch-Democratic villain is all the more striking because only six months ago political strategists in his own party were lamenting the Maine Senator's lack of a partisan edge. But to a large extent, Mr. Mitchell, a former Federal judge, has become a Republican target by default.
The Democrat who used to serve Republicans as a partisan punching bag was Jim Wright, then the House Speaker. But the pugnacious Texan was toppled from his post and forced to resign in an ethics scandal last year. His successor, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, is, as Mr. Weber put it, ''just too nice a guy'' to cast in the role of a political heavy.
Congressional Democrats say Senator Mitchell's emergence as a Republican straw man is a sign of desperation.
''One by one, their issues are leaving them,'' said a senior House Democrat. ''They can't talk about Communism, or the flag, or the balanced budget, or abortion, or taxes, so George Mitchell pops up on the screen. It's like a target-of-the-month club.''
Mr. Mitchell won't go that far, insisting that the machinations by House Republicans on taxes have nothing to do with Republican complaints about legislative procedure in the Senate. Hoping to diffuse any lingering ill will over the civil rights bill, he sought no restrictions on amendments or time limits for the debate this week on campaign financing.
''This is a total that's larger than the sum of the parts,'' the Senator said. ''I don't see any significance or lasting impact.''
But Mr. Weber said Republicans had other ideas. ''Some people have reputations as partisan slashers, and others as nonpartisan above-the-fray politicians,'' he said. ''Our view is that Mitchell is the former, that he has to finally shed his judge's robes.''
Mr. Weber conceded that Senator Mitchell was not yet the partisan lightning rod that Mr. Wright had been, but he said Republicans were working on it.
''I think he can be made to play that part,'' the Congressman said. ''He could grow into the role.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 27, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 944 words

HEADLINE: Hussein Must Be Stopped . . .

BYLINE: By Gary Sick; Gary Sick was a National Security Council staff member in the Ford, Carter and Reagan Administrations.

 BODY:
The seizure of Kuwait sends a further signal that President Saddam Hussein, the megalomaniacal leader of Iraq, must be stopped. If he is not, the consequences will be perilous for the Middle East and for the world.
Since Iraq's invasion of Iran a decade ago, President Hussein has made his ambitions starkly clear. He wishes to become the dominant power in Arab politics and the dominant voice on Arab oil. 
If his power grab succeeds, he will become the ultimate arbiter of OPEC policy, able almost singlehandedly to determine supply and price levels. Today, by virtue of Iraq's conquest of Kuwait, it has perhaps become the No. 1 oil superpower.
If Mr. Hussein alone can wield the so-called oil weapon, he will be in a position to influence international politics profoundly. That is an outcome devoutly to be resisted.
The least the West can expect from swollen Iraqi power is that the Arabs' relations with Israel would become more dangerous than they have been in the recent past. Mr. Hussein, after all, has shown a willingness to threaten and to act aggressively, without worrying unduly about risks to himself, his nation and its neighbors.
After his invasions of two neighbors, Iran and Kuwait, Saudi Arabia has reason to worry. So do others, including President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, a major rival of Saddam Hussein, with whom he has already come to blows; Turkey, with which Iraq has had an ongoing dispute over water, and even Jordan, which like Kuwait has attempted to ally itself with Iraq.
The U.S., its European allies and Japan, as well as the Soviet Union, can ill afford the long-term threat to regional and international stability that Iraq's latest foray poses.
The U.N. Security Council has condemned the invasion, demanded an unconditional pullout and called for immediate negotiations between Kuwait and Baghdad. Beyond this, the international community must take quick, forceful economic and military steps to defuse the crisis and to frustrate Mr. Hussein's appetite.
President Bush has taken a sensible first step by freezing Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in the U.S. Now, acting through the Security Council, world leaders should impose economic sanctions on Iraq. This entails an agreement that no government will purchase any Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil until Iraqi forces have fully and unconditionally quit Kuwait.
Since Iraq's dominant source of hard currency is oil exports and the country has no other significant source of income, a boycott would make its economic position very tenuous very fast.
President Hussein's invasion of Kuwait was partly prompted by Iraq's indebtness. The war with Iran strained Iraq's economy to the limit and put a great burden on its financial reserves. One of his immediate goals is to drive up oil prices so that Iraq can increase its revenues.
Historically, the effectiveness of economic sanctions has been diluted by the unwillingness of many countries to honor them, notably during the Carter Administration's hostage crisis in Iran.
If a boycott against Iraq is to succeed, both Saudi Arabia and Turkey should be persuaded to shut off oil pipelines. The Saudis, acting, say, in response to a request by the international community, could shut off the Iraqi pipeline across their territory to the Red Sea. Similarly, the Turks could close Iraq's pipeline across their country to the Mediterranean. But to stiffen wills in Riyadh and Ankara, there would have to be a U.S. military presence in the area.
Thus, the U.S. must immediately begin re-establishing a credible military profile in the Persian Gulf. A convincing deterrent to further Iraqi military action would require at least bolstering the Saudis' air defenses as well as increasing the U.S. naval presence and deploying a Marine amphibious unit.
Such a buildup would help deter a possible attack against Saudi Arabia and serve as a precautionary defense of the oilfields in eastern Saudi Arabia. It would also signal Mr. Hussein that the U.S. and the West will not tolerate further Iraqi invasions.
A buildup should not be difficult. The Pentagon's contingency plans over the past decade have been developed around the mission of defending the oilfields as a last ditch effort to preserve access to the region's oil.
The puny military forces of the Gulf countries, including Saudi Arabia's, are no match for Iraq's well-trained, battle-seasoned divisions, which may be tempted to roll down the Gulf coast. The immediate deployment of a squadron of U.S. aircraft to Saudi Arabia might help discourage such designs.
A U.S. air interdiction capability would make it extremely difficult for the Iraqis to seize and hold Saudi oilfields. Iraq's supply line would be long and open to air assault. In the end, President Hussein would risk military defeat.
This is not just America's crisis. In considering military options, we should seek the close cooperation of our friends. Moreover, the crisis hasoffered a fascinating opportunity to see the new spirit of U.S.-Soviet cooperation put into practice. Moscow voted with Washington in yesterday's Security Council meeting. And subsequently the Soviets issued a condemnation of the Iraqi attack in language almost identical to that used by the U.S. Significantly, Moscow indicated that it would not sustain its deliveries of military equipment to Iraq so long as the present situation persisted.
The weak international response to Mr. Hussein's muscle-flexing in the Gulf in recent years surely nourished his belief that he had little to fear from the world community and that he could get away with murder again. This time, he has to be made to see that he has overreached.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 490 words

HEADLINE: Iraq's Naked Aggression

 BODY:
Without warrant or warning, Iraq has struck brutally at tiny Kuwait, a brazen challenge to world law. Iraq stands condemned by a unanimous U.N. Security Council and major Western oil purchasers. President Bush's taste for bluntness stands him in good stead: ''Naked aggression'' is the correct term for President Saddam Hussein's grab at a vulnerable, oil-rich neighbor. 
Fortunately, despite its million-man army, Iraq is also vulnerable. It depends on Soviet and European arms, on Western banks and markets and on the agreement of its oil-producing partners to keep supplies down and prices up. If ever there was a case for collective sanctions, Mr. Hussein's latest transgression has made it. And he can no longer play the U.S. against the Soviet Union, as Moscow made plain yesterday by suspending weapons shipments to Iraq.
Mr. Bush has taken the right first step in barring trade with Iraq and freezing Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets now controlled by Iraq. Congress is already weighing further sanctions against Iraq; the invasion clinches the case. But these measures can be effective only if reinforced by the countries most directly threatened.
The integrity of every Arab state is at risk if Iraq fails to heed the U.N. demand for immediate withdrawal. The specious pretext for Iraq's invasion was a purported plea for aid from ''revolutionary youth in Kuwait.'' The same formula could as well be invoked against other Persian Gulf states, notably Saudi Arabia. Having sought to appease Iraq, Arab neighbors now face a bully whose appetite they have helped whet.
Oil and power are the stuff of this aggression. Iraq contends Kuwait has forced down oil prices by overproducing and by ''stealing'' petroleum. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt strove vainly to settle this dispute by direct negotiation. He has been repaid with the invasion. This leaves oil producers with a bitter choice - yield to Iraq and its radical allies, rewarding aggression, or risk reprisal by cutting Iraq's pipelines or increasing output.
Arab unity, and courage, may depend on the determination of outside powers. Iraq's long war with Iran has left Baghdad more than $50 billion in debt. Iraq desperately seeks foreign trade and investment. Sanctions conditioned on a pullout from Kuwait make moral and diplomatic sense. Having experienced the results of piecemeal appeasement in decades past, Europeans should understand the need to stand together against aggression.
The U.S. has no treaty obligation to come to Kuwait's aid. But the gulf states and most nations still look to Washington for leadership and help in organizing action. President Bush has responded with the right lead - a strong national stand and a strong push for collective diplomacy.
In attacking an Arab state, Mr. Hussein has assuredly banked on the acquiescence of his neighbors and the covetous passivity of his trading partners. He needs to be proved resoundingly wrong.

HEADLINE: Film Fallout: Bright Lights, Cranky City

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Six times in the last month, the eastbound lanes of the Brooklyn Bridge were closed for a full night, stranding thousands of unwitting commuters in snarled, honking processions along other escape routes from lower Manhattan.
The closing had nothing to do with the ubiquitous resurfacing, rebuilding and other highway construction projects that at least promise smoother travel in years ahead.
In fact, there wasn't a repair crew in sight. Instead, a movie-production company had commandeered the city's most famous bridge to film an ambulance chase and other stunt-driving scenes for ''Hudson Hawk,'' a new mayhem-studded thriller about a paroled criminal starring Bruce Willis, Danny Aiello and James Coburn. 
 
Not Camera Shy, Just Annoyed
The agreement the film company, Tri-Star Pictures, reached with the city allowed it to close all three eastbound lanes of the bridge from 10 P.M. to 5 A.M., and that is what happened Wednesday night and yesterday morning, as well as on the nights of July 16 through 19 and July 21.
And while the city contends that resulting inconvenience was relatively minor - and more than justified by the Tri-Star and other film companies bring to the local economy - there is at least an undercurrent of discontent about the growing number of film crews tying up streets, blocking sidewalks and inadvertently shining high-intensity lights in apartment windows around the city.
''This place is crawling with film companies,'' said Olga Bloom, the director of Bargemusic, a floating concert hall beneath the Brooklyn Bridge. ''It's not a deliberate rudeness. They have a job to do, and they just blindly pursue it. You don't mind accommodating a few times, but after a while, you feel abused. Why don't they invest in building studios in New York?''
Jaynne Keyes, the director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, which issues permits for filming in the city, said that film and television production companies generate about $3 billion in spending in New York each year. ''Hudson Hawk'' alone pumped about $500,000 a day into the city's economy during the month of filming here that ended yesterday, Ms. Keyes said.
Last year, 8,000 city permits were issued for filming movies, television shows, commercials, music videos and other productions, including 110 for feature films, she said. This year, 90 permits for feature films have already been issued.
 
'A Few Complaints'
Few of the permits involve productions as elaborate as ''Hudson Hawk,'' or dislocations as jarring as the closing of the Brooklyn Bridge, she said. ''There's always some inconvenience, and we do get a few complaints, but most New Yorkers understand that it brings money into the city as well as the excitement and enthusiasm that's part of what New York's all about.''
Ms. Keyes said traffic advisories are issued by the city's Department of Transportation when streets are to be closed for filming and production companies are asked to notify adjacent neighborhoods by distributing leaflets.
Inevitably, city officials said, some drivers do not hear the advisories and get stuck. But the city goes to great lengths to accommodate film companies because of stiff competition from other cities, Ms. Keyes said. Production companies do not pay the city for the right to use local streets or bridges other than for the overtime costs of paying police officers and traffic agents.
Although no more blockbuster closings are planned this summer, a crew filming ''The Hard Way'' with Michael J. Fox is in Times Square this week. ''Prince of Tides,'' with Nick Nolte and Barbra Streisand, and ''One Good Cop,'' with Michael Keaton, will be shooting later this month, and ''Billy Bathgate,'' with Dustin Hoffman, will be in town in September.
And for frustrated drivers who want to see what the Brooklyn Bridge looked like on recent nights, ''Hudson Hawk'' is due in movie theaters next summer.
