HEADLINE: WEEKENDER GUIDE

 BODY:

Friday
 
RICHARD REDUX
Richard III, Shakespeare's passionate villain, is back in New York, courtesy of the New York Shakespeare Festival. ''The Tragedy of King Richard III'' opened last night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, becoming the 15th in the producer Joseph Papp's six-year, 36-play Shakespeare marathon. Directed by Robin Phillips in his Shakespeare Festival directorial debut, this production features Denzel Washington (the star of Spike Lee's newest film, ''Mo' Better Blues'') in the title role and Mary Alice (who won a Tony Award in August Wilson's ''Fences'') as Queen Margaret. Others in the cast include Daniel Davis as Buckingham, Jeffrey Nordling as Hastings, Joseph Ziegler as Clarence, Nancy Palk as Queen Elizabeth, and Sharon Washington as Lady Anne. The play will be presented Tuesdays through Sundays at 8 P.M. through Sept. 2. Tickets, which are free, are distributed one per person at 6:15 P.M. at the theater, where lines usually form a few hours earlier. The Delacorte is adjacent to the Great Lawn in Central Park, near the West 81st Street entrance. Information: 861-7277. 
 
'WORKING': THE MUSICAL
In his acclaimed book ''Working,'' Studs Terkel captured the thoughts and feelings of America's working men and women. The waitresses, firefighters, teachers and others featured in those pages came to life onstage in 1978, when Stephen Schwartz turned the book into a musical. This weekend, the show will be revived by the British-American Youth Festival Theater at the Gershwin Theater of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts. Directed by Robert Shampain, it features 30 performers, ages 11 to 17, from the Brooklyn College Preparatory Center for the Performing Arts and the Tyne Youth Theater in Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, England. ''Working'' may be seen tonight and tomorrow at 7:30 and Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Tickets are $5 and will be available at the door one hour before curtain. The Gershwin Theater is near the intersection of Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Information: (718) 856-0936.
 
BAROQUE AT BARD
Three of this country's respected early-music specialists are Daniel Stepner, a Baroque violinist; Laura Jeppesen, a gambist, and John Gibbons, a harpsichordist and fortepianist. Together they form the Boston Museum Trio, which since its inception in 1973 has been one of the champions of the period-instrument movement. Tonight at 8, the ensemble opens its second annual summer concert series at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. Joining them tonight is the mezzo-soprano Judith Malafronte, singing works by Strozzi, Calestani and Allesandro Scarlatti. Also on the program are works by Monteverdi, Frescobaldi and Domenico Scarlatti. Tickets are $10; a subscription for the three-concert series, which continues on Aug. 10 and Aug. 17, is $24. Information and directions: (914) 758-6822.
 
A MUSEUM SETUP
For those who have wondered how the lifelike exhibitions at the American Museum of Natural History are created, a show opening there today will help unravel the mystery. ''Behind the Scenes'' will give museum patrons a chance to watch specialists and volunteers demonstrate the techniques used to create replicas of fossils, rocks, foliage and other components of the museum's dioramas. Visitors will learn about the film and video technology often used in shows, and they will also have a glimpse of two exhibitions now under construction, the Hall of Human Biology and Evolution, scheduled to open in the fall of 1992, and the proposed renovation of the fourth-floor hall of dinosaurs. The show is scheduled to run through April 7. The museum is at Central Park West and 79th Street; admission is $4 for adults and $2 for children. Hours are daily from 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M., until 9 P.M. on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays. Information: 769-5100.
 
Saturday
 
WATERLOO MUSIC
Just about an hour from Manhattan's masses of concrete and steel lies an oasis of grass and trees amid a Colonial and 19th-century restoration called Waterloo Village. For 15 years, the village has presented one of the area's most popular music festivals. On Saturday night at 8:30, the Waterloo Festival Orchestra, under the direction of the young Chilean conductor Maximiano Valdes, will play Vaughan Williams's Overture to ''The Wasps'' and Dvorak's Symphony in D minor. Also on the program will be Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto in D, with the Soviet emigre Mark Peskanov as the soloist. Waterloo Village is on Waterloo Road in Stanhope, N.J. Tickets are $20 for reserved seating under the tent, or $15 for lawn seating, and may be purchased at the Waterloo box office or from Ticketmaster at 307-7171. Information and directions: (201) 347-4700.
 
JAZZ PICNIC
In the opposite direction, another grassy musical mecca is the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay, L.I. On Saturday night at 8, the Friends of the Arts' Summer Festival will present the Preservation Hall Jazz Band from New Orleans, whose members include sexa-, septua- and octogenarians. The band will be led by two brothers, Willie and Percy Humphrey, on clarinet and trumpet, with Narvin Henry Kimbal on banjo, Frank Parker on drums, Frank Demond on trombone, and James C. Prevost on bass. At 7 P.M. there will be a picnicking contest, with prizes to be awarded for the most elegant, most delectable and most creative spreads. Registration is at 6:30 P.M. Admission to the concert is $15 to $25 for reserved seats, or $12.50 for the lawn. (You may bring your own chair.) Tickets are available from Ticketmaster at 307-7171. Information: (516) 922-0061.
 
HITS OF THE 50'S
In 1958, Vito Picone and the Elegants recorded ''Little Star,'' the hit song that sold 2.5 million copies and brought the group fame. Since then, the band has toured the United States, Mexico and Canada, and its songs have been included on the soundtracks for ''Joey,'' ''American Hot Wax'' and other films. The group returns home to Staten Island on Saturday night for ''Doo-Wop Hop,'' a concert of songs from the 50's. There will be two shows, at 7 and 9:30, at Veterans Memorial Hall at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace in Livingston. Tickets are $10 and $12 and are available from Harborcharge at (718) 448-2500, or from Ticketmaster at 307-7171. Information: (718) 448-2500.
 
Sunday
 
THE SCENE, CIRCA 1929
Elmer Rice's play ''Street Scene'' won the 1929 Pulitzer Prize for drama; in 1947, Kurt Weill turned it into a musical that Brooks Atkinson, reviewing it for The New York Times, called ''a play of magnificence and glory.'' On Sunday at 3 P.M., the Playhouse of American Classics will present a chamber theater production of this exploration of life in New York City's tenements. Directed by its artistic director, Terence McDonald, this performance opens the Playhouse's 1990-91 season, which will focus on New York life in the 1920's, 40's and 60's. Other plays will include ''My Sister Eileen'' and ''Two for the Seesaw.'' ''Street Scene'' will be presented at the Mazur Theater in the Murphy Center at the Asphalt Green Community Center, 555 East 90th Street. Admission is free, but a $5 donation will be requested at the door. Information: 662-8178.
 
WATER ROUTE TO HISTORY
Once the lifeline of New York's economy, the shipping lanes of lower Manhattan remain a vital link to the city's maritime heritage. On Sunday at the Alice Austen House and Park on Staten Island, a celebration of this heritage will take place when the fifth Nautical Festival opens at 1 P.M. Included in the afternoon's activities will be a masthead knot-tying demonstration at 1:30 and 3 P.M., a demonstration of a Coast Guard air-to-sea search and rescue at 2, and, at 2:30 P.M., a lecture on the history of New York Harbor by Peter Stanford, the president of the National Maritime Historical Society. There will be live music by the sea-chantey singers Stout and by the New York Brass Entourage. At 3 P.M., there will be a tour of the historic Austen house and gardens and its current photography exhibition on turn-of-the-century shipping in the Narrows. The Austen House is at 2 Hylan Boulevard in Rosebank. Admission is free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Iraqi Invasion
As the news of the invasion spread worldwide, the dollar rose, gold prices jumped and most of the world's stock markets fell. From Tokyo to New York, investors fled to the safe havens of the dollar and gold. [Page D1.] 
A new round of economic warfare seemed to be starting as the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait resurrected both higher oil prices and fears of OPEC domination of the world oil market. But many ground rules have changed, both for nations that export oil and for those that import it. [A9.]
In freezing Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in the U.S., President Bush has fenced off an estimated $30 billion from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Government analysts say. [A9.]
 
The Economy
Orders to factories for manufactured goods declined 1.5 percent in June, the Commerce Department said. It was the third time this year that the total declined from the month before. [D2.]
Every major accusation of criminal S.&L. fraud is under investigation by the Justice Department, Thornburgh said. [D17.]
The House approved legislation that would permit airports to levy a new tax on airline tickets of up to $12 on a round trip. [A17.]
 
Companies
Allianz A.G. will buy Fireman's Fund Insurance for $3.3 billion in cash. The deal is one of the last big steps by Europe's largest insurer to build a worldwide network. [D1.]
Nynex is creating an office of ethics and business conduct. The company faces criminal and civil lawsuits and regulatory penalties after accusations of impropriety. [D1.]
Macy's sold a 1 percent stake for a price that values its equity at $1.5 billion - about four times what investors paid when the company was taken private four years ago. The move is likely to reassure worried vendors about the retailer's financial strength. [D1.]
Union pilots who joined a strike against Eastern Airlines have the right to replace trainees hired during the carrier's rebuilding, a Federal judge ruled. [D4.]
Pratt & Whitney plans to eliminate 4,000 jobs by 1993 because of expected cutbacks in Defense Department contracts. [D4.]
 
International
The U.S. and Japan have reached an agreement that resolves a trade dispute over barriers that have blocked foreign companies from the Japanese telecommunications market. [D4.]
 
Markets
Stocks plunged because of the inflation fears touched off by the Iraqi invasion. Airlines and other users of petroleum products were hard-hit, but oil and oil-service stocks surged. The Dow fell 34.66, or 1.2 percent, to 2,864.60. [D6.]
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbled on fears of oil-fueled inflation. Yields on the Treasury's benchmark long bonds rose to 8.45 percent. [D14.]
Wheat futures prices closed slightly higher, but the corn and soybean markets fell, amid forecasts for more good crop weather in the Midwest. [D15.]
 
Today's Columns
Economic growth has been systematically overstated by the governments of Eastern Europe, two American economists conclude. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Food stocks are in favor with a number of analysts. During the 1980's, the group appreciated an average of 14 percent a year, outperforming the market except in 1987. Market Place. [D6.]
As the competition for new accounts becomes fierce, agencies are turning to professionals who specialize in finding new business. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D17.]

HEADLINE: Savings Cure May Kill the Patient

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
When President Bush gathered with Congressional leaders in the Rose Garden last Aug. 9 for the signing of the savings and loan bailout bill, he triumphantly declared, ''This legislation will safeguard and stabilize America's financial system and put in place permanent reforms so these problems will never happen again.''
But as the anniversary of the Financial Institutions Rescue, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989 approaches, the law looks like a blunt instrument indeed. Many economists and industry experts, and some regulators, say it not only failed to rescue the savings system but also inadvertently put commercial banks in some danger by creating a difficult operating climate - without addressing the crucial issue of deposit insurance.
On Tuesday, L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, gave one of his gloomiest forecasts to date. Because of a deepening downturn in commercial real estate markets that is spreading to almost every region of the country, he said, the assets of the Government's deposit insurance fund for banks could lose as much as $2 billion this year. That would make 1990 the third year in a row that the fund has posted an operating loss. 
In the last year, Federal regulators, highly sensitive to charges that they were too easy on shaky savings and loans, have started to question the quality of real estate loans on the books of commercial banks. That initiative has forced many banks to take big losses on their loan portfolios and others to close.
Adopting a defensive, almost fortress mentality, many banks have established tighter lending policies, restricting the money available to businesses and threatening to slow the economy.
Some analysts now say that even a mild recession could generate so many failures that the Government's fund that insures bank deposits might need a bailout, too.
The savings bailout bill left the crucial issue of deposit insurance unresolved. The legislation required only that the Treasury Department study the issue and report to Congress by early next year.
Yet it was the existence of deposit insurance, as much as any other single factor, that induced the savings crisis and could cause problems for the banks as well.
The system, set up in the early 1930's after many people lost the money they had in banks that failed during the Depression, placed the Government's safety net behind deposits. Thus, it gave bankers few incentives to avoid high-risk lending.
 
Radical Proposals
Radical proposals, from phasing out Federal insurance in favor of private insurance to slashing the current level of $100,000 an account, have been circulating on Capitol Hill. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told Congress last week that the Treasury was not likely to support a reduction in the $100,000 level but could limit insurance to $100,000 a person, no matter how many accounts. The level was last raised in 1980, from $40,000.
Deposit-insurance reform is a thorny issue. Some experts warn that any substantive change in the system - like reducing the amount insured to $25,000, as some members of Congress have proposed - could prompt runs at banks. Others, with a free-market bent, contend that the Government should greatly reduce its role in deposit insurance and require the industry to insure itself.
While there is no consensus on the cure, many analysts agree that as long as there is no change the entire financial system is vulnerable to another big shock and the American taxpayer will again be called to bail out the system.
''We have a situation in which an even larger debacle can be caused in the banking industry if we don't revamp deposit insurance,'' said Peter J. Wallison, a partner at the Washington law firm Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, who was general counsel to the Treasury from 1981 to 1985.
 
Idea for Private Insurance
Mr. Wallison has proposed a system in which large banks and savings and loan associations would have to form insurance associations on their own and offer deposit insurance to other large institutions. Any losses would have to be absorbed collectively by the banks in those associations, much as the members of the Lloyd's of London insurance market jointly share their losses.
Mr. Wallison noted that the nation's largest banks have $165 billion in capital to cushion against losses, far more than the $13.2 billion of reserves at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's bank insurance fund.
But Congress is expected to resist the idea.
''There is a question of whether the Congress is up to taking that kind of step,'' said Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. ''It generally likes to be able to blame deregulation and the regulators for all the problems.''
 
The $100,000-a-Person Plan
Still, some changes are expected next year. Many experts are saying the concept that seems to have attracted the most attention now in Congress is the one that Secretary Brady said last week that the Administration could support.
It would limit deposit insurance to $100,000 a person. Now depositors are insured for $100,000 in deposits in each institution where they have accounts, as well as for money in joint accounts up to $100,000, creating almost unlimited coverage.
They also predict that Congress could permit the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to adjust its premiums on deposit insurance depending on the risk of a bank's assets, and force depositors of the largest banks to take an automatic loss - of about 10 to 15 percent - on their uninsured deposits in the event of failure.
 
Fear of Strains on Banks
The issue of limits on deposit insurance and the condition of the commercial banks are closely tied. For increasingly, financial experts are asking whether the nation's commercial banking system is going to encounter such strains that the Government will be called upon to lend assistance.
Few predict that, even under the worst conditions, commercial banks would have problems of the dimension of the savings industry's crisis. The bank regulatory structure has been much stronger; banks have held a much more diversified array of assets, and their managements, in general, have been more professional.
But the banking sector is almost three times the size of the savings industry. Even a modest shock could be very costly to taxpayers.
 
An Industry May Disappear
While the fate of the banking industry is uncertain, the future of the savings industry seems clear. By the end of the decade, experts say, it will be extinct, in large part because of the bailout legislation.
On the rationale that the industry must pay up first, before the American taxpayer is made to pay, the legislation required the healthy institutions that remained to take a sizable amount out of their profits each year and put it toward the cleanup -even as their costs of doing business were raised. Under the legislation, capital requirements were increased to levels roughly on a par with commercial banks; the amount of money an institution could lend to a single borrower was limited, and a new rule said that at least 70 percent of an institution's assets, up from 60 percent, had to be invested in mortgage-related assets.
While few dispute the prudence of these changes, the speed at which they were imposed on the industry seems draconian, even to the industry's toughest critics.
 
'Vindictiveness in the Legislation'
''There was a kind of vindictiveness in the legislation that I don't think anyone really expected,'' said Bert Ely, a financial consultant based in Alexandria, Va. ''It made thrifts into second-class citizens.''
At the same time, regulators, with a host of new powers and a new-found zeal, moved to shut almost any institution that did not meet the higher capital standards. While much of this action is aimed at preventing an accumulation of losses at institutions that are likely to fail, it also has a strong political component.
Regulators do not want to be hauled before Congress and grilled on why they did not act quickly enough to close an ailing institution. One result is that the Government, casting about for buyers for hundreds of seized institutions, has found relatively few eager investors.
 
S.& L. Charters Lose Value
''All this means that the charter value of a thrift is now much less than before,'' said James R. Barth, Lowder Eminent Scholar in Finance at Auburn University in Alabama. ''And it is going to get harder to get people to come in investing in this industry, and you have driven up the cost of the bailout.''
Still, there is a large school of thought that says such pain is unavoidable and that even more pain should be imposed. In this view, revamping the deposit insurance system is not the surest way to prevent a repeat of the savings and loan debacle. Instead, these people say, both banks and savings institutions should be required to hold capital cushions, which include cash reserves and investments by shareholders, well in excess of 10 percent of their assets, up from current levels of 6 percent.
''Look at the early part of this century,'' said George S. Kaufman, John F. Smith Jr. Professor of Economics and Finance at Loyola University of Chicago. ''The capital levels were 20 percent. It doesn't take much of an economic shock to wipe out 6 percent capital.''

HEADLINE: Company's Rise is Built on Credit

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: REDWOOD CITY, Calif.

 BODY:
Credit cards are now being tried in fast-food outlets, grocery stores, movie theaters and other places that have historically not accepted them. And that is music to Hatim A. Tyabji's ears.
Mr. Tyabji's company, Verifone Inc., is by far the leading supplier of those ubiquitous little boxes that retailers use to check on the credit cards of customers. It garnered 65 percent of North American sales of such point-of-sale terminals in 1989, according to an industry newsletter, POS News in Chicago. And its revenues have grown at a compound annual rate of 70 percent for five years.
Now, Verifone, which went public earlier this year, stands poised to benefit from the rapidly spreading use of magnetic cards, not only at new types of retailers but beyond retail purchases. 
 
A Card Instead of Stamps
Some states and counties are beginning to issue magnetic cards to recipients of food stamps, welfare payments, unemployment insurance and other government benefits.
Verifone terminals, for instance, are being used in a New York State pilot project in which food-stamp recipients are given a magnetic card instead of stamps. When they buy food, the store runs the card through a terminal, which dials a computer to find how much money is in the customer's account. If the purchase is approved, the amount of the purchase is automatically deducted from the customer's account.
Health insurance is also starting to be handled that way. In one system already used in 50,000 drugstores, pharmacists can run a magnetic card through a terminal to find how much of a purchase is covered by insurance. The customer then pays only the amount not covered and the insurance company is informed without the pharmacist and customer having to fill out forms.
Indeed, transaction processing, or ''transaction automation'' as Verifone calls it, is one of the fastest-growing parts of the computer business. ''We have found a veritable gold mine,'' said Mr. Tyabji, the company's president and chief executive.
 
Small Computers
Verifone's terminals are actually small computers with built-in software and a built-in modem for communicating with other computers over the phone lines. Instead of a keyboard, they have alpha-numeric keypads like those on telephones, and instead of a full screen, they have small displays that can show a line or two of data. The machine reads the information off the magnetic card as it is run through a slot and then dials a phone number and connects with other computers to verify the credit of a customer. It then displays a message that the purchase should be accepted or rejected.
Because its machines are computers, Verifone has been able to program in other functions besides credit card authorization. The same box can be used by a retail shop to keep track of the hours worked by its employees, transmitting the information electronically to a company that produces payroll checks. Gasoline stations use Verifone boxes to keep track of inventory and reorder electronically when supplies are low.
Mr. Tyabji contends that computers are thus sneaking into retail establishments that otherwise would not purchase a personal computer. ''These are computers for people who don't know they're using computers,'' he said.
 
Some Clouds
But that is also Verifone's biggest risk. As more establishments get full personal computers, Verifone's boxes might not be needed. In the pharmacy system, only 12,000 of the roughly 50,000 pharmacies use Verifone terminals, with the rest punching in the account numbers of customers on personal computers, according to an official of PCS Inc., which runs the service.
Similarly, the huge makers of electronic cash registers, including the NCR Corporation and I.B.M., are working on building credit card reading and verification into their machines, similarly doing away with the need for a special terminal. Verifone officials hope that at least some of these companies will license its technology rather than develop their own.
Verifone was founded in Hawaii in 1981 by William N. Melton, who had founded another company that ran a data bank to help retailers verify checks. Verifone charged into the market for credit card verification terminals by cutting manufacturing costs to the bone, underselling its competitors by several hundred dollars.
But the company's first products did not work as they were supposed to. The company was poorly managed, perennially short of capital and lived from crisis to crisis. It was ''management by reactive panic mode,'' said Frank J. Caufield, a partner in the venture capital firm of Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers, which invested in Verifone in 1985.
 
New Management
In 1986 the venture capitalists recruited Mr. Tyabji, a high-ranking executive of the Sperry Corporation who had decided to leave when the company was bought by Burroughs to form Unisys.
A native of India who came to the United States to attend graduate school in electrical engineering at the State University of New York at Buffalo, Mr. Tyabji provided the professional management the company needed.
Mr. Tyabji is almost universally described as extremely intense and hard-working, even to the point of working without a secretary and answering his own phones. Burton J. McMurtry, a Verifone director and partner in Technology Venture Investors, an early investor in the company, said he and other directors have been urging Mr. Tyabji to slow down a little, to prevent health problems or burnout.
 
A Global Operation
Verifone, which moved here from Hawaii in 1985 to be closer to its customers, venture capitalists and engineering talent, is a widely dispersed company that went public in March at $16 a share. [It closed yesterday at $20.25, down 37 1/2 cents, in trading over the counter.] With only 900 employees, the company has development offices in Hawaii, India, Taiwan, Silicon Valley and near Sacramento, with manufacturing in Taiwan and a distribution center in Southern California.
Verifone has continued to gain market share in recent years, in part through the 1989 purchase of the point-of-sale terminal business of its closest competitor, the Icot Corporation of San Jose, Calif. Its competitors include National Business Systems of Canada; Omron, a Japanese company, and Hypercom, an Australian concern.
The company recorded net income of $10.1 million, or 50 cents a share, in 1989, up 57 percent from the previous year, as revenues jumped 68 percent, to $123.5 million. Analysts expect profits of 80 cents a share this year with sales growing to $170 million.
But Verifone is now facing saturation in its primary market, because most small retail shops that accept credit cards already have a terminal.
 
Looking Abroad
To grow, Verifone is looking at new areas. One is to expand international sales, which account for less than 10 percent of the company's revenues.
Another potentially huge opportunity comes from the acceptance of credit cards at places that never took them before, ranging from supermarkets to taxis. Such places generally have shunned the cards because the procedure takes too long or the purchase is not large enough to merit the processing expense.
Now Verifone, as well as competitors and credit card companies, are experimenting with systems that send information about invalid cards by radio waves to the terminal in the store, which holds the information. That allows a terminal to verify a card without having to connect to a central computer, cutting the time for authorization from about 20 seconds to a couple of seconds.
 
Transferring Money
Verifone has also been trying to make its terminals more versatile. In addition to authorizing use of credit cards, many of the company's terminals now automatically arrange the transfer of money from the bank that issued the credit card to the retailer's bank. The merchant thus avoids paper work and can get paid for a credit card purchase in a day instead of the 7 to 10 days it once took.
Other new uses, which also include time and attendance reporting, inventory control and electronic mail, increase the price Verifone can charge for its terminals, which now range from $100 to $1,700.
Verifone officials, and many in the electronic funds-transfer business, also envision far greater use of cards for government benefits, frequent-shopper programs, health insurance and other uses.
''This is far more than just credit cards,'' Mr. Tyabji said. ''We are changing the way people live and I would submit to you that we haven't even started.''

HEADLINE: Invasion Shakes Up Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar rose, gold prices jumped and most of the world's stock markets fell as the news of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait spread around the world yesterday.
From Tokyo to New York, investors fled to the safe havens of the dollar and gold because of the world tension, and they dumped stocks because of fears of higher oil prices, rising inflation and slower economic growth.
In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average slumped 34.66 points, to 2,864.60. [Page D6.] And bond prices dropped sharply and interest rates rose. [Page D14.] Dollar's Rise and Fall These were typical market responses to a crisis situation. But more surprisingly, the dollar, which had risen 2.1 percent against the German mark in an early reaction to the invasion, had fallen back by the end of currency trading in New York to just above where it started the day. 
The dollar also advanced and then retreated against all other leading currencies.
And gold, which rose about $12 on news of the invasion, drifted back down and was only $3.50 higher for the day, at $376.80 an ounce in New York.
Traders and analysts said that by the end of the trading day the military situation appeared to be less serious than thought earlier, partly because of the response from the United States and its allies and the cooperation from the Soviet Union, which cut off its arms shipments to Iraq.
 
Moderation of Concern
This meant that the longer-term view on the dollar - that it will decline because interest rates here will fall while they remain stable or rise abroad - took hold again. On Tuesday, traders holding this view had sent the dollar down to near its all-time low against the German mark.
''You bought the dollar on the invasion,'' said Richard E. Witten, vice president of foreign exchange at Goldman Sachs & Company. ''But when it appeared that what was going to happen next was not electric, you sold the dollar.''
By the end of the day in New York, he added, ''there was a moderation of concern.'' He warned, however, that Iraq could send the dollar up again with another surprise move.
But fears of higher inflation remain. Higher inflation is the first effect of higher oil prices. The expectation of this inflation, in turn, would force market interest rates higher as investors demand higher returns to compensate for the rising prices. And central banks, in an effort to curb price rises by slowing economic growth, could also push interest rates up.
But the jump in oil prices itself would also slow economic growth by reducing spending power. That is most worrisome in the United States and Britain, whose economies are growing very slowing and could be tipped into recessions.
This threat of both higher inflation and slower growth also makes choosing a level of interest rates that allows growth but fights inflation more difficult for central banks, like the Federal Reserve.
 
'A Negative for the Stock Markets'
The Iraqi invasion caused stock markets in London, Frankfurt, Paris, and Tokyo to fall sharply, and the United States bond and stock markets failed to recover much of the ground lost in the morning. And it is likely that expectations of higher inflation will remain for some time, weakening both bond and stock markets around the world.
''At the moment, this is clearly a negative for the stock markets,'' said Martin Paling, international investment strategist for James Capel & Company in London. ''We could be back to square one in a day or so, but it adds to our caution anyway.''
Madhav Dhar, a global strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, in New York, said the rise in oil prices worsened the already generally pessimistic outlook for world stock markets.
Many of the world markets are already sluggish or, like the American market, declining from all-time highs, partly because of disappointing corporate earnings.
 
Problems for Tokyo
Analysts expect the worst market impact to be felt in Japan, which imports all of its oil. Even before the Iraqi invasion, oil prices worldwide had begun to rise because of the recent agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce production.
The OPEC members had raised their target price by $3, to $21 a barrel for a mix of OPEC crude oils. Now analysts say a $25-a-barrel price is possible if Iraq decides to curtail production further on its own.
However large the increase, it will be magnified by the fact that the Japanese yen is so weak against the dollar, the currency in which oil is priced. Compared with an average price of $18 for Brent crude oil in 1989, for example, a $25 price for the Japanese, after accounting for a weak yen, is about a 50 percent increase.
The impact of higher oil prices on Japan contributed to the fall of the Tokyo stock market yesterday. The Nikkei 225-stock index lost 592.81 points, or 1.92 percent, to 30.245.18.
 
Worries in Europe
In West Germany and Britain, the impact of the higher oil prices will not be as severe because their currencies have strengthened significantly recently against the dollar. But concerns about the need for higher interest rates to fight inflation will not help the stock and bond markets.
The London stock market's main indicator, the Financial Times-100, fell 34.5 points yesterday, or 1.48 percent, to 2,304.5, while the DAX index in Frankfurt dropped 23.51 points, or 1.24 percent, to 1,869.38.
But the invasion has helped markets in countries that produce significant amounts of oil, gas and gold. The stock market in Norway, whose economy heavily relies on the revenue it receives from its North Sea oil production, hit a record high yesterday. And in Australia, the All Ordinaries Index shot up 30 points, or 1.89 percent, to 1,616.8, helped in part by a surge in gold and oil stocks.
 
Gains for the Dollar
In the currency markets, the dollar ended trading in New York at 1.5917 marks yesterday, just above its 1.5883 close on Wednesday. When trading opened in New York, however, after the invasion news swept the markets in Asia and Europe, the dollar rose to 1.6215.
Against the yen, the dollar closed at 149.25 in New York, up from 147.30 Wednesday but down from its intraday high yesterday of 151.50. In Toyko this afternoon, the dollar was trading as high as 150.20 yen, up from yesterday,s close of 148.90 yen.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Fell 1.5% in June

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Orders to factories for manufactured goods declined 1.5 percent in June, the Commerce Department said today. It was the third time this year that the monthly total of orders declined from the month before.
The report added to analysts' fears of a possible recession, which were intensified by rising oil prices caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. 
''We're in a precarious position, on the edge of a recession,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. ''With the problems in the Middle East and the threat of higher oil prices, that may be just enough to push us over.''
 
Soaring Oil Prices
After the Iraqi army pushed into neighboring Kuwait this morning, oil prices soared amid fears the invasion would reduce the world's oil supply.
But Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, contended that even a 25 percent rise in oil prices could be absorbed by the economy without halting its growth.
''Even if the higher price is enforced, our economy today is much better able to absorb modest price increases,'' Mr. Boskin said today in testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
In its report on factory orders, the Commerce Department said the decline was concentrated in durable goods, which are higher priced items expected to last more than three years, like major appliances and automobiles. Orders for these goods fell 2.8 percent from May, to $125.1 billion, after a 2.2 percent advance a month earlier.
 
Plunge in Military Goods
More than half of the decline in orders for durables was in military goods, which dropped by 20.3 percent, to $8 billion. Excluding the military sector, orders would have dropped only seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Orders for nondurable goods were flat, at $112.3 billion.
Robert G. Dederick, chief economist with the Northern Trust Company of Chicago, noted that factory orders had bounced up and down throughout the first half of the year and, as a result, the manufacturing sector ''is really just spinning its wheels.''
Orders had plummeted 5.5 percent in January - the sharpest drop since a 7 percent decrease in December 1974. They then rose 1.8 percent in February and 4 percent in March before dropping 2.1 percent in April. Orders were up 2.2 percent in May.
 
A Loss of Jobs
As orders decline, industry tends to cut production and jobs. In fact, the Labor Department had reported earlier the loss of 31,000 factory jobs in June.
Because many factory-made items, particularly durable goods, are purchased with loans, the manufacturing sector has been adversely affected by the high interest rates maintained by the Federal Reserve in its effort to slow the economy to curb inflation.
But even if the higher oil prices do not jolt the economy into recession, they tend to drive up overall living costs and hamper the central bank's anti-inflation efforts.
The factory orders report did contain one hopeful sign, a gain of six-tenths of 1 percent, to $36.1 billion, in the important category of nonmilitary capital goods. This barometer of business investment plans had fallen 1.8 percent in May.

HEADLINE: Dow Slumps 34.66 Points, But Oils Soar

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Inflation fears touched off by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait pushed most stock prices lower yesterday, including airlines and other users of petroleum products, but sent oil and oil-service stocks sharply higher.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which had sunk as much as 52 points around 11:30, closed at 2,864.60, down 34.66, or 1.2 percent. Trading activity soared to the highest level in nine months.
Eight of the 10 most active issues on the New York Stock Exchange included some of the world's biggest oil companies. Leading the list, Chevron rose 1 5/8, to 80 3/8, with nearly 12 million shares changing hands, and reached a new high of 81 1/4 during trading. Texaco, No. 2, surged 2 5/8, to 66 5/8, on 6.2 million shares and also reached a new high, of 68 1/2, before falling back. 
 
Volume Up Sharply
Volume jumped to 253.1 million shares from a strong 176.8 million the day before, but 1,211 stocks fell, 144 hit new lows and only 464 advanced. Activity was the heaviest since Oct. 16, when volume soared to 416.3 million after the previous session's slide.
Although crude oil prices have been climbing, analysts maintained that the situation in the Middle East was so fluid that the direction of prices was uncertain and would continue that way for some time. Hugh Johnson, head strategist for the Albany Corporation, a brokerage firm, said, ''If oil prices stay high, it could endanger the economic recovery, which is closing in on its eighth anniversary.''
The oil price rise also ''darkens the outlook for the economies of West Germany and Japan,'' he said, noting that they rely more heavily than the United States on Middle Eastern oil.
 
Saudi Reaction Awaited
''The key economic question,'' said Peter J. Canelo, investment strategist for the Wall Street firm of Bear, Stearns & Company, ''is where does the price of oil go?'' The big consideration, he added, ''may prove to be what the Saudis do.''
He argued that it was in the interest of Saudi Arabia and most members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to maintain moderate prices. After consultation with Stephen A. Smith, the Bear, Stearns oil analyst, he described his idea of moderate as around $18 a barrel for Saudi crude and the ''low 20's'' for West Texas intermediate.
''If Iraq really wants the price to stay high and cuts Kuwait's production, will the Saudis make up that shortfall?'' he asked. ''We believe the Saudis will increase production to achieve stability.''
Program trading - particularly program selling - helped push the market down sharply. Birinyi Associates, which tracks such activity, said the net effect of the buying and selling was to lop slightly more than 19 points off the Dow.
 
Other Oil Stocks Up
Among other oil stocks on the Big Board active list, Exxon rose 1 1/8, to 53 1/4, also reaching a new high of 55. Mobil rose 1 7/8, to 67 1/4, a new high. USX, which owns oil interests, rose 1/2, to 34 5/8. Phillips Petroleum rose 7/8, to 29 5/8, after a new high of 30 1/2. Unocal, the 10th-most-active stock, rose 2 1/8, to 33 1/4, with 3.2 million shares changing hands.
Arco gained 5, to 135 1/2; British Petroleum 4, to 79 3/4; Oryx Energy, 3 3/8, to 52 1/4; Amoco 2 7/8, to 58 1/4; Amerada Hess 2 7/8, to 52; Union Pacific, which has oil and gas interests, 2 3/8, to 77 7/8 and Pennzoil 2 1/4, to 84 3/8.
Companies that serve the oil producers also gained. Schlumberger rose 2 1/4, to 68 3/4, hitting a new high of 69. Dresser rose 2 1/8, to 55 1/2, with a new high of 55 3/4. McDermott International rose 2, to 34 1/2, yet another high.
Mr. Canelo of Bear, Stearns argued that ''if the energy sector benefits from higher oil prices, other sectors will be forced to pay the cost.'' He mentioned consumer durables and particularly cars, airlines, some utilities using oil and energy-intensive industries, like steel and aluminum.
 
Utilities Hold Up
Ford fell 1 1/4, to 39 7/8; G.M. 1 1/2, to 43 7/8, and Chrysler 5/8, to 14 3/8. Except for UAL, which fell 5 7/8, to 130 on financing woes, airline stocks fell slightly. Utility stocks held up well. Reynolds Metals lost 1 1/4, to 65, and Alcoa 1, to 67 1/4.
In response to a gold price rise, gold stocks advanced, with Newmont Mining, rising 1 3/4, to 51 5/8.
Fund American, which is selling Fireman's Fund to Allianz A.G., rose 11 5/8, to 49 3/4. But with a drop in bond prices depressing insurance investments, insurance stocks fell. A.I.G., a market favorite, fell 3, to 71.
Drug stocks fell in the wake of strong increases already made this year. Bristol Myers fell 2 3/4, to 62 1/4. Lilly 2, to 82 5/8, Merck 2 5/8, to 87 1/4 and Syntex 2 3/8, to 59 1/8.

HEADLINE: More Companies Choosing to Self-Insure Benefits

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
More than 50 percent of the nation's employees with health insurance provided by their employer now work for companies that design and insure their own health benefits, a sharp increase over the past 15 years, an insurance industry group reports.
Many smaller companies, including a majority of companies with 500 to 1,000 employees, are following the lead of Fortune 500 corporations that have long been self-insured.
Unlike traditional health insurance, in which a company pays premiums to an insurance carrier that bears the risks and pays the claims, a self-insured company assumes the risk itself and creates a fund with which to pay health claims. Money in the fund is usually invested until it is needed to pay the claims. 
 
Incentives for Self-Insurance
The major incentives for self-insurance include exemption from potentially costly benefits that are mandated by the states, exemption from state taxes on insurance premiums, and the ability of the self-insurers to design their own plans and invest the money previously paid as premiums until it is needed to pay health expenses.
The major drawback of self-insurance is the exposure to financial risk.
''The largest insurer in America is not Blue Cross/Blue Shield, but the nation's employers,'' said Jon R. Gabel, associate director of research and statistics at the Health Insurance Association of America, which provided the estimate on self-insured companies. Mr. Gabel called the growth of self-insurance ''a quiet revolution in health care.''
Only 5 percent of employees were in self-insured plans in 1974, Mr. Gabel said. That was the year of enactment of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, known as ERISA, which exempted self-insured plans from both mandated benefits and state insurance premium taxes.
Jim Kinder, executive vice president of the Self-Insurance Institute of America, which designs such programs, said the major advantage of self-insurance was: ''You're buying the level of services you need, not a product offered by an insurance company. It's the difference between buying a fully-loaded automobile, and buying an automobile with just the equipment that you want on it.'' 1989 Study A study last year found that 51 percent of the firms that converted to self-insurance from 1981 to 1984 would not have done so if there were no state-mandated benefits. The study was co-authored by Mr. Gabel and Prof. Gail A. Jensen, a health economist at the University of Illinois at Chicago.
Exemption from state-mandated benefits is one reason that Subaru of America, with 1,150 employees and headquarters at Cherry Hill, N.J., began self-insuring on July 1. ''We'll have greater flexibility in designing our health-care program,'' said Monica Haley, manager of executive compensation and benefits.
One advantage, she said, was that Subaru did not have to comply with state laws that require ''coordination of benefits'' or full co-insurance for employees whose spouses are covered by other policies. Under self-insurance, Subaru will co-insure only the difference between what the spouse's company pays and what it allows on a claim. The ensuing savings will enable the company to offer expanded benefits in other areas, she said.
Subaru will also be able to earn interest on the money that it would otherwise spend on premiums. The company will pay an insurance company to administer the plan.
 
'Stop-Loss' Insurance
Like other self-insurers, Subaru will now assume the financial risks previously borne by its insurance carrier. But to protect itself against unexpectedly large claims, it will buy catastrophic ''stop-loss'' insurance from a carrier, a common practice among self-insurers.
Large companies are better able to bear those risks. A study of 1,943 companies last year by A. Foster Higgins & Company, an employee benefits consulting firm, found that only 30 percent of companies with fewer than 500 employees were self-insured, while the percentage rose steadily for larger companies: to 52 percent for those with 500 to 999 employees; 58 percent for those with 1,000 to 4,999, and up to 82 percent for companies with more than 40,000 employees. Over all, 52 percent of the companies surveyed were self-insured.
Dewey Dresser, a benefits specialist at Dewey Ballantine Bushby Palmer & Wodd, a New York law firm, said the growth of the 1,100-employee law firm had put self-insurance on the horizon. ''We're approaching the level where we might consider it, but we're not there yet,'' Mr. Dresser said.
 
State Risk Pools
The trend toward self-insurance will have a minimal effect on state risk pools for uninsurable individuals, according to Carl Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Association. He noted that 24 states now have such pools, but with a total enrollment of only 53,712 of the two million Americans considered uninsurable. Although the pools are financed by insurance companies, based on a percentage of premiums, some states are now considering legislation that would require self-insurers to contribute as well, Mr. Schramm said.
The biggest disadvantage of self-insurance, experts agree, is the risk that the companies assume. ''A few unanticipated catastrophic cases like AIDS or cancer can threaten the solvency of a fund,'' Mr. Gabel noted.
Such possible catastrophes were the reason that Hill & Knowlton, a New York public relations company with 1,100 employees, decided against self-insurance. ''It crosses our mind every now and then,'' said Sharon Shea, director of employee benefits. ''But we're not a large company. If we should have a bad year, we'd be in trouble. With AIDS or cancer, you get one case and you're looking at $100,000 for one employee.''
Because processing claims can be complex and time consuming, more than 75 percent of self-insured companies turn to another company to administer the health plan.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term U.S. Bonds Tumble

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbled yesterday, sending interest rates up, after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The invasion raised the specter of a resurgence of oil-fueled inflation, which would undermine the values of bonds and other fixed-income securities.
The Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, were offered late in the day at 103 5/32, down 1 9/32, as the yield climbed to 8.45 percent from 8.34 percent on Wednesday.
A point in bond prices is equivalent to $10 on each $1,000 of face value. Thus, the long bond lost almost $12.50 on each $1,000 of face value, which is considered substantial. 
But prices of most corporate bonds, which usually take their cue from similar Treasury maturities, registered relatively small losses. The largest declines were in the junk bond sector, where they ranged between a half-point to a full point on RJR Nabisco issues.
Also unnerving to many bond investors was the relative stability of short-term Treasury note prices. That stability was interpreted as precluding any change in Federal Reserve policy because the short-term notes would be among the issues most immediately influenced by any change in Fed policy.
''The big questions in the bond market when we went home Wednesday were how much higher prices would go, and whether the delay over the Federal budget was preventing the Fed from slashing interest rates,'' said Jonathan B. Greenspan, chief trader at the Aegis Capital Management Corporation. ''We woke up to a cold inflation shower, with Treasury bond prices already crumbling overseas on news of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Gold was up $12 in London, where oil prices were also going through the roof.''
 
Oil and Gold Prices
Although gold and oil prices, viewed by many as barometers of future inflation, gave up much of their early gains, the bond market did not recover from its losses. About the only positive factor in the bond market was the dollar's early strength, which did not fade until the close of the New York foreign exchange market.
Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International, said that in light of the Fed's preoccupation with inflation, ''it is unlikely that the Fed is about to lower interest rates, even if the current economic situation increases the chances for a recession.''
''This is what bothered many bond investors today,'' he said.
But Mr. Brusca pointed out that ''the oil situation today is in no way similar to the 1973 embargo by the Arab members of OPEC.''
''Nor will the Fed print more money to pay for higher oil prices, as it did with disastrous results for inflation after the 1973 embargo,'' he added.
 
Banking System Reserves
What the Federal Reserve system did yesterday was pump a large amount of reserves into the banking system through four-day repurchase agreements. Whether the move was a technical adjustment or not, it kept the bedrock cost of credit - Federal funds - from rising. The funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, closed at 8 percent, after trading at 8 1/16 percent for much of the day.
As a result, discount rates on Treasury bills were relatively firm. The rate on 90-day bills was unchanged at 7.43 percent; six-month bills rose 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.31 percent, and the one-year bills gained 7 basis points, at 7.19 percent.
Meanwhile, the closely watched 8 percent notes of 1992, the shortest Treasury coupon issue, fell only 3/32, to 100 7/32, for a yield of 7.88 percent. By comparison, the 8.5's of 1994 fell 8/ 32, to 101 13/32, for a yield of 8.07; the 8.5's of 1997 dropped 19/32, to 100 3/32, and a yield of 8.29 percent, and the Treasury's long notes, the 8 7/8's of the year 2000, lost 21/32, at 103 8/32, as the yield climbed to 8.38 percent from 8.27 percent the day before.
The Treasury auctioned $4 billion of 44-day cash management bills at an average discount yield of 7.60 percent. If Congress raises the Federal debt ceiling from the current level of $3.1 trillion, the Treasury might have to postpone its record $32.25 billion refunding and other auctions scheduled next week.
In the corporate bond market, the prices of the two widely traded high-yield RJR Nabisco Inc., bonds each lost a point in light trading. The 2007 issue closed at 91.75 and the 2009 bonds at 113 5/8.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
The Hunt For Clients Intensifies

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
AS the competition for new accounts becomes fierce, a growing number of agencies are being forced to learn how to hustle.
In better times, many agencies simply relied on their reputations to attract new business or counted on the old-boy network to push business their way. But industry analysts said these systems are no longer effective because the slowdown in the economy has led many advertisers to cut their media budgets and avoid changing their accounts too often because every switch is costly.
''With so many small and mid-size agencies doing outstanding work, the agencies that will have the best chance of winning new business are the ones that go out and aggressively pull clients their way,'' said Lee Anne Morgan, a principal at Morgan Anderson & Company, a consulting firm that helps clients find agencies. 
Professionals specializing in finding new business for advertising agencies are in such demand that many top people in the field command salaries of $300,000 to $400,000 a year. A top new-business executive will make about 20 cold calls a day and will keep in touch with more than a thousand potential clients.
Large agencies like Young & Rubicam and Lintas USA have well-established departments for seeking out new business. But most small and medium-size agencies never bothered hiring such specialists.
Not any more. Take the case of Cadwell Davis Partners. Executives at the New York agency, which has billings of about $100 million, recently decided that the only way to guarantee healthy growth was to hire a new-business specialist.
''We would just sit back and wait for one of our clients to recommend us to someone new,'' said Franchellie Cadwell, the agency's president. ''It isn't a system that works well now.''
Specialists in locating new business have also become more important because clients are becoming more reluctant to change agencies, even if they are not entirely satisfied with the work they are getting. ''The cost of switching has become prohibitive,'' Ms. Morgan said. The hunt for a new agency takes a minimum of three months of full-time searching by a firm's top executives, time that many companies cannot afford in today's tough business climate, the analysts said. And, once a new agency is found, it can take more than a year to get it up to speed on the account, they said.
Insuring a constant influx of new clients was so important to the Saatchi & Saatchi Company that it dispatched a specialist in new business from its London office to teach its account acquisition system to executives at its American divisions, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising and Backer Spielvogel Bates, neither of which have been on a big winning streak this year.
''The agencies were counting too much on the old system of expecting current clients to substantially increase their budgets every year,'' said David Miln, the director of new-business development at Saatchi & Saatchi in London. ''We needed to be more aggressive. We have to teach everyone how to be the right kind of hunters.''
Some agencies are establishing departments that focus on generating new business because top executives have realized that they do not have the time to chase after new clients. ''I tried to do it myself, but it has become clear that I should have hired a new-business specialist from day one,'' said Cliff Freeman, who started Cliff Freeman & Partners in 1987. ''All my time was taken up doing work for the clients I already had.''
In addition, Mr. Freeman said, he was not any good at the job. So two months ago, he hired a specialist. His agency is already talking seriously with several prospective clients, he said.
Many agencies do not know how to put together a new-business department, and some are turning to consultants to do the job for them.
''Many agencies go about it all wrong,'' said Kathy McCabe, a partner at Creamer Towbridge & Case, a new-business consulting company. ''They pursue a prospective client like it was some prey that had to be chased down.'' Ms. McCabe said one of the most important things her firm teaches agencies is that it takes three to five years of conversations to build a relationship with a prospect that will pay off.
Still, not all agency executives think a new-business department is a necessity. Foote Cone & Belding Communications, for example, is one of the few large agencies that has no such department and last year received $250 million in new business.
''We don't go out and beat the bushes,'' said Norman Brown, the agency's chairman and chief executive. ''We still believe that if we do good work for our clients, the word will get out.''

HEADLINE: Boskin's View on Recession

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Amid a continuing barrage of weak reports on the economy, Michael J. Boskin, the Presidential adviser, said today that the chance of a recession during the next 12 months, while ''low,'' is ''certainly not zero.''
In an appearance before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Mr. Boskin also appeared to retreat from earlier admonitions by the Bush Administration that the Federal Reserve needed to further relax its monetary policy to keep the economy moving forward. He said that while it took time for changes in policy to take effect, the Fed did not necessarily have to cut interest rates in anticipation of a deficit-reduction deal between the White House and Congress but might wait until a deal had been struck.
In discussing the prospect of recession, Mr. Boskin said he disregarded this week's poor reports on the Government's predictive index and on construction spending. He said he would only be concerned about the decline in manufacturing activity, as reflected in the report on the nation's purchasing managers, if this persisted in coming months.
At another point, Mr. Boskin said that while the business cycle had not been eliminated as a fact of economic life, recessions would probably be less frequent in coming decades, partly because of better techniques of managing inventories.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
IRAQIS MASS ON SAUDI FRONTIER; ARABS AGREE TO MEET ON CRISIS; BUSH IS READY TO HELP IF ASKED

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Powerful Iraqi forces wheeled into position for a possible attack on Saudi Arabia today, while the United States and its allies continued to search, without discernible success, for a way to force Iraq to pull back from its rapid conquest of Kuwait on Thursday.
In Baghdad tonight, a spokesman for the ruling Revolutionary Command Council said Iraq would begin withdrawing its troops from Kuwait on Sunday ''unless something appears which could threaten the security of Kuwait and Iraq.'' But Baghdad radio specified that its ''provisional government,'' denounced as a puppet regime by the United States and most of the world, would remain in control in Kuwait. The White House discounted the Iraqi announcement.
 
Meeting in Saudi Arabia
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq agreed to meet on Sunday in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, with other Arab leaders, Saudi officials announced. The United States and the Soviet Union issued an extraordinary joint statement condemning the invasion, and the Arab League denounced Baghdad, but the outlook for diplomatic efforts was guarded. [Pages 5 and 6.] 
President Bush stressed the importance of Saudi Arabia and said, ''If they ask for specific help - it depends obviously what it is - I would be inclined to help in any way we possibly can.'' He stopped well short of vowing to defend the wealthy and strategically vital oil-producing kingdom with American arms, but conceded that economic sanctions often do not work.
Saudi Arabia, with the world's largest oil reserves, provides 15 percent of United States oil imports. It has been the linchpin of American foreign policy in the region for decades.
 
Military Option Said to Gain
Top American officials indicated that military intervention of some kind was rising rapidly to the top of their list of options. The United States told allies at NATO headquarters in Brussels that it had contingency plans for a military response if Iraq pushed on.
The State Department said 14 American oilfield workers were missing in Kuwait and were presumably in the hands of the Iraqis. But Iraq's Ambassador in Washington, Mohammed al-Mashat, denied in an interview that an attack on Saudi Arabia was imminent and insisted that Iraq held no Americans.
As financial markets on four continents swayed from the force of the turbulence in the Middle East, the Iraqi Army faced pockets of resistance in Kuwait from determined defenders. Reports from Kuwait before all telephone lines were cut spoke of explosions and gunfire shaking the country's main military barracks, and of firefights elsewhere.
Ports, airfields and the three land crossings into Kuwait were closed, said a British diplomat quoted by the Press Association in London. Most telephone lines to the little desert nation at the head of the Persian Gulf were severed, and a loyalist radio station was knocked off the air.
Its last, despairing message was an appeal to other Arabs, ''Rush, rush to our help.''
Pentagon officials said that more than 60,000 Iraqi troops were massing in the southern part of Kuwait, not far from a major oilfield in Saudi Arabia.
A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said Iraqi troops were within 5 to 10 miles of the frontier. The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said the Iraqis were massing on the border.
The White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said, ''They are close enough to the Saudi border to indicate cause for concern, but we don't know what their intentions or motives are.''
Squabbling broke out in the Bush Administration over who bore the responsibility for the United States being caught flat-footed by the Iraqi offensive. White House officials blamed the Central Intelligence Agency for providing faulty intelligence, and the C.I.A. blamed policy-makers for failing to heed ample warnings.
 
Parallel Drawn to 1930's
Increasingly, military analysts, scholars and politicians compared the situation in the Middle East with that in Central Europe in the 1930's - with a dictatorial aggressor, determined to gobble up neighboring countries, moving boldly while the rest of the world wondered what to do about it.
Saudi Arabia seemed to be in the pivotal position. Any regional American defense effort would require Saudi agreement to provide the United States with bases on a level never before contemplated.
Any effort to drive oil prices down, thus denying President Hussein one of the fruits of capturing Kuwait, increased oil revenues, would require increased Saudi crude-oil production.
The Arab League decided after two days of debate in Cairo to denounce Baghdad's conduct, but 7 of the 21 members abstained - Iraq, Jordan, Mauritania, Yemen, Sudan, Djibouti and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Although the Arab representatives had said they were holding back in the hope of fostering peace talks, their comments suggested that they feared Iraq's wrath if they spoke out.
In Jordan, a country that acts as an American ally on many issues, state-controlled newspapers backed Iraq and said the United States should not intervene in what they called ''our Arab region.''
 
A Call for Sanctions
Other major nations, including some that depend on Iraqi oil, joined the United States in condemning the invasion, and at the United Nations the United States pressed for broad mandatory sanctions. Mr. Hurd, the British Foreign Secretary, said his country was willing to take part in a total trade embargo against Iraq, but he added, ''It only works if everybody does it.''
The United States-Soviet statement of condemnation, a highly unusual development, was issued after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d paid a quick visit to Moscow to meet with his Soviet counterpart, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. The Soviet Union, Iraq's main military supplier along with China and France, cut off arms shipments on Thursday.
But the superpowers appeared to have less leverage than they once did in the Middle East.
''Ironically, the end of the cold war means there is less chance for the two powers to discipline smaller countries because there isn't the risk of a nuclear confrontation,'' said Robert Hunter, a former White House official who is now a senior fellow in Middle East Studies at Georgetown University.
 
'Draw the Line in the Sand'
It remained unclear whether the United States planned to move boldly to counter the Iraqi takeover in Kuwait, or tacitly acquiesce in it while throwing down the gauntlet on Saudi Arabia, or do neither.
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, called on President Bush to ''draw a line in the sand'' in front of Iraqi forces.
''We need to tell Saddam Hussein that an invasion of Saudi Arabia means war,'' he said. ''That message needs to be delivered this week while it might influence his decision.''
Representative William S. Broomfield of Michigan, the ranking Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, used even blunter language. He said: ''Saddam stuck his finger in our eye. I say, let's break his arm.''
Another Democrat, Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, who sits on the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee dealing with the Middle East, argued that Mr. Bush and others were underestimating President Hussein and his determination to dominate.
''This mistake will be compounded if George Bush doesn't understand he's not dealing with some errant European leader,'' Mr. Torricelli said. ''Congress and the President's pronouncements will have no impact on Saddam's policy. Nothing but the deployment of force and clear willingness to use it will do.''
 
Bush's Guarded Tone
Clearly conscious of the difficulties that American intervention would bring, Mr. Bush spoke in much more guarded terms at a brief news conference on the White House lawn late this afternoon before leaving for Camp David.
With Kuwait under occupation, the President said, ''the status quo is unacceptable, and further expansion'' by the Iraqi forces ''would be even more unacceptable.'' Mr. Bush declined to confirm reports that he had asked Turkey and Saudi Arabia, in telephone conversations with their leaders, to cut the two pipelines that carry Iraqi oil across their territories to the sea.
Any American military operation would have to be a major one, experts said, because of Iraq's military strength. The United States Army, with 700,000 troops, is not as big as the Iraqi Army, with a million, and there would also be problems with landing large numbers of troops, with bases and with resupply.
''We can dominate the Gulf from a naval standpoint,'' said Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ''We can keep the Iraqis off the water, we can dominate them in the air. But the question of ground troops in that vast desert, that's another matter altogether.''
Nonetheless, a ranking White House official said, a move by Iraqi forces into Saudi Arabia or to harm Americans in Kuwait would all but inevitably trigger a military response.
 
Dispatch of Ships
The aircraft carrier Independence, carrying its normal contingent of jet fighters, attack planes and bombers, is steaming from its post in the Indian Ocean to a position at the mouth of the gulf, along with six escort ships. It is a trip of several thousand miles. The Navy already has eight ships in the gulf, but none carries planes that pose any serious threat to Iraq.
In addition, the carrier Saratoga, which is based in Florida, and the amphibious assault ship Inchon, now at Norfolk, Va., and their escort ships are to leave for the Mediterranean next week.
The ships, plus the carrier Eisenhower, which may well stay on station instead of returning home after the Saratoga arrives, would give the United States considerably more punch. Baghdad and Kuwait are within range of planes operating from the Mediterranean, although some of the aircraft would require in-flight refueling.
Mr. Bush met at length at the White House with his advisers today, and he is to meet them again on Saturday at his Catoctin Mountain retreat, Camp David. He also spoke with a number of world leaders about strategies. The networks struggled to cover the invasion from their home bases, using stock newsreel clips and experts. Critic's Notebook, page 46.

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE CLIMBS THE MOST IN NEARLY 4 YEARS

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
In a mostly grim report that took many analysts by surprise, the Labor Department said today that the nation's unemployment rate climbed three-tenths of a point in July, to 5.5 percent, in the biggest increase since early 1986.
The number of Americans who are working also decreased sustantially. The report intensified worries among private analysts that the economy was tipping into recession or might have already done so.
At the same time, the Labor Department's report, generally considered the best single indicator of economic performance and the first comprehensive one published each month, also pointed to heightened inflation. Average hourly earnings jumped six-tenths of 1 percent last month, and the department increased its initial estimate of how much hourly earnings rose in June. 
 
Some Analysts Very Worried
''I can't imagine a release that could have read much worse,'' commented Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, noting that it came amid the acute uncertainty caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Higher oil prices are considered certain to further slow an already limping economy and likely to aggravate inflationary pressures.
Nonetheless, there were signs that however close the economy has come to ending its long expansion, it is not tumbling into an abyss. There was no increase, for example, in the number of workers who lost jobs last month and the ranks of factory production workers actually increased slightly.
Still, the overall profile of the economy was grim. One of the most discouraging elements in the jobs report, analysts said, was that the longstanding decline of jobs in goods-producing industries was no longer offset by strength in services.
''The services industry has been the major engine of job growth during the current economic expansion'' dating from late 1982, Dr. Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. ''But that engine seems to have sputtered in July.''
The Bush Administration, however, expressed no alarm. ''We believe the economy continues to grow, albeit slowly,'' said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. ''We don't see a recession.''
But Mr. Fitzwater added that sluggish growth ''does reinforce our concern'' for reaching an agreement to reduce the Government's budget deficit.
 
Federal Reserve Faces Problem
The Labor Department's report also led private economists to worry about the problem now facing the Federal Reserve. Confronted with such persuasive evidence of dwindling economic activity, the Federal Reserve would normally be expected to ease its policy in the hope that lower interest rates would provide fresh impetus.
But this time sudden price increases for oil and fresh wage pressures could prevent the Federal Reserve from easing interest rates. This raised the prospect of a business downturn that it could not head off and at least a mild case of the 1970's disease known as stagflation - a weak economy accompanied by high inflation.
The stock market declined today by 54.95 points as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, to close at 2809.65 after being down more than 120 points. Bond prices continued to tumble, causing the interest rate on the 30-year Treasury bond to rise to 8.55 percent from 8.45 percent on Thursday. Market analysts said events in the Middle East were a major factor in the market's movement, but the unemployment report also weighed in it.
The Labor Department report showed ''extreme weakness'' in the economy, said Elliott Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. The department's survey of businesses, to which economists pay close attention, put nonfarm payroll jobs at 110,706,000, or 219,000 below the June level. Although 162,000 of this reflected the laying off of temporary workers hired to conduct the census, analysts had been expecting a modest advance after adjusting for census workers - not a decline.
 
Construction Is Weak
Construction was particularly weak, losing 50,000 jobs, while the previously vigorous growth of jobs in health care slowed to 25,000 after gaining 40,000 in June and 45,000 in May.
Some analysts, including Norman Robertson of the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, found a measure of consolation in the fact that manufacturing lost just 7,000 jobs and that production workers, who account for the largest component in the manufacturing category, actually posted a gain of that amount.
But Mr. Straszheim said he was disappointed that factory jobs continued to decline, since manufactured exports had been counted on heavily to keep the expansion going.
The department's other main survey, of households rather than company payrolls, showed an even bigger overall job loss, of 436,000. Combined with a decline of 69,000 people in the labor force, this caused the number of jobless to rise by 367,000, to 6,814,000, and raised the unemployment rate to 5.5 percent, the highest level since August 1988.
While analysts said the figures were generally discouraging, they pointed to elements showing the economy was not falling into an abyss. The bulk of the rise in unemployment, for example, occurred among teen-agers and others seeking their first jobs or among those re-entering the labor force after an absence.
 
Teen-Agers Hit Hard
Dr. Norwood told the committee that while a smaller proportion of teen-agers looked for work this summer, more of those who did so failed to find jobs and the unemployment rate for teen-agers climbed to 16.3 percent, about a percentage point higher than in 1988 and 1989.
She added that while it was not entirely clear why teen-agers had more trouble finding jobs this year, job growth in retail trade and other service businesses that hire many young people has slowed considerably.
All population groups had higher unemployment rates last month than in June but apart from teen-agers, the only groups for which the rate rose more than the over all jobless rate were black and Hispanic workers. The rate for blacks rose nine-tenths of a point to 11.3 percent, while rate for Hispanic workers rose eight-tenths of a point to 7.9 percent.
The unemployment rate for adult men, at 4.9 percent, now stands a half point higher than a year ago while the rate for women, at 4.7 percent, is in line with the rates prevailing since late 1988, the Labor Department noted.
Among the largest states, the rate for North Carolina jumped nine-tenths of a point to 4.6 percent, while Florida's jobless rate fell eight-tenths of a point, to 5.7 percent. New York's rate rose a statistically insignificant two-tenths of a point, to 5.3 percent, while New Jersey's stood at 4.8 percent for the third straight month.
Among regions, unemployment rates continued to converge with the Northeast and Midwest both at 5.3 percent, the South at 5.5 and the West at 5.6, according to figures that unlike the others are not adjusted for seasonal variation.
The payroll survey also showed that the index of aggregate weekly hours edged up to 130.8 and that the percentage of nonfarm industries adding workers climbed to 51.9 percent.
The six-tenths of 1 percent rise in average hourly pay, to $10.09, compared with a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in June that was revised up from an initial estimate of three-tenths of 1 percent.
