SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1027 words

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
PRICE OF OIL RISES; STOCKS IN RETREAT

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil prices rose again yesterday and the stock market fell sharply in unusually volatile trading as investors feared that higher energy prices brought on by the turmoil in the Middle East could push an already weak American economy into recession.
After plunging more than 120 points in the biggest selloff since last October's ominous drop, the Dow Jones industrial average recovered rapidly and ended the day down 54.95 points, at 2,809.65.
In the oil markets, West Texas Intermediate, the American benchmark crude, closed on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $24.49 a barrel, up $1.38 from the day before and $8.55 since mid-June.
 
Bond Prices Fall
In the credit markets, the price of the Treasury's 30-year bonds fell and interest rates rose on expectation of renewed inflation, while the dollar and gold rose slightly. 
Energy prices have already begun rising for consumers. Around the country, some service stations anticipated higher gasoline prices by raising the pump price; the Michigan chapter of the American Automobile Association, for example, surveyed 100 stations in the Detroit area and found that 30 had raised the price by at least a nickel after closing on Thursday. Northwest Airlines said it would begin charging an $8 fuel surcharge on all domestic tickets as of Aug. 9.
Though the outlook for oil prices and inflation is as uncertain as the developing events in the Middle East, some analysts said the current fears of an inflationary impact seemed exaggerated.
 
View Called Incorrect
Speaking of the Dow's dance, Charles T. Maxwell, the vice chairman of C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell and an energy analyst, said, ''A climactic series of events has convinced people, I think quite incorrectly, of a devastating effect of inflation'' brought on by higher oil prices.
Mr. Maxwell said the market would not support higher oil prices for long, even if Iraq seeks them, unless other factors, like natural disaster, or blockade and embargo, intervene.
Daniel Yergin, of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, predicted that when the dust settled, the Iraqis would want to sell oil. ''These are one-crop economies,'' he said of the Persian Gulf nations.
Other energy experts and economists, taking a longer view, said yesterday that even if President Saddam Hussein of Iraq achieved his goal of raising the price of OPEC oil to $25 a barrel, an increase of about 50 percent from the levels that prevailed before the Kuwait crisis, the effect on this country's pattern of energy use would be modest.
Still, the effects would ripple through the economy.
 
Effect on Prices
''This is probably going to push up the Consumer Price Index by a percent or more,'' said George F. Friesen, an energy expert at Deutsche Bank Group. Higher energy prices mean more reluctance in Washington to raise energy taxes, and therefore a harder job in balancing the budget, he said. ''Increasing the Federal excise tax on gasoline is probably a nonstarter for this year,'' he said.
All the talk of price increases is coming long before a shortage could develop; the Persian Gulf is about six weeks from North America by tanker. In addition, it is not clear if the Iraqi invasion will result in a substantial supply interruption, or a price increase will be any higher than the $21 a barrel that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced it would seek last month.
An increase to $25, which would imply a price of $27 for West Texas Intermediate, which sells for more because it need not be transported so far, would stimulate domestic drilling and probably slow the decline in American oil production, but not stop it, experts said. Production is declining 4 to 5 percent a year.
The higher price would induce oil companies to spend more on exploration and production, but mostly abroad, industry experts said. In this country, companies would quickly turn to more costly ''tertiary recovery'' methods to squeeze more oil out of old fields that cannot be effectively operated at low prices. And the increase would rekindle a stalled trend toward greater energy efficiency and probably encourage energy research, experts say.
 
Research May Be Resumed
''In the last 10 years, the main activity of people working in alternative energy in laboratories has been sending out their resumes,'' said Mr. Yergin, of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. OPEC oil at $25 a barrel would ''get them back to their research,'' he said.
The total change in the energy bill from $25-a-barrel OPEC oil is difficult to figure, because higher prices would induce some conservation and would also lead to lower economic growth, which would also cut consumption. An oil price increase would also pull up the price of natural gas, experts say.
But an increase of about $10 a barrel would come to about $60 billion a year; the nation's energy bill last year for all sources was about $450 billion. The gross national product, or value of all goods and services, was about $5 trillion.
 
Higher Gasoline Prices
The biggest impact of higher oil prices would be higher gasoline prices, since about two-thirds of oil is used in transportation. At Oak Ridge National Laboratory, in Oak Ridge, Tenn., David L. Greene, a transportation researcher, said, however, that an increase to $25 would not have a large effect on motorists.
''Real fuel prices are as low now as ever,'' he said, pointing out that when inflation is taken into account, gasoline at $1.15 is cheaper than it was before the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74. And the per-mile cost of driving a car has never been lower, he said, because new cars go twice as far on a gallon as cars of the 1960's and early 1970's did. On average, the fleet is 50 percent more efficient.
Before the invasion, West Texas Intermediate was trading from $16 to $21, Dr. Greene pointed out, and an increase to $27 from the top of that range would add only 15 or 20 cents a gallon to gasoline. That is a consumer expenditure of $15 billion to $20 billion a year, which would have a significant effect on the general economy, but would probably make only a modest difference in the market for cars.

PUB-DATE: August 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1236 words

HEADLINE: Fight Is Intensified on Fake Documents for Aliens

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Armando Huerta arrived here two months ago from Mexico and, like many of the illegal aliens who continue to come to Southern California, went almost immediately to a seedy part of Alvarado Street near downtown Los Angeles.
There, Mr. Huerta said, he quickly found a man who offered to sell him fake identity papers. Mr. Huerta told the man he could afford to pay $19 - he had $20 but he needed to save $1 for the bus - and the deal was quickly struck. In a few minutes the 23-year-old Mr. Huerta had a counterfeit ''green card'' and Social Security card, allowing him to get temporary jobs in restaurants and construction.
Now Mr. Huerta is looking for a permanent job in a factory, and is settling in as a member of the region's huge illegal work force. 
 
The Most Pressing Problem
The ease with which Mr. Huerta and other newly arrived illegal immigrants can buy fraudulent documents and use them to find jobs has become one of the most pressing problems Government officials face as they try to enforce the nation's 1986 immigration law.
As long as illegal immigrants believe they can find jobs and relative prosperity in the United States, experts say, the Immigration and Naturalization Service will continue to have difficulty stemming the flow of illegal aliens from Mexico and other economically distressed nations to the south.
''This is the premier fraud problem facing the immigration service,'' said Lynn Nelson-Paretta, the service's senior special agent for investigations in Washington.
The 1986 law, the Immigration Reform and Control Act, gave many illegal aliens already in the United States a chance to become legal residents. But it was also meant to choke off further illegal immigration by making it more difficult for illegal aliens to find jobs.
 
Proof From Job Applicants
The law requires employers to demand proof from job applicants of their right to work in the United States, through documents like passports, driver's licenses, Social Security cards and immigration papers. Employers found not to have required such proof face fines or prison sentences.
Immigration officials say a vast majority of employers are meeting the law's requirements by demanding documentation from prospective employees. In fact, some employers are so fearful of the law's penalties, or so biased, that they refuse to hire any aliens.
A study made public earlier this year by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, found a ''widespread pattern of discrimination'' against people with a ''foreign appearance or accent.''
But other employers who are willing to check into an applicant's documentation have no legal incentive for doing so. The law does not require employers to verify the authenticity of documents, nor does it provide an easy way for them to do so.
 
It's 'a Mushrooming Industry'
With fraudulent documents so readily available, officials say, employers in regions and industries that have long relied on a low-wage illegal work force are still hiring large numbers of illegal aliens, sometimes knowingly and sometimes unknowingly.
''This loophole in the law has created a mushrooming industry of falsified documents,'' said Jorge Bustamante, president of the College of the Northern Border, in Tijuana, who has done extensive research on illegal immigration.
Counterfeiting is a problem in every city that attracts large numbers of illegal aliens, officials said, but such activity is very brisk in Los Angeles.
 
A Survey of Illegal Aliens
To gauge how widespread is the use of fraudulent documents, the immigration service surveyed 900 aliens who were arrested at work places last year. Of those 900, 233 admitted having counterfeit Social Security cards and 142 admitted having a fake ''green card,'' the common name for a permanent residency document. Officials said the survey probably understated the number of aliens with fake documents.
Prices for such documents vary widely. Most new arrivals can buy a green card and a Social Security card for $20 or more in central Los Angeles, with prices generally higher in other regions, investigators said.
More elaborate documents, like the card used to identify an alien as someone who has completed the first step in the process of becoming a citizen under the 1986 law, can cost at least $500. Fraudulent birth certificates and driver's licenses are also widely available on the street.
''Some employers even refer the undocumented immigrants to where they can get falsfied documents,'' Mr. Bustamante said. ''They are interested in reducing the cost of labor, and they can comply with the law by just seeing a document, any document.''
 
A Glance From the Bosses
After arriving here a year ago from Mexico, Guillermo Jacobo Abunader looked for day work with gardeners, construction companies and other employers who hire men from street corners without asking for documentation. But that type of work, which pays less than a steady job, is not always available. So Mr. Abunader bought a fake Social Security card and green card.
''It's much easier to find work with papers,'' he said. ''The bosses just want you to show them something. They just glance at them and are satisfied.''
The immigration service is developing a pilot program to allow employers to phone in and verify the documents being provided by job applicants. The agency is also considering recalling all old versions of the green card, including the mid-1970's version that counterfeiters have found particularly easy to copy.
For now, immigration officials say they are aggressively pursuing cases involving fraudulent documents. William M. Griffen, the supervisory special agent in charge of the immigration service's anti-fraud efforts in Los Angeles, said the office had obtained 129 felony convictions on document-fraud charges in the fiscal year ended last Sept. 30.
The pace of convictions this year is running slightly ahead of last year's, Mr. Griffen said, with 101 cases successfully prosecuted throught the first nine months of the fiscal year.
 
Search for the Counterfeiter
The agency's ultimate goal is to arrest the counterfeiters who are producing the false documents. But in most cases investigators must work their way back up a chain from the document sellers on the street through a variety of distributors before they can identify the counterfeiter.
In a recent case, immigration investigators bought counterfeit documents from a husband and wife team selling documents from a street corner in the Los Angeles suburb of Inglewood. Investigators followed the husband to the apartment of another couple in south-central Los Angeles, where the falsified documents were prepared by placing the buyer's name and picture on the counterfeit documents.
Investigators raided the apartment and found 4,000 blank counterfeit documents, $12,000 in cash and a stolen gun, said John Torres, a special agent for the immigration service in Los Angeles. From there investigators were able to trace the suppliers of one particular counterfeit identity card and arrest them as well.
Although the case resulted in three guilty pleas and one conviction on felony charges involving the possession of selling of falsified documents, investigators have not yet been able to find their ultimate target, the counterfeiter who made most of the documents being sold by those who were arrested.

HEADLINE: Subic Bay Journal;
Where American Might Is a Bit High and Mighty

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SUBIC BAY NAVAL STATION, the Philippines

 BODY:
Contemplating the grand sweep of Subic Bay, recognized for hundreds of years as one of the best-protected natural harbors in Southeast Asia, it is easy to see why the United States Navy wants to keep its access to the huge naval base here.
Despite recent strains in American-Philippine relations, Filipinos and American officials agree that the two nations are likely to reach a new bases agreement to replace the one that expires in September 1991.
But officials warn that Filipino sensitivity over sovereignty and the perceived weakness of President Corazon C. Aquino could combine with American arrogance and self-righteousness to make a new agreement impossible.
The negotiations themselves, after angry exploratory talks in May, are scheduled to resume in late August. The timing alone worries the American side, since funds for a new agreement should be factored into the fiscal year 1992 budget, which is put together by October 1990. 
 
What's at Stake
At stake is the future of two major bases and four minor installations that are the foundation of the United States' military presence in the region. Subic Bay Naval Station and nearby Clark Air Base are among the largest United States military bases overseas. With superb storage and ship-repair capabilities, an experienced Filipino work force and a large naval air station across the bay at Cubi Point, Subic Naval Station can support combat operations of several carrier battle groups and provide logistics for operations in the Western Pacific and in the Indian Ocean.
Subic also has an 833-foot drydock that can handle all United States Navy ships except battleships, and the only complete repair and reconditioning plant for military jet engines in this part of the world.
United States Navy officers talk about how they could live without this base, but they would prefer to keep it. The cost of replicating the installations elsewhere in the region is estimated from $3 billion to $8 billion.
To American servicemen, talking over cheeseburgers and club sandwiches, military and personal relations have already changed. Because of threats to Americans, airmen do not wear uniforms to and from Clark. Nor do Americans wear uniforms in Manila or traveling there.
''I heard five years ago you could wear your uniform in the streets of Manila and people would pat you on the back and buy you a beer,'' a naval officer said. ''Well, it's not true anymore.''
For Filipinos who want the bases and Americans out, the coup attempt last December, thwarted largely as a result of United States intervention, and the considerable aid the American military gave recent earthquake victims have been reminders of the dangers of precipitate American withdrawal. The bases employ nearly 80,000 Filipinos, provide $1 billion a year to the economy and represent nearly 5 percent of the gross national product.
While Filipinos who oppose the bases were grateful for the rapid, efficient American response to the earthquake, it also reminded them of their own dependency, which is not merely economic.
 
The Transition Period
''Nearly everyone agrees now there should be another bases agreement, and that it's better to get American help in making the bases economically viable once the Americans are gone,'' a Filipino official said. The Americans have said they want a transition of at least 10 years, he said, while many Filipinos have said a 5-year transition is plenty.
The Americans are likely to agree to grant use of all installations to the Philippine military; to ''privatize'' or ''commercialize'' some facilities, like ship repair, for which annual, contractual fees can be paid; to accelerate the handover of surplus weapons and equipment to a needy Philippine military from a shrinking American one; to provide expanded access to United States markets, and to offer more relief on Manila's foreign debt obligations of some $28 billion.
Manila is the second-largest recipient of American sugar quotas, officials point out, and a textile treaty, worth more than $1 billion in sales to the United States, expires at the end of 1991.
''We need an agreement for pragmatic nationalists that is responsive to Filipino sovereignty and that's also a good deal they shouldn't pass up,'' an official said. ''Because emotionally, they don't want to sign one.''
''I think it's doable,'' he said. ''But a lot could still go wrong.'' #3 Americans Slain The May discussions were a good example of the difficulties, all displayed in the glare of a Filipino press that often suspects that the bases issue is the motivation behind every American act. On the eve of the talks, three United States servicemen were killed, one at Subic and two at Clark. The Communist group called the New People's Army took responsibility for the killings at Clark, and Government officials said robbery was the motive in the slaying at Subic.
Once the talks began, Foreign Minister Raul S. Manglapus, who has said Filipinos must ''slay the American father image'' to become a sovereign nation, rebuked Washington for falling $96 million short on aid pledges tied to the bases.
The Americans said Washington's contributions were not a contract or rent for the bases, but a matter of the President's ''best efforts'' to provide aid. Anyway, they said, the pledge was a two-year one, so no shortfall could yet be claimed.
 
'Cash-Register Diplomacy'
The chief United States negotiator, Richard L. Armitage, Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security affairs, then said America valued its alliance with Manila, the bases provided mutual benefits and he did not want to engage in ''cash-register diplomacy.''
He has not been forgiven since for that comment, which was considered a grave insult, and two Filipino senators opposed to the bases have suggested banning him from the country. The suggestion is a reminder that under the Philippine Constitution, a new deal on the bases must be ratified by two-thirds of the Senate, where many of the 23 senators oppose it.
Filipino officials say they think another base agreement is possible in the ''context of a new relationship.'' In essence, one said, ''we want America to treat us like equals and eat some humble pie.''

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
Washington Calls on U.N. To Impose Boycott on Iraq

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The United States asked other members of the Security Council today to endorse its proposal for a worldwide economic boycott of Iraq and occupied Kuwait until Baghdad agrees to withdraw its military forces from Kuwait.
The Americans presented a draft Security Council resolution calling on the United Nations to ban all imports from Iraq and Kuwait, and all exports to the countries, except for medicine and supplies of a humanitarian nature.
The American plan, diplomats say, would urge countries not to trade with Iraq and Kuwait, a provision that implies that Turkey should cut the pipeline across its territory through which Iraq exports much of its oil.
The resolution would also ban financial dealings with Iraq or Kuwait but does not specifically tell governments to freeze the countries' overseas assets, although the United States and some other nations have done so. 
Under the United Nations Charter, any such sanctions package approved by the Security Council would be legally binding on all member nations.
 
'Strong Interest'
Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering, the United States representative at the United Nations, said today that he had begun consultations on the draft plan with other Security Council members and other countries. ''There is strong interest within the Council for moving toward sanctions if Iraq fails to withdraw,'' he said.
Meanwhile, the White House expressed skepticism today about a report on Baghdad radio saying that Iraq would begin to withdraw its forces on Sunday provided that its security is not threatened and that the Emir of Kuwait not try to return to his throne.
American officials said it was unclear how long the withdrawal would take and described the attempt to ban the Emir's return as unacceptable because the Security Council had said Iraq must unconditionally pull out.
The American move comes after the Security Council voted 14 to 0 on Thursday to condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, also on Thursday, demanding the immediate withdrawal of its forces and threatening to impose economic sanctions if Baghdad did not comply. The fifteenth Council member, Yemen, the only Arab member, did not participate.
The representatives of Britain, France and the Soviet Union, three of the five permanent Security Council members with veto power over its decisions, gave cautious support to the American proposals.
 
MORE EUROPEANS ACT
PARIS, Aug. 3 (Special to the New York Times) West Germany, Italy, Belgium, Norway, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Canada moved today to protect Kuwaiti assets from seizure by Iraq.
In ordering an effective freeze of Kuwaiti holdings, the six European Governments and the Canadians followed the example of the United States, Britain and France, which took similar measures on Thursday.
So far, only the United States and France have frozen Iraqi assets. In contrast, the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation and the Kuwait Investment Office are believed to have more than $100 billion invested in Europe, the United States and Japan.
 
Dutch Suspend Credits
The Dutch Government said it had suspended export credits to Iraq and Kuwait. Newspaper editorials criticized Western European Governments for not acting to forestall the invasion.
The Guardian in Britain said the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, was not a man to be swayed by soft words. The conservative Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung in West Germany said it was easy to proclaim that Mr. Hussein should be taught a lesson. ''But how?'' it asked. ''The industrialized nations need Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil and will buy it at any price.''
In announcing Ottawa's action, the External Affairs Minister, Joe Clark, said Canada would back any program of sanctions proposed by the United Nations Security Council.
Iraq and Kuwait jointly supply 1.4 million of the European Community's 9.1 million barrels per day of oil imports, and 600,000 of the United States's 7.2 million barrels a day of oil imports.
 
TOKYO, Aug. 3 (Special to the New York Times) The Japanese Government said tonight that it was freezing $20 billion to $30 billion in Kuwaiti assets. Iraq provides Japan with 5.6 percent of its imported crude, with Kuwait providing 4.6 percent.

HEADLINE: Deeper Economic Uncertainties Confront U.S. Policy Makers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
For the economic policy makers in the Bush Administration, Congress and the Federal Reserve, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait creates a new storm in an already unsettled atmosphere.
The economic uncertainty was reflected in the financial markets today. The Dow Jones industrial average closed almost 55 points lower, after having plunged by more than 120 points earlier in the day, and trading in the currency markets was volatile.
The budget negotiators from the White House and Capitol Hill can no longer be confident that the economy can withstand a $50 billion reduction in the Federal deficit, and they may question the wisdom of deep cuts in the military budget and increases in energy taxes. 
 
New Threat of Inflation
The Federal Reserve must now be concerned about a new threat of inflation, although unexpectedly unfavorable domestic economic reports might have led it toward lowering interest rates.
The Government reported last week that the economy for the last year has been running much closer to a recession than most economists had thought, and today it reported the steepest monthly rise in unemployment in more than four years.
Paradoxically, the Government's bailout of the savings and loan industry may become somewhat less costly if higher oil prices push up the value of Texas real estate. But the economic disparities between regions of the country, already a matter of political tension, could be worsened.
''The timing is particularly inopportune,'' said Robert D. Hormats, a former top economist at the State Department and the National Security Council, who is now vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International in New York.
 
'A New Uncertainty'
The situation in the Persian Gulf, he continued, ''has created a new uncertainty in an already uncertain environment, and we just don't know how to weigh all the implications,'' he continued, adding ''Until we know, it's hard to make intelligent policy decisions.''
Economists agree that if the invasion leads to a sustained increase in oil prices, the result would be higher inflation and less growth in the American economy. How much higher the inflation and how much lower the growth rate would depend on the size of the price increase, and that may not be known for weeks.
As a rule of thumb, an increase of $5 to $6 a barrel in the price of crude oil, not an unreasonable estimate, would result in a rise in the price of a gallon of gasoline of 12 to 15 cents at the pump. #1/ Translates Into $1 Billion Each 1-cent increase for gasoline means that consumers will spend about $1 billion less on other goods and services.
About half of that money would be recycled into the American economy in terms of higher profits for the domestic petroleum industry, but the rest would be lost abroad.
Among the results, most economists agree, would be an increase of at least 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index, the most common measure of inflation, and a slowing of the growth rate by half a percentage point or more.
Those shifts would create special problems for the budget negotiators, who are deadlocked after nearly three months of talks. So far, they have agreed only that the Federal deficit should be cut in the next fiscal year by $50 billion to $60 billion.
 
Concerns About Recession
Now, some of the negotiators and their economic advisers are concerned that such a cut might lead the already weak economy into recession, particularly if the Federal Reserve could not ease monetary policy to offset the tighter fiscal policy.
Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the top Republican on the Budget Committee, said today that many people felt this was ''not a very good time for Congress to be taking bold steps on either taxes or spending.''
The invasion also ''might make members of Congress think twice about how far and how fast the defense budget should be cut,'' said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief staff adviser on economic policy.
 
Gasoline Tax Effort May End
Finally, the likelihood of higher oil prices may have ended whatever chance there was for raising taxes on gasoline, imported oil or energy consumption.
In the main, economists agree with Mr. Hormats that the situation is ''serious but not catastrophic.''
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, said in an interview that the American economy was much more able today than it was in the 1970's and 1980's to absorb a rise in energy prices.
Charles L. Schultze, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, agreed with that analysis. ''If I lost a night's sleep over the first oil shock,'' he said, ''I'd lose a couple of hours over this one.''

HEADLINE: Lawmaker Says His Racial Insult of Health Secretary Was Mistake

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The chairman of a health subcommittee told the House today that he should not have called the Secretary of Health and Human Services ''a disgrace to his race'' when he criticized the Secretary's positions on Thursday.
''To the Secretary, I have to say I blew it,'' said the lawmaker, Pete Stark, the California Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health.
But Mr. Stark, who is white, repeated his criticism of the Secretary, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, who is black, for supporting Bush Administration policies that Mr. Stark called bankrupt and damaging to minority members. The lawmaker said his reference to race had obscured his central complaint about Dr. Sullivan's positions on abortion, health care and civil rights. 
Republican lawmakers strongly criticized Mr. Stark for his remark, and the White House castigated him for what it called his ''bigoted assault.'' Dr. Sullivan himself demanded an apology, responding to the remark by saying, ''I don't live on Pete Stark's plantation.''
Bob Schmermund, a spokesman for Dr. Sullivan said later today that Mr. Stark's latest comments were not the apology Dr. Sullivan wanted.
''He was right about one thing: he blew it, '' Mr. Schmermund said. ''Other than that, we certainly don't view what he said on the House floor as anything close to an apology.''
Questioned this morning at his daily news conference, the leader of the House Democrats, Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington, disagreed with Mr. Stark's attack, saying, ''I have a high respect for Dr. Sullivan.''
Later, just before Mr. Stark spoke, the House Republican leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, led a series of Republican critics who demanded an apology, charging that Mr. Stark had brought ''discredit on this institution.''He called Mr. Stark's attack ''as bizarre as it is deplorable.''
''No matter how heated our debate may be,'' Mr. Michel said on the House floor, ''no one has a right to bring into question a man's race or religion or national origin.''
Mr. Stark stood moments later and said Mr. Michel was ''absolutely right.''
 
Criticism Is Repeated
''To bring race or religion into a policy debate is wrong,'' he said.
But he then repeated his complaint that Dr. Sullivan was going along with Administration policies that Mr. Stark said hurt the poor and minority members. He said the policies were denying them good medical care, job training and extended unemployment benefits, as well as denying poor women abortions.
One black lawmaker, Representative Craig Washington, Democrat of Texas, rose in Mr. Stark's defense. He said he hoped Republicans criticizing Mr. Stark would vote for the Civil Rights Act of 1990, which was passed later in the day.
Mr. Stark first made his remarks in response to questions at a news conference he had called to discuss his sponsorship of an anti-smoking bill. He was unapologetic as he repeated them later at a second news conference, held after Dr. Sullivan demanded an apology.
Mr. Stark's attack apparently stemmed from a speech Dr. Sullivan delivered last month opposing proposals for federally sponsored national health insurance. Mr. Stark is sponsoring a proposal that would levy an added income tax to pay for such coverage.
Mr. Stark said that at the urging of Administration officials before taking his Cabinet position Dr. Sullivan had reversed his position on abortion, now opposing it, and that he had similarly been persuaded to oppose Federal health coverage for the uninsured. The lawmaker named the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, as those influencing Dr. Sullivan.
''He's a disgrace to his race, because he really does not have the courage to turn his back on Sununu'' and the Administration, Mr. Stark said.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said on Thursday that Mr. Stark's ''bigoted assault on the integrity and ability of Secretary Sullivan is an affront to the Congress and the Democratic Party.''

HEADLINE: CLOSE G.O.P. RACE FOR TENNESSEANS

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Of more than 100,000 votes cast on Thursday, only 158 separated the top two candidates today in a Republican primary race for the right to challenge Senator Al Gore in November's general election.
With 96 percent of Tennessee's 2,415 precincts counted, William Hawkins led Ralph Brown. Mr. Hawkins, an economist, had 50,979 votes; Mr. Brown, a businessman, had 50,821 votes. It will be Monday at the earliest before Tennesseans learn who won the Republican contest. 
Mr. Gore ran unopposed in the Democratic primary and is expected to handle easily whichever Republican he faces in the fall.
Mr. Brown, who was forced to declare bankruptcy a year ago, did not wait up for the results of his campaign, on which he spent less than $100. He turned in about midnight, said his wife of 50 years, Marie.
''He was very excited,'' she told a late-night caller. ''But it got late. You don't know who won, do you?''

Mr. Ford's Republican opponent in November will be Aaron C. Davis, a political newcomer.

All nine members of Congress from Tennessee are running for re-election, but only Mr. Ford and Representative Marilyn Lloyd faced primary opponents. Ms. Lloyd defeated David Ray Stacy, a pipe fitter.

HEADLINE: America's English Disease

 BODY:
America has just passed a milestone. Unfortunately it's on the way downhill. Last year, for the first time, the United States invested less in plant and equipment than Japan did, even though Japan's economy is half the size. The disparity suggests how grossly America is neglecting its future. 
Japan spent $549 billion on capital investment, compared with $513 billion by the U.S, according to the Council on Competitiveness in Washington. Though a single year's figures may be of limited significance, they are part of a long-term pattern. Since 1972 Japan has spent an average of 17 percent of its gross domestic product on capital investment, America only 12 percent.
Capital investment is probably the most important factor in determining a nation's future productivity and standard of living. American manufacturing productivity is greater than that of other major industrial countries. But this lead is bound to be lost if others continue to invest more.
A one percentage point lag in productivity per year for one century ''was sufficient to transform the United Kingdom from the world's undisputed industrial leader into the third-rate economy that it is today,'' William Baumol notes in a recent study of productivity. A long period of sustained underinvestment means lower standards of living at home and diminished power to exert influence abroad.
If Japan so chooses, its enormous surpluses could be invested to serve diplomatic as well as economic goals. America has the same option. But to aid the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe on the scale, say, of the Marshall Plan, the U.S. would have to generate sufficient savings, which it seems unwilling to do even though the economy is far larger than it was after World War II.
Americans, like their Government, prefer consumption to saving. Japanese may enjoy consumption just as much, but they get less say in the matter. Tokyo's civil servants maintain a powerful set of incentives to save, from high housing prices to a lack of consumer credit. Tapping this bountiful pool of savings, Japanese companies enjoy a lower cost of capital than their Western competitors. An economy run primarily for the benefit of producers has brought substantial consumer gains, too.
Washington lacks Tokyo's powers to decide what's good for people. But that's no excuse for its long neglect of low saving and investment rates. In Tokyo's diagnosis, America is suffering from a bad case of ''eikoku byo'' - English disease. The current budget negotiations may be the place to try to shift the American economy toward healthier and less profligate habits.

HEADLINE: Workers' Compensation: More to Do

 BODY:
Before 1914, workers in New York State who were disabled on the job faced a stark choice: Sue or starve. Then the Legislature devised a no-fault insurance plan that covered medical costs and two-thirds of lost pay. Albany closed its 1990 session by voting a deserved increase in worker benefits. It now needs to restore the compensation system to financial soundness. 
Under the 1914 law, workers gave up their right to sue employers. In return, workers were assured prompt payment of statutory benefits. Owners, for their part, paid the cost of premiums and lost the right to blame accidents on worker negligence. The state set up its own insurance fund in case private insurers refused to cooperate.
The plan promised fair benefits at minimal cost. Competition among the state insurance fund and private carriers kept premiums low. Accumulated reserves and surpluses earned interest that helped insurers offset increased claims.
In recent years, however, the system eroded. With medical costs rising, ''partial'' disability became a common practice, reducing employee benefits by half, to $150 weekly - often no better than welfare. Then, in the Dole v. Dow case in 1972, the New York Court of Appeals ruled that while employers could not be sued directly by their employees, they could be forced to pay damages in suits against third parties, like manufacturers of machinery involved in an accident. That forces insurers to set aside a large and growing part of their premium income to pay judgments to a small number of claimants, who would collect in any case from the third parties they sue.
Furthermore, urged on by Gov. Mario Cuomo, the Legislature has allowed the state to divert $1 billion in cash from the state insurance fund. The state pays no interest on the ''borrowing,'' forcing employers to pay approximately $90 million more in premiums annually to compensate for the lost interest and dividends. Should the state fund run short of cash to cover claims, it will be required to pay them from tax revenues.
The Legislature deserves praise for reviving the concept of total compensation and for raising benefits to $400 a week. But it has shamefully neglected to stop the drain on insurance resources caused by the Dole-Dow opinion and the state's interest-free borrowing. The Insurance Department has already authorized an increase of 29.4 percent in employer premiums, which now exceed $3 billion annually. Further increases will surely follow, discouraging expansion of employment.
To repair some of the damage - and allay fear that claims will have to be paid from tax receipts -the Legislature would be wise to repeal the Dole v. Dow decision and start paying interest on the money it took from the state fund.

HEADLINE: Farm Policy's Problem Is Subsidies for Few

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Get Fat Farmers Off Welfare'' (editorial, June 19), you characterize the inequity and inefficiency of farm subsidies. ''A Summit Challenge: Farm Subsidies'' (editorial, July 10) puts the issue in its proper trade context, emphasizing the intransigence of the European Community in the Uruguay Round and the need for comparable policy reforms in the United States.
Randolph Nodland of the National Family Farm Coalition writes (letter, July 10) that higher, not lower price supports, plus supply control, would solve our agricultural problems. A. L. McLeod's letter (same date) admonishes the United States for pursuing a Gorbachev-style policy of ''controlled markets'' in agriculture and advocates free markets for American farmers similar to those we are advocating in Eastern Europe. These letters, representing two poles of the debate over agricultural policy, provide much food for thought. 
As self-described liberals, we do not swallow arguments ''whole-hog from the libertarian Cato Institute's materials,'' as Mr. Nodland accuses you of doing. One of us, Willard Cochrane, while serving as economic adviser to Secretary of Agriculture Orville Freeman in the Kennedy Administration, designed and tried to carry out a supply control policy such as the National Family Farm Coalition advocates. In the end, farmers voted down the supply control approach in a 1963 referendum.
We now believe that high price supports and supply control are an untenable policy for United States agriculture, because of the global trading environment on which American farmers increasingly depend. To jack up domestic prices by artificially shorting the market, the United States would need to impose border controls to prevent cheap grain imports and would forsake its major market position as a net exporter. This would fly in the face of our obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to open world markets.
Mr. Nodland also contends that United States agricultural benefits flow primarily to the small- to-medium-size ''family farmer,'' and that their regressivity is ''the product of statistical manipulation.'' In a recent study, J. D. Shaffer of Michigan State University and G. W. Whittaker of the Economic Research Service of the Department of Agriculture found that in 1987, 60,000 farmers, representing only the top 3.6 percent of all American producers, received 42 percent of total direct payments, averaging $75,500. The average net worth of these farms was $745,000. The top 18 percent received 90 percent of direct payments. And this represents only direct payments. The study concluded that ''the direct payments significantly underestimate the total income transfers from the Treasury and consumers to farm operators and those who own farm land.'' We also reject the claim that these subsidies do not help cover costs of production for most farmers. The real problem is that the subsidies raise the costs of production because they are capitalized into land values, restricting entry into farming by younger operators. If costs of production are not covered by current prices, plus Government subsidies, it would be impossible, as Mr. Nodland states, for farmers to respond to low prices by expanding output without going out of business.
However, we also view calls for ''free market agriculture'' as naive. Government will continue to intervene in agriculture. The question is, What kind of intervention do we need? Not supply control and higher price and income supports, or free market agriculture.
The task of political leaders, both farm and nonfarm, in the 1990's must be to fashion a policy compromise in which commercial farmers are protected against sharp and unpredictable income declines, consumers are guaranteed a safe and bountiful supply of food, poverty in rural America is dealt with effectively and the environment is protected. And these objectives must be achieved without imposing trade-distorting measures at our borders. This cannot be accomplished by continuing farm policies in which the largest share of farm income subsidies goes to a relative few big successful farmers. This policy can only lead to still fewer, bigger and richer farmers, and rising land values.
 
WILLARD W. COCHRANE
 
C. FORD RUNGE
 St. Paul, July 18, 1990
 
The writers are, respectively, a professor emeritus at the University of Minnesota, and associate professor and director of the university's Center for International Food and Agricultural Policy.

LENGTH: 793 words

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Fruit of Appeasement

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein of Iraq has answered with a roar the long, dithering argument over whether it was wiser to indulge him or try to isolate and block him. That is why his blitzkrieg invasion of Kuwait, proving his insatiable ambition, has led so many European commentators to remember Hitler. The same kind of argument went on through the 1930's, until it was too late.
It is frustrating that there seems to be no quick military response available to stop him in his tracks and expel him from Kuwait. But that is the case. The geography is too difficult and he is too well armed. 
And it is disheartening that this first crisis of the new Soviet-American search for cooperation shows the superpowers can't contain their sorcerer's apprentices. They can make peace between themselves, but not around the world. A Soviet commentator now says, ''We created this monster with our arms supplies.''
Indeed, Iraq's army not only dwarfs all the other forces in the region, it is bigger than those of Britain and France combined. It has, thanks mostly to eager Western suppliers, the Arab world's one credible modern weapons industry.
The 53-year-old dictator has been called paranoid, a mad bull who shouldn't be provoked. The State Department believed in soothing. But he is coldly calculating and prepares his moves with care. He gave plenty of warning, with his repeated bellicose, self-righteous tirades and troop movements observed by satellite -and, no doubt, Saudi Awacs reconnaissance planes. No one responded.
Everyone was taken by surprise at the massive, irresistible takeover of Kuwait. That was because of the self-induced conviction that he was bluffing, that he only sought to extract limited, if still unreasonable, demands by intimidating fellow Arabs.
Intimidate he did, clearly demonstrated by the reticence of most Arab regimes to join the world chorus of outrage. Even now, some of them talk of negotiating with concessions. So far, at least, Saudi Arabia shows no sign of daring to cut the pipeline across its territory that carries much of Iraq's oil exports to the Red Sea.
There was collusion with Iran, Iraq's former enemy, before the latest meeting of OPEC to force the Kuwaitis to stop overproduction, which was depressing oil prices. And Iran has shown no interest in worrying Iraq by moving troops to the border since the invasion. Private reports from Teheran say, in fact, that people were dancing in the streets there because oil prices are rising and Kuwait, which gave generous help to Iraq in the war, has been humiliated by its former ally. Despite all the talk about Persian Gulf solidarity and Arab loyalty, relations in the area are always undermined by jealousies and shifting maneuvers. Mr. Hussein understands this well. He plays the game, but trusts only force and fear of his ruthlessness.
So he tested the waters, and had reason to think he had a good bet on getting away with what has aptly been called the greatest bank heist in history - Kuwait's hundreds of billions of dollars of foreign assets and its 200 years of oil reserves.
There should be no misunderstanding of his aim. He has explained it. He desperately needs money to pay his huge debts, to acquire more arms and reconstruct his country. But beyond that he is determined to become the great leader of the Arab nation, and not just another nation but a world power based on guns and oil. His relentless drive for a nuclear weapon is not only to threaten his neighbors and Israel; it is to change the whole balance of power.
The challenge can be ignored at direct peril. It must be acknowledged and faced. The first step is to deprive Mr. Hussein of the fruits of aggression. That means a great coalition of nations, perhaps possible given their first reactions, to cut off all further arms supplies and boycott all Iraqi exports.
The result will be an even sharper rise in oil prices and consequent economic disruption, but it will be cheaper than letting him succeed. It will take time to have effect, and the West must show its commitment by renewing strong oil conservation measures, which it should never have allowed to lapse for many reasons, including the environment.
This is also a way to show other producers the risks of another huge oil crisis and induce them to compensate for Iraqi oil so as to moderate the boycott's effects. Other Arab leaders scarcely have to be told that they are next on Iraq's list, but they have to be convinced that complacency is more dangerous than opposition.
Beyond that, arms control has to get serious. Not only East and West but much of the world militarized to absurd heights during the cold war. The arms race must be stopped in the third world too. The lesson Mr. Hussein has given is global.

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: Audubon Site Is Dropped For Building

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Using her powers under an obscure state law, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan yesterday placed such tight restrictions on money to be used to build a biomedical laboratory on the site of the old Audubon Ballroom that New York City officials said the project was effectively doomed.
In bitter negotiations over a project to be built jointly by Columbia University and the city and state, Ms. Messinger insisted on preserving more of the old building, in which Malcolm X was assassinated, than the sponsors wished, and on placing the new structure in a spot that city officials contend would require starting the approval process over.
 
Visceral Issue
Ms. Messinger sought to challenge the plan using a little-known veto power over $8.1 million in funds of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that had been earmarked for the $34 million project on Broadway at West 165th Street. In doing so, she dealt a major political blow to her longtime ally, Mayor David N. Dinkins, who had backed the idea despite strong criticism from many blacks and who often mentioned it as an example of a way to attract new businesses to the city. 
''It's about as close to dead as can be,'' said Mr. Dinkins's Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero. ''I guess maybe there's a faint heartbeat somewhere, but I'm not hearing it very well.''
Ms. Messinger said the project was too speculative and would commit too much public money to generate what the city said would be 300 full-time jobs initially. But the visceral issue in the debate over the project was preserving the ballroom, and her decision capped a twisting tale that began eight years ago when Columbia proposed to develop the site.
As it moved toward a final vote at the Board of Estimate later this month, the plan had recently come to divide the city from preservation groups and civil rights advocates, who wanted to save the distinctive terra cotta facade and the room where the black Muslim leader was shot in 1965.
As a compromise, the Dinkins administration agreed to preserve about 40 percent of the ballroom, and to build the lab around it. But Ms. Messinger and preservationists favored a plan by the Municipal Art Society to keep the whole ballroom and build the new building on a different corner of the block.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero and other officials said yesterday that the change would require resubmitting the project to the city's land-use approval process, which Columbia said it was unwilling to do. Hanging over the debate was the Board of Estimate's impending demise under the new city charter and Columbia's desire to gain approval before the system changes.
 
No Sign of Relenting
While the project technically remains on the Board of Estimate agenda, city officials said they saw no hope that Ms. Messinger's conditions could be met if she stuck by them. Ms. Messinger, smarting from some recent jockeying with the Dinkins administration for respect and influence over planning issues, gave no sign that she would relent.
Columbia issued a statement last night, saying it was ''disappointed that the questions and concerns raised in the public discussion of this significant project could not be resolved to permit the Borough President to approve the project at this time.''
Ms. Messinger's action came under a law that enables borough presidents to reject projects to be included in Port Authority master plans.
Under the city's latest plan, its Public Development Corporation was to contribute $10 million, the Port Authority $8.1 million through the State Urban Development Corporation and Columbia about $4.7 million through a combination of direct spending and borrowing. The parties were arguing over how to pay to preserve 40 percent of the ballroom, at a cost that the city initially estimated at $3 million to $5 million, but finally at almost $9 million.
Preservationists contended that the entire ballroom could have been preserved for about $4 million extra, while city officials argued it could cost more than three times that amount, with neither side agreeing on exactly what would need to be done.
Richard D. Emery, a lawyer for the Sugar Hill Historial Society, which wanted to preserve the whole room, called Ms. Messinger's decision ''a courageous and wise act.''

HEADLINE: Hotel Is Macklowe's Bid for a Shinier Image

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Harry Macklowe has quietly opened his elegant hotel, which towers 38 stories over Times Square. He hopes his stature will soar with it.
In an industry that many New Yorkers love to hate, no major developer's reputation has needed more rehabilitation - a ''gut rehab,'' in real-estate lingo - in recent years than Mr. Macklowe's. And the need goes beyond ego. A tarnished name can have economic consequences when a developer needs government approval for other projects, as Mr. Macklowe has in New York and California, and when he woos prestigious guests as a hotelier.
His hotel and high-technology conference center - a lucrative niche, he hopes, in a potentially glutted market - opened without fanfare in mid-June between a shuttered Blimpie's restaurant and a landmarked theater he owns on West 44th Street in Manhattan. 
Five years before, several buildings on the site were partially bulldozed without proper safety precautions one night to beat a proposed New York City moratorium on the demolition of single-room-occupancy hotels. The moratorium was to take effect the following night.
That Mr. Macklowe has named the new hotel for himself, a name that he says stands for ''a commitment to a very high level of efficiency and service,'' suggests that he feels his reputation has finally been redeemed.
To his critics, though, the name still means something else, which the stylized HM logo atop the Hotel Macklowe affirms.
Since 1985, Mr. Macklowe has lowered his profile somewhat and has invested further in good works (he had been regarded as an art patron before).
If his rehabilitation has not been complete, he has, at least, regained the full $2.7 million, plus $500,000 interest, that he paid the city as a buyout for a single-room-occupancy hotels that had been destroyed at the West 44th Street site. He received the refund earlier this year after the buyout law was undeclared unconstitutional.
''It's very unfortunate that we had a poor public image,'' the 52-year-old builder said, speaking in the past tense, over breakfast the other day at the Hotel Macklowe. He was displeased by still more questions about his past, which he either sought to deflect or answered warily, and preferred instead to discuss the hotel's future and how it might reflect upon his own. ''There's no question his reputation is being enhanced,'' said his lawyer, James Gill.
In May, Mr. Macklowe was honored, along with Mayor David N. Dinkins, by We Can, a deposit container collection center that caters to homeless people, many of them former residents of single-room-occupancy hotels. He helped renovate We Can's building on West 52d Street at a savings to the nonprofit organization of about $150,000.
''Redemption is for everyone,'' said Guy Polhemus, the organization's executive director.
Another new friend is former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who not only pilloried Mr. Macklowe after the demolition but returned his $10,000 campaign contribution and sued him. Mr. Koch has become more sympathetic since he joined Mr. Gill's law firm and has got to know Mr. Macklowe better.
''So why is he a monster?,'' Mr. Koch said. ''Did he illegally demolish those buildings? A grand jury found that he did not. He thinks of himself as a good guy.''
 
Continues to Haunt Him
The Macklowe firm and one of its vice presidents were indicted, but Mr. Macklowe himself was never charged in the illegal demolition - he testified without immunity from prosecution before a Manhattan grand jury.
But the incident was magnified by its location, just off Times Square, by the potential dangers that the demolition posed to neighbors and to passers-by, and by the timing - at night, just before the moratorium deadline, and as the city government, reversing policies that had contributed to homelessness, was seeking to preserve the remaining hotels whose residents, many of them poor, occupy single rooms.
The controversy helped galvanize anti-development forces and has haunted Mr. Macklowe, who was already an anathema in some quarters, in every venture since. He complains that it has made him an easy target for politicians in a city where tenants heavily outnumber developers and has subjected his subsequent projects -the latest, a proposed office tower on West 34th Street that would replace another single-room-occupancy hotel -to a higher standard of scrutiny and even to retribution.
Yet Mr. Macklowe has consistently provided his critics with ample ammunition of varying calibers, ranging from the West 44th Street controversy down to the marketing of his 65-story Metropolitan Tower on West 57th Street as a 78-story residence (the base of office floors with higher ceilings largely accounted for the difference, one of his lawyers said).
 
'Cynical' and 'Effective'
''My Catholic upbringing would say anybody is worthy of redemption,'' said Robert F. Wagner Jr., who was chairman of the City Planning Commission under Mr. Koch, ''but among developers he has displayed a pattern of extraordinarily cynical and ultimately very effective tactics.''
The green-glass Hotel Macklowe, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, rises from a limestone and marble facade punctuated by an Art Deco New York panorama etched in glass over the front door. It contains 100,000 square feet of meeting rooms on the lower eight floors and hotel rooms above. Mr. Macklowe is renovating the adjoining Hudson Theater - briefly referred to as the Macklowe Theater until the controversy over the demolition - which will be rented to corporate conferees and for other events. The world chess championship is scheduled there in October.
Hotel-industry analysts say it is too soon to tell whether, by catering to corporate conferences, Mr. Macklowe has carved out a profitable niche in an otherwise depressed market. (Executives of Aramis International, Citibank and Tiffany's were among those meeting there last week.) Two other hotels have recently opened in the Times Square area - the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza with 770 rooms and the Rihga Royal with 500 suites. An Embassy Suites hotel, with 461 suites, is to open next month, and the Ramada Renaissance, with 310 rooms, in 1991. #52 Percent Occupancy The Crowne Plaza is said to have reported an 82 percent occupancy rate in June. On an industrywide basis, the average break-even point is usually in the 70's. Mr. Macklowe said his hotel, where the summer room rate is $175 for a single and $195 for a double, hit 52 percent occupancy one night last month, which he called ''encouraging.''
His several hundred hotel employees are not unionized and Mr. Macklowe apparently likes it that way. His son-in-law, Kent Swig, and other executives of the Macklowe Organization are said to be negotiating a so-called neutrality agreement with the hotel and restaurant employees union under which management is not supposed to impede organizing efforts if the workers decide they want union representation.
Mr. Macklowe proudly shows off the hotel with child-like enthusiasm and an art enthusiast's attention to detail. Dominating the lobby are two specially commissioned oil paintings, ''Day'' and ''Night,'' titles that Mr. Macklowe's critics, and even some of his colleagues, say also seem to be a reflection of a loner who wants to be liked. He says there is no new Harry Macklowe - just a man whose accomplishments are beginning to be appreciated.
''I'm not talking about a fan club,'' he said, ''but the more people see our work and get to meet me, they are pleased with what they see.''
 
'The Process One Goes Through'
Among recent visitors to the hotel was Herbert Sturz, another former City Planning Commission chairman. After he pronounced it ''tasteful and elegant,'' he was asked whether the hotel is better than what was there before.
''I don't think that's the relevant question,'' Mr. Sturz said. ''Rather, it's the process one goes through. It's means and ends. And sometimes means become ends in themselves.''
Developers are routinely accused of cutting corners; Mr. Macklowe has often seemed to do so more clumsily.
In 1985, some of his colleagues were so concerned about how the West 44th Street demolition reflected on their industry that they convened a special panel of the Real Estate Board of New York and invited Mr. Macklowe to explain himself. The results were inconclusive. But a short time later, as evidence that the board members' concern had been well founded, preservationists mounted a vigil at a Fifth Avenue site in fear that its owner, too, would raze the buildings there under cover of darkness. #72d Street Project Later in 1985, the city threatened to withhold a temporary certificate of occupancy from his River Terrace apartment building at 515 East 72d Street because details had been modified without City Planning Commission approval, in violation of a special permit. To satisfy the commission, Mr. Macklowe agreed to renovate the esplanade along the East River from 103d to 125th Streets at a cost of $5 million.
''I wasn't able to do that because of what he had done on 44th Street,'' said Mr. Sturz, who was the planning commision chairman then, ''but because of what he had done on 72d Street.''
In 1986, the city sued Mr. Macklowe, maintaining that his River Tower apartment building at 420 East 54th Street failed to provide inviting public plazas in exchange for permission to build an extra 74,000 square feet. His representatives argued that the plans had been approved by the Buildings Department. The city countered that Mr. Macklowe's architect was responsible for certifying that the plans complied with zoning provisions.
If his reputation had preceded him in some circles, the 44th Street demolition all but made Harry Macklowe a household name.
 
Fine and Buyout
Mr. Macklowe testified that he had ordered the buildings demolished knowing that no permit had been granted but confident that safety precautions had been taken.
The city subsequently pressed the State Legislature, unsuccessfully, for tougher penalties against illegal demolition.
Mr. Macklowe paid a $2.2 million fine to settle the city's civil suit. He also paid the city $2.7 million as a buyout for the 59 rooms of the Lenox Hotel, one of the demolished buildings. Most of the fine went for construction of an 80-apartment residence, run by Franciscan priests, for the former homeless.
Mr. Gill, the lawyer, said Mr. Macklowe had also contributed several thousand dollars a month, voluntarily, for diapers and baby formula for homeless infants. Meanwhile, he challenged the constitutionality of the buyout law.
''Harry felt that landlords, even in the City of New York, have some rights,'' Mr. Gill said.
Under the city's moratorium on demolishing single-room-occupancy hotels, Mr. Macklowe was barred from building his new hotel on the site for four years. But he was able to begin two years early because the City Council eliminated the ban when the moratorium was renewed.
Mr. Macklowe is negotiating for Board of Estimate approval later this month of a proposed office building on 34th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. He has agreed to replace the 37 single-room units in a hotel that now occupies the site, but he is being pressed, by Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, among others, to provide as many as 170 that had been there before.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Oil prices rose again and stocks fell sharply in volatile trading as investors feared that higher energy prices brought on by the turmoil in the Middle East could push an already weak American economy into recession. West Texas Intermediate closed at $24.49 a barrel, up $1.38, after reaching a high of $26.25. [Page 1.] Iraq's invasion of Kuwait creates a new storm in an already unsettled atmosphere for economic policy makers in the Administration, Congress and the Fed. The budget negotiators can no longer be confident that the economy could withstand a $50 billion reduction in the Federal deficit, and they may question the wisdom of deep cuts in the military budget and increases in energy taxes. [6.] American support for a new lending organization intended to be the main conduit for assistance to Eastern Europe could be cut off by a dispute between Washington and the organization's management, Administration officials warned. [32.] 
 
The Economy
The U.S. jobless rate climbed three-tenths of a point in July, to 5.5 percent, as the ranks of employed Americans thinned substantially, the Labor Department said. It was the biggest increase since early 1986 in the rate, which had shown little change for nearly two years, and it intensified worries among private analysts that the economy was tipping into recession or might even have already done so. HEADLINE: 10-Day Car Sales Up 8.4%, Paced by Big Jump at G.M.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Cars of domestically produced cars rose 8.4 percent in late July, helped by sharply higher sales for the General Motors Corporation, the industry leader.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate for the industry in the 10-day period ended July 31 was 7.5 million units, although the rate for all of July was 7.1 million, compared with a 6.9 million rate through the first six months of the year.
Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, was reluctant to attach much significance to the surge. ''I don't like to put too much weight on any 10-day period,'' he said. ''I'm not sure it means anything.'' Vehicle demand in the United States has been depressed for about a year. 
Mr. Heinbach, noting the increase in energy prices because of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, said car sales may be depressed immediately as customers wait to see what happens to gasoline prices. He also predicted that shoppers may begin choosing smaller, more fuel-efficient cars, which would tend to hurt the Big Three.
''Up to now, car buyers' first preference has been comfort and performance,'' he said. ''Now they may begin thinking more about fuel efficiency.''
Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said he doubted that the late-July surge would last. ''G.M.'s sales increase is against a very weak year-ago period,'' he said. ''Sales at Ford and Chrysler are more indicative of the market's direction.''
General Motors said auto sales in the late-July period jumped 14.8 percent, to 112,817 units. Ford Motor reported a 14.4 percent drop in car sales, to 60,515. And the Chrysler Corporation posted an 11.5 percent decline, to 24,288.
Among the Japanese-owned manufacturers, the Honda Motor Company reported that sales of its cars made in this country rose 65 percent, to 23,020. The Toyota Motor Corporation said sales of its American-built cars were up eightfold, to 13,372, compared with the period a year ago. And the Nissan Motor Corporation's domestic car sales were up 7.9 percent, to 4,829.
Sales of domestic light trucks rose 11 percent in late July, to 149,210 units, from 134,444 a year ago. General Motors posted a 17.7 percent gain, to 63,018, Ford reported an 11.7 percent rise, to 51,755, and Nissan, a gain of 21 percent, to 5,600. Chrysler reported a 3.7 percent decline in light truck sales, to 28,837. Ford said sales of its Explorer four-door compact utility vehicle helped it increase its share of the light-truck market.
Karen Longridge, a spokeswoman at General Motors, said the company attributed the sharp increase late in the month to ''customer acceptance of our new products, the Chevrolet Caprice, Buick Park Avenue and Buick Regal sedan.''
 
Sales Down for Month
For the month, combined sales of domestically produced cars and trucks were down seven-tenths of 1 percent, while sales of imported cars and trucks dropped 8.9 percent. On a combined basis, car and truck sales fell 2.6 percent, to 1,224,132, in July, from 1,257,049 last year.
General Motors, which continues to gain market share, posted an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in domestic car sales for the month, to 279,055 units, compared with the period a year ago; Ford, which has been losing market share, lost 14.7 percent in domestic sales, to 159,184, and Chrysler, also losing market share, declined 15.7 percent, to 60,948. A Ford spokesman said the company expected to regain car-market share for the rest of the year because of the increasing availability of its new line of Ford Escort/Mercury Tracer subcompacts.
As a group, the Big Three domestic manufacturers captured 69.9 percent of all light vehicle sales in July, compared with 70.9 percent a year ago.

HEADLINE: A Long, Hot Summer in the Skies

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
It's summertime and the airlines are sweating. The normally prosperous travel season is proving a disappointment for the industry, and as a result the airlines are offering discount fares, although with many restrictions, that are unusual at this time of year.
Industry analysts attribute the summer slump to the fact that the airlines' fleets, bolstered by hundreds of new planes ordered years ago, are expanding faster than the number of passengers, which has been held down by the softening economy.
Available seats increased 6 percent in the first half of the year from the year-earlier period, while the number of miles flown by paying passengers increased only 4 percent. Not surprisingly, the industry's load factor - the average percentage of seats filled -dropped 1.6 percentage points on domestic flights during the first six months, to 60 percent from 61.6 percent. 
It does not help that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait is raising oil prices -a jump that means higher jet-fuel costs.
While no analysts are predicting an industry free fall - and in fact the sluggish domestic market has been partly offset by strong international traffic - many said the industry's expansion plans might have been too ambitious.
''The airlines are supposed to make up for the January doldrums during the summer, and it's not happening,'' said Paul Turk, an analyst for Avmark, a consulting firm based in Arlington, Va.
''We're seeing discounting this summer the likes of which we've never seen before,'' said Kevin Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. ''I see a consumer that is reluctant to spend and an industry that is forced to give fare promotions.''
For instance, Continental Airlines is trying to fill some of its seats with the airborne equivalent of a one-day sale. Those making last-minute plans who are willing to travel on a weekend before Aug. 13 can fly on Continental from New York to Bermuda for $99 each way and from Houston to Acapulco for $69 each way.
 
Many Restrictions, Few Seats
Most airlines are offering one-way fares from New York to Los Angeles for $138. But the restrictions are many and the seats are sometimes few. ''They're in the newspapers, but they may not be in the computers,'' one corporate travel manager said of the lowest fares. Analysts said that only if the slump continues into the fall will airlines offer more widespread discounts, possibly slashing business fares as well.
The summer's discount tickets are not refundable and must be purchased when reservations are made. And the industry's discount fares have been aimed at the leisure traveler; the business traveler is probably paying as much as ever. ''There have been some very deep discounts in the past few weeks, but they are sporadic and only in certain markets,'' said Gail Ruderman, president of Ruderman Travel, a chain of travel agencies based in Trenton.
The slump in air traffic shows up in lower second-quarter earnings reported in the last two weeks, which reflect the beginning of the summer travel season. Analysts also attributed the poor showing to higher maintenance costs, mainly attributable to the need to make hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of modifications to aging fleets. Fuel costs, which account for about 15 percent of an airline's expenses, rose sharply last winter and are expected to rise further since the invasion of Kuwait on Thursday. Indeed, Northwest announced yesterday that it would add an $8 surcharge on all domestic flights because of higher fuel costs.
American Airlines' profits dropped 27 percent, to $129 million. Two of the hardest-hit carriers were Delta Air Lines, whose profits dropped 61 percent, to $74 million, and USAir Group, which reported a loss of $75 million.
Delta's poor earnings are partly a result of competition from Eastern Airlines, which has been promoting what one analyst called desperation fares in an attempt to win back travelers lost in the 17 months since a strike led the airline to file for bankruptcy court protection. For instance, Eastern is offering one-way fares from New York to 30 destinations, including Florida, for as low as $69. So far, other carriers have been slow to match these fares.
In fact, only Northwest, United and America West Airlines have avoided the hard times that come when capacity outpaces demand. These airlines are benefiting from their Pacific routes, where traffic is surging. And Northwest and United have fewer costly new airplanes entering service.
The second-quarter net income of UAL Inc., the parent of United, rose 5.1 percent, to $148.2 million. America West's income more than doubled, to $6.14 million.
A major reason for the poor second-quarter earnings, analysts said, is the softening economy. The industry is one of the most vulnerable in an economic downturn. ''One of the first things people do is cut back on vacations,'' said Thomas Longman, an analyst with Bear, Stearns & Company.
Yet airline executives ordered hundreds of planes years ago based on optimistic economic forecasts. These extra planes are just now entering service. The airlines will take delivery of about 260 planes this year, 25 percent more than last year. 2 New Planes Each Month American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, is adding nearly two new planes to its fleet each month; the total number of planes it has on order or option is larger than its current fleet. And American, like most of the carriers, has no plans to retire any of its older planes soon.
The one bright spot for the industry is international flights, which have partly offset the sluggish domestic market. In the first six months of this year, international traffic grew 17 percent from the year-earlier period, and the percentage of seats filled grew 3.5 percent. Most of the large United States airlines are trying to expand their international route systems. American, for instance, recently purchased Eastern's South American routes.
