HEADLINE: Price Plunge Continues For Long-Term Bonds

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds continued to crumble and interest rates continued to rise yesterday, as more investors feared that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait would fuel a resurgence of inflation that would undermine the value of fixed-income debt issues.
A report from Moscow early in the afternoon, indicating that Iraq would withdraw its forces from Kuwait over the weekend, tended to arrest the decline. But the report - later confirmed by Iraq but discounted by the White House because it was conditional - did not cause bond prices to rebound nearly as much as stock prices did.
The only prices of Treasury securities that rose were those of bills and the two- and three-year notes. The demand for the short-term debt issues was attributed to the parking of funds by investors who had fled the battered stock market this week. 
''Much of the selling that greeted the opening of the New York bond market consisted of sell orders from Japan and Europe,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''The foreign sellers were reacting more to the July job data that the Government reported before the markets opened than the Mideast situation.''
Outwardly, the employment data was positive for the bond market, which thrives on any negative economic news. But the Government report of a drop of 219,000 nonfarm jobs last month was accompanied by data showing that hourly wages climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in July after a five-tenths rise in June.
''This raised the prospect that the recession many in the Street believe is coming later this year will be accompanied by a higher rate of inflation,'' Mr. Ricchiuto said. ''This was a double dose of bad news for the bond market, which dreads both the specters of inflation and the higher interest rates it breeds.''
Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the giant Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, said that ''had it not been for the Iraqi-Kuwait affair, many of us expected that the July employment numbers would prompt the Federal Reserve to start lowering interest rates today. The Mideast situation only delayed the move.'' ''Almost everyone in the Street expected the job data to remove any lingering doubts about the impending recession,'' he added. ''Besides, if the Fed had acted today, it could have helped stimulate interest in the record Treasury refunding auctions scheduled for next week.'' Senate Action Expected With the House approving a short-term rise in the debt ceiling and the Senate expected to follow suit over the weekend, the Treasury is expected to auction $11.5 billion of three-year notes on Tuesday, $10.5 billion of seven-year notes the next day and wrap up the midquarter refunding with a sale of $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday. Japanese insurance companies and other institutional investors have been taking up about a third of the Treasury debt offered in these refundings.
Late in the session, the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, were being offered at 102 4/32, down 1 2/32 on the day. A point is equivalent to $10 for each $1,000 of face value. The fall sent the long bond's yield climbing to 8.55 percent, from 8.45 percent the day before and 8.47 percent a week ago.
The Treasury's long notes are also closely watched because they are compared with Japanese and West German Government issues that serve as their long bonds. The Treasury's long notes, the 8 7/8's of the year 2000, fell 13/32, to 102 27/32, as the yield rose to 8.44 percent, from 8.38 percent the day before and 8.41 perent a week ago.
By comparison, the yield on the 10-year Japanese long bonds rose to 7.70 percent from 7.56 percent a week ago, while the similar West German maturity soared to 8.78 percent from 8.13 percent during the week.
The Treasury maturities involved in the refunding also drew interest. The outstanding seven-year notes lost 6/32, at 100 30/32, for a yield of 8.32 percent. But the current 8 5/8 percent three-year notes rose 3/32, to 101 19/ 32, for a yield of 7.96 percent, and the 8 percent notes of 1992 gained 5/32, at 100 12/32, for a yield of 7.79 percent.
 
Bill Rates Drop
Continued strong demand for Treasury bills caused their discount rates to drop. The rate on the 90-day bills fell 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.33 percent; the six-month bills lost 9 basis points, to 7.22 percent, and the one-year bills plunged 12 basis points, to 7.07 percent.
The only action by the Fed was to add a further $2 billion of reserves to the banking system through customer repurchase agreements. The move was considered technical and not aimed at influencing the key Federal funds rate that banks charge one another for brief loans. The funds rate closed at 7 7/8 percent after trading most of the day at 8 1/16 percent.

HEADLINE: Mideast Anxiety Jolts the Markets

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks took one of their biggest tumbles of the year yesterday amid widespread anxiety and uncertainty about the Middle East, but the close showed a solid recovery from the far lower levels earlier in the day.
After plunging more than 120 points in the biggest selloff since an ominous 190-point drop last October, the bellwether Dow Jones industrial average rapidly recouped half that loss. It closed at 2,809.65, down 54.95 for the day and 88.86 for the week.
On the currency markets, the dollar climbed further in volatile trading, to 149.93 yen, up from 149.25. And gold prices, after rising $3.50 an ounce on Thursday, posted a slight gain, adding 60 cents, to $377.40. [Page 39.] On the New York Stock Exchange, volume soared to 292.4 million shares from an extremely heavy 253.1 million the day before. And with many workers away on vacation, most brokerage firms worked with short staffs. Calls Went Unanswered Traders readily acknowledged that telephones occasionally went unanswered. The National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs the over-the-counter market, officially denied that its dealers were not answering phones. 
Statistics on the day's movements, normally available within a short time after the market's close, were still incomplete hours later. Traders said prices became so cheap in the middle of the day that investors rushed back to pick up bargains. I.B.M., for example, had sunk to 103 3/4 before ending the day at 108 1/8, down 1 5/8. More than 3.5 million shares changed hands.
General Electric dropped to 66 3/4 before bouncing back to 69 3/4, down 7/8, on volume of 3.4 million shares.
Many investors took comfort from a prediction late in the day by Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, that Iraq would soon withdraw from Kuwait. Iraq later confirmed that it intended to withdraw, but the White House discounted the announcement.
 
Grim Unemployment News
Beyond the fluid situation in the Middle East, new Government data yesterday showed that the unemployment rate had jumped to 5.5 percent last month. It was the highest level in two years and provided new evidence to investors that the economy is steadily weakening.
''We had a double whammy - two negatives in the market at the same time,'' said Kenneth P. Ducey, senior vice president of S. G. Warburg & Company. ''There was a lot of fear and a lot of panic.''
Watching the market from the Midwest, Sung Won Sohn, senior vice president and chief economist of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, remarked, ''Portfolio managers are scared of the stock market right now.'' He said they were ''reshuffling their assets,'' converting money into Government securities and cash.
 
'On the Verge' of Recession
He said the new unemployment figures, plus the rise in oil prices, ''reinforced the belief in the financial markets that we're on the verge of a recession.''
Taking no chances in the mounting uncertainty, investors pulled money out of normally recession-proof drug stocks and out of some of the best-known growth stocks, including McDonalds, American Express and Wal-Mart Stores.
McDonalds fell to a new low of 29 1/2, but recovered to 30 1/4, down 1/2. American Express fell as low as 26 1/2, but ended at 27 3/4, down only 1/4. Wal-Mart slid to 28 1/2, but came back to 30 3/8, up 1/2.
''Prices got pretty low,'' Mr. Ducey said, ''and stocks started to look attractive.''
 
Oil Stocks Come Down
Although oil prices seemed to be rising slightly, Wall Street sentiment that the increases should be moderate helped to lower oil stocks from their highs of the day before.
After soaring to a new high of 140 3/8, ARCO sank as low as 132 3/8 before ending the day at 133 5/8, down 1 7/8. Exxon, which traded as high as 55, dropped by the close to 53 1/8, off 1/8, with 3.26 million shares changing hands. Mobil jumped to a new high of 69, but fell back to 66 7/8, down 3/8, by the end of the day, also on volume of 3.26 million shares.
With airlines and other big energy users affected the most, the Dow Jones transportation average slumped 39.23. UAL accounted for most of the drop, falling 7 1/2, to 122 1/2, after hitting a new low of 114. Norfolk Southern slid 2 3/8, to 40; Union Pacific fell 2 5/8, to 75 1/4; Southwest Airlines dipped 1 3/4, to 25 3/4 and Delta Air Lines dropped 1 1/8, to 62 1/2.
Among the health-care stocks, Bristol-Myers Squibb traded between a low of 58 1/4 and a high of 61 3/8 before closing at 60 1/2, down 1 3/4, in heavy trading. Upjohn moved between a low of 37 5/8 and a high of 41 1/2, ending at 40 3/8, down 1 5/8. Becton, Dickinson ranged between 67 and 70 1/2 and closed at 68 5/8, down 68 5/8. Bausch & Lomb sank 5, to 62 3/4; it had traded as high as 67 1/2.
 
New Rule Takes Effect
The Dow fell sharply from the opening bell at 9:30. By 10, the blue-chip barometer had slipped 60 points. By 2 o'clock it had slumped 120 points, or 4.3 percent. Then, within 20 minutes, it had recovered almost 40 points and by well before 3 it had climbed 30 more.
Program traders operated in force much of the day, said Birinyi Associates, which tracks such market activity. By the end of the day, after five selling programs and two buying programs, program trading had clipped 37.99 points from the Dow. Birinyi said that in one 20-minute selling program starting just before 1 P.M., the Dow slid 23 points.
With investors far more nervous than ever, the market indicator might have dropped far more but for a new stock exchange rule that was used yesterday for the first time. It provides that when the Dow falls more than 50 points, program traders are not permitted to sell stock on a downtick - when the last sale is lower than the one before. The rule had previously been voluntary.
And on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, a plunge in stock-index futures prices touched off a two-minute trading halt that is one of the ''circuit breakers'' intended to prevent a runaway market collapse.
Technology stocks, which have been losing favor, continued to fall. On the American Stock Exchange, where stocks fell sharply on what was the heaviest trading day of the year, Amdahl, the computer company, fell 1 7/8, to 12 3/8. On the Nasdaq, Apple Computer ranged between 39 3/4 and 43 3/4 before closing at 41 1/4, down 2 1/4. Microsoft, the software producer, traded between 60 3/8 and 65 3/4, ending at 63 1/4, down 2 3/4.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Reports on Iraq and Jobless Lift Dollar in Volatile Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar climbed slightly today against most major currencies in trading that was volatile as dealers divided their attention between the Persian Gulf crisis and evidence that the United States economy might be on the verge of a recession.
Gold prices, meanwhile, after rising $3.50 an ounce in New York on Thursday after news of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, posted a minor gain on the Commodity Exchange today. Gold for current delivery settled at $377.40 an ounce, up 60 cents. 
Investors unloaded dollars early in the United States trading day, reacting to the latest economic statistics from Washington. The Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate shot up to 5.5 percent in July, from 5.2 percent in June.
Analysts said the report, which furnished one of the first insights into the economy's performance last month, flashed a recession warning. The July jobless rate was the highest since a 5.6 percent reading in August 1988.
 
Oil Jump a Factor
But the turmoil in the Middle East after Iraq's move kept dealers on guard against selling dollars aggressively. The jump in oil prices since the invasion Thursday has been a principal reason for the dollar's advance, which began Thursday against most major currencies. Oil transactions are conducted in dollars.
''There still was a great deal of buying interest,'' said Kevin Lawrie, treasury manager at the Bank of Boston's office in New York. ''No one's comfortable going home short of dollars over the weekend when anything can happen out there.''
Rumors that Iraqi troops had begun an assault on Saudi Arabia gave investors an extra incentive to buy dollars as a safe haven. But when word came later that Iraq planned to withdraw its troops from Kuwait this weekend, assuming the area was not threatened, the dollar buying subsided somewhat.
In New York, the dollar rose to 149.93 Japanese yen, up from 149.25 Thursday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 149.35 yen, from 148.90 at Thursday's close. And in London, it rose to 149.85 yen. Against the German currency, the dollar rose to 1.5935 marks, up from 1.5910.
The dollar also rose in value against sterling in the United States. One British pound brought $1.85375 late in New York, compared to $1.8545 late Thursday. In London, the pound rose to $1.8570 from $1.8495.
Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late quotes, included: 1.3505 Swiss francs, down from 1.3530; 5.3415 French francs, up from 5.3320; 1,166.00 Italian lire, up from 1,164.50; and 1.15125 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
Bullion dealers overseas said the markets were hectic with gold seesawing in a broad range. In London, gold rose to a late bid of $379.25, from $378.75 late Thursday. But in Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $378, from $379 Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $375.75, down from $379.39 Thursday. Silver changed little.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Fears on Economy and Oil Churn Commodity Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Recession fears, inflation worries and conflicting reports from the Persian Gulf ricocheted through the commodity markets yesterday, resulting in price moves with little relation to supply and demand factors.
''It seemed like a lot of attention was focused on what the latest rumors were,'' said Tim Evans, a copper trader with Deak International Inc., a New York-based dealer of metals and currencies.
Copper futures fell, and grains, soybeans and livestock were mixed. 
To further complicate markets already roiled by the Iraqi invasion, the Labor Department reported yesterday that nonfarm payroll employment fell by 219,000 in July and unemployment jumped three-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. The figures reinforced concern that economic activity was weakening.
The recession fears weighed heavily on the copper market, which is especially sensitive to signs of economic weakness. Copper futures settled 2.4 cents to 3.4 cents lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in August at $1.261 a pound.
Surging prices in oil futures - with the September contract of West Texas Intermediate crude oil settling $1.38 higher, at $24.49 a barrel - contributed to inflation fears, which prompted buying in other markets, including soybeans. On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybeans were 1 cent lower to 6 1/4 cents higher, with August at $5.86 1/2 a bushel.
But other grains were lower. Wheat futures settled 2 cents to 4 1/2 cents lower, with September at $2.80 1/2 a bushel, and corn was 1 1/4 cents to 3 1/4 cents lower, with September at $2.49 1/2 a bushel.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle were 0.03 cent to 0.53 cent lower, with August at 77.17 cents a pound.and live hogs were 0.65 cent lower to 0.35 cent higher, with August at 57.90 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
The Networks Cover Invasion From Afar

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
How can a television news operation cover a war that is over before it begins and to which cameras are not invited? Well, it rolls out stock newsreel clips, hauls in correspondents and lays on experts. Such were the weapons available to the evening news programs as they addressed the swift Iraqi conquest of Kuwait.
All three major networks devoted their Thursday evening news programs almost entirely to the invasion. By the time they came on, however, some 20 hours after the earliest dispatches, CNN cable had, as so often, pretty well covered the territory. 
First on the job for the networks, on Wednesday, was ABC's ''Nightline,'' which managed within an hour of learning of the attack to switch from its scheduled program on the problems of lesbian motherhood to the problems of Arab brotherhood and to accumulate the appropriate experts. One imagines that specialists like Gary Sick, a former National Security Council staff member, and Judith Kipper of the Brookings Institution began applying makeup as soon as news of the invasion came over the wire and kept it on in prospect of continuing demand.
ABC also made the most effective showing on Thursday evening. The package of reports presented by Peter Jennings on ''World News Tonight'' seemed fuller, better organized, more energetically delivered than those of its rivals. Viewers of ''The CBS Evening News'' may have been a little perplexed at seeing Dan Rather doing his stand-up in London. Had he got on the wrong plane? No, he had been vacationing in France. By last night he was in the Persian Gulf. A few seconds into ''NBC Nightly News,'' Tom Brokaw's telephone line to a reporter in a hotel room in Kuwait was cut off, which made for a somewhat shaky start and called attention to the visual medium's reliance that night on unseen reporters who in fact could not see very much.
The differences among the programs, however, were slight compared with their essential similarities. As far as substance went, they could not have been more alike if they had been controlled from a single newsroom. Whatever channel the viewer chose, he was told of the ambition of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to dominate the Middle East and of his warlike inclinations. Old pictures from the files attested to his army's slaughter of the Kurdish civilians in his own country and his attack on Iran. But the stills of the Kuwaiti invasion showed no fighting, just soldiers; they might have been troops anywhere.
Reports from Washington conveyed words of indignation from members of Congress along with the consensus from the White House, the State Department and the Pentagon that America's ''options,'' the favored word throughout the evening, were few and probably did not include military action - although that was left somewhat fuzzy as the President's statements became less definite. The best the programs could offer as visual accompaniment here were familiar pictures of United States naval vessels steaming along peaceably in the Persian Gulf.
All the networks presented the bad news that oil prices in the West would rise, and possibly shove the United States into a recession. Charts and graphs were called into service. All also addressed Israel's position, which seemed to have been improved by the invasion, at least in the public opinion market. The fight among the Arab nations, it was agreed, would distract attention from the Palestinian troubles and remind Americans that Israel had been trying for weeks to alert Washington to Iraqi intentions and had moved to forestall a perceived danger in 1981 when it bombed what it said was an Iraqi plant capable of producing nuclear weapons.
All these elements deserved notice, but lacking the immediacy and punch of pictures of the action, they could be treated more informatively on Thursday evening's straightforward talking-head programs, ''The MacNeil Lehrer Newshour'' and ''Nightline.'' The network news departments deployed their resources professionally, but found themselves in somewhat the same position as the United States in the face of a conquest accomplished in uncongenial territory: their most powerful weapons could not be brought into play.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Protecting Yourself From Losing a Home

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
In the Northeast, economic problems have led to a rash of residenatial mortgage foreclosures by commercial banks and other lenders. But conditions in New York and Boston are not typical of what is happening in some other parts of the nation, even though real-estate markets in most places continue to weaken and bank failures are at a near record.
When real-estate markets are sluggish, banks are under greater pressure to end mortgage delinquencies. Nevertheless, foreclosure is a drastic step that most lenders are reluctant to take. They see it as an expensive way to obtain only a partial repayment of a home loan. 
Here is a look at how consumers can prevent foreclosure.
 
Number of Foreclosures
 At the end of last year, there were 300,000 residential loans in foreclosure nationwide and 1.7 million delinquent loans. Thomas M. Holloway, a senior economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, estimated that the number of foreclosures and delinquencies today is not significantly different.
''There has been a big change in the Northeast, which was going like gangbusters in the mid-80's,'' he said, referring to booming home sales.
In Connecticut, filings for bank foreclosures almost tripled over the last two years, while in New Jersey, filings rose almost 50 percent in the first six months of this year.
Nationwide in the first three months of 1990, the percentage of mortgage loans on one- to four-unit residential properties in foreclosure was about three-quarters of 1 percent, according to the association. This figure is down sharply from the high of more than 1 percent in the second quarter of 1987, but still almost three times the level recorded in the third quarter of 1979.
 
Preventing Trouble
Homeowners are forced into foreclosure for a number of reasons, including losing a job, becoming seriously ill or being too much in debt. Most foreclosures follow the breakup of a marriage, said George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of urban and regional planning at Rutgers University.
But missing one or more mortgage payments does not mean foreclosure is inevitable. The key in preventing foreclosure is to contact the lender as soon as difficulties arise. Try to work out an arrangement to postpone or reduce the monthly obligation for a while.
''Banks in most cases will want to work with delinquent borrowers,'' said William Nicholson, the chairman of the American Bankers Association's housing and real-estate finance committee. ''But you have to have the desire and intent to make up the amount due.''
Among the ways to get out of a mortgage repayment morass are to defer or waive late charges, pay the interest only, establish a new amortization schedule calling for lower monthly payments, apply principal prepayments to the current debt and suspend or reduce payments.
Foreclosure is the legal step under which the title to a home is lost by an owner who has not made timely payments of principal and interest on a mortgage. It involves court procedures that can take up to 18 months.
Mortgage payments are usually due on the first of the month, and a homeowner is delinquent if the money is not received by the lender on that day.
But loan agreements usually have a 15-day grace period before a late charge, as much as 4 percent of the payment, is imposed.
Even before the 15th day, the lender may send a letter to the homeowner as a reminder that the payment is late. If the money is not paid immediately, additional letters are written and telephone calls are made, demanding payment.
After the 60th day, a notice is sent stating that a foreclosure action will begin unless payment is received. Once the homeowner is three months delinquent, the process begins.
 
Public Sale Is Scheduled
A lawyer for the bank does a title search and applies for a court order allowing a public sale of the property to be scheduled. At the sale the lender will bid up to the amount of the mortgage and thus end up with either the home or the amount that is owed.
''Up until the time of the sale, the borrower has an opportunity to reinstate the loan,'' said Pazel G. Jackson Jr., a senior vice president of Chemical Bank. ''He can pay back the interest and arrears and keep possession.''
Even when a homeowner cannot make mortgage payments and cannot sell the house for the mortgage amount or more, there are more palatable ways to get out of the loan than defaulting. Some government and nonprofit agencies have programs to inform the public about these alternatives.
 
Helping Yourself
They include allowing a new purchaser to assume the borrower's mortgage, granting a lower interest rate on the loan, holding a pre-foreclosure sale and voluntarily deeding the home back to the lender.
''Lenders will not help borrowers who are not interested in helping themselves,'' said Robert J. Engelstad, a senior vice president of the Federal National Mortgage Association, a private corporation that invests in home mortgages. ''These things can only be done when it makes economic sense for both the lender and the borrower.''

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
Trade Sanctions Against Baghdad Imposed by European Community

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The 12 nations of the European Community imposed an immediate embargo today on oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait and said they would stop selling arms and other military equipment to Baghdad as punishment for having invaded Kuwait.
Acting with unusual swiftness and force, the Western European countries also froze Iraqi assets in their territories, suspended trade and military cooperation agreements and ordered that measures be taken to protect all Kuwaiti assets ''to safeguard the interests of the legitimate Government of Kuwait.''
If Iraq fails to withdraw all its troops immediately, the European Community members warned, they will press for and carry out any ''mandatory and comprehensive sanctions'' ordered by the United Nations Security Council.
That seemed to imply that they would be willing to go so far as to send naval forces to the Persian Gulf if the United Nations imposed a blockade against Iraq. But community officials said military options were not discussed at a meeting here of senior political officers, which lasted more than three hours. 
One likely effect of the European action is to increase pressure on Turkey, which has been seeking membership in the community, to take anti-Iraqi measures.
A vital Iraqi oil pipeline runs across southern Turkey to Mediterranean ports, carrying 1.5 million barrels a day from Iraq's Kirkuk oilfields, equivalent to more than half of the country's total exports.
But officials in Ankara, the Turkish capital, said there were no plans to close the pipeline. That is likely to further discourage Saudi Arabia, which prefers not to act unilaterally, from closing its pipeline from Iraq.
The European Community's embargo ''is certainly the strongest signal to Iraq from anywhere in the world except the United States,'' said a Foreign Ministry official from Italy, which holds the community's six-month rotating presidency.
But the official cautioned that the real impact on Iraq depended ''very much on who else will follow us - the Japanese, for instance.'' He and others said that one aim was to goad the United Nations and other organizations, especially the Arab League and the Gulf Cooperation Council, into strong action of their own.
A ministry spokesman, Giovanni Castellaneta, said, ''As long as there is a single Iraqi soldier in Kuwait, as long as there is no legitimate and sovereign government, we will not be satisfied.''
President Bush, who has suggested that closing the Turkish pipeline is an option, called the Turkish President, Turgut Ozal, on Friday. But United States officials reached by telephone in Ankara said that there was no specific request for a cutoff.
 
Turkish Relations With NATO
Turkish Foreign Ministry officials have advised Mr. Ozal to move cautiously, but some of his advisers reportedly believe that the Middle Eastern situation offers an opportunity for him to prove that Turkey remains strategically important to its NATO allies.
That importance - and with it the prospects for Turkey's stalled application for membership in the European Community - is widely seen as having declined as NATO's military role changes in the new Europe. Even so, many Turks argue that a desire to be part of the West should not prompt any rash moves.
''Turkey cannot be the gendarme of the Middle East and does not have to move before its Western allies do,'' Cumhuriyet, a liberal newspaper, said in a commentary.
The European Community action today was a response to United States calls for stern worldwide sanctions against Iraq. Officials here said the proposal for a total oil embargo was made by President Francois Mitterrand of France in a telephone call to Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, who serves as community president until the end of the year.
In a statement on behalf of the others, the Italian Foreign Ministry said that the 12 members ''reiterate their unreserved condemnation of the brutal Iraqi invasion of Kuwait'' and demand ''the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces.''
''They consider groundless and unacceptable the reasons provided by the Iraqi Government to justify the military aggression against Kuwait,'' the statement said, ''and they will refrain from any act which may be considered as implicit recognition of authorities imposed in Kuwait by the invaders.''
 
Big Buyers of Iraq's Oil
Statistics provided by European Community headquarters in Brussels indicate that Iraq and Kuwait supplied 10.9 percent of the members' combined oil imports last year. Europe, including countries that are not part of the economic alliance, absorbs roughly one-third of Iraq's exported oil, virtually the only thing it has to sell abroad.
So the assumption among those who gathered in Rome today was that their embargo constitutes an important economic weapon. Because some European Community nations have been important arms suppliers for Iraq, the ban on future sales could also be significant if it is sustained for a long time.
The measures do not come without pain, especially for some European countries. Denmark, for instance, was said to have received 54 percent of its imported oil last year from Iraq and Kuwait, far more than the average, so it presumably will have to scramble to find alternatives.
Freezing Iraqi assets and eliminating Baghdad's trade preferences were seen as relatively minor steps. But the decision to move collectively to protect Kuwait's sizable financial stake in Europe could deprive any Iraqi-backed government in Kuwait of assets worth billions of dollars.
 
JAPAN WARY ON SANCTIONS
TOKYO, Aug. 4 (Reuters) - Japan's extensive trade with Iraq is making Tokyo cautious about approving sanctions against Baghdad, a Foreign Ministry official said today.
Japanese trade houses and engineering companies raced with their South Korean and European counterparts to open or expand business in Iran and Iraq after the war between the two Gulf countries ended in 1988.
The Foreign Ministry official, Yukio Okamoto, said Japan was the largest creditor of Iraq, whose debts are estimated by trade experts at around $70 billion, and second only to the United States as a buyer of Iraqi oil.
On Friday, 49 United States senators urged Japan to join the United States and other Western nations in economic sanctions, and President Bush called Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu today to make a similar appeal.
Mr. Kaifu told Mr. Bush that Japan would comply with sanctions declared by the United Nations Security Council, Mr. Okamoto said.

HEADLINE: Colombia's Advances in the Drug War Are Costly

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Almost a year into a violent drug war, Colombia claims that it has cut cocaine production, undermined powerful drug organizations and hounded top drug traffickers.
But it has also had to pay a heavy price in deaths, injuries and damage to Colombian cities and the economy.
As President Cesar Gaviria prepares to take office on Tuesday, Colombians are reviewing the successes and failures of a no-holds-barred struggle with drug traffickers which began after the assassination of the leading presidential candidate, Luis Carlos Galan, on Aug. 18. The crackdown brought about a campaign of bombings and assassinations by the drug dealers which killed hundreds of people and left many Colombians wondering if the anti-drug fight was worth the price. 
On Friday, Colombia's drug traffickers, who supply about 80 percent of the cocaine consumed in the United States, declared a unilateral truce in the drug war.
The truce has opened the question of whether the drug war will continue with the same intensity under Mr. Gaviria as it did under the departing President, Virgilio Barco Vargas.
Mr. Gaviria, a 43-year-old economist and like Mr. Barco a member of the Liberal Party, has received death threats from the drug cartels.
Colombian officials say the war against the powerful cocaine cartels is a long hard fight but they are gradually winning. Security forces have seized record amounts of cocaine, confiscated farms and properties from suspected drug traffickers, arrested scores of suspects and broken up dozens of cocaine laboratories.
Seventeen suspected drug traffickers have been extradited for trials in the United States.
The Government's biggest success was the killing by the authorities last December of the No. 3 leader of the Medellin cartel, Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha. But the police have failed to catch other top leaders of the Medellin cartel, Pablo Escobar and members of the Ochoa family, who are all on the run.
Mr. Barco said the crackdown had smashed the myth of the drug cartels' power. ''It's the beginning of the end for those who have sown so much grief among Colombians,'' he said last month.
Colombian and United States officials say the crackdown has cut Colombian cocaine production by 20 to 25 percent. Colombian security forces have seized 38 tons of pure cocaine so far this year, far more than the 26 tons found in all of 1989.
''For the first time ever, the Government is winning the war. The Medellin cartel is in disarray,'' said an American official who asked not to be identified.
But the Government has had a difficult job persuading many Colombians that the anti-drug fight is worth it. Many see drug addiction as an American and European problem, not theirs, and question why Colombia should make such a sacrifice.
 
Retaliation for Crackdown
The drug traffickers extracted a heavy toll in retaliation for the crackdown. The victims of the drug war include three presidential candidates, more than 200 policemen, politicians, judges and journalists.
The most brutal attacks were the bombing in November of an airliner, killing all 107 people on board, and bomb blast on Dec. 6 at security police headquarters in Bogota, which killed 67 people and wounded 653.
Officials estimate damage from the attacks at around $1 billion. Colombia's economy has been damaged by loss of foreign investment and a sharp drop in foreign tourists.
One effect of the war has simply been to drive the problem into neighboring countries. Western diplomats say some cocaine production is moving to Brazil, Peru and Bolivia.

HEADLINE: Trinidad Puzzles Over Cause of the Uprising

BYLINE: DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The chief preoccupations in this English-speaking nation of 1.3 million people are calypso, cricket and soccer. So the attempted coup against the Government, and the violence it spawned before its peaceful denouement on Wednesday, struck many Trinidadians as something alien.
''It's the craziest thing I ever heard of,'' said Kenneth Hamilton, a New York City public-school custodian who emigrated from his homeland 10 years ago and was vacationing with his family near the capital, Port of Spain, when he first heard the news of the coup last Friday. 
''We have lost our innocence,'' said Carson Charles, the Minister of Public Works, who predicted that Trinidad's easygoing ways would surely give way to an era of paranoia and increased police surveillance.
They and others agreed that the affair was far more violent than the upheaval that racked Trinidad and Tobago in the early 1970's after a ''black power'' uprising, inspired in part by the teachings of Malcolm X, helped to prompt an abortive military coup in which 15 people died.
The Government announced that at least 30 people were slain and more than 300 wounded during the siege just ended, most during a three-day looting spree by gangs of young men from the slums and by roving bands of the more well-to-do, who carted away their booty in pickup trucks and family sedans.
The leader of the rebels, Yasin Abu Bakr, a 48-year-old convert to Islam who once served in the country's mounted police, may have thought that he could repeat the example of Grenada in 1979, when a handful of leftists set off a popular uprising that ousted an unpopular Prime Minister.
Mr. Abu Bakr evidently believed ''that the people would rise up and help him,'' a Trinidadian businessman observed bitterly, surveying the devastation left by the looting and burning. ''Instead, the people rose up and helped themselves.''
 
Following of 300
There seemed little doubt that Mr. Abu Bakr's following of perhaps 300 people - most of whom lived on a lavishly appointed 10-acre commune, part of which had been illegally built on Government land - had drawn inspiration from the rise of Islamic fundamentalism in the Middle East.
But it appears that the affair also grew out of Mr. Abu Bakr's sense of his own importance, combined with his accurate perception that Trinidadians were fed up with Prime Minister Arthur N. K. Robinson, who imposed stern measures after worldwide oil prices began to skid in the early 1980's, crippling Trinidad and Tobago's petroleum-based economy.
But clearly none of the discontent was enough to provoke an insurrection.
''As geographically close as we are to Latin America, the culture here looks down on violent, revolutionary politics,'' said Dr. Selwyn Ryan, a Trinidadian political scientist.
''Actually, the resentment over economic and racial inequality was much more widespread in the 70's,'' said a veteran Trinidadian journalist who asked that he not be quoted by name. ''There was a strong feeling that black people in this society were not being given their due, even under a black Government.
''What happened here last week had nothing to do with this.''

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
U.S. Is Seeking to Forestall Any Arab Deal for Kuwait

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Having joined with Moscow and the Western allies in a solid front of opposition to Iraq, Administration officials said today that the United States was now trying to make certain that the Arab states would not undercut efforts to force a total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.
The officials expressed concern that Arab countries might agree to continued Iraqi control over Kuwait in return for a promise that Iraq would not attack other neighbors.
The officials are concerned that the natural instinct of Saudi Arabia and its neighbors to bargain with Iraq could weaken efforts to force a withdrawal through a combination of a worldwide oil boycott against Baghdad and an American military buildup in the Persian Gulf.
 
Bush Meets With Advisers
President Bush met with his top national security advisers at Camp David today, as the Administration continued to consider its options to force the Iraqis from Kuwait and to alleviate the Iraqi threat to Saudi Arabia.
In the first comment from the White House since the reports that Iraqi troops had moved close to the Saudi Arabian border, the Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, issued a statement at the White House that said, ''We continue to seek the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and restoration of the legitimate Government of Kuwait.'' 
''As we have stated before, all U.S. options are under consideration,'' the statement said.
As senior Bush Administration officials see it, the long-term threat posed by the Iraqi invasion is this: If President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is able to annex Kuwait or install a puppet regime there in place of the Sabah ruling family, it would mean that Iraq would effectively control 20 percent of the world's crude oil, and therefore be in a strong position to manipulate pricing by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for years to come. If Iraq can also intimidate Saudi Arabia into falling under its oil policies, Baghdad would effectively control about 45 percent of the world's crude oil reserves.
 
How Iraq Wins or Loses
''If the Iraqis withdraw and the Sabah family comes back to power then Saddam has lost,'' an Administration policy maker said. ''If the Iraqis withdraw and they are able to install a puppet regime, then Saddam has won. Aggression will have worked and Saudi Arabia will only be quasi-independent.''
The official added, though, that assembling a solid economic and political front to isolate Iraq is one thing, ''maintaining it is another.''
''We can already detect,'' the official explained, ''a strong impulse on the part of many Arabs to think that they can put Saddam back in his cage by tossing him Kuwait as a bone. They look at the Sabah family and say: 'Hey, they have plenty of money in Switzerland. They'll be okay. Why fight over them. Let's cut a deal.' ''
 
Long Term, Short Term
If President Hussein has a puppet regime in Kuwait, the official concluded, ''then he has a sledgehammer over the Saudis and OPEC. The real key now is whether the Saudis can understand their long-term interests rather than only their short-term fears.''
Apparently one reason that the Arab mediation summit meeting scheduled for Jidda, Saudi Arabia, on Sunday was postponed was that President Hussein was not prepared to attend and the Saudis did not want to meet without him for fear that he would perceive this as an anti-Baghdad initiative.
Administration officials were heartened, even pleasantly surprised, by the fact that the 12-nation European Community today froze Iraqi assets, halted all oil imports from Baghdad and banned arms sales to punish Iraq for invading Kuwait.
The Administration felt that at this stage - when military force appears to be an unlikely option - it was essential to establish a united economic boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil to deprive President Hussein of the economic benefits he anticipated from the invasion and, along with the military buildup, to bolster the Arab states in their willingess to stand up to Baghdad.
An official said one of the main reasons Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was so eager to enlist the Soviets in a joint condemnation of Iraq was to send a signal to the Arab states that not only are the superpowers ready to stand together behind them, but also that they cannot use a split between the superpowers as an excuse for waffling on their part.
 
Safety in the Gulf
''We are trying to tell the Arabs that 'we are together, so it is safer for you,' '' an official said. ''If you no longer have half of the international community ready to go along with a Big Lie,'' such as the Iraqi invasion's being based on the grounds that Kuwait was stealing Iraq's oil. Then, he countinued, ''it becomes much more difficult to sustain and those who are wavering will find it harder to justify their inaction.''
Some American officials viewed as an ominous sign the fact that at the Arab League meeting in Cairo on Friday, 6 of the 20 Arab League states voting abstained on the resolution condemning the Iraqi invasion, including Jordan, which most annoyed officials in Washington. The Jordanians explained to American diplomats that they abstained to keep their mediation efforts with Iraq alive, but the explanation was not believed. American officials fear that King Hussein of Jordan has simply thrown in his lot with Saddam Hussein, who is no relation.
As for the Saudis, they voted for the resolution but otherwise have kept silent. They have abstained from inviting American forces to use Saudi territory for maneuvers or from making any statements against President Hussein. As one senior American official explained it, Riyadh is trying to juggle three different impulses: to avoid appearing provocative to Iraq, to give time for Arab mediation to convince the Iraqis to pull back and for self-protection.
 
'Not a Moment Sooner'
''The Saudis are being the Saudis,'' the Administration official said. ''They want us there to save them one second before the Iraqis invade and not a moment sooner. We know that they would like us to go beat up Iraq, then they can come out and condemn us and then go home and thank Allah 80 million times for what we did.''
American officials, who were clearly caught by surprise and unprepared by the Iraqi invasion, are now growing increasingly concerned that the Saudis will come to President Hussein and ask ''What is your price?''
''Imagine,'' one American official said, ''that Saddam comes to them and says 'I would love to get out of Kuwait, but I just can't get out and let the Sabahs come back. How could I explain that at home? I can't be embarrassed like that.' Our answer would be, 'You put yourself in this fix, you figure it out.' But the Gulf Arabs might use that as an opening to say, 'O.K., just get out of Kuwait and promise you won't threaten us. You can leave behind whatever regime you want.' ''
 
New Military Government
Baghdad announced today the formation of a new military government for Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. The new Kuwaiti leadership, announced on Baghdad television, consists of nine men identified as Kuwaiti army officers. Earlier in the day, Iraq said it was building a new Kuwaiti army to back the government it installed.
American officials increasingly feel that only a restoration of the Sabah ruling family, which was always prepared to adopt an independent oil policy, can keep Kuwait's oil production free from the sway of Baghdad.
President Bush today sent the ousted Emir of Kuwait, Sheikh Jabir al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who has taken sanctuary in northeastern Saudi Arabia, a letter stating Washington's ''strong support for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces and our support for the legitimate leaders of Kuwait,'' Deputy State Department Spokesman Richard Boucher said.

The oil terminal in Ahmadi, Kuwait, is shown in 1971. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
U.S. Says Bush Was Surprised by the Iraqi Strike

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Despite Iraq's heavy buildup of forces along the Kuwaiti border in late July, the Bush Administration was surprised by the invasion this week and largely unprepared to respond quickly, Administration officials say.
The failure to anticipate the Iraqi attack has provoked heated debate within the Administration over the quality of intelligence assessments in the days before the invasion, including an unusual public defense of its work by the Central Intelligence Agency.
But while much evidence suggests that the invasion on Wednesday evening caught senior national security officials unaware, it is less clear whether that was because of faulty intelligence or a misreading of the situation by policy makers who saw Iraq's buildup more as a show of force than as final preparations for battle.
Officials may also have been dissuaded from more forceful action by Arab leaders' desires to pursue their own diplomatic efforts.
 
Officials Involved Elsewhere
Word of the invasion, which reached Washington at about 9 P.M. on Wednesday, found key Administration officials involved elsewhere. The National Security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, was at home, having taken an early evening off from his job. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was preparing to accompany President Bush to Aspen, Colo., for a speech. The American Ambassador to Iraq was in London, having been told days before that she could take a holiday. 
A more certain picture of the unfolding Persian Gulf crisis might have enabled the United States officials to seek to discourage the Iraqis, and to prepare a response should they fail. For example, the United States could have dispatched more American warships to the region, issued clear warnings of American economic sanctions and possible military reprisal, and undertaken diplomatic efforts with allies to avert Iraqi action.
In addition, Americans in Kuwait could have been urged to leave, but the State Department said today that it issued no travel advisories on Kuwait until after the invasion.
The United States is not believed to have offered military assistance to Kuwait or Saudi Arabia, and neither country requested it, although Washington has an unstated agreement with its gulf allies to defend them if asked.
 
Kuwaiti Forces Stand Down
Indeed, two officials said, Kuwaiti forces stood down before the Iraqi action, either out of a belief that Iraq would not attack or that resistance was useless, officials said.
Whether such measures could have forestalled the invasion is arguable. Many Middle East experts say little short of a vast show of American force would have stopped the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein.
Details of American assessments of Iraq's pre-invasion intentions are unclear, partly because those reports are classified. The C.I.A., which said Thursday that it had given ''very useful and timely information'' on the crisis, refused Friday to comment on any aspect of its Iraqi intelligence. State Department and National Security Council officials also declined comment.
Still, it is known that intelligence experts told the Administration as long as a week ago that Iraq was likely to invade at least part of Kuwait, and that those forecasts appear to have evoked little response from Government agencies.
 
Pessimistic Reports
As outlined in interviews, intelligence judgments about the Iraqi buildup began cautiously in mid-July and grew increasingly pessimistic with each new day.
Initial reports, based on satellite photographs and information from human observers, documented a march of Iraqi armor and troops toward Kuwait. When the buildup became public two weeks ago, the concentration had reached 30,000 and Iraq was inviting observers to the scene.
The first intelligence analyses, Government officials say, concluded that Iraq was bluffing, to force Kuwait and other members of the OPEC oil cartel to raise prices and reduce surplus oil production. But while public reports stuck with the estimate of 30,000 troops at the border, intelligence reports in succeeding days documented increases to 50,000, 80,000 and, a week ago, some 100,000 soliders.
 
Uncertain Estimates
Two officials who received briefings or read analyses of Iraq's movements said intelligence experts advised last weekend that Iraq's forces were preparing an attack on Kuwait and were likely to invade if their oil-related demands were not met.
The C.I.A. and the Defense Intelligence Agency assessments grew bleaker this week as talks between Iraq and Kuwait faltered and the Iraqis began to move combat support units into the border region, suggesting preparations for military action, officials said.
But their estimates still left uncertain the size and scope of the expected invasion, saying only that Iraq could choose to seize oilfields, occupy a contested island in the Persian Gulf or take over all of Kuwait, as it eventually did.
One official who received a Defense Intelligence Agency briefing the day of the invasion, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, said on Friday that the agency's experts forecast an attack then. But he said they appeared not to believe that Iraq would occupy all of Kuwait, partly because Mr. Hussein had previously assured the Saudis, Kuwaitis and Americans that no such invasion was contemplated.
 
Iraqi Advance Considered Likely
''I think the intelligence community believed it likely the Iraqis would advance to the oilfields and seize some territories that were previously disputed,'' he said. ''It also appears to me the Administration further interpreted, further reduced,'' the seriousness of that analysis, he added.
On the morning before the attack, intelligence officials told Middle Eastern experts at the National Security Council that an invasion was imminent, according to a former security council official who says he learned later of the warning.
A second official said intelligence warnings issued that day concluded for the first time that the Iraqi invasion was likely to be of such scope that it could extend through Kuwait and into Saudi Arabia.
Some officials who received those briefings said this week that they generally found little to criticize in the intelligence community's performance. One official who was familiar with the intelligence reports said that the agencies had benefited both from excellent technical intelligence, from satellites and electronic eavesdropping, and from what he called ''superior'' reporting from sources inside Iraq.
 
'Flawed' Assessments Described
The same information, however, left other senior officials unimpressed with the seriousness of the developing crisis. Some senior officials and other observers blamed muddled or faulty reports from intelligence agencies, and others complained that midlevel policy makers failed to heed the warnings they were given.
A senior White House official who demanded anonymity complained in an interview on Friday that C.I.A. assessments of Iraqi military aims were ''flawed'' and that the agency concluded that Iraq's saber-rattling was bluster, not genuine.
That was echoed by a ranking Pentagon official, who also refused to be identified, who said the C.I.A. concluded an invasion was imminent only hours before it occurred, far too late for useful military or diplomatic deterrents.
Some officials suggested this week that factors in addition to any lapses by intelligence agencies affected the American response.
They include an ingrained Government favoritism toward the Iraqis that dates from their war with Iran's despised former leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, and an unfamiliarity by top officials with the ruthless nature of Mr. Hussein's two-decade dictatorship. The Administration has had little contact with Mr. Hussein or his top officials in recent years.
''This may be an instance where our intelligence community worked and the policy analysis failed,'' Representative Torricelli said.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION: Man in the News;
Arab of Vast Ambition Saddam Hussein

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
With a single, swift military action, Saddam Hussein has dispelled the image he has assiduously tried to cultivate in the West as a man who can be trusted.
 
Iraq's 53-year-old
President is still the same radical revolutionary he was at age 22, when he attempted his first political assassination, and as unsentimental as he was 10 years ago when he presided over a firing squad as it executed more than 20 officials for disloyalty.
By seizing the desert sheikdom of Kuwait, Mr. Hussein betrayed and terrified his Arab brothers, destroyed the balance of power in the Persian Gulf, plunged the world's oil markets into chaos and challenged the assumption that the end of the cold war would bring peace to the world.
 
Expansionist Aims
Mr. Hussein sees himself destined to dominate the Arab world much as Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt did a generation ago. And as the world's biggest arms buyer, the commander of a battle-hardened army of one million men and the keeper of oil reserves second only to those of Saudi Arabia, Mr. Hussein has the tools to achieve his expansionist goals. 
These goals pervade the dozens of volumes of his writings, speeches and interviews, particularly those published in the years before the decadelong war with Iran sidetracked his political ambitions.
''We don't look on this piece of land here in Iraq as the ultimate limit of our struggle,'' he told a group of visiting Iraqi ambassadors in 1975. ''It is part of a larger area and broader aims: the area of the Arab homeland and the aims of the Arab struggle.''
After a coup attempt against him five years later, he called Iraq's political struggle a ''revolution which aims to destroy the bases of imperialism, to shine over the whole Arab world to make it a new power on the world scene.''
And only a few months before Mr. Hussein invaded Iran in September 1980, Mr. Hussein unveiled an ambitious pan-Arab charter for the decade, rejecting any superpower military presence in the Middle East, North Africa and the Indian Ocean and charting a course of regional nonalignment.
 
Threat to Israel
It was such boldness than prompted Mr. Hussein to invade Iran, a military miscalculation that cost tens of thousands of Iraqi lives and left him with a devastated economy, a dissatisfied population and an overblown military apparatus with nothing to do. Although the war gained no territory for Iraq, it marked the first time in recent times that an Arab country fought a war and did not lose, and Mr. Hussein emerged as a victor.
In the months before the invasion of Kuwait, he had predicted that another Mideast war was inevitable, threatening to ''scorch half of Israel'' with poison gas if it tried to attack Iraqi military installations.
Saddam Hussein was born into a landless peasant family in the village of Tikrit about 100 miles northwest of Baghdad on April 28, 1937. Orphaned as a child, he spent much of his youth quietly on the melon farm of an uncle who was a devout Sunni Muslim. But he became a member of the Arab nationalist Baath Party while still in high school, and at age 22 was one of 10 young party militants assigned to assassinate the dictator Gen. Abdel Karim Kassem.
The assassination plot failed and Mr. Hussein was arrested, but he escaped, fleeing 300 miles across the desert on a donkey to Syria and cutting a bullet out of his thigh with a penknife. Hearing of his adventures, President Nasser summoned the young revolutionary to Cairo, where he studied law and began the underground life of intrigue that would ultimately bring him to power.
 
The Ascent to Power
When the Baath Party seized power in a bloodless coup in 1968, Mr. Hussein became secretary and second-in-command to the new President, Maj. Gen. Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr, although it was clear from the beginning that it was Mr. Hussein who wielded power.
Mr. Hussein's accession to the presidency in 1979 was accompanied by a campaign of self-congratulation that outdid even that of his archenemy, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who was then the Iranian leader. On 20-foot high posters throughout the country, he is portayed in various roles - as a desert horseman, as a young graduate in cap and gown, as Commander in Chief in aviator glasses and military beret. Despite his fondness for uniforms and medals, he is not a military man.
Married for more than 25 years to a first cousin, Sagida Khairallah Talfah, a former teacher, he is often shown smiling broadly in photographs with the youngest of his five children in his lap, a cigar in one hand.
That image of the benign ''father-leader,'' as he is known, is promoted on nightly television where the beefy, moustached Mr. Hussein is shown focusing on some of the more mundane pastimes of Iraqi life, from attending a ritual circumcision to swinging a sickle with peasants in a wheat field. Official Iraqi publications often liken him to Hammurabi, the great lawgiver of the ancient world; a poem calls him ''the perfume of Iraq, its dates, its estuary of two rivers, its coast and waters, its sword, its shield, the eagle whose grandeur dales the heavens.''
 
'Abysmal' Rights Record
Mr. Hussein's rule has brought Iraq, once a coup-plagued country, its longest period of stability. More feared than loved, he has secured his power by an organized party structure and an interlocking system of police, internal security and neighborhood organizations unrivaled in the Middle East.
His is a country where the penalty for publicly insulting the President is death, and he has survived a number of assasssination attempts, some of them documented in a book written by his half-brother Barzan. The State Department's human rights report for 1989 decribes his human rights record as ''abysmal.''
Curiously isolated, Mr. Hussein has never cared about such criticism. He was impervious to the international uproar that followed his use of chemical weapons against Iranian troops and against Kurdish civilians in his own country. Surrounded by advisers afraid to give him bad news, he is not a man who likes to change his mind.

HEADLINE: House Grows Edgy as Elections Near

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The House of Representatives is heading into an election season with anxiety growing, as polls show the voters in an angry mood, the savings and loan issue gathers steam and the stalemate over the budget injects a powerful uncertainty into the fall campaign.
Poll takers are reporting an increasing discontent with incumbents, but no one is certain how that attitude will translate at the polls. House incumbents have enormous advantages, particularly in raising money, and voters still tend to view their own representatives more favorably than they view Congress as a whole.
Still, as the House heads home for the monthlong August recess, starting today, many members are edgy. Democrats and Republicans are in a fierce struggle to fix the blame for the savings and loan crisis, which is already roiling House races from Oregon to Georgia. And as the House adjourned without reaching a budget agreement with the White House, it consigned the risky final moves of the budget negotiations, with all their implications for the economy, to the heat of an election season. 
The crisis in the Persian Gulf has added new economic variables to the election-year equation. ''If that leads to gasoline lines in the country, that will create a revolution in each of our districts in terms of citizen attitudes,'' said Representative Jerry Lewis of California, who as chairman of the House Republican Conference is the No. 3 man in the party's leadership in the chamber. ''Suddenly the politics of 1990 become entirely different from what we were thinking about.''
 
'More Turmoil Than Normal'
Representative Vic Fazio, vice chairman of the Democratic Caucus, said: ''I believe there will be more turmoil than normal. I think even where incumbents are re-elected, their margins will be down, and I think that's pretty much true for both parties.''
It is not unusual for House members to be anxious in an election year, and many analysts say the House elections could still end up the sleepy sideshow they were expected to be. But the presence of so many uncertainties - in world events, in the economy and in the public mood - has raised the possibility that these elections could be something more.
History suggests the Republicans may be particularly vulnerable. The last time a President's party gained seats in a midterm election was in 1934, under President Franklin D. Roosevelt. Many House Republicans still bear scars from the midterm election of 1982, when their party counted itself fortunate to lose only 26 seats during a grueling recession.
Moreover, after listening to the Republicans claim credit for the longest peacetime expansion of the economy, Democrats are certain to hold them responsible for any storm clouds. One of them appeared Friday, when the Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate climbed three-tenths of a point in July, to 5.5 percent, the biggest increase in four years.
 
Economy Could Be a Key
Representative Beryl Anthony Jr., chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, predicts that Democrats will add 2 to 5 seats to their current 257-to-176 margin. ''If the economy continues to soften,'' Mr. Anthony added, ''we have a potential for those numbers to go up.''
Republicans, clearly worried about the turmoil over the budget, are reluctant to offer predictions. ''I think it's very fluid,'' said Representative Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip. ''I think it's somewhere between up 10 and down 10.''
Many House Republicans, accustomed to running as tax-averse guardians of the public treasury, have been pleading with President Bush to take a more confrontational tone with Congressional Democrats in the budget talks. Many fear that Mr. Bush's willingness to discuss new taxes and the details of Republican taxing proposals that have leaked out in recent weeks have left their party badly exposed while extracting little from the Democrats.
''I think there's a real conflict between those urging the President to run a 1990 strategy and those who are urging him to run a 1992 strategy,'' said one House Democratic strategist, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. Mr. Fazio asserted, ''The President wanted the fallout to be this election, not next election.''
 
Feverish Finger Pointing
Already, the savings and loan issue is stoking public anger and discontent, many politicians say. Lawmakers have engaged in intensive efforts to limit the damage, with the House scrambling to pass legislation before adjourning this week to strengthen penalties for savings and loan crimes, including life sentences for major participants in savings and loan crises. The measure passed 424 to 4.
At the same time, both parties are engaged in a feverish round of partisan finger pointing. As Democrats blame the Republican White House for the crisis, Republicans are aiming at Capitol Hill - not only current Democratic members, but also past leaders like Jim Wright, the former House Speaker, and Tony Coelho, the former majority whip. Both resigned last year and both had political vulnerabilities on the savings and loan issue.
Alan Secrest, a Democratic poll taker who handles many House races, describes the savings crisis as a principal engine of the public's discontent. Interviews with voters also show they are frustrated over the budget difficulties and issues like the Congressional pay increase, he said. Both parties pledged not to use the raise as an issue when it was passed last year, but it is simmering at the grass roots, Mr. Secrest and other analysts say.
''The underlying theme is twofold -the perceived absence of common sense in Washington, and secondly, the perceived absence of accountability,'' Mr. Secrest said. ''What we don't know at this point is whether these disparate storm clouds will organize themselves into a political hurricane.''
Representative Mike Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, said, ''If you're a Congressman, and you're in a 55-45 race, this could have a heckuva impact.''
 
Incumbents Still Have Advantage
Incumbents in both parties are hunkering down and counting on the formidable advantages of incumbency to protect them. Re-election rates in the House have been running extraordinarily high in recent years; in 1988, 409 House members sought re-election and 402 prevailed, a re-election rate of more than 98 percent.
''Whatever the public mood is, the way campaign money flows in House races will have a powerful effect on the ability of challengers to be competitive,'' said Fred Wertheimer of Common Cause, a Washington advocacy group that is a leading critic of the current system of financing campaigns. Both houses of Congress have passed measures that would change the system.
Mr. Wertheimer noted that for the 1988 elections, incumbents received $82 million from political action committees, while challengers received $9 million. ''The average challenger does not have the threshold amount of resources necessary to run against an incumbent of either party,'' he said.
Both parties, and presumably many potential challengers, have been viewing the 1990 elections as largely a holding action, with the real struggle coming in 1992, when redistricting and the likelihood of many retirements raise a large possibility for change.
 
Change of Mood Unexpected
Many decisions were made, both by challengers and party strategists, before the current mood and the current possibilities were clear. ''Sort of capriciously, out of the blue, we suddenly have something stirring that means better candidates, better funded, might have had a greater impact,'' Mr. Fazio said.
In the meantime, analysts say, the candidates who are running this year are adjusting. Mr. Gingrich says he would like to see Republicans build on the anti-incumbent mood by running against a Congress he portrays as a creature of 36 years of Democratic machine rule. ''I think you go to the country and say, If you're sick of incumbents, let me show you the guys who have been in charge since I've been 11,'' Mr. Gingrich said.
Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic polltaker, says most incumbents are sensitive enough to their districts to recognize the sour mood toward Washington and to respond to it. ''Most members of Congress are doing a lot more this time to separate themselves from the institution and to make sure they are perceived as close to home,'' Mr. Garin said.
''The campaign commercials of 1990,'' he said, ''are much less about seniority and power and clout in Washington and much more about fighting the people's fights back home.''

HEADLINE: Miss Cotins and Christopher Low Wed

 BODY:
Elizabeth Hyde Cotins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Cotins of St. James, L.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Alfred Maximilian Low, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Low of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Paul B. McInerny officiated at St. Mary of the Isles Roman Catholic Church in Islesboro, Me. 
Mrs. Low, 23 years old, will teach nursery school starting in September at the Park Avenue Christian Church Day School in New York. She graduated cum laude from Hunter College. Her father is the manager of career development at AIL Systems, a defense electronics company in Deer Park, L.I. Her mother, Carroll C. Cotins, teaches second grade in the Middle Country School district and is an agent at Prudential Willis Real Estate in Setauket, L.I.
The bridegroom, 25, is an economist with Carroll McEntee & McGinley, government bond dealers in New York. He graduated from New York University, where his father is the chairman of the English department.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Wisconsin;
The 'Seniors' at Summer Session Are of the Gray Variety

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis.

 BODY:
Many students at the University of Wisconsin have been surprised by the age of hundreds of their classmates at this year's summer session. These classmates are retirees, mostly from Florida, whose ages range from the early 60's to the early 80's.
''It was like a casting call for 'Cocoon,' '' said Barbara K. Wilder, a junior nursing major from Three Lakes, Wis., referring to the 1985 movie that depicted Florida retirees who became rejuvenated after swimming along with alien beings.
Harlande Samson, dean of summer sessions and intercollege programs, said about 450 non-Wisconsin residents, many arriving through packaged travel promotions, and about 90 in-staters over the age of 62 were auditing classes this summer. 
Auditors, who are like guest students, do not receive credit from the university for the classes that they attend free of charge. They are not allowed to take the exams given to the undergraduate and graduate students nor to ask or answer questions in the classes.
 
Some Resentment
But some undergraduate students resent the large number of the elderly who are crowding into their classes.
''I appreciate the fact that they want to be there, but sometimes it's disrupting,'' said Beth A. Moede, a senior from West Bend, Wis., who is majoring in history and journalism.
Ms. Moede, who is taking an American history class this summer in which about 30 of the 100 students are over 62, cited incidents when some of them interrupted the lecturer, talked loudly among themselves and sometimes even snored loudly in class.
''Students have to take the exams,'' she said. ''Sometimes the senior citizens take away from what I'm trying to get out of the class.''
Glen J. Gendzel, the visiting lecturer who is teaching Ms. Moede's class, disagreed with her assessment. ''I find they're pretty good,'' he said. ''Mostly they just want to contribute what they remember.''
He added that having people in the class who actually lived through the history that he was teaching could be a ''precious resource.''
Edmund Clingan, teaching a European history course in the summer session, said 53 of 85 students in his class were in their 60's. He said he allowed them in his class because the undergraduate enrollment was lower than he expected. ''There are some distractions, but in general, I found them to be quite well behaved.''
 
A Fee Proposal
Recently, the university's Board of Regents has begun talks about charging tuition to nonresident guest students over the age of 62.
The university now charges about $125 per credit for out-of-state guest students under 62. Under the proposal before the regents, elderly out-of-staters would pay half that amount.
Ruth and Bernard Zeigler of West Palm Beach, Fla., said they would like to return to Madison next summer but would reconsider if the price to attend classes was too high.
Mr. Zeigler, who is 83, and Mrs. Zeigler, 78, are both taking a European history class and an American history class this summer. They pointed to the large contribution that the elderly made to the local economy and said it would be unfair to charge them for classes.
 
Praise for Health Services
Madeline L. Livant, who is in her 70's and is also from West Palm Beach, is taking classes in European history and the opera this summer. She said the excellent health-support services led her to come to Madison for the summer.
''Madison's wonderful,'' Mrs. Livant said. ''But as old as we are, we need that available health possibility.''
The number of out-of-state guest students over the age of 62 has doubled since the summer of 1989, said Mr. Samson of the summer session and intercollege program. He attributed the increase to promotional campaigns by local private dormitory owners. ''They promoted Madison as a great place to spend the summer,'' he said.
William J. Levy, general manager of the Towers, a private dormitory in the campus area, said about 240 elderly people were living at the Towers this summer. He said most of them were from Florida or Arizona, where he travels each winter to promote the Towers and Madison. Eight weeks at the Towers costs $975 a person, which includes room and board, he said.
The Towers started to recruit the elderly nationwide in 1989, Mr. Levy said. The Towers would have had to lay off student employees during the summer without the elderly people staying there, he said.
Madison began offering free classes for guest students over the age of 62 in 1975, Mr. Samson said. He said that when the policy was enacted, very few of the elderly people attending classes were from out of state.
Not all the regular students are critical of the elderly guest students. Jamshid J. Sardar, a sophomore from Flossmoor, Ill., who is majoring in journalism, said he has enjoyed having the elderly in his comparative literature class this summer. ''I think it's good to see they're getting out and furthering their education at this stage of their life,'' he said.

They are among the 450 non-Wisconsin residents over the age of 62 who have audited classes at the university this summer. (Tom Capp for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Michigan State;
Tuition Increase Inspires Threat From Governor

DATELINE: EAST LANSING, Mich.

 BODY:
Gov.
James Blanchard says he is planning to order tuition refunds to students at Michigan State University unless the university lowers a proposed tuition increase. 
On July 27, Mr. Blanchard eliminated a $7.4 million Research Excellence Fund for the university. He substituted a plan to devote $600,000 to a tuition-assistance fund that would limit the increase for in-state undergraduates to 6.5 percent, rather than the 7.2 percent approved by the university. The remaining $6.8 million would be added to the university's regular allocation from the state.
The increase would cost in-state freshmen and sophomores an additional $217 a year and juniors and seniors $225.
In the academic year starting next month, freshman and sophomores will pay $3,245 a year, including the increase. Juniors and seniors will pay $3,278. If the university does not lower the tuition, each of the 31,642 in-state undergraduates will receive about $20 from the state.
State Budget Director Shelby Solomon said the disbursement of the money had not been worked out.
The president of the university, John DiBiaggio, said he was sorry ''that there has been a reduction in allocations to the Research Excellence Fund, a fund created to spur economic development and jobs creation.''
Mr. Blanchard told all state universities last year that an increase of more than 6.5 percent for the 1990-1991 school year or a combined tuition increase of more than 14 percent for two years would be unacceptable. Michigan State had a total increase of 15.1 percent in the last two years.
