HEADLINE: Lifestyle: Sunday Brunch;
Dim Sum: Pay-as-you-Chew Dining

 BODY:
These Chinese restaurants offer dim sum and other dishes for Sunday brunch. The listing was compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.
 
Mandarin Court
61 Mott Street (Canal Street), (212) 608-3838 - It's fun and adventurous to eat dim sum, and economical as well: you can order as much or as little as you want and pay accordingly. Mandarin Court is one of the hottest dim sum spots in Chinatown. It is clean and contemporary, with pastel walls, sparkling tiles, sleek black tables and an open kitchen up front. On Sunday, the selection on the dim sum cart is fresh and varied. The dumplings are brightly seasoned and light, filled with sweet shrimp, scallops or delicious sweet and sour pork. Other options are turnip cake with Chinese sausage, roasted cubes of eggplant with a sweet hoisin sauce, and fried scallops with a black pepper sauce. 
Mandarin Court's recent additions to the menu emphasize dishes with minimal frying and lighter sauces: a seafood assortment in a pineapple boat, jumbo shrimp with mango, and shrimp and scallops with pine nuts. For dessert there are vanilla tapioca pudding, black sesame roll and coconut Jell-O.
Dim sum is $1.50 an item, and main courses range from $5.95 to $14.95. Sunday hours are 8 A.M. to midnight, and dim sum is served from 8 A.M. to 3 P.M. (Diner's Journal, Feb. 3, 1989).
 
HSF
46 Bowery (Canal Street), (212) 374-1319 - This clattering and colorful restaurant buzzes all day long, from its dim sum breakfast until midnight. The dining room is a gastronomic roller derby, with waiters spinning around the room behind carts overloaded with small portions of dumplings, roast duck, shredded chicken and all manner of shrimp, squid, pork, fish and pastries. The turnover at HSF is fast and furious, so the food is generally hot and fresh when you get it. Dishes on the regular menu include Peking duck, orange beef or chicken, and whole roasted sea bass with a sweet and sour sauce.
Dim sum ranges from $1.60 to $2.75 an item; main courses are from $6.95 to $16.95. Sunday dim sum is from 7:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. (Article, Dec. 23, 1988). A second branch of HSF offers a similar range of food at 578 Second Avenue, between 31st and 32d Streets, (212) 689-6969.
 
King Fung
20 Elizabeth Street (Canal Street), (212) 964-5256 - This restaurant is about as close as you can get in New York to the feeling of a boisterous and colorful establishment in Hong Kong. Large circular tables are occupied by three or four generations. This can be an amusing place if you are in the right mood, and some dishes on the budget-priced menu are first rate.
On Sunday, a dim sum menu is served for breakfast and lunch. The selection includes beef balls with watercress; steamed pork with bacon; fried shrimp, pork and vegetable dumplings, and sweet and sour spareribs. Other items are delicious whole Peking duck with pancakes; baked lobster Chinese style with soy sauce, scallions and black beans, and whole roasted flounder with a ginger-scallion sauce.
Dim sum ranges from $1.60 to $2; main courses are $5 to $13. Sunday hours are 8 A.M. to 11 P.M., and dim sum is served from 8 A.M. to 2 P.M. (Article, Dec. 23, 1988).
 
Oriental Pearl
103-105 Mott Street (Canal Street), (212) 219-8388 - The main dining room at this sprawling 500-seat Chinese party palace is a carnival of ceramic statues, dragons with flashing eyes and colored lights. Oriental Pearl serves superior and wide-ranging dim sum for brunch with fried and steamed dumplings (shrimp, scallop, chicken and ham), shrimp cake with chives, and spareribs with black bean sauce. Other selections on the regular menu include deep-fried shrimp with walnuts; scallops with black pepper sauce and broccoli; braised goose and taro root casserole, and braised duck with mixed vegetables. For dessert, there is the traditional semisweet red-bean soup or fruit.
Dim sum is $1.60 to $2.95 an item; main courses are $6.95 to $14.95. Sunday service from 8 A.M. to 11 P.M.; dim sum from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. (Review, April 28, 1989).
 
Shun Lee
43 West 65th Street, (212) 595-8895 - This is certainly among the more elegant and comfortable uptown Chinese restaurants. Patrons enter through the bar, where playful papier-mache monkeys frolic overhead. The dining room, which resembles an amphitheater, is done in black, creating a dramatic background for the tongue-thrashing, red-eyed dragons overhead. Shun Lee is now serving a dim sum brunch on Sunday featuring steamed dumplings; shrimp (har gau); mixed vegetables with coriander and peanuts called funggar, and honey-roasted pork bun.
Fried items include crispy chicken with lemon sauce and seafood roll with ham. Other dishes are beef chow fon with wide rice noodles ($7.95); family-style bean curd ($7.95); sizzling scallops with an oyster flavored sauce (10.50), and honey Peking ribs ($10.50).
Dim sum is $3.95 an item. Sunday brunch from noon to 2:30 P.M. (Review, May 4, 1990).

SECTION: Section 2; Page 9, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1408 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
East Meets West In a Dying Steel Town

BYLINE: By HARRY KLOMAN; Harry Kloman is a film critic and contributing editor for In Pittsburgh Newsweekly.

 BODY:
On a humid Saturday in July, police stop traffic from passing along a largely abandoned two-block portion of the main street through Braddock, Pa. (population 4,775 and falling), to allow the Japanese film maker Hiroaki Yoshida to continue shooting his first American movie, ''Iron Maze,'' in some of the town's abandoned buildings.
As the sparse afternoon traffic detours along the bumpier side roads, an elderly man, his breath thick with alcohol, approaches the set and asks the production designer, Toby Corbett, for a cigarette. Mr. Corbett has just smoked his last one and recommends the man to a crew member nearby. ''These people live in the past,'' Mr. Corbett later remarks about his encounter with Braddock. ''And there's no future for them and no present. Many of them are hoping there will be a third World War.''
His observation referred to the heyday of Braddock, a once-booming steel town located up the Monongahela River about 10 miles from downtown Pittsburgh. In the 1940's, the city and its surrounding towns lived on the steel industry, and the region especialy profited during World War II, when man and steel together fought the Germans and the Japanese. In the last few decades, the flow of Japanese steel and automobiles to America has turned Braddock and other communities like it in the Pittsburgh area into decaying industrial landscapes. 
''We needed an American steel town where the industry was not healthy anymore and it was affecting the towns around it,'' says the film's producer, Ilona Herzberg, who grew up in East Germany, West Berlin and Toronto. ''There was never really any other city that was being considered.'' She calls the production's maze of economic and political ironies ''a mirror within a mirror within a mirror.''
''Iron Maze'' is based on a story idea by Mr. Yoshida (''Twilight of the Cockroaches,'' 1987), who took his inspiration from ''In a Grove,'' the 1927 Japanese novel by Ryunosuke Akutagawa, which was also the basis for Akira Kurosawa's classic 1951 film, ''Rashomon.'' Mr. Yoshida's latest movie concerns a Japanese investor, Sugita, who buys a dying Pennsylvania steel town and wants to turn its defunct mill into an amusement park. The investor is almost killed by an assailant in the empty mill, and a local man named Barry, who once worked in the mill, confesses to the crime. When the town police chief grows suspicious, an investigation unfolds in which various witnesses to the assault, including Sugita's young American wife (played by Bridget Fonda), tell their versions of what happened.
Japanese investors provided the film's $10 million budget, $7.5 million of which was spent in Pittsburgh. The company filmed nearly eight weeks in the area, and two of those weeks in Braddock, where Ms. Herzberg says the company tried, whenever possible, to buy local products and services. Though Mr. Yoshida had no time to meet Braddock residents, Ms. Herzberg would occasionally talk with people during breaks in filming, and she became familiar to some of them. ''If you had been here 30 years ago, you would have seen one hell of a town,'' said Steve (Straighty) Vasko, a Braddock native, to Ms. Herzberg on the last day of filming. Mr. Vasko happened upon Ms. Herzberg in front of a weedy lot between some abandoned buildings on Braddock Avenue, the main street. The two had met and spoken before, and Ms. Herzberg says the people of Braddock treated the movie's crew like good neighbors. The town's volunteer fire company used its hoses to create a rainstorm for the movie, and as a memento, Ms. Herzberg offered to photograph the firemen in a barroom set constructed in an abandoned Braddock building. She told the men they could ask ''the prettiest girls on the set'' to join them in the photo.
Ms. Herzberg recognizes the dubious honor bestowed upon Pittsburgh by the production's choice of the region as a place to make a film about industrial decline. So, too, does Mr. Yoshida, though both say residents showed them no resentment. The closest they came was in pre-production, when Mr. Yoshida and three other Japanese men toured an operating mill they were considering for use in the movie. The mill workers grew silent when the foreigners passed through because, according to Ms. Herzberg, they thought the visitors wanted to buy the mill.
Mr. Yoshida says he realizes that Americans who see ''Iron Maze'' may have trouble sympathizing with Sugita, but he insists his work has a wider context than mere politics or economics. ''Sugita has a dream,'' Mr. Yoshida says. ''He wants to build an amusement park. He's trying to realize his own dream, his own innocent dream. It's a very traditional American way, having a dream and trying to make it true.
''Before being an American,'' Mr. Yoshida continues, ''Barry is a guy who used to be very proud of his job and his town. Then he lost everything. Sugita is a Japanese guy, but before being a Japanese guy, his father is a successful businessman and millionaire, so he was born rich, and he doesn't know about danger. Before being Japanese or American, they're human. This exists all over the world.''
Though Mr. Yoshida hopes to enlighten people with his movie, he is going about it with a rather unusual philosophy. ''It's very important to make misunderstanding,'' he says, pausing to grin wryly. ''Right now, Japanese people are trying to avoid misunderstanding, but I don't think it works. Misunderstanding is very important to understanding each other. We cannot understand each other without making misunderstanding, without making trouble. So let's make more misunderstanding, so finally we will be able to be friends. It doesn't make sense to try to avoid trouble or conflict or struggle.'' Mr. Yoshida says his film involves many misunderstandings, some between Japanese and Americans and some among the Americans themselves.
One of the film's executive producers, Edward R. Pressman (''Wall Street''), says that having a Japanese director make ''Iron Maze'' may help buffer reactions to the subject matter. ''If a film portraying the influence of Japanese financial power - how it's brought to bear in a foreign arena like Pittsburgh - were described by an American film maker,'' says Mr. Pressman, ''it would perhaps seem like a self-evident, Japan-bashing kind of subject. The very fact that it's being told by a Japanese film maker makes it less confrontational.''
Most of the mill scenes in ''Iron Maze'' were shot in an empty mill in nearby Duquesne. A week before filming ended, Mr. Corbett said he found the decaying mill to be a safer workplace than an abandoned Braddock hotel and its mounds of diseased pigeon droppings on the third floor, which he had to transform into several sets.
A contract with the Regional Industrial Development Corporation, the mill's current owner, banned visitors from the set and required that the production company have the mill inspected by experts. A structural engineer determined that its catwalks could support camera equipment and dozens of crew members, and an environmentalist identified areas with hazardous materials, like asbestos and heavy-metal dust. On the environmentalist's advice, the production company removed the hazards and offered the entire company fitness tests and X-rays and masks to wear. ''It's not worth a movie to jeopardize anyone's health,'' Ms. Herzberg said of the precautions. ''It was a real education in environmental issues.''
Now that filming has ended, the mill's owner will tear down the steel-making buildings at the site and restore numerous others, such as machine shops, in an industrial development project that is designed to salvage 18 of the approximately 50 buildings there. Mr. Yoshida's film, then, will be the last use for much of the century-old mill, which made national news headlines in the mid-1980's when local residents fought to preserve some of its steelmaking operations after United States Steel, its owners at the time, announced the mill's closing.
Yet despite their grim recent histories, both the mill and the town of Braddock evoked brighter feelings for their foreign visitor. ''When I went to the steel mill the first time last year,'' Mr. Yoshida says, ''I felt I was in a church, or in some way I felt I was in an amusement park. I felt a lot of exciting or happy or interesting things in an abandoned steel mill. I don't feel it's a dirty place or a boring place or ugly place.

Pressman Productions) (pg. 9); Hiroaki Yoshida, the director, with Jeff Fahey and Susan Traylor, part of the cast, and Terry Edwards, a crew member (Suzanne Tenner/Edward R. Pressman Productions) (pg. 20)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2655 words

HEADLINE: Fiat's Thrust Into Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: TYCHY, Poland

 BODY:
FRANCESCO GALLO, director of international operations for the Fiat Group, had the proud and worried look of an expectant father as he paced through the half-finished $1.3 billion assembly plant that Fiat is helping build here amid southern Poland's fields of hay and corn.
Mr. Gallo hopes that by next spring, assuming that Fiat can overcome such common Eastern European problems as parts shortages and a snail-like work pace, the new plant will begin producing 160,000 sprightly subcompacts a year.
As Fiat's point man for Eastern Europe, Mr. Gallo is in a pivotal position because his company has the most ambitious expansion plans for Eastern Europe of any Western corporation.
In the high-stakes competition to sell cars to the 420 million people in the fragmenting Soviet bloc, Fiat is pushing ahead with local partners on huge projects in Poland, Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union that involve more than $8 billion in investment and may produce more than 1.2 million cars a year - more than the Soviet Union's output. Fiat has been busy forming joint ventures, taking equity positions and committing some of its best managers to the effort. 
''Eastern Europe will be the market with the greatest expansion over the next few years,'' said Mr. Gallo, during a pause in one of his whirlwind, once-a-month visits to check on Fiat's progress in Poland. ''We don't have to wait for demand to increase. There is already huge pent-up demand.''
Fiat, which has licensed designs and provided production expertise to Eastern European auto makers for decades, is vastly increasing its role now because it expects the region to develop quickly in the wake of Communism's collapse.
 
 'The Most Aggressive'
''It's clear that Fiat has been the most aggressive,'' said Stephen Reitman, automobile analyst with UBS Phillips & Drew in London. ''Fiat has a lot of products that match the aspirations of these developing markets.''
Mr. Gallo predicts that car sales in Eastern Europe, about 2.4 million units last year, will double within five years. Indeed, some auto executives see the market swelling to 7 million cars a year by the end of the decade, which would represent more than half the annual sales in the United States or Western Europe.
Expanding into Eastern Europe is a central part of Fiat's strategy because Western Europe's auto market promises to grow far more competitive as quotas on Japanese cars are phased out this decade - a development that could hurt Fiat more than other auto makers given Italy's strong quotas. The Turin-based auto maker is riding high nowadays, with a record $2.8 billion in earnings on revenues of $41 billion last year, and this enables it to devote so much money and effort to Eastern Europe. But Mr. Gallo says that Fiat, Italy's largest industrial group, fears losing prestige more than money if its Eastern European efforts fall flat.
Fiat was in a dead heat with Volkswagen last year to be No. 1 in Western European auto sales, but with Fiat leading the pack into the East Volkswagen has strained to keep close behind by moving aggressively in East Germany. With its expansion plans in East Germany and Hungary, the General Motors Corporation also intends to be a strong presence, while Ford, Peugeot, Renault and the Japanese lag far behind.
Here in Tychy - in what is the nearest to completion of Fiat's new Eastern European projects - the company is working with its state-owned Polish partner, Fabryka Samochodow Malolitrazowych (FSM), to produce small, but zippy, cars that will be a modest step upward from the tiny, underpowered models that Poles now drive. Fiat is also negotiating with Fabryka Samochodow Osobowych (FSO), a state-owned car maker based in Warsaw, to jointly produce 120,000 mid-sized cars a year by 1993.
But these projects are modest compared with Fiat's plans in the Soviet Union, where the company has agreed to pump in money, design expertise and production know-how to help produce 900,000 cars a year in Yelabuga, 600 miles southeast of Moscow. That project will create one of the world's largest auto complexes and nearly double Soviet car-making capacity. (See box.) ''These will be the first cars sold in the Soviet Union that carry a Western nameplate,'' said the 56-year-old Mr. Gallo.
The Fiat executive, who spent five years heading the company's American operations, sounds very much like the economics professor he once was in discussing the opportunities and obligations that Westerners face in Eastern Europe.
''We have a very strong interest that Eastern Europeans should progress,'' he said. ''They must solve their problems themselves. But we can contribute. We can help them to reinvent their economies.''
''The first priority is to give people a sense that something is being done,'' he said. ''They cannot increase production overnight. But we can increase the availability of goods through aid.'' In the Communist world, there has been little incentive to work hard, he adds, ''not because there isn't money, but because there is so little to buy with that money. We have to help provide better goods for them to buy.''
 
The Tychy Project
 Mr. Gallo's goals are being realized in Tychy, a community of weather-beaten houses, obsolete factories and patchy farms west of Cracow. FSM, based in nearby Bielsko Biala, is investing $650 million in the new plant, while Fiat is putting up an equal amount to buy machinery. FSM is to repay Fiat with the proceeds from 500,000 of the Polish-made cars, tentatively called Micros, that Fiat expects to sell to the West at the rate of about 70,000 a year. The plan to export Micros is part of a program in which Fiat will take more than 300,000 cars from its Eastern partners to sell to customers in the West. Last year, Fiat sold more than 2.2 million cars worldwide.
''With this new car, we will be expanding our product range in Europe,'' Mr. Gallo said. ''It is not economic to produce 70,000 cars like this in Italy, but it is economic to produce 160,000 in Poland, with us taking 70,000.'' Fiat, which may take an equity stake in FSM as part of the Polish company's future privatization, expects FSM to expand output to 240,000 Micros a year by 1993.
Fiat's cooperation with FSM is a signal example of East-West symbiosis in which Western companies benefit from new markets and low-cost, highly skilled labor, while Eastern European companies, consumers and workers arguably gain even more. For Poland, Fiat's involvement means new technology, more jobs and management expertise in fields like accounting and labor management.
What is more, the partnership will have a trickle-down effect since Fiat and its component suppliers are giving financial help and teaching Western ways to hundreds of FSM's suppliers, like producers of upholstery and ventilation systems.
''I don't like to boast, but you can say that this will be the most modern factory in all of Poland,'' said Jozef Popczyk, director of FSM's Tychy plant. ''Western help is essential for us. Without Western cooperation, we would remain at low technological levels.''
Like most Eastern European auto makers, FSM owes much of its past progress to a Western partner. FSM was a machinery manufacturer until 1971, when it signed an agreement with Fiat to assemble the Fiat 126, a minuscule car with a top speed of 62 miles per hour that Mr. Gallo calls a ''toy.''
After Fiat licensed the car design to FSM and built the Polish company's production line, FSM began making 200,000 126's a year.
The high-ceiling FSM factory, though a decade ahead of some Eastern European plants, remains backward by Western standards. Many basic welding procedures are done by hand, rather than by robot (there are only two in the plant). Instead of being at body level, as in new plants, the assembly line moves overhead, forcing workers to strain to reach up. FSM produces about eight cars per worker per year, one-quarter the ratio at many Western manufacturers. ''This is our plant of the 1960's,'' Mr. Gallo said.
 
Helping Hands
 FSM is not the only auto maker to seek Fiat's help. In 1966, Warsaw-based FSO asked the Italian company to help design and install production equipment. Lada, the Soviet auto maker, and Zastava, the Yugoslav car maker, have turned to Fiat to design and engineer cars and production lines. Zastava is negotiating with Fiat for the Italian company to significantly raise its stake, currently 18.5 percent, in the company that makes the Yugo. Indeed, Fiat boasts that half the cars sold in Eastern Europe are Fiat derivatives.
Other Eastern auto makers have also relied on Western assistance. Dacia, the Romanian auto maker, has worked with Renault. Skoda, Czechoslovakia's state-owned auto maker, asked Bertone, a Turin-based consultant, for assistance in designing and engineering its sporty Favorit. Porsche helped on the power train.
Thanks to Western help, the most advanced East European car makers, considered to be Skoda and Zastava with Lada placing third, are only a half-dozen years behind the West, industry analysts say. But the most backward manufacturers, like Dacia and East Germany's Trabant, are two decades behind in areas like sturdiness, design and pollution control.
''They don't have many of the more interesting gizmos and goodies that the Western companies have: multivalve engines, sophisticated suspensions, optional four-wheel drive,'' said Karl Ludvigsen, president of his own automobile consulting firm in London. ''They need Western help. They have not been active enough over the years in improving the cars to have sufficient indigenous engineering capabilities. They didn't have to worry about updating to keep up with consumer demand.''
Since the Iron Curtain began to crumble last year, Eastern and Western auto makers have engaged in an intricate mating dance.
In East Germany, Volkswagen linked up with Trabant to build 250,000 Polos a year in a $2.9 billion project, while G.M.'s Opel division joined Wartburg, East Germany's other auto maker, to produce 150,000 Kadetts a year.
In Czechoslovakia, virtually everyone is pursuing Skoda, considered by many to be Eastern Europe's top car producer. Industry officials say Volkswagen has the inside track.
In Hungary, Ford plans to invest $80 million in a components plant, while G.M. plans to build 200,000 engines and assemble 30,000 Kadetts a year.
''This is the most exciting market around,'' said Thomas R. Mason, vice president for sales at G.M. Europe. ''It's all business we haven't had before.'' One reason for setting up factories in Eastern Europe, he explained, is that many countries in the region restrict imports from Western manufacturers unless the companies build plants in those countries to generate hard currency.
Fiat has won more than its share of partners, in part because of its long history in the East, which includes selling cars and components to pre-revolutionary Russia in 1912.
No doubt Fiat's biggest challenge now is to insure quality in the Eastern-made cars that it sells to the West. Fiat has strained to improve its reputation for quality over the past decade, and the last thing it wants is to see that slip.
''Are we going to be able to reach the level of quality that will be adequate for the Western market? Our answer is yes,'' Mr. Gallo said. ''This doesn't mean it will be an easy task.''
 
The Search for Dealers
 He knows that under Communism, FSM workers were pressured to meet production quotas, and often let quality slide. He has heard about the Polish book called, ''126 Jokes About the Fiat 126.'' And so Fiat is sending 200 production experts to FSM from Italy to make sure that quality is good and the assembly plant runs smoothly.
Setting up dealerships in Eastern Europe is also a major problem. Instead of using dealers to sell cars, FSM and other Eastern auto makers relied on government offices where consumers trudged in to add their names to multiyear waiting lists.
''It is more bureaucratic distribution than a marketing system,'' Mr. Gallo said.
Fiat has not begun setting up a dealer system in Poland, but it and other auto makers have rushed to establish networks in fast-changing East Germany. G.M., for example, has established 300 dealerships there.
''The largest challenge is finding the individual entrepreneurs,'' said Mr. Mason, the G.M. vice president. ''The auto dealer is probably the epitome of the free-market entrepreneur, but these markets haven't had entrepreneurs for 40 years.''
The litany of problems for auto makers setting up in the East also includes coping with language differences and a painfully outmoded telephone system, locating dependable components suppliers and finding housing and making life comfortable for employees sent from the West.
 
Keeping Above Water
 But for Ryszard Welter, FSM's chairman, Fiat's involvement means salvation, rather than problems. At a time when the Polish Government's crash program to battle hyperinflation has caused purchasing power and industrial production to plummet, Fiat is helping to keep FSM above water. In addition to lending money to build the new plant, Fiat is providing cash to help finance FSM's inventories.
Fiat is also providing so much know-how that Mr. Welter says other Polish executives come around to ask him about Western technology and business techniques. The technology the new Fiat model brings to FSM includes rust-proof steel, catalytic converters, shiny metallic paint, electrostatic painting equipment and 100 robots for precision work and quality control.
''It's very unlikely that we would have the money or technological means to produce a car that's as good,'' Mr. Welter said. FSM's dream, he says, is to develop and market a car by itself, but he admitted this would be difficult ''because we are not well known in the European market and we don't have our own distribution network.''
As for FSM's 26,000 employees, Fiat's involvement is a godsend because it is giving FSM a future when many obsolete Polish factories have none. ''It's a big chance for us,'' said Jerzy Fedorczyk, a quality-control inspector.
 
THE BIG ONE: YELABUGA
 FIAT'S plans to help build 900,000 cars a year in the Soviet Union could become the largest Western project in Eastern Europe. Some industry executives say the manufacturing complex at Yelabuga will cost $7 billion, but Fiat officials say their equity will be just a few hundred million dollars.
Fiat will play many roles. First, in a contract for hard currency, it will provide design and production expertise for a factory that is to produce, by late 1992, 300,000 cars a year modeled on its small Panda.
For a second plant, Fiat is acquiring a 30 percent stake in a joint venture to produce, by late 1993, 300,000 cars a year of a new model the size of Fiat's somewhat bigger Uno. Fiat will export one-third of these to the West.
''To demonstrate that these are quality cars, we will bring some back to sell in Western Europe,'' said Cesare Romiti, Fiat's chief executive.
Then Fiat is negotiating to help with a third factory that aims to assemble 300,000 mid-sized cars a year like the Fiat Tipo by 1995. Fiat will also join a venture to build a highly robotized plant to produce 900,000 engines and gear boxes a year.
Moscow chose Fiat to be its partner partly because it was so pleased with its 1966 contract with the car maker under which Fiat licensed its 124 model and helped design a 650,000-car-a-year plant.
Questions about the Soviet Union's political stability do not frighten Fiat, said Francesco Gallo, Fiat's director of international operations. He says Fiat, which helps assemble cars in dozens of countries, has learned to control risk.
''Outside of Europe you don't find many countries with social and political situations more stable than in Eastern Europe,'' he said. ''You must be satisfied that the risk is controllable.''

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris;
How Much Will Hussein Try to Grab?

 BODY:
Is Iraq's Saddam Hussein another Hitler, who will gobble up neighbor after neighbor, until finally stopped?
That view was spreading in America as last week ended, and with it a feeling of powerlessness to affect the outcome. Bombing Iraq would risk destroying the very oil that provides the United States with a national interest in the Persian Gulf. For now, economic warfare seems to be the order of the day. 
On Friday, as rumors spread of further Iraqi millitary action, perhaps against Saudi Arabia, financial markets quaked and fell. They stabilized only after the Soviet Union forecast an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.
Oil prices zoomed upward, as traders bet that Mr. Hussein's original goal - $25 oil - would be realized. Only a few weeks ago, September crude oil futures were around $17 per barrel. On Friday, they traded above $26, although the price slipped to $24.49 by the end of the day.
Mr. Hussein seems to have the upper hand on oil supply. With his troops in Kuwait, it is unlikely that other oil exporters will wish to incur his wrath by discounting crude quotes. But demand may be another matter. There are adequate crude inventories now, and with the United States economy limping along, any substantial rise in oil could be enough to bring on a real recession, which in turn could force oil prices lower.
The United States would be in a better position if it used a lot less oil. Energy taxes years ago would have cut the budget deficits and encouraged conservation. But Congress was paralyzed by regional rivalries and the fear of reaction.
The sudden rise in oil prices leaves the Federal Reserve in a quandary, facing the decision whether to ease credit and fight recession or tighten it and fight inflation. Short-term rates fell, which may reflect a flight to safety or a hope the Fed will ease. But long-term rates rose, signaling that traders are not persuaded a recession is inevitable.
The panic hit stock markets around the world, with oil and precious metals stocks up and almost everything else down on heavy volume. But there was some buying late Friday, and share prices recovered about half what they had lost earlier in the day. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week down 88.86 points, or 3.1 percent, to 2,809.65.
Small stocks generally performed even worse, with the Russell 2,000 down 5.1 percent for the week, and briefly trading on Friday at its lowest level in 18 months. The behavior of those stocks, not usually involved in program trading, coupled with the fact that index arbitrage was virtually impossible for most of Friday under a new Big Board rule, should at least keep program traders from getting the rap for the latest fall. Don't bet on it.
So far, it appears that individual investors have refused to join in the selling spree, betting that this sharp fall, like ones before it, is temporary and not a precursor of worse things. Whether or not that position proves to be wise may depend on how effective the world is at halting Mr. Hussein.

HEADLINE: Currency;
The Dollar Spirals Down

 BODY:
THE dollar fell just short of its post-World War II low against the German mark last week. Without Saddam Hussein it might have made it. The Iraqi President's invasion of Kuwait sparked buying of the dollar, a safe haven, on Thursday and there was enough support left on Friday to offset a worrisome economic report. The American unemployment rate jumped to 5.5 percent in July, from 5.2 percent, giving another signal that the sluggish economy may be near a recession. But because of the unrest in the Middle East, traders would not dump dollars in anticipation of lower interest rates. The dollar still closed at 1.5875 against the mark, its second-lowest level since the war. With any relaxation of tensions in the Middle East, the low of 1.5700 should not stand much longer.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Unsettling Iraq Factor

BYLINE: Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
SADDAM HUSSEIN, the President of Iraq, bet that Kuwait was vulnerable and it was. So were most of the world's markets, which tumbled dramatically after Iraq's invasion of the emirate last week as the outlook clouded for oil prices, inflation, economic growth and the balance of power in the Middle East. .
The markets had been under stress before the invasion. Interest rates around the world are high. Many economies are slowing or are growing more slowly than anticipated. Earnings reports are coming in lower than expected - and the prospect is for less to come. 
The Amercan stock market was weakening and Japan's was already reeling. West Germany's market was worried by higher interest rates and, again, the cost of German unification. Italy has problems with its coalition government. Britain is near a recession.
Hong Kong, which had been reaching new heights regularly, was stunned by the invasion, which sent the Hang Seng index tumbling by 111.69 points or 3.4 percent. Oil-rich Norway, whose all-share index had been propelled to new highs four days last week by rising oil prices and the expectation that they would rise further after the invasion, fell 1.6 percent Friday under the weight of inflationary fears.
''We've been skittish on these markets anyway,'' said Madhav Dhar, global strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. ''This was not a healthy environment. We expected markets to roll off anyway. And this will aggravate that.''
Cliche though it is, the only certainity now is uncertainity and it alone is enough to roil stock markets. The unknown - what the Iraqi leader might do next - kept traders and analysts close to their computer screens Friday and responding - by buying dollars as a safe haven or dumping stocks because of inflationary and interest rate fears - to bulletins like ''State Department says Iraqi troops within six miles of Saudi border'' or ''Shevardnadze says U.S.S.R. 'has been assured' Iraq to pull out soon.''
But about as fast as the Iraqi forces moved into Kuwait City, economists and analysts around the world were examining the longer-term impact, pushing numbers through their black boxes and churning out estimates of the inflationary, interest rate and economic growth consequences both of the invasion and of higher oil prices. These scenarios, none of them very good, will be digested by investors this week and should add to the downward pressure on markets.
Kieth Skeoch, chief economist at James Capel & Company in London, estimates that with a $25 per barrel price for oil, inflation in the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada could be five-tenths of 1 percentage point higher in the next year. And economic growth could be cut by as much as four-tenths of 1 percentage point from what it might have been. For the United States and Britain, whose economies could be near the brink of a recession already, this not comforting.
Guy Rigdon, director of strategy at UBS Phillips & Drew in London, said he expected interest rates in Europe will be pushed up about half of a percentage point. And in Japan, he said, the oil price rise (he is also assuming $25 a barrel) will insure that the Bank of Japan will raise the official discount rate, now 5.25 percent, and keep interest rates higher longer.
He estimates that, based on this rise in interest rates, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index, which fell 4.4 percent last week to close at 29,515.76, should drop below 28,000, the low it reached during the market collapse in the first quarter of the year. In Europe, he expects that markets could fall 10 percent to 20 percent from where they were.
Last week, West Germany was down 4.1 percent; Britain, whose decline was somewhat offset by the positive effect of higher oil prices on its North Sea oil production, fell 2.0 percent; France, 4.9 percent, Spain, 5.5 percent, and Italy, 4.7 percent.
Merrill Lynch, according to its chief international equity strategist, Thomas Robinson, has already changed its investment levels in several markets, cutting them in Japan and the United states and raising them in the few countries that will beneift from higher oil prices, like Norway, or are not as dependent on oil, like Switzerland.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
For Foreign Investors, the Dow's Direction Is Relative

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
THE eruption of a shooting crisis at one of the world's pulse points typically sends nervous international investors scurrying for the safety of the dollar. Sure enough, when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday, the greenback soared - but only for a few hours. Then, the dollar sagged again, as investors pondered the impact costlier oil could have on the fragile United States economy.
Those concerns already had been felt in currency markets. On Tuesday, the dollar fell within hailing distance of its postwar low against the German mark - 1.57 marks on Dec. 31, 1987. German investors have watched the take-home value of the Dow industrials tumble more than 11 percent in the last year. For British investors, the decline has been 7 percent.
Japanese investors see the market differently. With the weakness of the yen, the Dow is worth about 14 percent more in Tokyo today that it was a year ago. And for the American home team? At the close on Friday, the Dow was 5.9 percent ahead of its level a year ago.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Utilities Get Some Takeover Action

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
BEFORE the eruptions in the Middle East sent the theorists back to their computer keyboards on Thursday, the Dow Jones utilities had been enjoying a rare market rally, gaining nearly 5 percent over the past two weeks. The reasons were largely defensive, analysts said. With the fearsome gyrations of the Dow industrials and the damage inflicted on the Dow transports by the recent decline in United Airlines shares, the dull world of electricity production - all those reliable dividends, all that recession-proof revenue - seemed especially peaceful.
The serenity scenario seemed to evaporate with the invasion of Kuwait. Utilities, after all, are purchasers of oil, and oil seems destined to become more expensive. Not only that, the pessimists argued, but oil-driven inflation might prompt monetary officials to boost interest rates, making the yields on utility stocks less attractive than those on bonds. All that second-guessing took its toll on the fledgling rally, and the Dow utilities index ended the week at 209.7, down roughly 11 percent since the start of the year. 
What is not yet reflected in the index, however - but what has become increasingly clear to some money managers and analysts - is the emergence of a slow-acting takeover virus in the utility industry. The first hostile takeover battle is playing itself out in Kansas. Some patient money managers are already cashing in on an arbitrage opportunity provided by the pending merger of two California utilities. And others are quietly stocking up on shares of some Ohio companies they see as possible takeover candidates.
All of which suggests that whichever way the global tug-of-war goes, life will be far from dull in the utility patch.
The local fireworks broke out on July 23, when the Kansas City Power & Light Company offered $27 a share, or $875 million, for the Kansas Gas and Electric Company. There have been friendly unions between utilities, but this first hostile deal has shaped up as a classic ''barbarian'' battle. Board meetings were hastily convened, at which somber directors weighed the pending offer. Squads of lawyers filed competing briefs on behalf of each utility, and shareholders chimed in with lawsuits of their own.
On Thursday, with the market's attention riveted on the Middle East, the directors of Kansas Gas turned down the Kansas City Power offer as ''inadequate,'' and said the acquisition would hurt the employees, customers and communities served by Kansas Gas. The rejection certainly didn't hurt Kansas City Power; with the utility stocks in a rout, the shares of Kansas Gas closed the week below $24, 11 percent less than the amount Kansas City Power had offered.
Analysts are predicting renewed bidding. Kansas City Power is seeking additional generating capacity and its takeover target has capacity to spare, said Barry Abramson, an energy analyst with Prudential Bache. Thus, the bid probably would have been made regardless of the drubbing the stock market has given utility stocks.
''Kansas City Power & Light sees a long-term strategic issue here, and was just taking advantage of a price decline,'' Mr. Abrahamson said. Given the breadth of that price decline in the utility sector, are other takeovers likely? ''Yes,'' he said, ''but I think they will be done for selective reasons, not as a wholesale consolidation of the industry.''
One deal in the works is the friendly merger of San Diego Gas & Electric into Southern California Edison, a unit of SCEcorp. But even friendly utility mergers move at a glacial pace, said Christopher Wiles, assistant vice president and portfolio manager for Federated Management in Pittsburgh. The deal was approved by the companies in November 1988, and officers of the San Diego utility predict that they will not get a green light from regulators before 1991.
But meanwhile, money-managers have not been idle. The merger agreement calls for investors to get 1.3 shares of SCEcorp for each share of San Diego Gas & Electric. As of Friday, 1.3 shares of SCEcorp cost $49.73 on the New York Stock Exchange, while San Diego cost $43.50 a share. ''So if you want to own Southern California Edison, and you think this merger is eventually going to go through, you can buy San Diego and get the SoCal at a 12 percent discount,'' Mr. Wiles said. (He does, and he has.) The prospects for utility takeovers are shaped as much by regional factors as by the stock market. The Pacific Northwest has power capacity to spare, and fast-growing utilities in nearby California seem likely to need additional capacity. Nevertheless, Mr. Abramson is not excited about the takeover prospects in that quarter. The weak utilities in the Southwest - including the El Paso Electric Company and the Tucson Electric Power Company - are so eager to sell their excess capacity, he said, that ''it is a buyer's market there now.''
Not so in Ohio, said Mr. Wiles, who has been investing in American Electric Power, which operates in six other states, the Cincinnati Gas & Electric Company and DPL Inc., which owns the Dayton Power & Light Company. All are solid utilities trading at prices that offer above-average yields, he said, because ''people are still punishing them'' for the mess they made of the Zimmer nuclear project several years ago.
''But now they are converting the plant to coal,'' Mr. Wiles said, ''and that project is coming in ahead of schedule and under budget.'' Although the coal conversion, being deftly managed by American Electric Power, raises concerns about future air-quality restrictions, Mr. Wiles believes that today's stock prices fully reflect those worries.
''Of course, you can't play these stocks just as takeovers, because those deals can take so long,'' he said, ''so you have to like the underlying company.'' Still, he added, American Electric Power is by far the strongest of the Zimmer trio and ''it wouldn't surprise me if A.E.P. bought one of its partners, most likely Cincinnati.''

LENGTH: 1502 words

HEADLINE: Life After Wall Street: Less Stress - Less Money, Too

BYLINE: By DEBORAH L. JACOBS; Deborah L. Jacobs, based in Brooklyn, writes on business issues.

 BODY:
She was an arbitrageur and he was a trader, and before they reached their mid-30's, they had a combined annual income that sometimes exceeded a half million dollars. In the days of 1980's glory - or high-speed greed, depending on the point of view - they were like many of their Wall Street colleagues: always running, and making more money than they ever thought possible.
Then Ann and Richard Adrian walked away from it all. Today, scattering across the country, people like the Adrians have embarked upon new and very different lives. Some have made the change voluntarily and, because they had had substantial savings, with relative financial ease. But many, forced out of their brokerage firms or investment banks by cutback after cutback since Oct. 19, 1987, have been unwilling converts to the life of lower pay. 
Whether or not they miss Wall Street, few have the option of returning, at least for now. Forecasts of further layoffs continue to sweep through downtown's winding, narrow streets. ''Unless there's a clear and rapid upturn in the business,'' at least half of the estimated 50,000 professionals who will have lost their jobs between the fall of '87 and the end of '90, may be expected to leave Wall Street, said John Artise, vice president at the New York outplacement firm Drake Beam Morin Inc. What, then, has become of the Adrians and the others? On Wall Street, Ann and Richard Adrian hedged their investment bets against inflation, rising stock prices or fluctuations in foreign currencies. Now, their hedges are against roses or, gardenias, say, as they have sold their Manhattan condominium, moved to the Hamptons on Long Island and started a gardening and landscape business.
The couple had dreamed of working for themselves ever since they met in 1983 at an office softball game. Mr. Adrian, formerly of Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company once had wanted to be a forest ranger, but switched his major at Yale from forestry to economics. A gardening and landscape business thus combined two interests.
Ms. Adrian was an elementary school teacher earning $8,000 in 1977 before she went to work on Wall Street, winding up at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. ''The stock market crash and slow year after made the decision easier,'' she said of their dual career change.
She and her husband had substantial assets and few debts and, thus, the luxury of devoting themselves with relative ease to the new life. They have been living on their savings for a year, plan to take landscaping courses this fall at the State University of New York at Farmingdale, buy a pickup truck and learn to operate a bulldozer.
On Wall Street, Mr. Adrian said, ''You're on every minute when you're at work. Now you have to worry about plants growing - but the response time's not as fast.''
They say they have no desire to go back to the Street. ''It's not like we've become illiterate about business,'' said Ms. Adrian, who still follows market developments. But now she can go water-skiing before breakfast. RICHARD DANBECK, 48, who says he had planned to leave Wall Street when he reached the age of 50, moved up the timetable after laying off junior associates whom he had trained.
A salesman of fixed-income securities who earned about $200,000 a year, Mr. Danbeck has become a Buddhist and is getting a master's degree in East Asian studies at Columbia University. He said his new schedule gives him more time with his family. ''You may have had time before, but you come home and you're so into yourself being a hitter that you don't really listen,'' said Mr. Danbeck, who used to leave his New Jersey home at 5:00 A.M. for the commute to Wall Street and sometimes did not return until 9 or 10 P.M.
While the Adrians and Mr. Danbeck left Wall Street by choice, many others have been forced out. Diane Gianfortune said her ''entire world'' - including her marriage - fell apart. Having risen from secretary to senior associate in Salomon Brothers's municipal finance department, Ms. Gianfortune, now 40, spent 14 years at the company and was earning roughly $100,000 annually when the bubble burst.
Unable to find a comparable job, she turned a hobby into a business and started Cheshire Gourmet Cheesecakes Inc. - named for the grinning cat in ''Alice in Wonderland.'' Her specialty, sold at the Four Bridges Shopping Plaza on Staten Island, is a (large) bite-size cheesecake that costs 60 cents. ''Wall Street took my heart,'' Ms. Gianfortune said. ''No matter what you did, someone else higher up always seemed to get the credit.''
Paul Lehman also opted for food. Now, less than three years after he quit his job as a stockbroker, his Steamer Hot Cocoa Inc. is in the black. Why did he leave his old life? Boredom, he says.
Despite all the complaining about Wall Street, many would like to return. It isn't easy.
Rita De Silvio, a job counselor whose New York headhunting firm specializes in brokerages, said that even ''the creme de la creme traders can't get jobs commensurate with their skills.''
Nella Barkley, president of the Crystal-Barkley Corporation, a New York career counseling firm, said that to help overcome the traumatic losses of security, prestige, job, title and steady income she advises clients to write each of their skills on a separate business-sized card. It's a ''subliminal message'' that they have assets apart from their jobs, she said.
A transition period of at least six months typically follows being dismissed or quitting without first having something else in place. And many who leave the Street are reluctant to speak openly about it.
One investment banker in his 40's, for example, who lost his job in December demanded anonymity in disclosing that he had spent the winter teaching skiing in Vermont.
Another Wall Street refugee - let go as a trader with a large bank, spent eight months looking for other employment before he found the only viable option, with a Florida arbitrage boutique. ''I was too caught up in the whole Wall Street machine,'' he said, adding that a year ago he never could have considered Florida. ''It took losing my job to see there was a whole country of people that had been making substantial livings outside of the canyons of Wall Street.''
Among the related alternatives to Wall Street are jobs in small businesses or consulting services that draw on skills or contacts in financial services. Laid off last year from a job as a fixed-income strategist at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. that earned him nearly $150,000 annually, Michael F. Carr, 55 years old, looked briefly for other jobs, and then started his own portfolio management firm in Lodi, N.J. Ronni Burns, once a regional manager in limited partnerships at E. F. Hutton with a six-figure income, now conducts training seminars in the sale of financial products. WARREN HUDGENS, once an investment banker earning $125,000 a year, is 39 years old and a househusband with four children in Whitefish, Mont. (population: 3,500). The family is living in a brand-new, 3,000-square-foot house (purchased at a foreclosure sale for $80,000) on his wife's $25,000 salary as a part-time occupational therapist at a local hospital, plus about $15,000 in earnings on savings. The Hudgens have bought a cabin on 40 acres overlooking Glacier National Park. Mr. Hudgens uses the 400,000 frequent flyer miles he accumulated during his days as ''a hyperactive type A,'' to fund an occasional family vacation.
Though he said he treasures the time he spends with his family, Mr. Hudgens still subscribes to New York Magazine and reads about $100-a-person restaurant dinners that he could afford when he was working 80 hours a week and earning more than $125,000 per year. And occasionally, he said, he asks himself: ''How can I no longer be relevant?''
 
LIVING WITH LESS
The income cuts for those leaving high-stakes Wall Street are by no means easy.
Richard Danbeck, no longer pulling down $200,000 a year as a securities salesman, went back to school in January of last year and kept thinking ''Isn't this great, it's America.'' Then, he said, ''You realize that the February bonus check isn't there and you have no income.''
Mary Ann Sessler, formerly at Bankers Trust, once spent at least $100 a month to dry-clean the silks she wore to work. When she quit the bank to work in an adoption agency, Spence-Chapin Services to Families and Children, her income was cut in half. She has used more than a third of her savings, now walks instead of taking taxis, entertains at home rather than at restaurants and has switched to a cleaner who charges by the pound, not the garment.
Diane Gianfortune, although her last name in Italian means ''great fortune'' and she once earned $100,000 at Salomon Brothers, is the sole support of two teen-agers. She used her severance and bonus from Salomon to start a gourmet cheesecake company, and last year took a second mortgage on her home in order to expand her business. ''It hasn't been an easy two years,'' she said.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Boris Yeltsin, Man of the Hour?

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
Vladimir Kvint, Professor of Political Economy of the U.S.S.R. and a former professor at the Communist Higher Party School in Moscow, is a member of the ''Siberian school'' of market-oriented economists. Professor Kvint, who is currently a distinguished lecturer at Fordham University, spoke with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times through an interpreter.
 
Q. In June the Communist Party Congress met in Moscow and President Gorbachev emerged as the party's undisputed leader. What did Mr. Gorbachev win?
 
Professor Kvint: Gorbachev's victory was a Pyrrhic one. Heated discussions took place at the congress, but they were of no interest to anyone in the country. Why do I say this? Because it was very clear that the congress was attended only by people who are not really interested in the democratization of Soviet society and of the economy. 
 
Q. But didn't the congress reaffirm perestroika and give Mr. Gorbachev support for moving ahead more rapidly with the economic reforms?
 
Professor Kvint: In mid-1989, later than all the rest of the people, Gorbachev understood that he failed with his first economic reforms. He then moved immediately to protect himself from these failures by creating the institution of the presidency. From that point on he became a dictator in the sense that as President he is not responsible to the Parliament or the party.
Let me give you an example. Three weeks ago, Gorbachev issued a decree taking away the rank, medals and awards of General Oleg D. Kalugin, a general in the K.G.B. General Kalugin did not hamper perestroika's progress in any way but he made disclosures against the K.G.B. during the congress. It was the first time in the history of the Soviet Union that a K.G.B. general spoke out against the K.G.B. Kalugin said the K.G.B. still exerted total control over the Soviet people. He charged that the K.G.B. still listens to everyone's telephone conversations and that it still follows foreigners, and so on.
It was a brave step on the part of the general, but now he is not a general anymore. Gorbachev deprived him of everything he had gained during his life for criticizing the K.G.B.
 
Q. Does Mr. Gorbachev have the power to bring about true economic reform?
 
Professor Kvint: Soon, I think, Boris Yeltsin will take power away from Gorbachev. On June 12, Russia, under President Yeltsin, declared the sovereignty of Russian laws over Soviet laws. The Baltic republics did it earlier; the Ukraine did it two weeks ago.
Gorbachev will remain president of the Soviet Union, but his power will largely resemble the power of a president in a country where the prime minister is the main figure. That is why Gorbachev decided to join with Yeltsin last week to create a commission for economic reform. He is simply acknowledging that Yeltsin is now emerging as the country's most powerful leader.
The United States should recognize the role of Yeltsin as the real leader of the nation. After all, who stopped the blockade of Lithuania? It was Yeltsin. The day after he was elected president of the Russian republic, he declared that Russia would establish direct ties with Lithuania even if the Soviet Union wouldn't. That ended the blockade of Lithuania because Russia has 92 percent of the Soviet Union's oil. Although oil production is down, Russia could supply the United States with 2 to 2.5 times the amount of oil Iraq now sells it.
 
Q. How will we see Mr. Yeltsin's power emerge?
 
Professor Kvint: Yeltsin has said openly his way is the way to the market economy. When he left the Communist Party at the congress in June, it was not just a gesture.
Mr. Yeltsin already abolished more than half of the ministries in the Russian republic. He also created something unheard of before. Out of 28 ministers in Russia, he created 8 that are without ministries. Each has only 20 people working for him. The purpose of these eight ministers is to cut the central Soviet bureaucracy.
For example, although the oil resources are in Russia, they are governed by two central Government ministries. These two ministries in Moscow deprive the oil industry of its independence. Yeltsin wants to abolish the power of these ministries and make the enterprises totally independent.
 
Q. And after that?
 
Professor Kvint: The next step then is to make Russia totally independent of the Soviet Union in hard currency. The Soviet Union has always had a monopoly on foreign trade. Yeltsin has already established a new bank for foreign economic relations for the Russian Republic. This bank will reallocate to Russia all of the hard-currency profits that now go to the Soviet Union from Russia's exports. Now all of the profits from Siberia's oil and gas exports go to the U.S.S.R. Yeltsin will keep those profits in Russia. Q. President Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Kohl of West Germany have been talking about helping the Soviet Union by extending credits and aid. President Bush has been reluctant to join in. Which course is correct?
 
Professor Kvint: Bush's course is so correct I am amazed. The Europeans have proposed giving about $12 billion in aid to the Soviet Union. But the real issue is not how much aid to give, but to whom. Aid given to the central Government not only will be misused, it will be harmful. Today, if you give the central Government $12 billion, it means that they won't have to cut $12 billion from the military budget. It means that the Soviet Union can continue to give money to Castro and Libya and to other negative regimes. Don't forget, the Soviet Union, based on the size of its economy, gives proportionately six times more aid than the United States.
But even if all of the $12 billion in aid were to be used correctly with none of it going to the military, I have calculated that it would at best add only 0.5 percent to the Soviet Union's rate of economic growth. In 1977, when exports of Western industrial goods to the Soviet Union were at their highest, they also contributed only about 0.5 percent to its rate of growth.
President Bush's approach is right. First send in the specialists to look at the country, then give aid to specific projects, not the central Government.
 
Q. Do you see the climate improving for foreign investment in the Soviet Union?
 
Professor Kvint: Each region is different. Siberia has the best situation. Azerbaijan, on the other hand, is a very dangerous territory. But next to it, there is Dagestan, also a Muslim republic, but it is a republic that is stable.
In the near future, political risk will be reduced in the Baltic republics as they acquire real economic independence. But the key fact to remember is that the Soviet Union should not be thought of as a single unit. In fact, it will very soon cease to be a single state.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vladimir Kvint (Neil Boenzi/The New York Times); drawing.

HEADLINE: A Testament to Sexism at High-Tech Companies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was disturbed by the voice in Howard Muson's article (''One Company's Short-Lived Loyalties,'' July 8). Thousands of people get laid off every day but perhaps only a few have a writer/husband who tells the world how terribly the ''little woman'' was treated. It would have helped all of us had she told the story herself. 
I have worked as an employee, executive and senior consultant with Fortune 200 computer companies and entrepreneurial high-technology companies over the last seven years of a 25-year professional career. Women are easy targets in the high-tech world, and this article fuels the controversy that ''this is a man's business.''
In my high-tech career, I have witnessed and experienced a discomforting amount of ''women bashing'' by male executives at all levels who are frightened about losing control and resort to attacking others whom they perceive as a threat to their economic well-being. Women who fight back are in a no-win situation. If the battle escalates, the corporate survival instinct still appears to favor the male.
I have also met and worked with a number of very bright and talented female managers who do an outstanding job as long as things are going their way. But as soon as things start to get rough, too many of them announce quite publicly that it is time for them to ''start their families,'' or whatever else will remove them from the fray.
I am disturbed by both of these trends. When I look at high-tech companies today, I see very few female managers in the pipeline for any executive office. If American business is to succeed in the global economy, we need to create environments in which the best and the brightest make it to the top.
 
JUDITH H. CAREYS
North Chelmsford, Mass., July 7
 
The writer is president of Delphi International, management consultants.

HEADLINE: Michael Porter Redux: Yes, but . . .

 BODY:
In an article on the July 22 Forum page, Michael E. Porter, a professor of business administration at the Harvard Business School, discussed the issue of American competitiveness (''Japan Isn't Playing by Different Rules''). Professor Porter believes that the United States has been moving away from one of its fundamental principles - faith in competition - having been seduced by a mistaken view of the reasons for Japan's success in the world marketplace. He argues that a competitive ''home environment'' is a prerequisite for global success.
Some of the letters received in response to the article follow.
 
MITI Is Still Going Strong - Just Look at Boeing
 
To the Editor:
 Professor Porter demonstrates a woeful ignorance of big business and the economic situation in Japan. He argues that there is no difference between American and Japanese business environments and insists that Japanese industrial policy and guidance by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry and other Japanese agencies is either nonexistent or ineffective. He says Japanese companies no longer participate in the consortiums and other Government-sponsored programs that characterized the successes of Japan in the past. 
This is simply at variance with the facts. To take just one area, there are 70 consortiums and Government-sponsored research efforts in high-definition television. Together, Government and industry have invested more than $2 billion in this important emerging technology. Likewise, there are major business and government consortiums involved in supercomputing, software automation, biotechnology, advanced ceramics, telecommunications and aerospace. Indeed, MITI orchestrated the deal between Boeing and the Japanese aerospace industry for development of the new 777.
These facts, which most observers of the Japanese industrial scene are well aware of, contrast sharply with the agonizing debate over ''picking winners and losers'' in the United States. Clearly the Japanese are not doing what we are doing.
 
CLYDE V. PRESTOWITZ Jr.
July 25, Washington
 
The writer is president of the Economic Strategy Institute and a former Commerce Department official.
 
Wall Street Scared The Daring Out of Industry
 
To the Editor:
 Michael Porter's powerful article is another right and proper wake-up call to American industry.
But he does not note that during the merger and acquisition-happy decade of the 1980's, Wall Street put enormous pressure on American chief executives to reduce costs and improve margins. The very idea of taking even prudent risk fell deep in fear's shadow. This same pressure did not exist in Japan where market share was the goal.
During the same period of wealth generation, the Nikkei average tracked the Dow Jones industrial average almost point for point. Isn't that curious in our free-market system?
 
ROBERT L. DILENSCHNEIDER
President and C.E.O.
Hill and Knowlton Inc.
New York, July 23
 
Educators Arise, Business Needs You
 
To The Editor:
 Professor Porter's observations should not be missed by American educators. His characterization of a ''national environment'' that ''promotes rapid progress'' is reminiscent of the recent call by David Kearns, president of the Xerox Corporation, for business to tell education what its expectations are and then to support politicians and educators who, in Kearns' words, ''are willing to risk failure to gain success.''
It is an exceptional time to move beyond complaints and toward decisive action.
 
WILLIAM BAGLEY
Choate Rosemary Hall School
Wallingford, Conn., July 24
 
Stop the Rhetoric, Let the Exports Begin!
 
To The Editor:
 If we as a nation are going to compete with the Japanese, we need far less ideological rhetoric and far more exporting.
The United States, and in particular our high-technology companies, have products and services that are sought after around the world. Recent studies by the Commerce Department have concluded that our small and medium-size companies can export early and profitably, competing well with their Japanese counterparts. If this is the case, what's the problem?
The problem is, quite simply, that only five out of every hundred United States companies export. The rest stay home, content to watch their domestic market share erode to foreign competition, often Japanese.
These companies haven't realized that exporting makes good business sense. It is both necessary and profitable. After all, international markets are four times greater than the domestic market; 95 percent of the world's population is outside the United States, and global population is increasing 70 percent faster than the United States population.
Recognizing the window of opportunity now open for American exports is only the first step. Small and medium-size United States companies interested in seizing this moment to start an exporting venture need to develop international sales strategies and aggressively pursue overseas markets.
Now is the time for United States firms to take advantage of these global opportunities and regain our leading position in world trade. The payoffs from exporting will be increased profits, a strengthened economy, a better future and more jobs for our American workers.
The message for the 90's is clear: Export or expire!
 
JOSEPH P. GLYNN
Boston, July 23
 
The writer is president of Glynn International Inc., an international trade management firm.
 
Military Secrecy Did Business In
 
To the Editor:
 Professor Porter has ignored the pivotal reasons for our loss of global competitiveness.
It's not that Japan, Germany and the United States are playing by different rules. All three have strived for rapid improvement, innovation and upgrading as much as for economies of scale. The difference is one of strategies and priorities for industrial-economic security and growth.
American priorities and strategies have been for military-industrial growth, while Japanese and German priorities and strategies have emphasized civil-industrial growth.
For decades, about 60 percent of American scientists and engineers have been employed in the development and production of weapon systems, a process conducted in secret and exempted from accountability in a competitive open market - a requirement for civil-industrial competitiveness and growth.
Consequently, cost overruns, delays in deliveries and gaps between planned and actual performance capabilities of United States weapons, nuclear and space systems haveJU grown steadily. But our manufacturers of those systems continue to grow without risk of failure, because they serve vital requirements of the United States security establishment.
And yet our industrial and economic security has steadily eroded because our executives have become indolent, not only because of the exemptions from open-market accountability, but also from their dependence for growth on pork barreling by security powers.
Such companies as General Motors and General Electric used to be paragons of American national and global competitive leadership in markets for automotive and household electronic products. But, since acquiring military equipment manufacturing capabilities, they have lost their competitive standing in the consumer markets. Meanwhile, Japanese and German manufacturers of consumer products have based their growth in competitive markets on new technology developed by and acquired from United States defense contractors.
In the early 60's, to preserve the strength of the United States dollar in international monetary exchanges, the United States Government launched the Pentagon foreign arms sales program and canceled its policies for cooperative development and deployment of common conventional weapons with its democratic allies.
During the 80's, the United States Government pursuaded allies of Japan and West Germany to cooperate in efforts to devalue the United States dollar to decrease prices of United States products in export markets, thus reducing American trade deficits. Meanwhile, however, United States manufacturers have continued to close factories in the United States and to open them in industrializing countries of the Asian rim, Mexico or South America. And Japanese and European manufacturers have exploited advantages of the devalued dollar by building and operating factories in the United States.
In effect, the United States Government and industrial leaders have been more concerned about the security and vitality of the United States dollar than about the security and vitality of United States competitiveness, productivity and job security for American citizens. They have persisted with the growth of the United States military, even though such growth has exacerbated American trade deficits, financial deficits and political insecurity.
 
PROF. ROBERT E. McGARRAH
University of Massachusetts School of Management
Amherst, Mass.
 
The writer is a former assistant director of international research and engineering at the Defense Department.
 
The Role of Competition in Two Great Depressions
 
To the Editor:
 Michael Porter complains that ''America has been retreating from one of the most fundamental principles that has distinguished our nation from others: our faith in competition.'' This sweeping defense is historically inaccurate.
Competition itself has widely been identified as the major cause of the two Great Depressions of the past century (in the 1890's and the 1930's). In the 1930-33 period, Herbert Hoover, Franklin Roosevelt and Bernard Baruch described the problem as ''cutthroat'' and ''destructive'' competition, and ''overproduction.''
Both presidents actively sought to revise the antitrust laws, and Roosevelt's original New Deal suspended them for a time. Baruch proposed a ''worldwide Supreme Court of business'' to regulate industrial output. Similarly, economic histories conclude that excessive duplication and overbuilding of railroads led to the crash of the 1890's.
These conclusions may have been incorrect, but it is disappointing that today's advocates of all-out competition never take up the question of why these conclusions were reached by people of presumably different ideological perspectives. True enough, economists often remind us that various forms of ''protectionism'' caused the debacle of the 30's, but why did everyone else disagree with them at the time?
The problem is easily explained in the form of a puzzle that should be given attention at the Harvard Business School, where Porter teaches. It is a principle of managment that duplication is wasteful, and it is a principle of economics that competition is efficient. How can both principles be correct when duplication and competition are synonymous?
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Los Angeles, July 24
 
The writer is a professor emeritus of the Graduate School of Public and International Affairs, University of Pittsburgh.
