HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
A Marriage With Video Technology

BYLINE: Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
IN the future it may be impossible to tell the difference between a personal computer and a television set. The two technologies are colliding even today, and in a few years we are likely to see conventional business computers giving way to ''smart TV's'' or ''video computers.''
''It is safe to say that 10 years from now there will be more things that look like TV's but that on the inside are really personal computers than there are personal computers today,'' said Nick Arnett, editor of Multimedia Computing and Presentations, a newsletter based in Santa Clara, Calif.
Consider the recent classified advertisement that Mr. Arnett said he saw in a Silicon Valley newspaper:
''Software opportunity. Multimedia, High Definition TV. Current projects include architecture and design of futuristic multimedia work stations and the development of state-of-the-art HDTV systems for applications in the entertainment industry. Complex man-machine interface, windowing systems, object-oriented programming and data bases, real-time machine control, image/video processing.'' 
The advertisement was placed by the Sony Corporation, the giant consumer electronics manufacturer that suddenly sounds a lot like a computer company. In fact, Sony already makes an impressive line of scientific and engineering work stations, and it is in the vanguard in developing hand-held computers that recognize handwriting.
Radius Inc. of San Jose, Calif., a leading manufacturer of monitors, has also seen the future and decided it is video. The company recently introduced its Radius TV System, a remarkable television subsystem for Apple Macintosh II computers that sells for $2,795. It consists of a so-called video engine that plugs into a Mac expansion slot, an audio-video processor that sits outside the Mac and special software for controlling and manipulating video images.
When equipped with Radius TV and a color monitor (Radius, of course, but the Apple 13-inch RGB monitor can be used with an optional display controller), the Macintosh can display, store and manipulate any video image, including input from broadcast and cable television, video cassette recorders, laser disk players, video cameras and digital cameras.
The video can be displayed on the computer screen in real time, directly from a feed - at 30 frames a second, the same as televison - with no apparent loss of quality. In computer terms, the system displays 16-bit color images, which means that each dot making up the image has 16 possible color components, yielding images that are not quite photographic quality but certainly equal to what most television sets produce.
The Radius software presents a mouse-driven control panel on screen that lets the user change channels, switch among video sources and adjust such variables as brightness, contrast, color and hue. The size of the video window can be changed, up to the dimensions of a full 13-inch screen, and it can be moved around the screen.
A stock trader, for example, might wish to monitor the Financial News Network in a corner of the screen while keeping track of stock prices at the same time.
Granted, $2,795 is a lot of money for a television set, and if the computer user simply wanted to watch the baseball game in one corner of the screen while working on a spreadsheet, it would be far more economical to buy a little color portable and hook it up alongside the computer. But Radius TV goes beyond that, using all parts of the video signal, including parts that we often do not see. For example, ''close captioned'' programs are sent along with text, allowing hearing-impaired people to ''read'' the television. The text is sent along with the audio and video information in a form called ASCII (pronounced az-KEY), which a computer can read.
The lay user cannot currently perform such tasks, but the software that comes with Radius TV is a tool allowing programmers to develop such applications. Other applications might include instructing the computer to search incoming ASCII text for one or more key words - ''gold,'' for example, or ''no new taxes.'' When the computer detected those words in the video signal, it would capture the video and audio portions, or perhaps open a window on the computer screen and crank up the volume to let the user know that an item of interest was being discussed.
Up to three incoming signals can be monitored at once, ''sort of like a TV news clipping service happening in real time,'' said Tony Bove, co-editor of the Bove & Rhodes Inside Report on Desktop Publishing and Multimedia, published in Gualala, Calif. Some people might use Radius TV to capture and print the transcript from network evening news programs. While Radius TV is impressive in the ways it brings video and audio into a computer, it is not designed to send processed images back out. One cannot play back through a video cassette recorder a video clip that has been edited on the computer, but the edited materials can be distributed on a computer network.
The system has a lot of potential applications in desktop publishing. A person writing a newsletter on advertising, for example, might use Radius TV to capture a television commercial. Using the software that comes with Radius TV, the writer could ''grab'' a frame from the commercial, edit it and drop it into a newsletter. A newspaper graphics editor might capture the image of the President directly off the screen as he speaks at a televised news conference, process the frame and beat an otherwise impossible deadline.
Of course, some users might want to grab more than a frame. Radius TV could be used to process video segments taken with a camcorder on a factory floor, for example. Those segments could be digitized by Radius TV, manipulated and incorporated into a computer-based training program for workers.
Andrew Singer, vice president of engineering at Radius, said some corporate customers were exploring the use of Radius TV as the hub for a security system. Cameras placed around a building might be assigned different channels on a company cable television system, and the computer could be programmed to grab a frame every three seconds. The computer could also be programmed to switch to full motion video when an image changed significantly - for example, when a truck pulled up to a loading dock.
Some companies might figure out a way to use Radius TV to merge video, audio and electronic mail. Imagine the possibilities: The boss's scowling face pops up suddenly to fill the worker's screen and growls, ''Watson, come here, I want you.''
''For interactive training, multimedia applications, broadcast TV - for anybody working with more sophisticated pictures, images and graphics, particularly motion and animation, a whole set of tools is becoming available,'' said Stanley Klein, editorial director of the S. Klein Newsletter, of Sudbury, Mass. ''Radius is providing a platform for third parties to develop end-user applications.''

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1575 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: July 29-August 3

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
Iraq Marches, Kuwait Crumbles and the Markets Convulse
 
It's as if President Saddam Hussein of Iraq sat at a trading desk, with enough capital to suddenly, violently dump yen, unload Treasury bonds, buy oil, bid up the dollar, hoard gold, invest in Norwegian and Australian commodity stocks and sell shares almost everywhere else. Such were the convulsions after Iraq invaded Kuwait and seized its rich oil supplies. Some analysts tried to assure each other that, with the world's stockpiles high and extra production capacity available, oil prices will not soar as they did in the 1970's. But even before the invasion, many in the oil industry said that prices were likely to rise by 50 percent within five years. Now President Hussein governs almost 20 percent of the world's oil supplies. An additional 37 percent, in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, are within half a day's drive by tank. Whether by intimidation or outright posession, said Christopher Flavin, vice president for research at the Worldwatch Institute, ''Iraq could control over half of the world's oil reserves. It lends a whole new tone to oil vulnerability.'' 
 
Japan Moves In on Europe
 
One of Europe's ''national champion'' computer makers is no match for a Japanese heavyweight. ICL P.L.C., Britain's largest computer maker, agreed on Monday to let Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan buy an 80-percent interest for $1.29 billion. The purchase, if approved by the European Community, will crown the expansion strategy of Takuma Yamamoto, the company's chairman, by making Fujitsu the world's second-largest computer company, behind Internatonal Business Machines. The Europeans have planned a loose network of technology companies - national champions - capable of taking on the Americans and Japanese. But since two other supposed champions - Olivetti of Italy and Groupe Bull of France - lost money last year, both are potential targets for the Japanese.
 
Yeltsin's New Credibility
 
Two years ago, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union called Boris N. Yeltsin undisciplined and disruptive, purging him as Moscow party chief. But by this May, not even Mr. Gorbachev's opposition could keep voters from making Mr. Yeltsin the President of the Russian Republic. Now Mr. Gorbachev has joined with Mr. Yeltsin to form a commission to revamp the nation's economy. Herbert S. Levine, a scholar of Soviet economics at the University of Pennsylvania, said that Mr. Gorbachev's move has ''enormous significance'' for the nation: ''Here's a man who has tremendous political instincts, but he has been reluctant to take economic risks,'' Mr. Levine said. And the intellectuals who derided Mr. Yeltsin as a buffoon now see him as the best hope for economic reform.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
The Looming Recession?
 
Thursday's invasion of Kuwait and Friday's unemployment report left virtually every economist talking of recession - some in the future tense, some in the conditional, a few in the present. Unemployment rose to 5.5 percent in July, the highest in two years and up three-tenths of 1 percent from June. Other figures last week - the leading economic indicators, the purchasing managers index - also indicated weakness. ''The economy is barely above water,'' said Alan C. Lerner, a managing director and economist at Bankers Trust. But wages that rose at more than a 7 percent annual rate last month and oil prices that are sharply higher keep the Federal Reserve from easing rates much without aggravating inflation, he said. Stocks plummeted on the week's news, recovering somewhat on Friday afternoon after the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, predicted that Iraq would soon withdraw from Kuwait.
 
Bank Fund Shrivels
 
Is a bank bailout in store? Probably not, said the nation's top banking regulator last week. But L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said that the fund to insure bank deposits will lose money in 1990 for the third straight year. He blamed weakening real estate markets and an onslaught of bank failures. The fund would be left with assets of only $11 billion, less than 60 cents for every $100 of insured deposits. ''The insurance fund is under considerable stress, and it is at the lowest point at any time in modern history,'' Mr. Seidman said. But he sees no need for the Government to replenish the fund. ''At this point, we believe we can handle anything we can see,'' he said on Tuesday. Will later news of a slowing economy change his views?
 
More S.& L. Bad News
 
Other bad news from Mr. Seidman: The Government will need another $100 billion in the fiscal year beginning on Oct. 1 to finance the savings and loan bailout. Appearing before Congress in his other role, as chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, he said the money was essential for the agency to keep up its pace of closing and selling off failed savings and loans.
 
The Upside of Censorship
 
An old marketing lesson repeated for the 1990's: Better sales through censorship. Karen Finley sold out two performance art shows at Lincoln Center recently after the National Endowment for the Arts refused to renew her grant. And a No Excuses jeans commercial featuring Marla Maples aired on television newscasts free after the networks refused to accept it for pay. Ms. Finley's work deals with sexual themes, sometimes humorously, sometimes stridently. The No Excuses advertising agency, Lois/GGK was far more calculating, virtually guaranteeing network rejection by having Miss Maples toss out some supermarket tabloids that have pantingly covered her friendship with Donald J. Trump. But remember that ''Banned in Boston'' was once a movie's best endorsement. And even James Joyce picked up sales for all the trouble he had getting ''Ulysses'' into this country. Profiting from censorship has its limits, though. Whatever chocolate icing Ms. Finley wears in her performance, Duncan Hines is unlikely to ask for her endorsement.
 
Steinbrenner Pere et Fils
 
He earned his job the old-fashioned way. Hank Steinbrenner was named to take over the Yankees on Tuesday by his father, George, who was banned from running the team the day before. Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, forbade father and son from so much as conversing about the team.
 
COMPANIES
 
Smaller Auto Makers in Jeopardy
 
Small cars sell well; the smaller car companies, maybe not. Some analysts say that each quarter brings the Chrysler Corporation, smallest of the American Big Three, closer to the point where a partnership will become essential. Second-quarter earnings dropped 47 percent from a year ago, to $180 million, and the company predicts a third-quarter loss. Slower sales and buyer rebates are hurting Ford and General Motors as well, but Chrysler is the most vulnerable. Several small auto makers have been taken over, entirely or in part, in the last year - Jaguar by Ford, Saab by G.M., and Fuji Heavy Industries, the Subaru maker, by Nissan. Chrysler has ended a joint venture with Renault, but still needs a foreign ally to share development expenses and reduce its dependence on North American markets. ''Long term, they would be in much better shape if they were able to combine resources with someone else,'' said Harvey Heimbach, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. ''Not necessarily merger, but joint ventures with another company.'' A possible partner: Fiat.
 
Honda's New Speed
 
Top speed 168 miles per hour. Zero to sixty in less than six seconds. These Ferrari-like figures come from the once-humble Honda Motor Company, in the new Acura NSX. The $60,000 price is a veritable bargain considering that $100,000 is usually the minimum cost of such road-burning performance. Honda hopes that the aura of its new car will brighten its entire Acura luxury line, propelling Honda's American car sales past Chrysler's.
 
Bumpy Weather for UAL
 
Investors fled from the UAL Corporation as banks reportedly backed away from financing an employee takeover. With higher oil prices threatening the company as well, its shares fell 41 points last week to finish at 122. The unions face an Aug. 9 deadline for their deal, with an extension possible. The stock, down from a 52-week high of 294, seems to have no more bounce than a 10-year-old airline seat cushion. But asking industry analysts about the airline's prospects practically causes them to twitch and tremble. ''You learn with UAL never to say never,'' says Thomas Longman, an analyst at Bear Stearns. ''They say around Wall Street that just about everybody has lost money one UAL at one point or another.''
 
Trouble at the Chicago Merc
 
Sorry is the man who risks becoming an example of the problems he says don't need fixing. Karsten Mahlmann resigned as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade on Wednesday in a swirl of financial and legal troubles. Mr. Mahlmann and his fellow commodity traders have protested the Bush Adminstration's plan for greater Securities and Exchange Commission policing. We can govern ourselves, with help from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, they said. Now Mr. Mahlmann's company, Stotler Group Inc., has defaulted on its debt. The futures commission accused an affiliated firm of misusing customers' capital to shore up Stotler, and a Federal judge appointed an attorney to watch the money.

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Part 2, Page 25, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 963 words

HEADLINE: Managing;
Inviting the Headhunters Inside

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
THE Baxter Health Care Corporation's Hyland division, a Deerfield, Ill., company that makes protein solutions from blood plasma, is looking for someone to fill a senior position. Several Hyland insiders qualify - but just barely. So Hyland has asked Conex Inc., a New York recruiting firm, to evaluate the insiders, compare them to outsiders and then present Hyland with a slate of candidates from both groups.
''Even when the inside people are good, there is always that flicker of hope that someone ideal will turn up,'' said Cleopatra Gomez, Hyland's staffing manager. 
What was once a clear-cut division of duties - top management evaluated insiders for promotion, search firms scoured the rest of the world - has become yet another casualty of the tumult of the 1980's. The barrage of mergers, divestitures and restructurings has meant that many executives are being asked to evaluate subordinates they barely know. And, the wave of downsizing has put so many experienced people out of work that it is hard for top management to resist checking what's available on the unemployment lines before promoting even the most deserving insider.
The result is that companies are setting aside once-sacrosanct promote-from-within policies and asking executive recruiters to help them choose between their own people and those available outside.
''I think it is healthy for an insider to actively compete in a formalized way with other candidates,'' said David K. Downes, executive vice president of the Equitable Capital Management Corporation, a New York asset-management company that often asks search firms to evaluate insiders and outsiders for open positions. ''It is time that people realized that being next in the hierarchy no longer means they will automatically be deemed the right person to move into the job above them.''
Recruiters say Mr. Downes's attitude has grown prevalent. ''Companies no longer promote people who have most of the traits they are looking for, when there might be someone outside who has all of them,'' said Paul R. Ray Jr., chief executive of Paul R. Ray & Company, a Fort Worth recruiting firm. Nor should they, added Lester B. Korn, chairman of Korn/Ferry International in Los Angeles. ''At high levels, the board owes it to shareholders to see if they can't find someone better outside,'' he said.
Reasons for bringing recruiters into the internal evaluation process vary widely. William J. Turner, for example, felt he had no choice. He had been chairman of Forstmann & Little Industries Inc.'s four industrial businesses for less than six months when he had to fill a couple of executive positions. He asked Heidrick & Struggles, New York recruiters, to help him evaluate candidates. ''It's a cop-out for a hands-on business manager to ask an outsider to evaluate his people, but I hadn't been around long enough to know the insiders well enough to judge them myself,'' Mr. Turner said.
Partners in joint venture companies often turn to recruiters to assuage fears that either partner might try to stack the corporate deck with its own people.
When the president of Centel Facilities Communication, a joint venture between Centel Business Systems and the Houston Sports Association, recently resigned, he was replaced with someone from Centel Business - but only after the Paul R. Ray firm presented him as a top candidate for the job. ''By going outside for help, we didn't have to worry that the Centel people had been prejudiced in his favor,'' said Neal Gunn, executive vice president of Houston Sports, which owns the Houston Astros and operates the Astrodome.
Indeed, executives who do wind up promoting from within often say they are glad they brought a recruiter into the processs - if for no other reason than to hear a competent outsider register a vote of confidence in the internal staff. WHENEVER he cannot find a clear-cut internal candidate to fill a job, Thomas Havern, director of human resources at Hiram Walker-Allied Vintners Inc., asks Sidney G. Stricker, a principal at Stricker, Sur & Associates, to evaluate insiders and outsiders alike. Mr. Stricker has handled numerous searches for the company - so many, in fact, that many of the insiders he is asked to evaluate are people that he originally placed in their jobs, and thus knows quite well.
As often as not, Mr. Stricker comes back with a recommendation to promote one of them into the vacant position - an eventuality that delights Mr. Havern. ''Sometimes, looking outside makes you realize how good your own people are,'' he said.
Still, most recruiters say that internal search can represent a political minefield if handled incorrectly. Gerard R. Roche, Heidrick's chairman, put it this way: ''The chairman may think he is just asking for added input, but the typical insider will say, 'Hey, I've been working for you for four years, and you need Roche to do a two-hour interview before you know how good I am?' They really resent this.''
Conversely, the recruiter can serve as a lightning rod for that resentment if the insider does not get the job. Fred Siegel, Conex's president, guesses that sometimes that is the only reason he is asked to evaluate insiders. ''It's political,'' he said. ''Management wants us to take the flack when the vice president who thinks he's a shoo-in for president gets turned down.''
 
RECRUITERS WITHIN: THE ADVANTAGES
 
* Top management is new and does not know the insiders well.
 
* The recruiter originally placed the inside candidates with the company.
 
* The recruiter can deflect blame from management if an outsider is hired.
 
* It is easier to have one person compare insiders and outsiders.
 
* An impartial outsider can minimize political battles over hiring.

HEADLINE: SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Argentina's Glittering Trove

BYLINE: By Cristina Carlisle; Cristina Carlisle is on staff at The Times bureau in Buenos Aires.

 BODY:
Excited by stories of a mountain of silver, the colonizing Spanish in the early 16th century gave the name Rio de la Plata - River of Silver - to the great South American river system that ends at Buenos Aires. In the Andes, along the continent's western rim, their dreams would be fulfilled. So abundant was the supply of the glittering metal that in the 17th century, in Potosi alone - now part of Bolivia - more than 3,000 mine shafts were opened. Visitors of the time were amazed to find chairs, tables and even the most ordinary of household objects, such as sinks and pitchers, made of sterling silver or silverplate.
Though the Indians had already mastered sophisticated silverworking techniques by the time the conquistadors arrived, the new European influence would make itself increasingly felt throughout South America. Silversmiths arriving with the flood of artists and craftsmen from Portugal, Spain and Italy into Buenos Aires when it became the capital of a new Spanish viceroyalty in 1776 began a tradition that has been handed down from father to son and is very much alive today. 
Colonial (as well as contemporary) silverwork has long been a passion for Argentines. Now, with prices as much as a tenth of those in New York - partly because decades of economic turmoil have forced Argentina's impoverished middle class to sell off family treasures - the market here is beginning to attract international attention. Christopher Hartop, a silver specialist for Christie's New York, recently visited Buenos Aires and said he found that although there were few exceptional pieces, prices for antique pieces were often much lower than in New York.
Possibly Buenos Aires's most distinguished silversmith is Juan Carlos Pallarols. His workshop (Defensa 1094; telephone 361-7360; no set days or hours), filled with his personal collection of colonial furniture and silver objects, is in his home overlooking Plaza Dorrego in the colonial district of San Telmo - an area that has become the center of the city's antiques trade.
Descended from a line of prestigious Catalan silversmiths, whose works are found in the Vatican and in major Argentine collections, museums and churches, he is training two of his sons to become the seventh generation of Pallarols in the trade. His own creations, he says, are in the hands of King Juan Carlos of Spain and President Francois Mitterrand of France, and are often selected by the Argentine government as official gifts to foreign dignitaries.
Mr. Pallarols's work - exclusively in sterling silver (with a purity level of 925 out of 1,000, or 92.5 percent silver) - reflects both the curvaceous lines of the southern European tradition to which he was born and the imagery of his native South America: delicately chiseled cockatoos from the Amazon, condors from the Andes, thistle flowers from the Argentine countryside or passion flowers from Paraguay and northern Argentina.
Prof. Hector Schenone, art historian and expert in Latin American colonial silver, describes Mr. Pallarols as ''an excellent silversmith who can do anything.'' He says there are other good Argentine silversmiths, all working outside Buenos Aires in provincial towns, but that they are more limited in the styles they can do.
Aside from his colonial pieces, similar to 17th- to early 19th-century European models, many of Mr. Pallarols's more elaborate creations are in a style known as plateria criolla, or creole silverware. Originating in the 19th century - when the growth of commerce in Buenos Aires after the fragmentation of the viceroyalty and subsequent independence from Spain led to a large increase in cattle-raising gauchos on the Pampas - it consists of objects and attire used by these Argentine cowboys, as well as richer versions made for the owners of the estancias, or ranches.
Creole items include whips called fustas or rebenques, knives called facones and belts called rastras. Decorated with silver and sometimes old coins, these wonderful thick leather belts were worn by gauchos with bombachas - wide trousers that narrow toward the bottom and fasten at the ankle.
Even the gaucho's horse was decked in silver. Its chapeado - halter, bridle, reins, stirrups, breastplates and saddle trimmings, called cabezales - was made of leather inlaid with silver, or more luxuriously, with both silver and gold. Some estancia owners went so far as to have chapeados made of solid silver or gold. A symbol of status, the gaucho's glittering apparel was paraded during religious holidays or other festivities. Even today, a special occasion will still find gauchos in full regalia.
At Mr. Pallarols's shop and elsewhere, you will also find the mate (pronounced MAH-tay), a vessel from which a traditional bitter herb tea is drunk. The custom of drinking mate was passed on by the Indians to the conquering Spaniards and today is especially popular in Argentina and Uruguay.
The first mates were simple gourds from the calabash tree. Later a great variety of shapes, sizes, styles and ornamentation evolved. Sometimes they were embellished with silver trimmings, sometimes made entirely of solid silver and even of solid gold. A mate normally comes with a bombilla, a separate straw, often made of silver, with a strainer at the lower end to trap the leaves.
Prices for works by Mr. Pallarols vary widely, depending on the size of the piece, the intricacy of the work and the amount of silver involved. Custom work is welcome. At the lower end of the scale are pillboxes, some inlaid with rhodochrosite, or Incan rose, a glassy, rose-red semiprecious stone found in the Argentine Andes, as well as simple money clips, both for $30 (because of Argentina's long history of inflation and the fluctuating exchange rate, dealers quote silver prices in dollars).
Tupos - copies of the delicate silver clips used by Indians to fasten shawls or ponchos - sell for $30 to $150. A calabash mate with silver trim costs $80 to $100, and solid silver mates range from $300 to $500. Facones cost $200 to $3,000; picture frames, $80 to $800; silver chandeliers, $1,000 to $4,000, and very large, heavily ornamented colonial-style mirrors, $12,000.
Samuel (Cacho) Setian has a solid reputation for his knowledge of facones, the knives used by gauchos. He and his wife, Alicia, have a spacious shop, Alhambra, facing Plaza Dorrego (Bethlem 423; 361-1097; open noon to 7 P.M. Sunday through Friday). Here an assortment of antique furniture, porcelain and other pieces surrounds cabinets stocked with colonial and creole silver and his renowned collection of knives.
Originally a fighting weapon, the facon was also used by the gaucho in his daily tasks. It was normally tucked into his belt behind him, with the sharp edge pointed upward inside the sheath - ready for battle. The blades were imported from Europe, but the handle and sheath were made by local silversmiths.
Mr. Setian has a unique piece made for a 19th-century Argentine president, Gen. Justo Jose de Urquiza, by his Sicilian silversmith, Pablo Cataldi, that is inlaid with gold and estimated to be worth $50,000. He also has many knives priced at $2,500, $1,000 or even $250.
Three years ago, the brothers Javier, Jose and Jaime Eguiguren opened a shop called Eguiguren (Libertad 1389; 812-6328; open Monday through Friday 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 4 to 8 P.M., Saturday 10 A.M. to 1 P.M.) in the elegant Barrio Norte neighborhood. Their silver is tastefully arranged in display cases or set among period furniture that is also for sale. Three-quarters of the stock is usually from the 19th century, with a few objects from the 17th century and a bit more from the 18th. They also deal in creole silverware and some contemporary items.
Prices for mates at Eguiguren begin at $400. A 19th-century rastra belt with silver coins and a silver thistle flower at the front sold for $800. Two 18th-century altar plaques, beautifully embossed with botanical motifs, sold for $11,000. A pair of 19th-century five-branched candelabra with central flower-form vases from colonial Peru was $14,000.
Ricardo Pardo heads Casa Pardo (Paraguay 782; 313-8170 or 312-0980; open Monday through Friday 10 A.M. to 1 P.M. and 3:30 to 7:30 P.M., Saturday 10 A.M. to 12:30 P.M.), a traditional silver shop in the financial district, founded in 1892. Over the years, Pardos have served as advisers in the formation of major private and museum silver collections. Much of the firm's business still consists in acting as a contact between potential buyers and collectors with things to sell.
In addition to some less interesting pieces, the shop - a large, nondescript rectangular room - houses some exceptional items, such as an elaborate bridle, halter and rein set made in Buenos Aires in the late 19th century that sold for $1,500. A chain of little silver barrels and eagles made up the bridle and rein; the halter had large silver flowers on either side.
A wide assortment of silver items can be found at the Sunday antiques fair at Plaza Dorrego. They typically include Art Deco broaches studded with marcasites ($40 to $80), brushes and mirrors ($200) or cigarette cases ($30 to $200). Shopping here is fun, and the occasional find is possible, but it takes a trained eye to distinguish quality and authenticity.
Of the major auction houses in Buenos Aires, Sarachaga (Juncal 1248; 812-8424 or 814-2591), owned by Juan and Martin Sarachaga, is the only one specializing in colonial and creole silverware. Two sales a year offer 150 to 180 pieces each, usually including mates, antique spoons and soup ladles, soup terrines, bowls, round trays known as pailas and coffee and tea sets. The sales are catalogued by Hector Coscia, one of Buenos Aires's most renowned silver specialists. Buyers receive a certificate identifying their purchase and extending a money-back guarantee should doubt arise as to its authenticity.
Because silver pieces in the colonial style were, in fact, being produced up until the beginning of the 20th century and very few bore the silversmith's mark, authentication and dating are very difficult. Most of the everyday items made from silver in the 17th and 18th centuries were melted down and reused, and copies of early pieces abound. Those original early works that do survive are mostly held by private collectors and museums, though authentic 18th-century religious artifacts, such as chalices, missal holders and crucifixes, are easier to come by.
Some of the colonial silver was done with purity levels of 900 or 950, but many of the items for daily use had a higher copper content to make them more durable. Their silver purity level is usually 800. Shops scattered all over Buenos Aires have copies of classic European silver pieces, including trays and flatware, but virtually all of that is silver plate.
Those who do not have an expert eye should confine their shopping to the handful of prestigious dealers and keep away from places that claim to have abundant offerings from the 17th or 18th century. Some price negotiation is acceptable.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 5; Page 9, Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: Anecdotes in Wood, Paint and Cast Iron


BYLINE: 
By Kathering Ashenburg; Katherine Ashenburg, who often writes about architecture, is the editor of the Arts and Books section of The Globe and Mail in Toronto.

 BODY:
The clerk in the well-stocked Point-a-Pitre bookstore smiled at me when I asked if he had any books on the island's architecture. ''One does not visit Guadeloupe for the buildings,'' he said. Probably not, in most cases. But even on a tropical island blessed with beaches, Brobdignagian flora and a usually dormant volcano, the houses tell graphic and often delightful stories.
The styles of France and Africa, the constant threat of hurricanes and earthquakes, the economies of plantation life, attitudes about death, trading links with New Orleans - all these and more are in Guadeloupe's buildings for the reading. Not sermons in stone, but certainly anecdotes in wood, paint and that most beloved of Caribbean roofing materials, corrugated iron.
Architecture writers (including the authors of ''Caribbean Style,'' published by Clarkson N. Potter) trace the humblest of Guadeloupe's buildings, the case (popular house), to African slaves imported to work the coffee and sugar cane plantations in the 17th century. These unprepossessing structures, whose dark interiors are typical of houses of the poor in hot climates, are everywhere on Guadeloupe, from the hilly villages of Basse-Terre (the western island) to the towns and countryside of Grande-Terre, the more populated eastern island. 
In essence a wooden cube whose sides can be as small as three to five yards, the case exists in some form on all the Caribbean islands. On Guadeloupe, the traditional house contains from one to three rooms; its corrugated iron roof may be flat or gently pitched. In either case, the roof is always nailed to the frame in a deliberately gingerly fashion, so that very powerful winds can shear it off neatly without damaging the house itself. (And it works, judging by the number of new roofs on old houses seen on a post-Hurricane Hugo visit last February.) The Guadeloupean case is often set on stone blocks, partly to minimize contact with termites and centipedes, and partly to make house moving easier. Guadeloupeans own the houses but rarely the land. When the lease on the land is up (or, as often happened in former times, the owner of the case was needed to work a distant field), the little house is simply put on a wagon or truck and transported to its next destination.
One can dismiss the case as dilapidated and primitive; indeed, the British writer Patrick Leigh Fermor, wandered around the outskirts of Guadeloupe's biggest town, Point-a-Pitre in the late 1940's, and the size and shape of the houses reminded him of ''derelict confessional boxes,'' he said in his book ''The Traveler's Tree.'' While Guadeloupeans enjoy one of the highest standards of living in the Caribbean, many continue to live in cases, perhaps because most island living is done out of doors.
The case can afford unexpected pleasure to sympathetic eyes. When something is stripped to its essentials, the subtle variations - the scalloped edge on a veranda, the pitch of a roof, the regular rhythm of shuttered French doors - take on a powerful charm.
What strikes most visitors first on a walk through a village such as Ste.-Anne or St.-Francois or driving through the outlying sections of Point-a-Pitre is the Guadeloupeans' canny use of color. Some cases are still unpainted and their weather-beaten boards have their own silvery beauty, but when house paint became widely available in the Caribbean between the two world wars, the islanders discovered a most congenial medium.
There are regional differences: Haitians favor frenetic shades like orange and turquoise and the English islanders prefer primary colors, while the French islanders on Martinique and Guadeloupe admire what they call tendres couleurs.
The tender (or, less romantically, pastel) colors of Guadeloupean cases include melting ice cream tones of peppermint pink, lemon, creme de menthe and cafe au lait. The trim on shutters, frames and doors is often brighter and unexpected - eggplant for a pale blue house, a knowing combination of aquamarine, sky blue and black for a white house.
Another inexpensive way to beautify these tiny boxes came by way of a 19th-century American invention, the jigsaw. Whenever possible, a case has a veranda, and the jigsaw brought forth the veranda's trim on the posts - the cutout suns, moons and flowers that encourage breezes while filtering sunlight. When cutout trim is too expensive, something of the same airy, perforated effect is achieved with decorative concrete blocks.
Guadeloupeans are sternly protective of the privacy of their case and may look up threateningly at a tourist who so much as glances in the open French doors. It's possible to get some sense of the proportions and dimness of a case, albeit a converted one, on the outskirts of Point-a-Pitre on the main road from Ste.-Anne. On the left as you approach the city, in the middle of a long row of workers' houses, the sign outside a beige house says ''Bibliotheque Municipal'' (Municipal Library). When I stepped inside, books were ranged methodically along the dark walls, a stern librarian sat behind a vase of tropical flowers, and a lone little boy was reading ''Tintin.''
As families grew more prosperous and added rooms, the case merged into the low-slung veranda-encircled house found in hot countries around the world. The owners of Guadeloupe's plantations lived in enlarged versions of this informal style, or in houses that recalled French farmhouses or manor houses. Most of the island's plantation houses have either disappeared or are inaccessible, hidden behind vast hedges of croton or hibiscus or dimly glimpsed at the end of an avenue of palms.
The easiest plantation house to see from the outside (privately owned and not open to the public) is Zevalos on the road between St.-Francois and Le Moule on the eastern side of Grande-Terre. However, Zevalos is highly uncharacteristic. Legend has it that the house's prefabricated cast-iron frame was made in the late 19th century in Gustave Eiffel's Paris workshop and destined for Louisiana. When the ship transporting the frame ran into trouble near Guadeloupe, the director of the sugar plantation at Zevalos bought the elements and built himself a house amid the fields of cane. Today the fields have given way to suburban houses, but Zevalos remains - a two-story exercise in cast-iron lace that looms up dramatically from the flatlands of Grande-Terre.
The actual house, of yellow bricks, is deliberately upstaged by the curlicues and arabesques of the white-painted iron veranda and balcony that wrap around it. Time has robbed Zevalos of its proper setting, but even so it looks strangely citified and imperturbably French with its dormer windows, tiled roof and symmetrical French doors. Its size, its detail and its undeniable elegance are impressive, but Zevalos also looks, well, prefabricated.
The only other building on Guadeloupe of this type, the St.-John Perse Museum (9 Rue de Nozieres, Point-a-Pitre) is much more appealing. Smaller and surrounded by a lush little garden, it looks surprisingly at home on its city street close to the market. Surprising because the museum is unabashedly fantastic. Unlike at Zevalos, its exaggeratedly overhanging balcony, also made of prefabricated cast iron, is not balanced by a veranda on the first floor, and this top-heavy effect gives the house the look of a Swiss chalet realized in pastels and transported to the tropics.
It's Swiss too in its neatness and passion for decorative detail: beside the lacy cast iron, the accessories here include scalloped tin borders, white wooden trim that aspires to the condition of eyelet embroidery, rosettes, medallions and Moorish tiles. As at Zevalos, the house is yellow brick and the cast-iron parts are white, but a lavish use of aquamarine trim adds to its festive air. Guadeloupe's best-known poet, St.-John Perse (1887-1975) was born on a nearby street when this house was relatively new, and today the museum houses an island drawing room furnished with 19th-century artifacts, changing exhibitions and a breezy attic reading room with books by and about the poet.
Another Point-a-Pitre museum, the Schoelcher Museum (24 Rue Peynier), is also a fantasy, a Beaux-Arts jewel box that was built in 1887. Victor Schoelcher was a Frenchman largely responsible for freeing the slaves in the French West Indies, so it seems partly ironic, partly appropriate that the museum dedicated to his life and achievements is an architectural copybook of ornate Franco-classical motifs. Columns, pilasters, urns, wreaths, swags, filigree balconies and gates are knit together in a building that should be pompous but only manages to be irresistible. Its charm is partly due to its unerring proportions, partly to its color: how can you be intimidated by a museum the color of strawberry sherbet, with pistachio trim? Patrick Leigh Fermor disliked Point- a-Pitre more every day he was there, describing it as an accumulation of shacks and comparing its central streets to the ''more squalid thoroughfares of Salonika.''
He was needlessly harsh. If Gabriel Garcia Marquez wrote in French instead of Spanish, Point-a-Pitre would be the kind of romantically decrepit town where his characters might act out their half-glamorous, half-seedy fates with ease. Few of Point-a-Pitre's buildings date from before 1845, when an earthquake destroyed much of the town, and the central streets around the Place de la Victoire and the Cathedral of St. Pierre and St. Paul are lined with cheerful 19th-century townhouses. Their cast-iron balconies are reminiscent of New Orleans's French Quarter, which is only natural given the 19th-century commercial links between the two French-speaking ports. But the jaunty, rather raffish neighborhood, with its paradoxical air of languid purposefulness and its shifting affinities - now with France, now with Africa, always with the tropics - is very much Guadeloupe.
The Guadeloupean touch with color is also evident here, from the yellow and white double-balconied Maison Hayot, at the northwest corner of the Place de la Victoire, to a very smart, very citified blue, cream and pink town house one house away from the northeast corner of the same square.
The Place de la Victoire, with its solemn sandbox trees, government buildings and statues of local heroes, is Point-a-Pitre's civic showplace, and the houses bordering it are necessarily the town's spiffiest. A few blocks away, in the streets around the cathedral - Rue Lamartine, Rue Alsace-Lorraine, Rue Bebian - the atmosphere is more relaxed. The cathedral's Spanish stucco facade is the color of mango sherbet; inside, thanks to its cast-iron skeleton and wooden roof, its palette is cool, nearly monochromatic.
The owners of the neighboring townhouses were less restrained, trimming a mint green house with orange, lining pale gray doors with the creamy peppermint pink that is one of Guadeloupe's signature colors. The generous S-brackets supporting the balconies, the Gothic arches or curlicues on the balcony railings, even the accommodating curve with which a building rounds the corner soften the two- or three-story houses' vertical lines. The ground floors are generally commercial space and those above domestic. The details grow more delicate as the eye ascends upward, from the massive rounded doors on the main floor to the 19th-century cutout trim and decorative tin borders on the upper floors.
In common with other Caribbean islands, Guadeloupe reserves its most varied and playful architecture for the dead. The cemetery at Ste.-Anne is characteristic: as you approach the village on the main road from Point-a-Pitre, suddenly a miniature city crowded with cathedrals, classical temples and chunky modernist structures climbs a hill on your left. It's a boldly black and white necropolis, the family vaults patterned with ceramic tiles in diamonds, stripes and checkerboards, almost as if a tiny city planner had gotten a great deal on bathroom tiles.
THE hilly little streets in Ste.-Anne's cemetery are crammed with more architectural styles than living Guadelopeans can claim. The mausoleums are crammed too, with ceramic crucifixes bursting with roses and pansies, portraits of the departed, real and plastic flowers, tall red glass vigil candles, plaques marked ''Regrets'' or ''Notre Mere.'' But the scene is far from lugubrious; it's domestic, even cheerful. In one tiny cathedral, large formal portraits of a couple - he in his best suit, she holding an immense handbag and wearing the traditional foulard (madras scarf) - flank an altar with a crucifix, several statues and a plaque in their honor. A mop and cleaning materials stand in one corner, and there's a bench where friends and family can relax.
A group of women and girls on an early morning visit entered the cemetery, chatting and laughing, as we were leaving. Gaudelopeans dislike being photographed and often shake a warning finger at cameras, but I needn't have worried about their reaction to ours. The oldest of the lot nodded approvingly and hoped we had made some nice pictures: ''C'est joli, n'est-ce pas?'' We agreed: it was indeed pretty.
 
IF YOU GO
 
Museums The museums are open from 8:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. and 2:30 to 5:30 P.M.; they are closed Saturday morning and all day Sunday. Admission is about $1.70, calculated at 5.8 French francs to the dollar. St.-John Perse Museum, 9 Rue Nozieres, Point-a-Pitre; telephone 90.92.28. Schoelcher Museum, 24 Rue Pey-nier, Pointe-a-Pitre; 82.08.04.
 
Reading ''Caribbean Style,'' by Suzanne Slesin, Stafford Cliff, Jack Berthelot, Martine Gaume and Daniel Rozen-sztroch (Clarkson N. Potter), at $40, is a lavishly illustrated introduction to the interiors and exteriors of Caribbean houses. K. A.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 20, Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1158 words

HEADLINE: About Men;
The Quick, the Dead

BYLINE: By Mark McGurl; Mark McGurl is on the staff of The New York Review of Books.

 BODY:
The year my family invested in Florida real estate I decided the world was meaningless. I had nothing in particular against Florida, or investments for that matter - I simply happened to be 15. It was a hormonal kind of thing.
I took the insight seriously, though. I reduced my repertoire of facial expressions to two: scowl for nighttime, smirk for day. I chucked the colorful parts of my wardrobe, draped my limbs in dogmatic black. I wandered the earth, or more accurately the town in New Hampshire where I lived, and I showered it with contempt. I prayed, casually, for clouds and rain. For floods. Earthquakes. I also prayed, somewhat hypocritically, that my voice wouldn't crack in class and that the girl with the red notebook wouldn't notice that my nose had reached adult proportions a few years in advance of the rest of my face.
The investment in Florida was one my father would later regret. In the meantime, though, we had what was, for us, a shocking luxury: a fairly slick apartment high up in a building on the beach. We installed ourselves there to celebrate a tropical Christmas. 
From the balcony, one had the impression of being at the bridge of a very tall ship; the azure sweep of the Atlantic halted, invisibly, somewhere beneath your feet and the whole world seemed water. When the clouds hugged the shore, you could glimpse, in the distance, swatches of ocean where the sun still peeked through. Beyond the horizon somewhere was Haiti, and beyond that, France, Zanzibar, Afghanistan. An embracing immensity. I might even have found it comforting. The afternoon I arrived, I stood on the balcony and pronounced the vista meaningless.
I soon settled into a vacation torpor. I woke up past noon, ate some doughnuts, fell asleep again. I thus avoided many unnecessary conversations. I emerged from the apartment in late afternoon. By then the temperature had cooled a bit, the light had softened and the honeysuckle was releasing its perfume in earnest. Walking down the road to the 7-Eleven to buy breakfast - a Slurpee and some Milk Duds -I nearly gave way to transcendence. I resisted.
And then, one evening, a tremendous storm. Our building, one apartment thick, shuddered clear through with every thunderclap. As I peered out the glass doors over the balcony, the sea seemed to have swollen malevolently, overfed by the rain.
Beach-front property suddenly didn't seem such a luxury. Perhaps thinking this very thought, my parents turned in early. For my part, I did not believe in the possibility of my own death, so I stepped out onto the balcony as soon as I heard their door shut. The world was angry. Holding onto the railing, slapped by the wind, I stood mesmerized by the sea. The last glow of dusk had been extinguished, and the water surged in various dark shapes. Leaning over, squinting against the rain, I could see straight down to the beach, where there was some light; the surf crashed a few feet from the first floor of the building, sending up a spray of luminous white. In the spray I spotted a flash of yellow. Whatever it was, it seemed substantial, but it was hard to tell in the darkness. I watched it for a long time, then decided it was driftwood.
In fact, as I later learned, it was the wreckage of an old boat, which, until the storm hit, had been afloat a few miles off the coast, headed to shore. It had been filled with Haitian men and women at tempting a night passage to a land with an economy that could support them.
I woke up surprisingly early the next morning. I went down to walk along the beach. The sky was a piercing, perfect blue, and the ocean had receded to an apologetic calm. The sand was littered with junk of every sort: shoes, Clorox bottles, a mangled life vest. I was half-looking for the big yellow thing, about which I was still curious, but it appeared to have floated elsewhere. I had the beach to myself.
Up ahead I saw something tumble forward in the surf, tumble back with the wave's retraction. I started forward to investigate. It was the body of a man. By the time I got to him, he was free of the water, warming in the sun. He was a large man, naked above the waist, clothed below in green polyester bell-bottoms. While the rest of his body was brown, his face was eerily white, and swollen. His eyes, mercifully, were closed.
What I remember above all was his stillness. In a childhood game you can, if you try, still your breathing remarkably. You can play dead, and for an instant your friends will be scared. If they keep staring, however, they will notice a tiny heaving in your chest, and they will laugh. They will prod you until you laugh as well. This man's chest was utterly still. I watched it for several seconds, focused in. My eyes, through pure force of habit, kept expecting to see him move. Perhaps from staring so hard, I grew slightly dizzy. All of a sudden I felt very young; I wanted help.
Six or seven bodies washed up on the beach over the course of the morning, but after the first one there was always a crew of men with gaffing poles and body bags ready to clear them away.
A small group of people, mostly residents of my building, gathered on the sand to watch. Instinctively, I joined them. I thus learned the origin of the yellow driftwood. Haiti was poor, the onlookers said, it was ''third world.'' People practiced voodoo there and had a bad government. I accepted all this, though I remember being perplexed that such a desperate place could be just over the horizon. There was talk of a meaningful irony: of aiming for the Gold Coast, and getting there, but getting there dead. A grim parody of a sunbather. Although I didn't fully understand what was being said, the important thing was that someone nearby was succeeding in making sense of it all, talking the horror down to size.
There was some compassion in what the adults I stood with said, but there was also a sense of great distance. Of course. The dead and the living, in this case, had never had much in common. As we talked, the scene before us seemed to flatten out, lose a dimension. I was not in the habit, back then, of falling into line with anything, but on this occasion something changed. The group's perceptions became, suddenly, my own: I was watching misfortune, not participating in it. In exchange for my pretentions to complete independence I was given something a little more realistic - the independence of one group - those who are safe - from another - those who aren't.
By nighttime I considered myself a minor expert on Haitian affairs. At the dinner table, I waxed sociological, repeating to my parents what I had heard on the beach, as though the words were my own. I guess you'd call this ''acting like a grown-up.'' The expression describes with unusual precision what I did that afternoon and evening, and what I would do more and more as years passed, until I had learned my lines by heart and was no longer really acting.

LENGTH: 1261 words

HEADLINE: On Language;
Acronym Power

BYLINE: By Jack Rosenthal; Jack Rosenthal is the editorial page editor of The New York Times. William Safire is on vacation.

 BODY:
One way to stand out in a world swimming in mere abbreviations is to assemble the letters into pronounceable words. As several recent examples show, acronyms fall into distinct categories.
The most obvious reason to coin an acronym is mnemonic, to make a term easy to remember. Mothers Against Drunk Driving are plenty MADD. Students Against Driving Drunk are surely SADD. They have now been joined by a group of black fathers in Omaha eager to provide role models for their sons. Men Against Destruction/Defending Against Drugs and Social-Disorder are Mad Dads.
There is an obvious danger in straining for acronyms. An editorial in The Times once sighed that perhaps the time had come to create, for the name alone, the Action Committee to Reform Our Nation's Youth Morals. 
Other acronyms provide shorthand for technical terms. The Pentagon has turned this kind of acronymics into an art form. Slickem, Glickem and Mirv - the terms sound more like a law firm than the vocalized names of missiles. SLCM's are sea-launched cruise missiles; GLCM's are their ground-launched cousins, and MIRV's (multiple independently targetable re-entry vehicles) are long-range missiles with more than one warhead. Such terms, like laser and scuba, eventually become so commonplace as words that we forget their acronymic origin. (Laser: light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation; scuba: self-contained underwater breathing apparatus.) Modern electronics offers some arresting new shorthand, like LUTS, which stands for ''light units, Times Square.'' Question: How much is a LUTS? Answer: It's equivalent, its creators say, to 85 foot-lamberts. Question: So, how much is a foot-lambert? Answer: The amount of brightness radiated from each square foot of area as measured from street level. Question: Yes, but why does anyone care? Answer: Because the underlying concern here is that the Great White Way remain light and lively. That's why New York City requires special lights and signs for the new buildings already soaring along Broadway and Seventh Avenue and on the towers soon to rise in the massive 42d Street redevelopment project.
Mitts is another acronym spawned by modern technology. It stands for ''minutes of telecommunications traffic,'' a statistic to measure voice, fax and data transmission on public circuits to other countries. It's the idea of Gregory Staple and Mark Mullins, consultants to the International Institute of Communications in London. Who has the most Mitts? The United States, with so many phones, has the largest total - 5.3 billion in 1988. But on a per capita basis, the United States ranks only ninth, well after Hong Kong, Singapore and (because of its many calls to the United States) Canada.
While some acronyms are shorthand for the technically complex, others are shorthand for the socially profound. Not mere cute fads, they provide useful and convenient ways to describe widely experienced realities. That makes them more truly new words, likely to last.
Nimby - ''not in my backyard'' - has been familiar in New York since the mid-1980's, but now it is becoming understood everywhere, because it describes attitudes expressed everywhere, whether by neighbors upset by the prospect of a shelter for the homeless in suburban New York or a new airport in exurban Denver. The neighbors, these days, are much less likely to submit to municipal authority with docile good citizenship.
Another such acronym is Gomer - for ''get out of my emergency room.'' It's not a new term. Medical insiders' lingo, it refers to whining, undesirable patients. More recently, however, the term has taken on a particular meaning, referring to old, poor patients. As pressure to curtail medical costs increases and as the number of inner-city physicians diminishes, more ailing old people are likely to struggle to get to hospital emergency rooms, and more attendants are apt to think, if not say, Gomer.
Nimby and Gomer have several points in common. Both seem to have survived the 1980's and made their way into the language. And both terms may indirectly typify the 1980's. They both involve exclusion, and they have the letter M in common: M as in ''my.''
 
THE LAST, AH, WORD
Just as new names and new concepts generate occasional new words, an underlying imperative of language regularly pumps them up also: the desire to be novel, expressive and colorful.
A circular example is neat! In the 1950's, it was the youthful word of choice to express superlative approval. That changed to terrific, pronounced TRIF-fack by the New Frontiersmen in the 60's. Then came super, which yielded in turn to EX-cellent. What is it now? Students home from five colleges in the Northeast report that EX-cellent endures, but a new in word is also heard: neat!
Several other neologisms have endured long enough to take seriously:
Blowing off. This started as a collegiate term meaning ''ducking'' or ''avoiding.'' Now it has entered political speech and taken a bow on page 1 of The Washington Post. Here is Fred Wertheimer, president of Common Cause, the public-interest lobby, talking in February about questionable campaign finance practices: ''Both Democrats and Republicans acted in a way that is blowing off what parties can do in House races.''
Random. A collegiate term that has become a staple of speech in Boston-area schools and elsewhere is used as an adjective and as a noun. As an adjective, it retains its usual meaning of ''haphazard'' or ''purposeless,'' but it's also used to mean ''ambiguous,'' as in ''That sure was a random movie.'' As a noun, it describes miscellaneous people or activities, as in ''Who was at the party?'' ''Oh, randoms.'' Or ''What did you guys do last night?'' ''Oh, random.''
Outing. A harsh tactic that bears no relation to a picnic in the park. The term describes the efforts by some gay people to disclose the secret homosexuality of public figures. It is derived from ''coming out of the closet,'' the act of publicly acknowledging one's homosexuality. Some writers for gay publications defend outing as a way to assail public officials who are privately homosexual but present themselves as homophobic. Others denounce the tactic as an intolerable invasion of privacy.
Spending down. This social-welfare term describes what is often a nightmare for older adults whom society deems not yet poor enough. It refers to what they must do with their assets - in some cases, even selling their home - before Medicaid will pay for long-term nursing care.
Word or Word up. These are terms popularized in rap music that mean ''truly,'' ''honestly,'' as in the expression ''you have my word.'' The term has been popular in black and youth culture for some time. ''Word Up'' is the title song of an album by Cameo issued in 1986 (''Come on, ba-by, tell me what's the word - A word up'').
Now the term has broken out into more general use - in a Pepsi-Cola television commercial by BBDO Worldwide. It is performed by Young MC, a rap performer and Grammy Award winner who has a degree in economics from the University of Southern California.
The ad, called ''Cool Cans,'' provides printed translations of the rap. For example, he chants: ''So yo! Stop kicking. Your pace better quicken/Before they run out or your clock stops ticking.'' Translation: ''Get this limited edition while supplies last.'' The closing reverses this patter pattern. Young MC says, in standard parlance, ''Really, I'm not kidding.'' The translation this time: ''He says, 'Word Up!' ''
And that, word up, is the last word.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2513 words

HEADLINE: Why Rabbit Had to Go

BYLINE: By JOHN UPDIKE; John Updike's novel ''Rabbit at Rest'' will be published in October.

 BODY:
''Rabbit AT Rest'' will be the fourth and last of my so-called Rabbit books. Each of them occurs in the ninth year of a decade and was written, more or less, in the ninth year of the decade.
The first one, ''Rabbit, Run,'' was written in 1959 with no thought of there being a sequel. It was composed by a youngish man, 27 I believe I was, who had received a Guggenheim grant by promising to write a novel - hence, having accepted the grant, I felt obliged to write the book. I had published one previous, quite short novel, ''The Poorhouse Fair.'' My sense of myself was of a sort of sprinter. My name, if known, was known by way of contributions to The New Yorker magazine. My original concept had been to write two novellas, to be bound into one volume, which would contrast two approaches to the game of life: one would be the rabbit approach, a kind of dodgy approach - spontaneous, unreflective, frightened, hence my character's name, Angstrom - and the second was to be the horse method of coping with life, to get into harness and pull your load until you drop. And this was eventually ''The Centaur.'' But I began the rabbit book first. 
It was subtitled, in my conception of it, ''A Movie''; I imagined the opening scene as something that would happen behind credits, and I saw the present tense of the book as corresponding to the present tense in which we experience the cinema. There is no real past in the movies; things happen, one after the other, right there in front of us. The present tense, in the late 50's, was not at all a common device in American fiction. The only instance that I had encountered was in a novel by Joyce Cary, the British writer, called ''Mister Johnson,'' about an African civil servant. I don't know if it's remembered or forgotten, but it's a wonderful book, one of the best novels about Africa - certainly one of the best books written by a white man about Africa that there is. I have been told since that Damon Runyon wrote in the present tense, but for me Joyce Cary opened the door.
I discovered as I began to write how delicious the present tense is. Instead of writing ''she said and he said'' it's ''he says and she says,'' and not ''he jumped'' at some past moment, but ''he jumps,'' right now in front of you. Action takes on a wholly different, flickering quality; thought and feeling and event are brought much closer together.
And so the present tense proved to be a happy one and I wrote on and on in a little room in the corner of East Street and County Road in Ipswich, Mass., a town I'd moved to in an attempt to get away from the charms and distractions of New York City. I was there provisionally, seeing if I could be a freelance writer. I had had a job in New York, I had done my New York thing, I could tell Uptown from Downtown, I had undergone the Manhattan initiation rites that writers should undergo, and was up in New England experimentally, out on a limb as it were. I sat in that little room, the old sewing room, looking out at a very complex telephone pole, and the excitement of writing a novel was so great for me that my feet, in scuffing, wore two bare spots on the floor, which might still be there.
Anyway, I completed the book; it was indeed a full-length book, too full-length to include with the horse novel, which I then made into another separate book. And that of course is the way we accumulate a shelf of books, every idea subdivides and becomes two and then four, and in that manner you can have written 37 books and not have had very many ideas.
''Rabbit, Run'' was published, with mild sales, fair reviews. People asked me about the ending; they found it ambiguous. What really happened? The hero is last seen running. I thought that Rabbit's immersion in the blind act of running was a sufficient ending for the novel; it didn't occur to me we needed to know more about this man.
But the decade passed, a decade that brought me good news and bad, and that brought the country a lot of news. The 60's were an exceedingly newsworthy decade, from John F. Kennedy's assassination on. A lot of things happened, things that were more or less distressing to Americans older than 30.
I had written a book called ''Couples,'' which had sold enough to make me feel entitled to write a long poem, all about myself, under the false impression that that would be interesting to people. But I made the useful discovery that in fact an author is interesting only as a storyteller, only as the conduit whereby certain imaginary events get onto the page. And so my long poem about myself, called ''Midpoint,'' fell quietly into the void - more quietly than a stone down a well, which at least does make a sort of little plip.
It was then my notion to complete a kind of Pennsylvania tetralogy. I'd written a book that took place in the future, ''The Poorhouse Fair,'' one that took place in the immediate present, ''Rabbit, Run,'' one that took place in the remembered past, ''The Centaur,'' and I wanted to write a historical novel about James Buchanan, Pennsylvania's only President - a fascinating man, at least to me. I did so much research I began to dream about him. One day I woke up and told my wife, ''James Buchanan is my best friend.''
Well, it was one thing to fall in love with James Buchanan but another to try to write a historical novel. I found that I couldn't bring myself to do all the fakery necessary in writing a historical novel. Never having lived in a log cabin, I found myself inhibited about describing one; never having participated in a Washington 19th-century political parley, I found myself at a loss to imagine exactly what went on. Even things like buggies and spittoons loomed as mysterious. So I found myself balked in the attempt to write the Buchanan novel and I finally made it into a play, putting upon the director and the set designer all these difficult particulars that eluded me.
By now it was high time for me to write a novel. I had made a deal with myself at the beginning of this freelance career I've spoken of: I would give my publishers, to make up for the losses they'd suffered on the intervening books, a novel every other book, with collections of something or other in between. So the rhythm would go, presumably, loss, small gain, loss, small gain. It was novel time, and Buchanan hadn't worked out as a hero.
And there was all this distress around me - Vietnam distress, race riots, marches, agitation of all sorts. Suddenly it seemed to me that Rabbit Angstrom of Pennsylvania, about whose future some people had expressed curiosity, might be the vehicle in which to package some of the American unease that was raging all around us. And so I wrote ''Rabbit Redux.'' It felt good to be back in the present tense and good to try to locate in this small section of southeastern Pennsylvania echoes and ramifications of the national and international disturbances that were so preoccupying in the late 60's.
Having composed, then, one sequel, and having had the sequel fairly well received, obliged me, it seemed, to write another; one sequel leads to another. A motive of the artistic life, after all, is the completion of sets. That childhood instinct we have to make collections, to tidy up and round out, affects adult enterprises as well.
But in the meantime, I had a whole decade to live, on my own track. People would ask me, ''What's Harry doing?'' as though he was a real person, but I had no idea what he was doing. For one thing, I lived in Massachusetts and he was living in Pennsylvania. I didn't even know he'd become a car dealer.
When the time came, when 1979 came - each novel, by the way, was written in a different house, as it turned out, at a different address - I was in a different town, I had a different wife, a different sense of myself. I was full of beans, really, looking back on it from my present relatively beanless condition. I was in my mid-40's, just a kid. The town we lived in, I should say, was away from the sea and in size and social atmosphere reminded me of the town in Pennsylvania, Shillington, that I had grown up in. The house was even the same shape - long and narrow, with a deep backyard. From the room I wrote in, I saw rows of yellow school buses. I was at home in America, all right.
I needed a hook, into 1979. I mean, what can you say? Although the first novel had had a few overheard news items in it, it wasn't really in a conscious way about the 50's. It just was a product of the 50's; it was a helplessly 50's kind of book written by a sort of helplessly 50's guy. The 60's were much more self-conscious, much more conscious of themselves as a decade. The 70's seemed somewhat amorphous.
But we happened to be in Pennsylvania, staying with some friends of my wife's, and it was June, and there was some anxiety about our getting away because there were terrible gas lines all over the state. And my host was so hostly, or else so keen on our departure, that he rose very early in the morning and got in my car and went and waited in a gas line to get me gas to get out of there. So the gas crunch became my hook: running out of gas, which is the first phrase in ''Rabbit Is Rich.'' The general sense of exhaustion, inflation, Jimmy Carter's fainting during one of his trots - all that seemed to add up to a national picture.
The paradox was that although the theme was running out of gas, I was feeling pretty good. And so the book is kind of an upbeat book in spite of itself. It's really a cheerful book, very full, it seems to me insofar as I can be a critic, of itself and its material. I really had to cut it short at the end - it was threatening to go on forever. Tennyson said what he wanted was a novel that would go on forever, but it's not what I want. So I moved briskly to the arrival of Angstrom's granddaughter in his arms; the book is really about his becoming a grandfather, written years before I myself became one. He is rich in a number of ways, and discovers of course that to be rich is just another way of being poor, that your needs expand with your income and the world eventually takes away what it gives.
But it's a big, basically bouncy book that won prizes. Why some books win prizes and others don't is a mystery. In part it was that by this time, I'd been around so long, and was obviously working so hard, that people felt sorry for me and futhermore hoped that if Rabbit and I received a prize we would go away and put an end to this particular episode in American letters. But no, I've felt obliged to produce a fourth!
Again, I groped for the hook. It was quite easy to have a blank mind about the 80's; there was a distinct fuzziness about it. It was Ronald Reagan's decade and very cool, in the McLuhanesque sense, and all I really knew was that my hero would be 10 years older and probably feeling no better than I did, and maybe even a little worse - since he had peaked earlier than I did. I saw him in Florida. I thought a new state might perk up Rabbit readers. The Updikes - a branch of them, my father's brother and sister - went down to Florida in the 1920's when their own father, my grandfather, became ill with tuberculosis, and so Florida has some personal relevancy for me - a warm spot in my heart, you might say. Also, my mother for almost as long as I knew her had been trying to write a novel about the discoverer of Florida, Ponce de Leon. So I made some trips, in 1988 I think it must have been, to gather background.
I couldn't wait to begin the book; the opening of it occurs late in 1988, after the Presidential election and just after the crash of Pan Am Flight 103 in Lockerbie. In writing, I several times had to stop to let real time catch up with my fictional time. The private events are the main thing, of course, but you don't want some public event, atomic war or a giant earthquake, to cancel the world and make everything anachronistic. A few months after I began, in April of 1989, my mother was hospitalized, and from then on I had to keep making trips to Pennsylvania to check on things. I had a hard time keeping momentum, and noticed in rereading, even on the last set of proofs, some repetitions and inconsistencies.
You might say it's a depressed book about a depressed man, written by a depressed man. Deciding to wind up the series was a kind of death for me. Even though I left Pennsylvania in the early 50's, as long as my parents were alive I had a living link with the state. My father died in 1972 but my mother lived on, and so I had continuing reasons to visit Rabbit's territory, to refresh my sense of it and check up on changes. But as she became older I saw that my link would end someday, and end with it my grip on Rabbit's world. My mother died in October, 10 days after I finished the first draft; her dying became interwoven with my own sense of aging and my hero's even more severe sense of aging.
Yet all those visits, to her in the hospital and out of it - I hadn't had such a strong dose of my native turf since leaving it for college. My fictional city of Brewer is, I guess it's no secret to say, based on Reading, in Berks County. And though I was raised in a suburb of Reading, I had never lived there, and putting Rabbit into Brewer in ''Rabbit, Run'' was actually an act of fantasy, something like the country of Kush in ''The Coup,'' and I got the geography all scrambled up, and it's all rather vague and, as it seemed to me at the time, enchanted. In ''Rabbit at Rest'' it's less vague - the area at last, in my taking leave of it, began to make sense.
Another reason for winding up: I felt that if I was going to make a kind of meganovel out of the series, and bring all the threads to a gathering, four novels was about the limit. We've all heard of tetralogies, but after that there's no word for it. And with sequels, there is an accumulation of loose threads, of characters you invented and used, so that the elements increase geometrically, and beyond four would become very messy. Even so, each Rabbit book has been longer than the preceding, and this is the longest.
The action ends in October; I used Hurricane Hugo to round out the climax, but of course the events that now seem important about 1989 - the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe - occurred quite late in the year. But Rabbit feels them coming - at one point he asks himself, ''If there's no Cold War, what's the point of being an American?'' His sense of being useless, of being pushed to one side by his wife and son, has this political dimension, then. Like me, he has lived his adult life in the context of the cold war. He was in the Army, ready to go to Korea, hawkish on Vietnam, proud of the moon shot, and in some sense always justified, at the back of his mind, by a concept of freedom, of America, that took sharpness from contrast with Communism. If that contrast is gone, then that's another reason to put him, regretfully, to rest in 1990.
This essay is adapted from remarks made before the American Booksellers Association convention in Las Vegas in June.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 30, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 293 words

HEADLINE: Race, Ethnicity and the Privileged

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Perhaps I should be grateful to Andrew Hacker for mentioning my book ''Preferential Policies'' (July 1) during his long editorial on affirmative action. However, I must reply to his sheer invention of ''Mr. Sowell's contention that the ways groups get distributed are largely a matter of choice'' - an invention that sets up his cheap shot that my position leads to the conclusion that a predominantly black custodial work force at Queens College would indicate ''black people prefer sweeping up.'' 
Contrary to Mr. Hacker's remark, ''Preferential Policies'' - like all my other books on race and ethnicity - argues that there are innumerable factors determining economic outcomes. For example, on page 129 I refer to ''the many variables determining the interest, skill, and performance of those individuals from various groups who are being considered for particular jobs, roles, or institutions.'' After discussing two of these factors, I then refer to ''innumerable other factors, of varying degrees of complexity and influence.'' Did Mr. Hacker not read that far? Or did he find it necessary to reduce a serious, painful and dangerously polarizing social issue to a false dichotomy between ''choice'' and racial discrimination?
Nor does it help matters for Mr. Hacker to make the lofty but confused statement that ''the line between choice and constraint is seldom distinct.'' There is no such line, distinct or indistinct: all choices are made within constraints. The nature and variety of those constraints, the nature and variety of the incentives at work and the nature and variety of the groups involved are what ''Preferential Policies'' is all about - not Mr. Hacker's cheap dichotomy.
 
THOMAS SOWELL
Stanford, Calif.
