LENGTH: 243 words

HEADLINE: Race, Ethnicity and the Privileged

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As an African-American who worked at the United States Consulate in Madras, India, for four years, I feel compelled to respond to the terribly distorted parallel Thomas Sowell attempts to draw between the unique experience of the ''scheduled castes,'' or so-called untouchables, in India and that of affirmative action for African-Americans.
While Indira Gandhi was perhaps one of the most Machiavellian politicians I have ever observed up close, it is a credit to her administration that she (a light-skinned member of a privileged group) persistently pushed for an enlightened response to the deplorable economic and social conditions of the darker-skinned scheduled castes in her country. An estimated 500 million people in India still live in villages, and many of them are part of the scheduled castes. Did Mr. Sowell look closely at the rationale for reserving places at the universities for the darker-skinned ''untouchable'' applicants to Indian medical and engineering schools? If so, he would have found that the privileged classes can buy their way into and through these professional schools with rupees and dollars. In a nation where a servant must survive on $15 to $40 a month in wages, which is tantamount to economic bondage even in India, very few members of the scheduled castes have access to sufficient amounts of money to assure them a place in a medical or engineering school.
 
M. ANTHONY FITCHUE
New York

SECTION: Section 10; Page 3, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1459 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: House Auctions;
Stirring Up the Buyers in a Slow Market

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
The housing auctioneers put in a good day's work June 23 at the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel. With 800 people in the audience, 68 apartments at a condominium called Executive Plaza, at Seventh Avenue and 51st Street, went on sale.
They were the remaining inventory still held by the sponsor after a conversion of the 1,400-room Taft Hotel in 1986 to a mixed-use building. It has separate condominiums for stores and a seven-floor luxury hotel, now the Parc One, as well as a 445-room residential component.
''We built one of the finest hotels in New York City and the assumption was that the stuff upstairs would appreciate,'' said Andrew S. Goodstein, vice president of Goodstein Development Company, a partner in the sponsorship group. ''But when the market turned down we decided we might as well sell.'' 
Of the 68 units, with a total offering-plan price of $17 million, a total of 57 were sold at the auction for $9.3 million. That was 32 percent below the pre-auction offering prices, but enough to satisfy the sponsor, who held back only 11 apartments. ''People had been afraid to buy because they thought the market might drop further,'' Mr. Goodstein said. ''But seeing everybody bidding on the same unit assures the buyer of value.''
For buyers and seller alike, the Executive Plaza auction seems to have been a success. But there have been unsuccessful auctions as well, few buyers turn out, few bid, and the seller withdraws the units. Poorley conceived or designed housing is not necessarily going to attract competitive bidding at auction, although it might help establish what the true market for the housing is.
The longer-term question is whether the auctioneers will succeed in making the technique a fixture in American home sales once the market gains strength.
Some are trying, but it won't be easy. ''In general the public believes the auction is the ultimate fire sale,'' said Louis Goodkin, head of the Goodkin Research Group in Lauderdale-by-the-Sea, Fla., noting that they had been used extensively after the 70's slump in Florida real estate. About a third of the buyers were investors, ready to rent out the housing and await appreciation after the developer, or an institutional lender who had taken over the inventory, had given up.
Sellers themselves usually do not think of auctions as fire sales and auctioneers do not promote them that way. They are essentially trying to stir up excitement in a drab market. A sizable sale at a reasonable discount can provide more cash than the seller would get after a long holding period and expensive sales costs.
But some brokers believe that auctions could serve a wider and longer-term purpose. Perhaps they could be elevated to the status of art and antique auctions, which have hardly led to price depreciation for those products. It will not be easy, in American society. But the auctioneers, who typically earn a negotiated commission based on gross sales, like to look abroadf fror precedent.
Kenneth M. Lusht, chairman of the department of insurance and real estate at Pennsylvania State University, tells of house auctions in Melbourne, Australia, in a study sponsored by the National Association of Realtors.
Auctions there are held in established neighborhoods for property in high demand, he said. There is no announcement of what price a seller will accept, and he can refuse the best offer. The auction is used in rising markets by sellers to get better prices. Mr. Lusht found that prices averaged 7 percent higher in auction sales than in privately negotiated sales for similar houses.
''It's a Saturday morning sport it to go to the house and watch a $500,000 sale on the front lawn,'' he said. ''In the United States, the mindset is that if there's an auction, something is wrong. If people could be educated that an auction is not a distress sale and it would be used in active markets, then as far as I could tell it would benefit the seller.''
In New York City, the Corcoran Group and Halstead Properties would like to enlist high-priced properties in auction sales. Corcoran expects to hold an auction in October of 15 to 25 Manhattan condominiums that have asking prices of more than $1 million. It will avoid co-ops on the theory that resistance from boards of directors might complicate matters.
Halstead says it is exploring the possibility, gearing its approach to smaller apartments in newer condominiums with oung owners who need to move. ''We would agree with the sellers on a confidential reserve price,'' said Clark Halstead.
But these plans clearly are a response to the soft market. Barbara Corcoran, president of the Corcoran Group, said that the condominiums she plans to auction have been on the sales market for an average of six months. Most of the sellers are individuals still living in their apartments but eager to sell and move. They are asked to advance 1 percent of the asking sale price for the promotional fee for the auction.
The longer-term consequences of the use of auctions are disturbing to those interested in sustaining longterm home values. The general home-owning public no less than home builders have a stake in nurturing long-term appreciation in the face of cycles in the sales market.
Martin Berger, a principal in the Robert Martin Company of White Plains, one of Westchester's largest developers, said that auctions create instability and make people feel that what may be their main investment in life is insecure.
He criticizes developers for auctioning off property even in a soft market. ''In a soft market the last thing that anyone needs is an atmosphere of instability,'' he said.
But smaller builders with unsuccessful sales cannot necessarily hold out. Carrying their pitch to developers, auctioneers like Sheldon Good, the Chicago real-estate man who organized the Executive Plaza sale and many others nationally, says, ''Discounts off asking prices now can range between zero and 20 percent. In a slow market with the high cost of carrying property, in a year or two they'll need 50 to 60 percent discounts.''
At Executive Plaza, centralized location was a telling factor for a youthful, international buying clientele that probably does not intend to remain too many years using that location for a fulltime primary residence. The sale cost the sponsor $500,000 plus a negotiated commission, probably somewhat below the 6 percent of gross sales the auctioneer asks.
Abraham Eisner, executive vice president of Gelt Funding, which provided mortgages for most buyers, said that 30 of the 55 buyers it supplied with loans were either private investors or corporations seeking apartments for their transient people. Only 19 sales were made for owner-occupancy. Six of the purchasers were buying Manhattan apartments for occasional use.
Sometimes, auctions can stimulate sales in family housing as well. In Brooklyn, several thousand people turned out for an auction of 50 apartments by Sheldon Good in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn. They were in Borough Park Village, a 122-unit gut rehabilitation of five buildings on 51st and 52d Streets between 18th and 19th Avenues. Apartments had sold so well at $140 a square foot in 1986 that the sponsor raised them to $180 a square foot, said Shmuel Lefkowitz, president of Prime Resources Group, the selling agent. Sales slumped.
''Even in the summer of '87 the economy began going down,'' said Mr. Lefkowitz. But all 50 units sold in one auction at 25 percent to 35 percent below the book price. Four-bedroom, 1,800-square-foot apartments that had been offered for $312,000 typically went at auction for at about $230,000.
Borough Park Village exemplifies a development that even before the auction had attracted buyers. But it needed the stimulus of the auction approach to shove it out of the sales doldrum at realistically lower prices. The first 12 apartments were offered on an absolute basis, and the sponsor, satisfied with the prices, gradually offered the rest that was as the auction proceeded.
The successful auctions - the only ones the sellers are willing to talk about - have proven that there is a market ready to buy property. They have occurred in a weak market and probably will have the salutary effect of reducing inventory and laying the groundwork for greater firmness and stability to come.
But the longer term use of auctions in the marketing of houses to users seems more questionable. A house in its setting is a unique product. Most sellers will not want to take the risk or accept the expense of offering their houses for sale in such a process. And most buyers probably won't want to leave their decisions on where to live or when to move to the uncertainties of an auction process.

An article on Aug. 5 about housing auctions misidentified the hotel at the base of the Executive Plaza condominium in midtown Manhattan. It is Parc Fifty-One.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
The Art Of Politics Goes Abstract

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT gubernatorial races have generally been pretty straightforward affairs: two parties, two candidates; no muss, no fuss. Each side lined up, snarled a bit and retired to the voting booths, where Democrats usually voted Democratic, and Republicans lost.
This year, you can't track the permutations and possibilities without a scorecard. The theme, however, remains clear: nothing is quite what it was. For Democrats, Republicans and those somewhere between, the old equations about how one reaches the governor's chair have been complicated by new variables - from the mixed legacy of a departing incumbent, to the implications of an angry electorate and an ailing state economy, to an independent candidate who has party stalwarts rethinking their loyalties and priorities.
''It's uncharted territory,'' said Everett C. Ladd, a professor of political science at the University of Connecticut and the director of the university's Roper Center for Public Opinion Research. 
Former United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., of Greenwich, is generally considered a major source of the atmospheric disturbance that has sent so much of the old order flying. A Republican who jilted his party to run as an independent, Mr. Weicker has led the opinion polls since he joined the race and has garnered endorsements from people in both parties. His clarion call, in speeches throughout the state, is that voters should throw out the bath water and not worry too much who or what gets lost in the process.
''We have deregulated very many things,'' Mr. Weicker said recently. ''It's high time we deregulated politics.'' A monopoly on power by the two-party system, he said, has had the same effects that monopoly has in business: ''bad product and high prices.''
Bound up with Mr. Weicker's appeal, but separate from it, pollsters say, is a groundswell of anger and dismay among voters about taxes, the state's floundering economy and what people appear to feel is a decline in the state's quality of life. Gov. William A. O'Neill, who led the state through the 1980's, felt the wrath first, and he ultimately withdrew from the race for re-election in March, as his approval ratings plummeted.
The leading Democrat who is trying to succeed Mr. O'Neill, United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison, of Hamden, has been forced onto what he has conceded is something of a tightrope. His campaign has been based around encouraging voters to vent their feelings about the need for change, but not too much change. All Democrats should not take the blame, he argues, only the old ones, like Mr. O'Neill.
''There's a potential for conflict,'' Mr. Morrison said in discussing his message to voters. ''But my idea is that we need to get back to basics, what the Democratic party has stood for.''
The possibility of a state income tax has been a major theme of the Democrats' intraparty debate. Mr. Morrison, who is considered one of the most liberal members of the state's Congressional delegation, has spoken in favor of a progressive wage tax that would ease tax burdens on the poor. Mr. O'Neill, by contrast, stood staunchly against an income tax.
This summer, however, Mr. Morrison began to step away from an income tax, saying he would veto it unless it was proven to have the support of a majority of voters. Mr. O'Neill, on the other hand, has appeared to tacitly endorse the one candidate in the race who openly supports a wage tax, State Representative William J. Cibes Jr., of New London, who will face Mr. Morrison in the Democratric primary on Sept. 11.
 
'Force for Change'
Although Mr. O'Neill has not publicly endorsed Mr. Cibes, he has repeatedly called him a good and loyal friend whose efforts to be heard as a candidate should be supported. Members of the Governor's staff are also working on Mr. Cibes's behalf, as are the Governor's chief campaign fund-raisers.
Mr. Weicker, who remains a Republican while running under his owner Connecticut Party banner, has said he would endorse Mr. Morrison if he were not running himself.
The Republicans' candidate is Representative John G. Rowland, of Waterbury.
''Who is the force for change?'' asked Professor Ladd. ''Is it Wiecker, or Rowland, or in some sense is it Morrison? I think the race could be very volatile in those last weeks.''
He said he believes that the winner in November will likely be the candidate who most thoroughly convinces voters that new breezes will blow in Hartford, and that despite Mr. Weicker's lead in the polls, ''it's not clear yet how the impulse for change will attach itself.''
A poll released last week by the Roper Center's Institute for Social Inquiry indicated that the race has tightened. Of 500 residents statewide questioned between July 23 and July 30, 37 percent said they liked Mr. Weicker, down from 41 percent in mid- to late-June. Twenty percent said they supported Mr. Rowland, up from 11 percent in June.
 
Political Evolution
Mr. Morrison's support also increased, though by a smaller margin, to 13 percent of the respondants, up from 9 percent. Mr. Cibes fared even more poorly, with only 7 percent saying they would support him in a three-way race against Mr. Weicker and Mr. Rowland. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points.
Among the Republicans - the minority party in the state, with about 470,000 registered voters, compared with about 680,000 registered Democrats and 580,000 unaffiliated voters - there have also been plenty of signs that political life is evolving.
There have been party jumpers, party joiners and those who - against every grain of party tradition - say they want the Democrats to do well in November, because that might hurt Mr. Weicker, who has shown popularity among Democrats.
There also seems to be a bit of confusion: the Republican Party's state chairman, Richard Foley, argued for months that people who desert the party are turncoats who should no longer be trusted. Among those who came under particular fire was the Republican minority leader in the State Senate, Reginald J. Smith, of New Hartford, who went to work for Mr. Weicker.
Then, last month, Mr. Rowland decided he wanted a Democrat, Joan R. Kemler, for State Treasurer on his ticket. Ms. Kemler, who served as a temporary Treasurer under Mr. O'Neill in 1986, promptly changed her party affiliation. Then Mr. Foley said that Republicans should seek qualified people whereever it can find them and not be blinded by party labels.
A spokesman for Mr. Rowland, Jack R. Goldberg, said Ms. Kemler was chosen because she was the best person for the job, but he added that if Democratic voters are wooed into accepting Mr. Rowland's ticket as a hybrid, ''that would be fine.''
 
'Major Party' Status
Leaders of both traditional parties are wondering whether this year's three-way race could change Connecticut's political landscape, especially if Mr. Weicker should win by a large margin. If the Republican or Democratic candidate receives less than 20 percent of the general election vote, for example, his party would lose ''major party'' status under the state election law. For the losing party, that the blow could be devastating. Currently, in a town election, if a majority of voters approves a Republican ticket for the board of selectmen or the school board, the minority position on the board automatically goes to the Democrats.
If the Democrats or Republicans were squeezed under that 20 percent wire, Mr. Weicker's Connecticut Party, would become the state's new major party, entitled to a position on all those local boards.
''For both Republicans and Democrats, the priority is to beat Lowell Weicker,'' said Mr. Cibes's campaign manager, Jonathan Pelto, the former political director the state Democratic Party. ''With Mr. Weicker out of the way, the long-term threat is eliminated.''
On other hand, Mr. Pelto said he believes Mr. Weicker's candidacy has helped the Democrats in their hopes of retaining control of the General Assembly. With both Mr. Weicker and Mr. Rowland scrambling for campaign funds among Republicans, Mr. Pelto said, the pool of money available to Republican Assembly challengers has been cut.
''Six months ago, I would have said that the Democrats would have lost control of the Assembly,'' he said. ''Now I think they will probably remain in control.''

CORRECTION-DATE: August 19, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 5 about the gubernatorial campaign misstated the position of a Democratic candidate, Representative Bruce A. Morrison, on a state income tax. Mr. Morrison said that as a public official, he had never advocated an income tax for Connecticut.

LENGTH: 263 words

HEADLINE: Because of Kessel, High Electric Costs

 BODY:
The Long Island Power Authority is the wrong agency, at the wrong time, doing the wrong job in an ineffectual and inefficient manner. The threat of taking over Lilco is no longer credible, and we certainly don't need the Long Island Power Authority to decommission Shoreham. 
The problem at Lilco now is a runaway management that subordinates the public interest to personal greed and the whimsical meanderings of an ever expanding ego.
Any company which, at about the same time, has the highest rates in the nation, a chief executive with salary and benefits to rival a maharajah, a reliability record approached only by ''wrong way Corrigan'' and an advertising budget that knows no bounds is a company out of control. All the press releases by Governor Cuomo, Mr. Kessel and the local politicians will not get it under control. The Public Service Commission is as useless as the Long Island Power Authority and the Consumer Protection Board.
What is needed is something like what the Municipal Assistance Corporation (Big Mac) was for New York City. We need legislation to set up an agency to oversee Lilco's budgets (including salaries, bonuses, pensions, consulting agreements and golden parachutes), enforce standards of service reliability and curb the excesses of Lilco's management. The rationale for such an arrangement would be the bail-out given so generously to Lilco by New York State. If we don't do this, we can anticipate that a runaway Lilco management will continue to suck the life out of Long Island's economy.
 
HENRI ZEICHNER
 Plainview

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Florio's Tax Changes: Courageous, but More Are Needed

BYLINE: By John Atlas; John Atlas of Montclair is a public-interest lawyer and co-chairman of New Jersey Citizen Action, a coalition of 65 civic, community and other groups, based in Hackensack.

 BODY:
IN the face of a huge deficit, a school finance crisis and a tax structure unfair to working families, Gov. Jim Florio's tax increase was an act of courage and leadership.
He broke with Democratic leaders across the country who have been too timid to challenge the Republican tax policies that favor the rich at the expense of nearly everyone else. Jim Florio may be the Roosevelt of the 90's, ushering in a new era of progressive reform.
As Governor, he inherited a tax system that taxed the middle class at a much higher rate than millionaires.
A recent study by Citizen for Tax Justice, a research group based in Washington, shows that a middle-income family of four (making about $53,000 a year) in New Jersey actually shells out a larger share of its income in state and local taxes than a family earning more than $900,000. The middle-class family pays 9.7 percent of its income in property, sales, excise and income taxes; the wealthy family pays only 8.2 percent of its income in these taxes. 
Meanwhile, low-income working families pay 12.7 percent of their total family income - 50 percent more than millionaires' tax rate.
In other words, the current state tax system takes its biggest bite out of families who are already being squeezed the hardest, those who find it tough just to pay the bills.
New Jersey's unfair system relies too much on regressive property and sales taxes. These are ''flat'' taxes that are not related to the ability to pay. The state's property tax rate is one of the highest in the country, hurting the middle-class homeowner. Meanwhile, the income tax rate on millionaires is one of the lowest in the nation.
Governor Florio's bold plan raises revenue from the well-to-do, who are currently paying far less state and local tax (as a share of income) than average working families.
It targets that money to finance education and to provide badly needed property tax relief for most New Jersey families. It also shifts financing responsibility for certain services (e.g., family support services) from localities to the state while implementing a property tax credit to provide relief to average-income homeowners. The Florio plan represents genuine leadership on tax reform. Entering office in January, Mr. Florio faced a daunting task trying to address the enormous state deficits, the need to pump new dollars into poor and middle-class school districts and the unfair tax system. His solution: tax the wealthiest New Jerseyans, the same folks who got a tax windfall under Ronald Reagan and who have paid so little at the state level. This initiative has earned Mr. Florio a national reputation as a bold, straight-talking leader.
Since 1968, Republicans have dominated national politics by wooing the middle class with populist attacks on inflation, social programs and so-called ''big government.''
Mr. Florio is trying to show the Democrats how to woo a new coalition that brings together the poor, the working class and the middle class. In doing so, he is seeking to overcome racial and cultural divisions that have separated working-class whites from minority voters and middle-class liberals.
Will the Governor emerge as the populist national figure blazing a path for a timid Democratic Party? The pendulum of American history is on his side. Political experts suggest that the era of the Reagan revolution is over.
But policy shifts are not inevitable. Those concerned about education, the environment, public ethics, homelessness, civil rights, affordable health care, a fair tax system and closing the gap between rich and poor have a stake in Mr. Florio's success. The eyes of the nation will be watching New Jersey to see if his policies work, politically as well as economically.
Mr. Florio's plan is not perfect, though it stands as the best that could be accomplished now. A better plan would be more progressive and provide more property tax relief.
Despite criticism from conservatives, the Florio plan makes a very regressive system somewhat less regressive.
Under the Florio plan, the richest families are still taxed at a rate that is less than that of the poor. The richest 1 percent of New Jerseyans will pay 11.3 percent of family income; the poor will pay 12.8 percent.
The gap is even wider when Federal income tax deductions for state and property taxes (a benefit that accrues only to homeowners who itemize) are included. The total burden on the poor (who do not itemize) stays at 12.8 percent while falling to 8.8 percent for the $900,000-a-year family.
A better plan, like the one proposed by New Jersey Citizen Action, a nonprofit organization whose purpose is to increase citizen participation in government, would do the following:
* Furnish more property tax relief by providing for state financing of the judiciary, which is now paid for out of local property taxes. The Governor's plan does not provide state financing.
* Adopt a tax credit of up to $750 for both homeowners and tenants, which kicks in whenever property taxes exceed 4 percent of family income, for families with income up to $75,000. The Governor's plan has a tax credit of only $500 for families with income below $70,000.
* Eliminate some of the sales and excise taxes, which hurt the middle class and the poor. The Florio sales and excise tax increase takes away part of the relief it provides elsewhere to middle-income and lower-income families.
* Eliminate special advantages that a few large, profitable corporations enjoy. The Florio plan is for the most part silent on the issue of corporate taxes.
* Impose a top marginal income tax rate of 8 percent for those whose income exceeds $250,000. The Governor's top marginal rate is 7 percent for those whose income exceeds $150,000.
In addition, the Governor needs to develop a closer working relationship with grass-roots groups that espouse the political and economic concerns of poor and middle-class people and the elderly, on a wide range of issues - from the environment, to education, to jobs and housing. Independent grass-roots groups can help sell and support his policies.
The wealthy are already mobilizing, arguing that the Florio plan will hurt New Jersey's economy. But corporations across the country realize that services are as important as taxes in assessing the relative strengths and weaknesses of the business climate from state to state. Issues like financing for schools and roads, which affect the quality of life, are often more important to business than corporate tax levels.
Taxes are not the most critical factor. If they were, everyone would locate in low-tax and poor states like Mississippi.
We must streamline state government, improve services for the public and reform our unfair tax system. We can do all three.
The state's fiscal crisis is real. Government must be cost-effective. There is no excuse for waste, cronyism, sweetheart contracts and a bloated management cadre. These are unacceptable vestiges of a brand of politics we can no longer afford.
We cannot stick our heads in the sand and pretend that spending cuts can solve everything. We cannot ignore legitimate public needs, slough off more responsibility to local government and return to an unfair tax structure.
A more progressive tax system and the mobilization of grass-roots citizens can help Jim Florio ride the crest of history.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); 

STATE: NEW JERSEY, USA (96%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: ;NEW JERSEY

SUBJECT: TAXATION; FINANCES; BUDGETS AND BUDGETING; EDITORIALS; REFORM AND REORGANIZATION TAXES & TAXATION (97%); FAMILY (92%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (90%); MIDDLE INCOME PERSONS (90%); TAX LAW (90%); PERSONAL & FAMILY INCOME (90%); TAX INCREASES (90%); TAX REFORM (89%); TAX RELIEF (89%); PROPERTY TAX (89%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (89%); EDUCATION FUNDING (89%); GOVERNORS (89%); REAL ESTATE (78%); FAMILY SERVICES (78%); SALES TAX (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (78%); SCHOOL DISTRICTS (78%); HOMEOWNERS (78%); BUDGETS (78%); US STATE GOVERNMENT (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (78%); POLITICAL PARTIES (77%); INCOME TAX (75%); LOW INCOME PERSONS (74%); REAL ESTATE MARKET (72%); EDITORIALS & OPINIONS (59%);

133 of 925 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1, Column 5; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1865 words

HEADLINE: Brodsky's Role Sets Campaign Agenda

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
AS Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky sees it, the recently concluded legislative session in Albany was a nearly unqualified success. ''We ended spring borrowing, funded the libraries, improved reimbursement rates for hospitals, increased school aid'' and, in general, ''cut spending by state agencies while improving fiscal aid to local governments.''
Mr. Brodsky, a four-term Democrat who sees himself as the leader of the Westchester delegation in the Assembly because of his seniority in that Democratically controlled chamber, said, ''Westchester did fabulously, with its best year economically.'' He said the ''county's share of budget actions in aid of municipalities is just over $45 million.''
The view from elsewhere in Westchester produces a different image, however, even among fellow Democrats. They see a mixed record, with most of the criticism focused on a single item: the inability of the county's elected officials to persuade the Westchester delegation in Albany to press for an increase in the county sales tax. 
 
$96 Million to Share
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, a Republican who resisted Mr. Brodsky's efforts last year to replace him as the county's top elected official, had proposed raising the tax by 1.5 percent, to 7.25 percent, with villages, towns and the cities of Peekskill and Rye, their school districts and the county government sharing an estimated $96 million in increased tax revenues.
Proponents said that enacting the tax would help forestall another steep rise in county property taxes next year, but it never came up for a vote in Albany. Although the Westchester delegation was split on the issue, Mr. Brodsky was identified with its eventual demise.
''Why did I oppose the sales tax?'' he asked rhetorically in a recent interview. ''Because to throw good money after bad for this government,'' he said, referring to Mr. O'Rourke's administration, ''is crazy.''
He described Mr. O'Rourke's budget helmsmanship as ''a fiscal basket case.'' He said the county government was ''out of control, and without a spending cap and spending cuts there is no point in giving them huge new revenues.''
 
Brodsky as Gatekeeper
The image of Mr. Brodsky setting terms as the legislative gatekeeper in the Assembly has bothered county government officials and annoyed some Democratic legislators, who see say Mr. Brodsky as ignoring a bipartisan effort on the Board of Legislators to find budget cuts. It has also fixed the political agenda for this year's Assembly election in Greenburgh.
Mr. Brodsky is being challenged by Louis Giampiccolo Jr. of Tarrytown, a 29-year-old International Business Machines employee. He is making his first run for elected office, but knows a political issue when he sees one. Beginning his campaign with a broad attack on ''Democratic spending policies,'' he has since narrowed his comments to the sales tax impasse and his opponent's role in it.
Mr. Brodsky ''can't have it both ways,'' Mr. Giampiccolo said. ''His demands that the county government cap spending are ludicrous, to say the least, when he voted to increase state taxes and fees by a record $3.2 billion - $1.4 billion last year and $1.8 billion this year.''
The Republican candidate, who also has Conservative Party endorsement, said Mr. Brodsky ''has voted against Republican initiatives seeking a cap on state spending, but he never fails to vote for state mandates that the county must enact and tax local taxpayers for.''
 
What Increase Would Have Meant
Not surprisingly, Mr. Giampiccolo has translated what he said the proposed sales-tax increase would have meant to the town of Greenburgh, which represents most of the 87th Assembly District he is seeking to represent. The rest of the district is in northwest Yonkers.
The sales tax, if enacted, would have represented $4.2 million to the town's six villages, $2.5 million to the eight school districts and $4 million to the town government itself, Mr. Giampiccolo said.
Mr. Brodsky said there was no question that the towns, villages and school districts ''deserved'' sharing in the proposed sales-tax increase. ''But why shouldn't all of it go back to the communities,'' he asked, ''since the tax is generated in those communities?
''In fact, if Greenburgh wanted to go from 5.75 percent to 7.25 percent, it could do so today without a law and it would be up to the county to pre-empt it. I'm willing to engage in constructive discussion with anyone, including Andy and the Board, about what it would take to get my support.''
 
Democrats Challenge Brodsky Role
Mr. Brodsky's position has been challenged by some Democrats on the Board of Legislators. A bipartisan resolution seeking the Albany delegation's support in getting the proposed sales-tax increase on the floor of the Legislature included a pledge ''of a zero percent increase in the property tax,'' said Sandra R. Galef, the Democratic minority leader.
''That would apply to the first year, with any increase in the second year limited to the cost of living,'' Mrs. Galef said. ''This legislation had the full support of the Democratic caucus'' on the Board of Legislators, ''and the Albany delegation should have at least put it on the agenda.''
Although Mr. Brodsky had not been shy in accepting responsibility for the proposal's rejection, she said that ''he was not the only member of our delegation opposed to it.'' At least one other Democrat, Assemblyman Ronald C. Tocci of New Rochelle, opposed it.
Only one Republican in the county's Assembly delegation, Assemblywoman Cecile D. Singer, who represents Eastchester, Scarsdale and northeast Yonkers, said she favored putting it on the agenda. In the State Senate, which is controlled by Republicans, it also failed to reach the floor despite entreaties by Mr. O'Rourke.
 
'Quarrel Is With County Executive'
Legislator Audrey G. Hochberg, Democrat of Scarsdale, who is co-chairman with Legislator Timothy S. Carey, Republican of Montrose, of a newly formed committee seeking new revenues and spending cuts, said they were fully engaged in looking for the savings Mr. Brodsky was seeking.
She said she thought ''Richard's quarrel is more with the County Executive'' than with the Board of Legislators.
''This is only the first year of a new approach on the Board to deal with county issues through a bipartisan coalition,'' Mrs. Hochberg said. ''I don't think people outside of county government know how sincere and hard-working the coalition is.''
The coalition was formed late last year after Republicans ousted their long-term chairman, Edward J. Brady, Republican of Thornwood. It agreed on a replacement, John E. Hand, a Yorktown Heights Republican, who took office in the new session beginning in January.
Even before that, the coalition of six Republicans and five Democrats in the 17-member chamber worked together to reduce Mr. O'Rourke's proposed $1 billion budget for this year from a level that would have required a property-tax increase of 27 percent to one requiring a 17 percent increase.
 
Way Is Opened for a Higher Levy
Some funds were later restored, mostly through the use of 1989 surpluses that would otherwise have been used to reduce next year's budget. This procedure, frowned on by county budget officials, opens the way for an even higher property-tax levy next year and the need for the special commission on additional revenues and capital enhancements headed by Mr. Carey and Mrs. Hochberg.
Mrs. Hochberg said, ''We saw the sales tax proposal as a way of containing property-tax increases, and we did get some support, from Young, and Zaleski,'' she said, referring to Assemblymen Terence M. Zaleski of Yonkers and Gregory P. Young of Mount Vernon, both Democrats, ''and from Cecile Singer,'' the Eastchester Republican.
As for the Board's special commission, ''we have seen some slowdown in hiring,'' she said. The administration has agreed to the Board's request for quarterly reports, enabling the legislators to follow spending and hiring trends rather than getting their first look in November, when the next year's proposed budget is presented to the Board for approval.
As for the legislative session recently completed, ''It was very bad for us in terms of revenues,'' Mrs. Hochberg said. ''We were actively working toward entering Offtrack Betting, but changes made by the State Legislature would make it a less viable revenue source,'' she said.
The increased reimbursements for hospitals will be ''helpful,'' she said, ''but it will be somewhat offset by an increase in the county's payouts for Medicaid.'' The library financing, $15 million for the next three years statewide, represented a ''very small amount of money,'' she said.
 
Brodsky Cites Grants
Mr. Brodsky spoke enthusiastically of the environmental-quality bond act on the November ballot, ''which includes $300 million in matching grants for local recycling, of which Westchester should get $15 million.''
The county will collect an extra $2.4 million in sales-tax revenues, and its municipalities $2 million, he said, as areas covered by the tax were expanded to include auto rentals, parking, 900 additional-charge call-in telephone numbers and other services.
Mr. Brodsky also spoke of his role in heading the Assembly's Investigations Committee. The work of the committee, Mr. Brodsky said, has led to a reform of proprietary business schools, findings that the state's biggest polluters were state agencies and that local governments were violating prevailing wage laws.
 
The Opponent's Background
The Assemblyman's opponent, Mr. Giampiccolo, was born and raised in Tarrytown, where he said his family has lived for 60 years, and his father, Louis Sr., is the former deputy commissioner of public works for the town of Greenburgh.
The candidate graduated from Sleepy Hollow High School in 1978, from Fordham University in 1981 and from Pace University, where he received a degree in b usiness administration, in 1982.
He began working for I.B.M. in 1983 and is now a systems engineer in the marketing department of I.B.M.'s New York Media Branch office in Manhattan. He is a captain and a company commander in the U.S. Army Reserve where he began serving nine years ago, having graduated from Fordham's ROTC program.
 
Fed Up With 'Tax and Spend'
Mr. Giampiccolo said he was a Republican district leader in Tarrytown and has participated in community activities there. ''The reason I got involved in this year's election race,'' he said, ''was that, like many other taxpayers, I got fed up with the tax and spend attitude of our State Legislature.''
He said he would be asking Mr. Brodsky ''When are you going to stop running for County Executive?''
He said the Democrat also ''should be asked to tell his constituents why he does not support the proposed sales tax, even though it had overwhelming support in the Board of Legislators, where they agreed to a sunshine clause that if communities were not applying the new tax directly to tax relief, the state could revoke it.''
The Right to Life Party candidate in the 86th Assembly District race is Geraldine Timoney of Yonkers.

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 33, Column 2; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 2003 words

HEADLINE: THE SUMMER REPORT: CURRICULUM;
The Home Front

BYLINE: By Thomas C. Hayes

 BODY:
SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.
BUT even now, thunderclouds are gathering: a popular movement to train adults to be their children's first teachers is rumbling in the middle distance; commercial learning centers are raining on the independent tutoring market; community colleges are building up a new front, and parents are realizing with lightning clarity that the cost of college far exceeds tuition.
TIME to break out the umbrellas.
 
EACH WEEK, Blanca Nieto brings a storybook, a coloring book and printed sheets describing simple games and puzzles for Maria Acosta to explore with her youngest sons, who are ages 4 and 5. ''They are learning fast,'' said Mrs. Acosta, whose two older children go to school. ''They know colors, up and down, and how to compare big and small. I want them to get what we did not: to go to college, to get a career.'' 
Mrs. Nieto and Mrs. Acosta, Mexican-born daughters of migrant farm workers, are high school dropouts who married in their teens, bore children by their mid-20's and settled in the neighborhoods of West Dallas. They are also part of a broadening movement, with Mrs. Nieto as a group leader, that in the last few years has trained thousands of parents nationwide, including many from low-income families, to teach their young children in the home.
Missouri became the first state, in 1985, to offer an in-home preschool learning program to all residents. Today, school districts in Southern California, New Mexico, Texas, North Carolina, New York and Ohio are experimenting with Missouri's Parents As Teachers (P.A.T.) approach.
An Israeli model, the Home Instruction Program for Preschool Youngsters, has taken root in 13 states, including Texas, Arkansas and New York. Next month it will add Connecticut, Michigan, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia. Unlike P.A.T., this program, known by its acronym Hippy, aims for an older group, preparing 4- and 5-year-olds for the classroom and their parents for guiding and helping them learn.
 
'Programs Will Grow'
''Quality preschool programs can have an impact, especially on families with disadvantaged backgrounds,'' said Dr. Wade F. Horn, commissioner of Federal programs for children, youth and families in the Department of Health and Human Services. ''There is no question that these preschool, home-based programs will grow.''
Government support will likely spur that growth. The Bush Administration wants Federal spending for Head Start to rise by $500 million next year, to $1.8 billion. That would expand home education for preschoolers in low-income families to 60 percent of eligible households, from 37 percent, Federal officials said.
Bills pending before the House and Senate would use $100 million over five years to begin Parents As Teachers programs in 1,000 school districts. The bills envision Federal contributions declining to 75 percent of the original funding in three years and to 25 percent in five years. The legislation would also set up a National Parents As Teachers Center to advise state officials in training parent educators.
The new impetus for in-home preschool learning comes partly from recent studies showing that such programs give youngsters - especially those from low-income families - an edge after they enter grade school. Missouri educators, for example, found that 3-year-olds whose parents participated in the program since their children's birth were more adept at problem-solving, language and social skills than others not in the program.
Parents also seem to benefit, sometimes enrolling in classes to attain the diplomas that were beyond their grasp as teen-agers. Others are learning to read and write.
 
'Wants It for Her Child'
Deborah Troy, an unmarried mother of two children, 4 and 7, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, said that in the group of 10 parents she leads, a mother who cannot read is one of the most active members.
''She didn't get the education,'' Ms. Troy explained, ''so she wants it for her child.''
Ms. Troy, who is 28, said she wanted to complete secretarial courses at La Guardia Community College when her daughter, now 4, starts school. She said she had to quit college when her daughter was born.
The nation's most comprehensive, state-financed program for preschoolers is in Missouri. State Educators spread advice on child development, based on the writings of the child development experts Burton White and T. Berry Brazelton, to 100,586 families in the state with children ranging in age from week-old infants to 3-year-olds, with a few programs for 4-year-olds. State financing has grown to almost $13 million in the coming school year, up from $2.7 million in 1985-86, for a program that includes screening for medical and learning disorders.
The Missouri program aims to give parents or other care providers a practical awareness of child development stages from birth through age 3, using a combination of in-home visits and group sessions.
Karol Ackermann, a former program coordinator for a children's hospital, who lives in Florissant, Mo., a St. Louis suburb, signed up for the program at the hospital immediately after her son, Nathan, was born. Two weeks later a parent educator arranged a first visit. Nathan is now 3, and since his birth Mrs. Ackermann has worked with two parent advisers.
''I was concerned at one point that Nathan wasn't rolling over as soon as a lot of other mothers had told me their children had rolled over,'' she said. ''I was super-sensitive about this and overly concerned about a number of things. But the parent educator told me Nathan was setting his own timetable, and she pointed out areas where he was normal.''
Such tips are reinforced by monthly group meetings at a local elementary school or early childhood resource center. Participants range from affluent suburbanites past the age of 40 who are having their first child to impoverished, unmarried teen-age mothers.
 
Less Stress, More Fun
''Our assumption, going into any home, is that here are parents who love their children, want the best for their children and want to get information that can make parenting less stressful and more fun,'' said Sue Treffeisen, training coordinator for Parents As Teachers in St. Louis.
Home visits are scheduled in evenings, early mornings and on weekends, if necessary, to accommodate working parents or other care givers, such as grandparents or other family members, Mrs. Treffeisen said.
Hippy also assumes that parents, or other primary care givers, are a child's first teachers. Developed during the 1970's in Israel to bring literacy and learning skills to preschool children of low-income families, Hippy spread during the 1980's to a half-dozen other countries, including the United States. By September, some 4,000 American families, including those of Mrs. Nieto and Mrs. Acosta in Dallas and Ms. Troy in Brooklyn, will be teaching their youngsters using materials developed 21 years ago by Dr. Avima D. Lombard, now director of early childhood education at Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
So far, no public funds have been budgeted specifically for Hippy in the United States; rather, local administrators eke out financing elsewhere. In Arkansas, which has 2,000 families in Hippy, the most of any state, local school districts use Federal money budgeted for low-income children's programs such as Head Start, and for programs involving parents in school activities.
The Save the Children Foundation is administrator and major financial source for the Bedford-Stuyvesant program, which currently involves 70 families. In Dallas, the city's public school system sponsors a program for 30 families using state and Federal money allocated for bilingual studies and migrant-worker education. The Ford Foundation, the Lowe Foundation, the Wolens Foundation, the Hearst Foundation, the Hasbro Children's Foundation and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. have given Hippy USA in New York grants.
Dr. Miriam Y. Westheimer studied the causes of high dropout rates in New York schools for a dissertation at Columbia University's Teachers College. She has been national director of Hippy USA since it was organized two years ago under the auspices of the National Council of Jewish Women.
Dr. Westheimer said that tensions between community groups and school administrators and teachers in inner cities and low-income areas make cycles of bad learning habits, classroom frustration and unemployment hard to break. ''But if you can take kids when they are just starting out in school, and get parents and the community working with the schools, the chances of bridging those differences are much greater,'' she said.
Hippy's weapons in this battle include 18 storybooks, 60 activity packets and a set of 16 plastic shapes, which parents use with their preschoolers.
 
The First Teacher
In Dallas, parents, grandparents or other relatives in the program bring the children to group meetings every two weeks with their parent trainers and the program coordinator from the public schools.
''Hippy builds on the basic bond between parent and children,'' Dr. Westheimer said. ''Hippy works to make parents their children's first and most important teacher, which they are anyway.''
To accomplish this goal, Hippy requires local administrators to recruit and pay paraprofessional trainers, usually mothers with children already in Hippy, to distribute and collect learning materials every week. Trainers also explain the materials' use, often taking the role of the parent, with the parent responding as the child.
The paraprofessionals ''are the key,'' Dr. Westheimer said, noting: ''We would not allow a program to start where retired teachers, social workers or other professionals go into the home. By seeing eye to eye with the families, being from the community, paraprofessionals have a much better sense of the issues families face.''
Parents like Mrs. Nieto, one of two group leaders in the West Dallas home-study program, have more credibility with other low-income mothers, Dr. Westheimer said. ''People like Blanca tell us immediately that it's not that parents don't want to do anything for their children, which is said too often about low-income parents,'' she said. ''It's that they don't know what to do to get their kids to succeed in this system.''
 
Working 80 Hours
Mrs. Nieto, who is 28, joined the program with her 4-year-old daughter, Violeta, last year. Despite a full-time job on the night shift at a nearby manufacturing company, she said she worked as much as 80 hours a month on home-instruction visits and group sessions.
Her oldest son, Luis, who is 9, and her husband, Jose, a carpenter, also read stories to three younger children from books she brings to her home and to the homes of 14 other families in her group. In some cities, English and Spanish versions of the original Israeli materials are available, but for now Dallas administrators use only Spanish versions.
The Dallas school system pays Mrs. Nieto $7.48 an hour as a group leader, or nearly $1 an hour more than she earns at her factory job. School officials said the home-instruction effort costs an estimated $400 per child. By contrast, administrators of Missouri's P.A.T. say that that program costs between $210 and $225 per family.
Mrs. Nieto said she left high school, which she attended in four states each year as her parents kept step with farmers' harvesting and hiring seasons, after the 10th grade. But that wasn't because she didn't think education was valuable.
''I kept an encyclopedia for 10 years that one of the schools was going to throw out,'' she recalled, standing near a row of yellow tulips she tends in her front yard. ''The time we as parents can spend with our little children is special. I want all the education for my children that I can give them.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 42, Column 3; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 1448 words

HEADLINE: THE SUMMER REPORT;
Cultural Imperatives

BYLINE: By Margo Kaufman

 BODY:
SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.
BUT even now, thunderclouds are gathering: a popular movement to train adults to be their children's first teachers is rumbling in the middle distance; commercial learning centers are raining on the independent tutoring market; community colleges are building up a new front, and parents are realizing with lightning clarity that the cost of college far exceeds tuition.
TIME to break out the umbrellas.
 
WHILE educators feud over what constitutes ''cultural literacy'' and the best core curriculum for the nation at large, Americans go on cheerfully being regionally different in speech, thought, attitude and cultural referents. What is knowledge in Texas is ignorance in Minnesota, and vice versa. 
''Here, you have to know about the desert,'' said Nancy Baldwin, a program coordinator for the General Instrument Education Center, a management training company in Phoenix. ''You have to understand about heat. It can be 110 but you don't feel it because it's dry heat. The humidity is low so you don't sweat like you do when it's 90 in New Jersey.''
Should you still need to cool off, however, the shore is closer than it looks on a map.
''Because we're in the desert they've built this thing called Big Surf where you can go surfing,'' Ms. Baldwin explained. ''There is a manmade ocean wave with a sandy beach, palm trees and some quonset huts. For seven bucks a day you can go lie on the beach. It's like being in San Diego.'' Not exactly. ''You have to know when the tide is low,'' said David Bradley, a writer who divides his time between San Diego and Philadelphia. ''The difference between the beach being crowded or not in summertime depends on how much beach there is. When the tide is high there's 25 percent less beach than when the tide is low. Every January you get a tide book from the lifeguard department. It also lists the expected grunion runs.''
San Diego illiterati take note. Grunions are little fish that come up on the beach several times a year to spawn. ''It happens at night,'' Mr. Bradley said. ''You take beer and a friend down to the beach and watch.''
Every city has its own definition of a hot date. In San Francisco, it's dinner at Stars and a night at the opera. In Fort Lauderdale, it's racing the cigarette boat down the Intracoastal Waterway and - barring an unfortunate encounter with the Florida Marine Patrol - dinner at Shooters. In Chicago, it's two good seats at a Cubs night game.
''Someone once asked me to compile a cultural-literacy guide to Charlottesville,'' said Joseph Kett, a history professor at the University of Virginia and co-author of the ''Dictionary of Cultural Literacy,'' which just shows how culturally ignorant of Charlottesville that someone was. ''It's called Hookville'' among local cognoscenti, Professor Kett said. ''It was C-ville, but the 'C' is shaped like a hook, so it simply became Hookville.''
To save strangers from further humiliation, Professor Kett also noted that ''If you're referring to the University of Virginia, you don't call it the Campus, you call it the Grounds.''
At Harvard the campus is the Yard; at Stanford, the Farm.
''There is potential for miscommunication all the time,'' Professor Kett said. ''There are lots and lots of subcultures each with its own language.''
And menu. ''You've heard of Wheaties, the Breakfast of Champions?'' asked Rene Pena, a specialist in community education service for Children's Television in Dallas. ''In Texas, it's menudo,'' a spicy soup made of cow innards. ''Texans eat it a lot,'' Mr. Pena said, ''normally in the morning, after they've been partying all weekend.''
In Chicago, culinary sophisticates ''know what's 'everything' on a hot dog with everything,'' said Patrick Clinton, a journalism professor at Northwestern University, who confided everything: ''mustard, relish, celery salt, tomatoes, onions, a dill pickle spear that goes the length of the hot dog and two or three pickled peppers.''
The ''Tom Cruise'' at the Stage Deli in New York City comes with sliced brisket, grilled tomatoes, served open face and topped with melted mozzarella. In Cleveland, Tom's his old New York self. But in Los Angeles, Tom comes with shrimp salad, egg salad, lettuce and tomato served open face.
There are guidelines for achieving local cultural literacy. ''You need to know about the dominant economy of an area because so many different people's lives are connected,'' said Jerry Jellison, a psychology professor at the University of Southern California. ''Like if you're in a small town in the Midwest you need to know about farming and agribusiness. And in Los Angeles, you have to know about the film industry. You have to know who Peter Guber is,'' and the grosses on the latest releases.
In Michigan, ''people who work for the automobile industry, they'll say, 'I work for Fords, not Ford,'' said Gerald R. Miller, a communications professor at Michigan State University. ''If you didn't know, you might think it was a drugstore.'' Professor Miller added that even Michiganders outside the automotive industry are hyperaware of which models are selling how well nationally and internationally.
Their car-conscious California counterparts even recognize makes and models at 85 miles an hour.
Names in higher education are the ones to drop in Boston. ''Knowing who the president of Harvard is and the president of M.I.T. and the president of B.U. is an absolute must for having a conversation, even at a train station,'' said Marian Bach, a trust administrator at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. (This is an especially difficult trick these days when two of those names are changing and the third could become Massachusetts' governor.) ''And then there are certain industrial family names that have been in New England ever since we got started.''
Professor Jellison agreed that one must know something about history to comprehend culture. ''There's factual history,'' he said, ''like who was the mayor, and key events,'' like when the local team won back-to-back National Basketball Association championships. ''And then there are the local icons.'' Like the elephant that attacked its keeper and was chained for the rest of its life - a name (Ziggy) that comes trippingly to the tongue of in-the-know Chicagoans. (The keeper was Slim Lewis.) ''You also have mythic history,'' Professor Jellison said. ''In Texas, you have to know about being a cowboy. In Minnesota, you don't complain about the weather, and in Portland, you understand about being an outdoors person. This is how people define themselves.''
''New Yorkers are great shoppers,'' said Pat Thaler, associate dean at New York University's School of Continuing Education. ''They love to get things at a fair price and if they can get wholesale or a discount, all the better. We have the Lower East Side; Sunday is the day to go. We have discount stores. Of course, New Yorkers aren't going to buy cheap if it isn't good.''
Professor Miller maintains that the culturally literate know how people talk about getting from place to place. ''In Michigan,'' he said, ''if you asked how far it is to a destination, we would say 25 miles. But in California, they would say half an hour,'' because Californians don't look at the odometer when they're stuck on the freeway; they look at the clock.
New Yorkers judge distance by blocks, which they cover fast and aggressively, treating ''Don't Walk'' signs like polite suggestions. ''We don't necessarily wait for the right light,'' Dean Thaler said. ''But New Yorkers are very quick. Most of us know how to get across the street in one piece.''
Most Californians are well versed in the vagaries of earthquakes, while Floridians could probably list the names of hurricanes for the last 20 years. Middle Westerners know the year of the ''Big Snow,'' and residents of Washington State can recall in excruciating detail when Mount St. Helens ''lost her top.''
Of course, no matter how much you know, you can never know enough. Mr. Bradley, though, has devised a minimum competency test. ''When I moved to Philadelphia, I turned on a black radio station and they were announcing a concert,'' he said. ''The disk jockey said tickets were available in all the usual places. I had no idea what the usual places were, so I asked my friends where to get tickets. And they said, 'Oh, the usual places.' ''
''If I had to come up with a definition of cultural literacy,'' Mr. Bradley said, ''it would be that when people say 'the usual places,' you know.''

GRAPHIC: Drawing

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 8, Column 3; Education Life Supplement

LENGTH: 691 words

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD;
Degrees in Whole Earth

BYLINE: By Kathleen M. Berry

 BODY:
MUCH as the creation of a women's studies major reflected a kind of consciousness-raising for students in the 1970's, so environmental studies may be a generational barometer for the 1990's, as colleges and universities increasingly create curriculums on the environment and grant their graduates degrees.
''Many of the smaller private colleges have students who are very active in the environment,'' said Dr. Verne Howe, chairwoman of the National Association of Environmental Educators and a professor at Southern Vermont College in Bennington, Vt. ''But there's no consensus on how many programs there are nationally.'' 
At the University of California at Berkeley, undergraduates can choose between a bachelor of arts in environmental sciences or a bachelor of science in conservation and resource studies.
Southern Vermont's environmental-studies degree program enrolls about 15 undergraduates annually, with courses on forest ecology, environmental history, cartography and environmental law.
Perhaps the most far-reaching program, though, is at Tufts University in Massachusetts, which established an Environmental Literacy Institute last year. By teaching awareness of the environment to faculty members - 24 took part in the new program this spring -the university hopes to integrate environmental topics into courses campuswide. This fall students who take economics, accounting, literature and history will have environmental articles and books woven into their courses.
Engineering schools are responding to the environmental clamor by offering undergraduate and interdisciplinary programs that combine subjects like physics and microbiology with aspects of environmental management.
The Massachusetts Institute of Technology recently created an undergraduate program in environmental engineering. Carnegie-Mellon University has added a designated minor in environmental engineering in which students choose two-thirds of the required courses outside their major field of study.
''Educators are realizing that we must teach more than just the technological aspects of the field,'' said Prof. David E. Marks, chairman of the civil engineering department at M.I.T. ''There's no such thing as a free environment and students are learning about the costs of pollution, which the technology community has avoided.''
As a result, the tenor of the new programs is generally pragmatic. Many students are combining a major in environmental studies with another in communications, history, business management or political science.
Prof. Richard G. Luthy, chairman of Carnegie-Mellon's civil engineering department, said recent events such as the San Francisco earthquake and the Exxon Valdez oil spill off Alaska, had triggered a demand for courses from students.
''These are enormous problems in remote locations that have outraged many citizens,'' Professor Luthy said. But he added that, when presenting the material, ''We must teach more than how oil disperses from tanker spills.''
In response, many business schools have integrated environmental problems into the study of crisis management. Lester B. Lave, a professor of economics and engineering and public policy at Carnegie-Mellon, teaches a ''Health, Safety and Environmental Regulation'' course for business students. In one class, students brainstorm ways in which they could become millionaires by controlling pollution or population growth.
''Students think business managers are there just to maximize stockholder concerns,'' Professor Lave said. ''I try to deal with the non-obvious issues, the ones they're not likely to encounter on the job until real trouble happens.''
Graduates typically are finding jobs in state and Federal agencies working with water-quality control or regional planning. Educators warn, however, that in environmental studies career interests often exceed opportunities.
As Robert Singer, executive director of the Coolidge Center for Environmental Leadership, which counsels universities in the Boston area, noted: ''We have the unfortunate task sometimes of discouraging people from following a career track in the environment.''

HEADLINE: Tax Plan Sticks New Yorkers With Bailout Tab

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New Yorkers should be aghast at your distressingly shortsighted editorial (''The Right Way to Raise Taxes,'' July 25) in support of placing a cap on the Federal returns for state and local taxes. This provision could mean a change in the Federal marginal bracket for New York taxpayers from 36.1 percent to 39.8 percent.
Such a proposal, if enacted, will levy a disproportionate tax burden on New Yorkers, who live in the highest taxed state in the country. It could be argued that a portion of New York State's taxes reflects the assumption by the state of social costs not borne by other states or that ought to be borne more by the Federal Government. But it is difficult to rationalize this burden by contending, as you do, that we are reaping the advantages of these taxes in the form of ''improved schools and other public services.'' New Yorkers would seriously question such alleged benefits, as well as their costs. 
There is a further bizarre inequity. This proposal transfers to residents of highly taxed states, such as New York, a heavier share of the cost of cleaning up the savings and loan mess. A majority of the thrift failures occurred in Texas, Florida and Southwest states with low or no income taxes. Their residents will experience no increase in their tax bills if this proposal is enacted, while New Yorkers will be asked to pick up the lion's share of a cost created in states whose taxpayers will enjoy the advantage of having New Yorkers pay the bill. It is difficult to discern tax fairness in such an absurd result.
The high-tax states will be the losers, as taxpayers realize the advantage of living in states with less regressive tax policies. The effect on the New York State economy could be chilling in times of economic difficulties. Your reader base may remain unchanged, but a larger percentage of readers may choose to live in Florida.
 
GEORGE H. HEYMAN JR.
 New York, July 26, 1990

HEADLINE: Tax Plan Sticks New Yorkers With Bailout Tab;
Our Spending Problem

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Right Way to Raise Taxes'' (editorial, July 25) is a perfect example of the politicization and obfuscation of economic reality in this country. There is no economic theory that supports any tax increase as a remedy to a weakening economy.
The United States does not have a ''revenue shortfall'' (our total revenues as a function of our gross national product have been consistent for decades) or a ''deficit'' problem (we have more than adequate national net worth to handle our deficit financing). What we have is a spending problem. Any economic analysis that is not politically biased can see our spending is run amok. 
You should be directing indignation toward a broken-down ''democratic'' process in the way we spend our tax dollars. We have special-interest groups out of control dictating to a corrupt, self-perpetuating Congress. Our Federal Government has become analogous to the inefficient charitable institution whose beneficiaries receive 5 cents of every $1 in contributed donations. The bureaucracy has to be reorganized.
Are the ''poor'' awash in all the red ink we are spilling? I think, rather, our bloated government bureaucracies are so deep in the public trough, they can only cry out for more taxes!
Your recent opinion poll reported 60 percent of the American public disapproved of the President's handling of the deficit and 52 percent disapproved of increased taxes.
The news media's cynical, arrogant analysis interprets this as a public that wants the spending but refuses to pay for it. The public has repeatedly sent a mandate to the White House to hold the line on taxes, that is, stop transferring money from the productive to the nonproductive (our bureaucracy). Unlike you, I didn't hear a national wave of relief at President Bush's tax capitulation, but a wave of disgust.
 
STEVEN L. EBER
 Coral Gables, Fla., July 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 302 words

HEADLINE: Tax Plan Sticks New Yorkers With Bailout Tab;
Blow to Homeowners

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Right Way to Raise Taxes'' (editorial, July 25), endorses removal of tax deductions for home mortgage interest and state taxes, instead of increasing tax rates.
By virtue of losing this Federal tax deduction, residents of states with high income taxes, such as New York, California, Hawaii and Vermont, would pay higher taxes. Most states impose income taxes in the top range of 6 percent to 8 percent. Texas, Florida, New Hampshire and Washington impose no income taxes. Their residents would pay no additional Federal income taxes.
Homeowners will suffer. Our Government has encouraged homeownership by a tax deduction for mortgage interest and realty taxes. The increased income tax cost to a typical homeowner with a $100,000 mortgage will exceed $4,000 a year in after-tax dollars, representing $6,000 of pretax earnings. Without the deduction, some homeowners will be unable to meet mortgage costs. Foreclosures will increase. Fewer young families will be able to buy a home. Fewer homes will be sold. Home resale values will tumble. The building industry will suffer. A pyramiding effect on jobs and the local economy will ensue.
Our country has a mobile population, which follows opportunities, jobs, better and less costly living. Higher taxes cause both families and factories to move to low-tax states, compounding economic disruption in high-tax states.
A fair and simple revenue-raising alternative would be to increase the tax rate on higher levels of income, above $150,000, say. Increase it again as income passes $500,000, $1 million and beyond.
In addition, untold tax revenues would result from properly funding the Internal Revenue Service and training its personnel to enforce the law effectively.
 
ERNEST R. FIELD
 Great Neck, L.I., July 26, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 19, Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 738 words

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Making A Killer

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Iraq's capture of Kuwait is, of course, a declaration of war against Western power and economic independence.
It is so obvious that the only two questions remaining are how the West will respond and why it came as a surprise.
They are inseparable. Unless the West at last faces the truth about why it failed to see the plain danger, it will not be able to act decisively now. That will make another adventure by the Iraqi dictator simply a matter of a little time. 
Only a few months ago, Saddam Hussein made shriekingly clear his intention to use his million soldiers, his Soviet tanks, French planes and American technology to destroy Israel and control the Middle East and the oil that moves the world.
The way to stop him before he attacked was an immediate Western embargo. When an enemy points a pistol and says he will pull the trigger, there is no high moral obligation to wait until he does.
Now it will cost more, to staunch the blood. The ultimate goal now has to be the elimination of the incurably murderous Baghdad dictatorship by Western, Japanese and Israeli economic and military reprisals.
Total air and naval blockade of Iraq, including turning off Iraqi pipelines running through Saudi Arabia and Turkey, could ruin Iraq and bring about the dictator's end.
So far President Bush has reacted with the minimum steps needed to look his ashen face in the mirror. That gives him a little time to see if our allies will join us in effective action - or whether we will all just thrash around, amusing Saddam Hussein with futile bluster.
Mr. Bush needs time, which is costly, because Western leaders failed in their duty to prepare action against the plainest threats of aggression since Adolf Hitler.
Why in the name of sanity is there a Western alliance, glistening with planning staff and elegant headquarters, if not to agree in advance on how to meet such a threat?
Saddam Hussein, like other serial killers, wrote ''Stop me'' on the wall. First, he cried out his lust for empire. Then he handed the West his first battle plan by threatening to attack Kuwait for lowering oil prices. Then he moved his troops to the frontier.
Intelligently, he wanted to find out if the West had any intention of trying to stop him. When he discovered the answer, he moved across the border.
Now, with or without direct invasion, Iraq can control the ruling clans of Saudi Arabia and Jordan - or blow them away. Both families are already terrified by the meagerness of their popularity at home.
In 1970, the Israelis saved King Hussein of Jordan from the Syrians. Who will save him from Saddam? The Iraqis plan to attack Israel one day. In 1981, the Israelis destroyed the Iraqi nuclear reactor and were piously denounced in the West. After Kuwait, does Senator Robert Dole still want to cut military support for Israel?
The West was blind to the truth about the Middle East because it had put out its eyes with the dagger of its own lies.
The first lie is that Israel is the root of danger in the Middle East, but that if it would only agree to some kind of Palestinian state, peace would follow.
But Palestinians cannot give Israel peace. Only the Arab nations can do that. For decades they refused and still do.
One victim of the Kuwaiti invasion was any lingering Palestinian dream of a separate state. It would be run by Saddam Hussein's Palestinian allies. He would then be a pistol shot from Israel's heart.
The invasion proves one more weary time that it is not Israel that prevents Middle East peace. It is the Arab tyrannies, eager not only to destroy Israel but to shed blood in their perpetual feuds and wars.
But decade after decade the West sold weapons to the dictators. Greed for cash and oil was the reason. And for cash and oil, the West deluded itself into thinking that the sheiks and kinglings created by its colonial offices and oil companies were real political rulers.
The second suicidal lie: The Arab threat is only dangerous to Israel. Too bad for the Jews, sure, but look, not as important for the West as oil. And not as important for Moscow as selling all those Soviet tanks, now on view in the streets of Kuwait.
Now, Saddam Hussein has made the mistake of showing the West that tyrants cannot be appeased, neither with money and guns, nor with lies.
That is the mistake all tyrants make. And that is how they are brought down - but only if truth finally brings courage.
