HEADLINE: The Endangered Civil Service

BYLINE: By Paul Volcker; Paul Volcker was chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

 BODY:
However well-intentioned and enlightened its policies, any government, from the White House to the local motor-vehicle registration office, is only as good as its workers. For the Federal Government, this undeniable truth has recently spelled trouble. It seems to be getting ever harder to staff top-flight political positions, where the turnover rate on average has been about 18 months. Meanwhile, morale, and with it commitment to the job, have been declining among civil servants. Their pay is inadequate. They face an apparent lack of public respect. And not surprisingly, recruiting needed talent is proving more difficult.
In light of these facts, it isn't entirely coincidental that last year began with stories of outright corruption in Pentagon procurement. Then the political scandals at the Department of Housing and Urban Development competed for headlines with evidence of influence-peddling in Congress. And now a mixture of short-sighted public policy and maladminstration will force taxpayers to pay hundreds of billions of dollars to make good the Federal guarantee of savings and loan deposits. 
It should come as no surprise that such shortcomings weaken that fabric of public trust so essential to a democracy. Another serious cost is that fewer of our most talented young people see government service as a worthwhile and challenging career.
No doubt, some of the problem stems from a general weakening in our collective obligations to good citizenship. Among the world's democracies, we are near last place in that most fundamental form of citizen participation, casting ballots. This year the Internal Revenue Service estimates that for the first time unpaid taxes will exceed $100 billion. We seem reluctant even to be counted for the census.
Three years ago, 36 public-spirited Americans, from both sides of the political aisle, joined with me in a private ''National Commission on the Public Service'' to address the erosion in the quality of the Government's workforce. Our report described a ''quiet crisis'' among government employees. Since then, the situation has worsened.
The most basic of our recommendations for reform was addressed to the nation's educators. They need to elevate the importance of civic education and community service in school curricula. In addition, we have recommended a well-publicized, competitive program providing college scholarships to some of the best of our young people in exchange for a few years in government service.
No less important is leadership, above all from the Oval Office. After two presidents who campaigned against Washington, George Bush has clearly changed public rhetoric about government. This could have a substantial impact on how the American people view the public service.
Pay and ethics reforms make up another essential impovement. When such changes were enacted for the top levels of the Federal Government last fall, pay improved at least for senior Federal executives and judges. Hardly generous, the increases at least got salaries of senior Federal judges up to something visibly above what major law firms are paying new law graduates! We must now give a higher priority to fairer pay for the rank and file of the Civil Service.
Also high on the agenda is the problem of rapid growth in the number of political appointees. Presidents understandably want to name people to ensure policy action consistent with their political goals. But their present number - 3,000, compared with barely 200 in Franklin Roosevelt's time - dilutes the effectiveness of presidential leadership. It leads to a loss of professionalism. Moreover, the promotion prospects of the career service are undercut.
Another important component of reform is reducing the complexity of conflict-of-interest rules and reporting requirements that are discouraging qualified people from political posts.
All of this emphasizes the need for some mechanism to keep the state of the public service under continuing review. So, we urged that a ''National Advisory Council on Public Service'' be put in place by Congress and the President. Legislation to that effect has passed both houses of Congress and is awaiting the President's signature. A council could also be a means to involve the private sector more systematically in efforts to improve the public service. Both business and government, for example, face a challenge of productively employing a larger proportion of minorities.
In this exciting and challenging time for all Americans, nations everywhere seek to emulate our democracy, our freedoms and our economic success. How tragic it would be if at this time of unparalleled challenge and potential success, we let the ordinary processes of democratic government erode - and put the whole enterprise at risk.

142 of 925 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 524 words

HEADLINE: Isolate Iraq

 BODY:
Iraq's Arab neighbors have canceled the summit meeting scheduled for today; they can't bring themselves even to try to stop Saddam Hussein's million-man army and undo his conquest of Kuwait. That's now the world's business, and it can be accomplished only with unity and leadership that produce hard-hitting sanctions.
If there's any good news at all about the invasion, it's that other powers seem to recognize they must act, before Iraq's megalomanic war lord gains control of nearly half the world's oil. 
Washington and Moscow pointed the way Friday. Creditably and courageously, the Soviet Union broke with Iraq, its longtime ally, and joined with the United States in demanding an immediate Iraqi withdrawal and urging a total arms embargo on Iraq. Yesterday, the European Community imposed essential preliminary sanctions. Japan has taken some similar steps.
In grabbing Kuwait, Saddam Hussein has affronted nearly everybody. This is the first invasion of any Arab state by another, thereby shattering the cherished myths of pan-Arabism. Every oil-importing country suddenly finds its supplies imperiled and prices soaring. And all nations have reason to be outraged by a violation of frontiers tantamount to armed robbery.
And now, Saddam Hussein has exposed as a sham his promise to withdraw his troops. Who will replace them? ''Volunteers'' for a new Kuwaiti army, recruited from his own soldiers. The bitter joke typifies his lawless cruelty. The only rational response is to isolate Iraq and compel its unconditional pullout. United outrage can turn the often-toothless United Nations into a tiger. It can invoke the Charter's punitive Chapter 7 to impose mandatory and powerful economic sanctions. And these could be enforced by turning the oil weapon back on Saddam Hussein, by severing the pipelines through which Iraq exports 90 percent of its oil.
Leadership from President Bush is essential to achieving such unity. He has rightly warned that for Iraq to cross Saudi Arabia's borders would tread on vital U.S. interests, and just as rightly, he declines to rule out a military response.
But he needs to do more than reassure Iraq's terrified neighbors. He can now work with the Soviet Union and other powers to overcome the Arab fears of outside help and to win support for essential countermeasures.
The first retaliatory steps have been taken. But asset freezes and trade embargoes are scarcely adequate. A blockade in the Gulf would not cripple Iraq's economy. But it could be devastating if coupled with closing the pipelines.
Turkey and Saudi Arabia control those pipelines. Each has reason to fear reprisals by Iraq and neither relishes being viewed as a Western surrogate. But how different their position would be if the Security Council unanimously invoked the U.N. Charter to impose mandatory sanctions against Iraq. Collective diplomacy to isolate Iraq could finally realize what the Charter envisioned: collective security.
There is no reason to concede the fruits of aggression to the aggressor. There is every reason for a world united in outrage to press for the total isolation of Saddam Hussein.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1286 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
When Imitation Isn't the Sincerest Form of Flattery

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

 BODY:
IF America's armchair quarterbacks ever voted for their favorite piece of furniture, chances are they might elect the La-Z-Boy recliner. With huge cushions that gently mold to the supine contours of the heftiest fan and a footrest that stretches obligingly forward to prop up weary feet, the La-Z-Boy has become an icon of middle-class creature comforts.
It is also one of the most copied pieces of furniture in the United States. Rival manufacturers can duplicate every La-Z-Boy design and refinement with little fear of being sued under patent and trademark laws, and generally sell their products for less. 
''We put an awful lot of money into these designs,'' said Richard Micka, La-Z-Boy's vice president for administration. ''But the minute you show them off at the furniture shows, people start knocking them off.''
A debate over whether and how to curb such practices has come sharply into focus because of proposed Federal legislation that would allow companies to protect the design of their products much the way an artist or writer copyrights works of art.
A powerful alliance of business groups and a bipartisan coalition of Congressional leaders are pressing for legislation that would entitle companies to protect new designs with what amounts to a 10-year copyright. A company would have only to show that its design is different from that of earlier products.
Something as small as a distinctive curve on an automobile bumper would be covered by the new law, and virtually every kind of product marketed in the United States could be protected: automobile bodies, coffeemakers, running shoes, sunglasses, furniture and luggage. Clothing would be exempt.
Supporters of the bill, which was introduced last year, insist that innovative design is a pillar of manufacturing strength, and that protecting creative companies from low-priced copycats is essential to American competitiveness.
''It's important that we do anything we can to protect American jobs and American companies, which are being eroded by people deliberately producing copycat products,'' said Representative Carlos J. Moorhead, the California Republican who is the bill's principal author.
Opponents contend that the bill would impose an enormous tax on the public by eliminating competition and raising prices throughout the economy.
''After all, we're talking about creating monopolies here,'' said Representative Robert W. Kastenmeier, the Wisconsin Democrat who is the measure's leading opponent. ''If you look around your living room and everything in it is subject to protection, one wonders what the transaction costs of life will be.''
Indeed, say critics, the measure could even thwart the Pentagon's efforts to obtain low-cost spare parts for weapons systems. In the early 1980's, the military was embarrassed by discoveries of exorbitant prices paid for seemingly mundane parts. Investigators later concluded that the biggest problem was that parts could be obtained only from the original weapons manufacturer. For the last five years, the military has been trying to foster as many alternative parts suppliers as possible in an effort to bring down prices through competition.
Underlying the tug-of-war are basic issues. What is innovation? Does it involve a tangible improvement over an earlier product - a faster computer chip, a quieter dishwasher, a more reliable anti-lock braking system for cars?
Or is an innovation merely something that is different from earlier products - the distinctive casing for a telephone, or the curve of an automobile bumper?
Would new protection for design stimulate innovation by providing extra financial incentives, or would it stifle competition and harm consumers?
These arguments have produced unusual political alliances. Representative Moorhead's bill has been endorsed by the Bush Administration and top Congressional Republicans, but one of its biggest champions is the House Majority Leader, Representative Richard Gephart, the Missouri Democrat.
Business supporters include a long list of manufacturers and trade associations. Among them are all of the nation's automobile and truck companies, as well as the United Auto Workers; luggage manufacturers like American Tourister and Hartman; furniture makers like La-Z-Boy and Herman Miller; and the Kohler Company, a manufacturer of bathroom and kitchen equipment.
The opposition is equally diverse. The Consumers Union, the Consumer Federation of America and the Center for Auto Safety all say that the measure would mean higher prices. Automobile insurers are also opposed, arguing that the measure would add as much as $400 million to the cost of automobile repairs because it would eliminate independent supplies of low-cost body parts. Large discount retailers like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the K mart Corporation are fighting the measure, which they fear will block their access to appealing but low-priced merchandise made abroad.
The most basic change envisioned in the Moorhead bill would involve altering the standard for what constitutes a protectable innovation. Under current law, companies can obtain design patents. But to do so, a company must show that its design is more than just different. It must be new and useful and it cannot be ''obvious'' to others skilled in the same field.
These are the same tests that have been applied throughout most of American history to patents for new machines or chemical processes. But manufacturers complain that these tests are too rigorous for designs, which are not based on new technology but on small flourishes that add to a product's esthetic appeal or comfort. As a result, they say, design patents often take years to obtain and are difficult to enforce.
The new law would essentially reduce the burden of proof. A company would merely have to register its design and demonstrate that it is different from what already exists. Both sides agree that the measure would undoubtedly cover things like automobile bumpers and fenders, even if these are not innovative in any profound sense.
''This elimination of any creativity requirement is a radical departure from existing intellectual property laws,'' argued Clarence Ditlow, the head of the Center for Auto Safety, a consumer advocacy group, in testimony this spring.
''Clearly, though,'' he said, ''the new 'design copyright' would create enormous private benefits - profits - for proponents of the legislation, at the expense of U.S. consumers.''
Product designers consider their work every bit as creative as that of painters and sculptors. But lobbyists for design protection argue that technical innovation is not the real issue. The bigger point, they say, is that companies invest millions of dollars to promote and market their designs, only to have imitators ride their coattails.
They also point out that governments in Europe and Japan have long maintained design protection. In fact, those countries have asked the United States to adopt stronger protection to cover their own products when imported here, and the issue is expected to come up in the next round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs.
The main opponent to passage is Representative Kastenmeier, who heads the House subcommittee responsible for patent legislation. Indeed, the Senate passed similar measures five times before 1976, only to have the Wisconsin Democrat kill the measure through inaction.
Recently, Representative Kastenmeier described himself as a lonely skeptic. ''Almost everybody on my committee supports this legislation, except me,'' he said.
It remains unclear whether he will try to kill the bill again or yield to the wishes of his own party's leadership.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
More New Magazines, And These Beckon To Black Readers

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
FROM Los Angeles to Boston, black entrepreneurs, swimming against the tide of falling advertising pages and high mortality rates in the magazine industry, are establishing magazines aimed principally at black readers.
Many are drawn to the business by a belief that an estimated $300 billion in spending power among American blacks in the 1990's will propel advertisers to search out new ways of reaching this market. A diversity of interests in the black community - from fashion and beauty to politics and the arts - also will feed a demand for their magazines, they say.
''The increase in black-oriented magazines is a result of the emerging black middle class and their varied interests,'' said Samuel J. Chisholm, president of the Mingo Group, a New York advertising agency specializing in targeting black consumers. ''And because the interests in the black community are varied, there seems to be a need for information that supports those varied interests.'' 
Today at least 25 black-oriented magazines are competing for a national readership. American Visions, a five-year-old magazine based in Washington, focuses on the arts, history and culture. The magazine began to turn a profit last December. New York-based Emerge, offering articles on politics and lifestyles to middle- and upper-income readers, made its debut last year. The magazine is 80 percent minority-owned, with Time Warner Inc. owning 20 percent. Reach New England, a Boston-based quarterly in its first year, is aimed at minority entrepreneurs in the region.
It often takes years for a new magazine to make a profit, and it is not surprising that Emerge and Reach New England are still in the red. Even in the best of times starting a magazine is a struggle. Figures from the Standard Rate and Data Service, a magazine reference guide, indicate that of the 225 magazines that have started since 1988, 119 have failed.
This year has been especially bad for the industry. Manhattan Inc. and 7 Days recently folded. Time's advertising pages were down 7.5 percent for the first six months of this year from the same period last year, and Ebony's were down 9.4 percent.
Like many magazines, Ebony is privately held, and its owner, Johnson Publishing Company, does not disclose profits. Another established leader of the market, Black Enterprise, which is owned privately by Earl Graves Ltd., reported sales of $15.1 million last year, up from $6.6 million in 1980. Newcomers are having a harder time attracting and keeping advertisers than these older black publications. They say that financing is difficult in a weak economy, that investors are warier than ever of highly risky ventures, and that advertisers are scarce.
Emerge has averaged only 20 advertising pages an issue. In recent issues ad pages rose, but it has yet to reach its break-even point of 35 pages (the magazine has scheduled 34.6 pages for its October anniversary issue). American Visions, on the other hand, sold 40 pages of ads in its June issue, double the number it needed to break even.
Experts say that some of the newer black publications have an edge: low overhead. With desktop publishing and new printing technologies, they have been able to start magazines without huge capital expense or personnel requirements. And some introduce their publications without the usual start-up costs associated with buying subscription lists and putting out expensive mailings.
 
Carving Out a Niche
These new publishers insist they have identified an important segment and that they are waiting for advertisers to arrive at the same conclusion. ''There is always a tight and small pie for black print media advertising dollars,'' said Wilmer C. Ames, editor of Emerge. ''But we're not competing against 1,000 magazines, and the market is growing by leaps and bounds.''
Others in the field are less optimistic. ''It is hard to believe that all of these new efforts will survive because, to most advertisers, black magazines are an afterthought,'' said Charles N. Jamison Jr., executive vice president of Jamison and Leary Advertising Inc. in New York, which specializes in the black consumer market. ''You will find enough advertising support for, say, three or four magazines on hunting alone to survive, but black magazines are not perceived as being a viable target.''
Advertisers privately say that they are already reaching black consumers through ads on television and in other magazines. A large share of the readership of GQ, Sports Illustrated and Elle is black, researchers say. And some advertisers say that with any one of those plus either Black Enterprise, Ebony, Essence or Jet, they can meet their advertising target.
''There is no real difference in the eyes of advertisers because a magazine is black,'' said Hugh J. O'Brien, executive vice president of the Dallas office of Bozell & Jacobs, which includes American Airlines, Greyhound and Dial among its clients.
''New publications have a hard time, because major advertisers are not willing to take a chance. Advertisers are not going to carve money out of a budget unless they have already defined that market as being of interest to them.''
''The advertising situation is the most frustrating part of running this magazine,'' said Keith T. Clinkscales, a 26-year-old Harvard Business School graduate who publishes Urban Profile, a two-year-old quarterly offering an 18- to 35-year-old black audience a mix of social commentary and political articles. ''It is difficult to convince makers of tennis shoes, soft-drink companies and major upscale cosmetics producers that there is a value to advertising in black media.''
''There is a certain invisibility of blacks in the eyes of the American business system, and that system doesn't like to extend parity to black business,'' said Rene John-Sandy, the publisher of Class, an 11-year-old magazine providing news, the arts and celebrity features to an American and Caribbean readership.
Despite the problems and the likelihood that some of these magazines will fail, publishers of older established publications and their newer counterparts say they hope that the market has room for all. ''There are 35 million blacks in the United States, and Ebony, Jet and Essence are only reaching about two million of them,'' Mr. John-Sandy said.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 26, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Noonan Q & A;
What She Said At the University

 BODY:
PEGGY NOONAN, speechwriter for Presidents Reagan and Bush, answered questions at a forum last week at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Following are excerpts:
Question: As the person who came up with the ''Read my lips - No new taxes'' phrase, what are the implications of that phrase for the future, now that it looks like that pledge is sort of wavering?
Answer: That tends to be the first question I'm asked these days. I think the change of the President's position on ''read my lips'' was truly a watershed event. The President and the Republican negotiators had better come up with a really good reason for the end of the read-my-lips vow. When you say really blunt, declarative things in a really blunt, declarative style, it will be memorable. And when people remember that you said it and then you change your mind, they will hang you with that sound bite. It was a real gamble on Bush's part. 
Q. Isn't it humbling to have been part of an era of the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer, according to government statistics, and a meaner America?
A. Humility for anybody who's been involved in any kind of public life is definitely appropriate, but my analysis of the past decade differs with yours. I do not see it as having been a retrogression at all. I do see it as a rather stirring time. Big things happened in the world. Communism was defeated. The American economy - I think we're in the 93d straight month of unprecedented growth.
Q. What about things like the banking and the housing scandals?
A. Well, the S.& L. thing is complex. As a staunch Republican, I could make a speech where we blame it on the Democrats. I think it is an awful, awful mess. And certainly in terms of the way we all live, and in terms of public policy, it is certainly a much bigger thing than stuff that loomed so large just a few years ago, like Iran-contra. But essentially, I think Reagan was a pretty good President. I think he will probably rank among the best of this century. I'm sorry to make you throw your head back like that. I guess you've read the Kevin Phillips book [''The Politics of Rich and Poor''].
Q. It seems one little sound bite can make or break you. Is this a necessary evil?
A. It's a media problem. The young people who do speeches for major politicians, they've heard the whole buzz about sound bites. And now instead of writing a speech, which is to say a serious text with serious argument, they just write sound bite after sound bite.
Q. Now that Communism seems to be declining, what fills the void as the major platform for the Republican Party?
A. I don't know. We're all depressed. Look, there will always be trouble. Somebody said the other day the big dividend of the peace dividend is peace. It doesn't mean you can tear up your entire defense structure. This isn't the end of history. Qaddafi will get the bomb - all sorts of interesting and horrible things could happen. So I personally don't mourn the departure of Communism as an issue.
Q. The Bush campaign staff must have been extremely happy with the big victory in 1988, but wasn't it a campaign full of name-calling and mud-slinging?
A. No it wasn't. There should have been more name-calling, mud-slinging and fun. It should have been rock-'em-sock'-em the way great campaigns have been in the past. It was tedious. As for name calling, there was just precious little. I think you are referring to what has been called the ugliness of the campaign in terms of the Willie Horton ads. Is that what you mean? I think the Willie Horton issue was a legitimate issue, and I don't think Bush has anything to regret in that area because it speaks of styles and ways of governance. In that case Dukakis's.
Q. Do you foresee that in 1982 or any time soon?
A. No. I think in '92 they'll still go through every day as saying, ''We got our one shot on the evening news and apart from that let's not make a mistake, because if we do that's the lead and we look stupid.'' What is the answer to that problem, I don't know. It is a media problem.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In Europe, Immigrants Are Needed, Not Wanted

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
A BRIEF walk along any street in downtown London, Paris, Frankfurt or Milan immediately shows how immigration from the third world has turned many Western European cities into melting pots. But 30 years after this process began, a surge of racist incidents, smoldering hostility toward immigrants and new moves to keep out poor foreign workers show how Western Europe still has to come to terms with this change.
With new prosperity making Western Europe the most powerful magnet for poor immigrants after the United States, plans by the 12-nation European Community to eliminate its internal borders after 1992 have suddenly turned immigration into the region's most explosive social issue. In country after country, polls show that the public is strongly opposed to new immigration and, in some cases, even favors repatriation of some of the 12 million immigrants now in the region. 
Yet, as the United States has discovered in trying to curb the influx of undocumented aliens, economic forces - the flight from poverty and the chance of a relatively well-paid job - are invariably more effective in attracting new immigrants than border controls and hostility are in keeping them out.
The appeal of moving to Western Europe is steadily growing, not only to those without hope in the traditional emigrant countries of North Africa, but also to those newly unemployed in Eastern Europe. Today, just as young Moroccans risk their lives to reach Spain in small boats, the railroad stations of Berlin and Vienna are crowded with Poles, Romanians and others seeking a new life farther west. ''You don't have to be a visionary to predict that the Turks in Germany will be pushed into France and Spain or that Italy will soon face grave difficulties,'' a French commentator, Yann de l'Ecotais, wrote in L'Express magazine, referring to the 1.4 million Turks in West Germany and the growing numbers of North Africans in Italy.
In some places, immigrants have become the scapegoats for high unemployment, although they often do manual or low-paid jobs that natives refuse. And non-white or non-Christian immigrants are often seen as a threat to ethnic, religious and cultural traditions.
In the medium term, another force may come into play. With a slump in birth rates and a jump in life expectancy, experts believe that by the turn of the century Western Europe will need immigration to sustain its growth. ''In the coming years, Western Europe will have to coexist with hostility toward immigrants and a demand for immigrants,'' said Jean-Claude Chesnais, a population expert at France's National Institute of Demographic Studies.
But for today's politicians, the immediate priority is clear: to be seen to be addressing the immigration problem in such a way as to reassure electorates that their national identities are not about to be transformed by alien influences.
For example, in France, where anti-immigration feelings are feeding the growth of the extreme rightist National Front, the Socialist Government recently dropped plans to allow immigrants to vote in local elections, fearing it would lose more French votes than it would win immigrant votes. In Spain and Italy, countries with long traditions of emigration, governments are trying to reduce illegal immigration from North Africa. Similarly, London has ruled that no more than 250,000 Hong Kong Chinese will be granted British passports before the colony reverts to China in 1997.
When a single regional market is formed at the end of 1992, foreigners entering one European Community country could travel freely to the 11 others. Finding a common policy involves not only deciding which outsiders will require visas to enter the Community, but also insuring that illegal immigrants, political refugees, drug traffickers and terrorists do not profit from the border-free region. London, for example, insists on the right to check citizens from non-Community countries who enter from another Community country. Bonn favors a more liberal visa policy for Eastern Europe than France and Britain favor. Spain is alarmed at the prospect of having to demand visas of citizens from its former colonies in Latin America.
Aware that even stricter measures may be insufficient to neutralize the pull of prosperity and the push of poverty, the Community is also turning its focus toward aiding countries that export most migrants - although in Eastern Europe it is also motivated by the need to encourage democracy and capitalism.
In the case of North Africa, Spain, Italy, Portugal and France have decided to sponsor a more ambitious initiative. If successful, the planned Conference on Security and Development in the Mediterranean would not only address the relationship between immigration and North Africa's problems of poverty, population growth and unemployment, but would also tackle questions of security and economic development throughout the Mediterranean area.
Long-term programs of this kind, though, seem unlikely to alleviate the social tensions currently being stirred by the immigration problem. Rather, many politicians believe the only real answer lies in fully integrating existing immigrant communities. But most Western European countries still seem reluctant to accept that they have already become multi-ethnic societies.

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1295 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The United Nations Comes of Age, Causing Some Anxiety

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
WITH the end of the cold war, the United States and the Soviet Union are forging a working alliance at the United Nations that offers the organization its first real chance in 45 years to function as it is supposed to.
The two superpowers and the three other permanent Security Council members - Britain, France and China - are finding that they can play their assigned role as custodians of international order, working together to try to resolve conflicts in the Persian Gulf, Namibia, Central America, Cambodia and the Western Sahara.
After Iraq's troops stormed into Kuwait last week, the Soviet Union and the United States were shoulder to shoulder again in the Security Council, running their first joint crisis-management exercise in the United Nations. They pushed through a resolution condemning the invasion and threatening Iraq with global economic sanctions if it did not pull out.
The more cooperative atmosphere within the Security Council is rubbing off on the General Assembly, encouraging the third-world majority there to drop its anti-Western polemics in favor of consensus. 
Over the last year, the General Assembly has unanimously endorsed the importance of free markets and democracy in development, banned ecologically harmful fishing nets, accepted white South Africans' right to safeguards under black rule and agreed to negotiate a treaty on stabilizing the world's climate by 1992, all at the urging of the United States and the Soviet Union.
But the superpowers' emerging partnership belies wide differences in their perceptions of the organization. It also arouses the suspicions of third world countries, who fear that the organization will become an instrument for imposing the views of the northern industrialized nations on the developing south.
''Since the renaissance at the United Nations is closely linked to the strengthened role of the permanent Security Council members, it raises fears in the south of an hegemonic directorate,'' Olga Pellicer, Mexico's deputy representative at the United Nations, said in a recent address.
In recent years the Soviet Union has gradually set forth a vision of the United Nations as the cornerstone of a more cooperative world order, guided by a powerful Security Council ready to intervene in crises and tackle environmental perils and other new threats to security.
Moscow has backed its vision with cash, agreeing to pay more than $210 million due the organization. This year it upgraded its presence at the United Nations by appointing a Deputy Foreign Minister, Yuli M. Vorontsov, as its new chief delegate.
But while Moscow was warming to the United Nations, Washington was lukewarm at best. For most of its two terms the Reagan Administration was openly contemptuous of the organization. President Bush, a former Ambassador to the United Nations, appears more sympathetic, but America's response to Moscow's change of heart remains cautious.
American diplomats argue that the existing machinery should be given a chance to work and stress the difficulty of financing grandiose initiatives like those suggested by Moscow.
Many members of Congress continue to view the United Nations and its agencies as inefficient, bloated bureacracies often hostile to American interests. Their skepticism has led to the withholding of $675 million due the organization.
 
Ending the East-West Deadlock
Washington and Moscow also differ sharply over the Middle East, with the United States opposing Soviet demands for a major United Nations role in making peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors.
In a new Council on Foreign Relations study, George L. Sherry, a former United Nations official, says America's caution may reflect the fact that it is torn between competing impulses.
After winning the cold war, Washington is tempted to pursue a unilateral foreign policy, he argues, as suggested by the Panama invasion. On the other hand, he says, Washington also knows it now has a rare chance ''to establish a peaceful, civilized world order.''
Sir Brian Urquhart, the former top peacekeeping official at the United Nations, said he believes that the United States is not moving fast enough to exploit Moscow's changed views and develop the peacekeeping potential of the organization. He likened present arrangements to ''a sheriff's posse'' that rides out only after the rustlers have gone.
The most dramatic manifestation of the new American-Soviet cooperation at the United Nations came in last year's jointly sponsored General Assembly resolution in which the two superpowers promised to work together to strengthen the United Nations.
The Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, John R. Bolton, the top Bush Admninistration official in charge of United Nations issues, said the resolution reflects ''major changes in our bilateral relationship that will end the East-West deadlock at the United Nations.'' Many observers believe that Moscow's enthusiasm for the United Nations stems directly from a commitment to change at home and reflects a belief that a more peaceful world will allow it to cut military spending and develop its own economy.
''For the Soviets the United Nations is emerging not as a vehicle of retreat but as a less costly and more legitimate way to influence events,'' wrote Thomas G. Weiss of Brown University and Meryl A. Kessler of Harvard University in a new study of Moscow's United Nations policy.
Although Moscow was looking for a better relationship with Washington before Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985, it was only in September 1987 that the Soviet leader set forth his view of a pivotal role for the United Nations. It came in a landmark article in Pravda uninvitingly titled ''The Reality and Guarantees of a Secure World.''
 
'A Wilsonian Vision'
During the cold war, Soviet leaders had treated the United Nations with suspicion, seeing it as at best a platform for anti-Western propaganda, at worst an obstacle to world revolution.
But in the article, Mr. Gorbachev offered what Prof. Richard N. Gardner of Columbia University calls ''a Wilsonian vision'' of a world ruled by international law, with a reinforced Security Council, expanded use of peacekeeping forces, a stronger World Court and new organs to deal with global challenges.
Many developing countries fear that the emerging United States-Soviet cooperation means that the superpowers will be tempted to impose the industrial world's priorities, like environmental protection, human rights and fighting the drug trade. Third-world nations fear that their overriding concerns, like debt, falling raw-material prices and developmental aid, will be overlooked.
''It is always their agenda, not ours,'' Mrs. Pellicer, the Mexican diplomat, said.
As a result, the third world is now fighting a rear-guard action against the superpowers' growing influence. Developing countries have thwarted efforts to give the Security Council a say in environmental matters and the war against narcotics.
While the Security Council is resolving some civil wars, Ethiopia, the Sudan, Somalia, Mozambique and Sri Lanka testily resist United Nations mediation in their internal conflicts.
Many diplomats say that the more assertive third world mood will make it harder to achieve new global agreements, particularly environmental accords that require developing countries to comply with new international standards.
And if the United Nations cannot produce global solutions, nations may prefer regional answers. As part of its efforts to knit a divided continent together, the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe plans its own institutions for resolving disputes, protecting the environment and enforcing human rights.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 3; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1263 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Operative Word in America: Deficit

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
CONGRESS is packing itself off for an August vacation, leaving untouched the nasty business of cutting enough spending and raising enough taxes to squeeze $50 billion out of the ever-swelling budget deficit.
If the scene sounds familiar, it should. It has been played and replayed for more than a decade by lawmakers and the Administration as resolve gives way to blue smoke and mirrors. But this time the stakes on all sides are higher.
What distinguishes this year's budget drama is the sheer size of the deficit: as much as $232 billion for 1991, even by the Administration's estimate, when the cost of bailing out the savings and loan industry is included. Even under the most optimistic forecasts, the numbers get worse before they get better. 
The message lawmakers will take home to constituents is that at least for the foreseeable future, any ''peace dividend'' from the end of the cold war will be washed away by the sea of red ink. But the message that could have much more significance is the one of deepening frustration and cynicism that constituents seem to be sending back.
''People are mad about the savings and loans, about the HUD scandal, about the budget,'' said Representative Mickey Edwards, an Oklahoma Republican. ''The perception out there is that 'we called the leaders and there was nobody home.' Every incumbent ought to take a poll; what they'd find is that their ratings are 10 points lower than they think.''
But frustration also afflicts the lawmakers as they try, with little effect, to reward or serve or at least placate their constituents. For the last decade most creative energy in Washington has been devoted not to policymaking but to budget legerdemain - and to avoiding the automatic spending cuts that are supposed to provide the threat of discipline.
Meanwhile, lawmakers and Administration officials have learned that there is little percentage in inventing programs for which there is no money, and little reward in making things work better when what matters politically is the appearance that the deficit is being reduced.
From the beginning, the $120 billion Medicare program, which helps cover health care costs for the elderly, was and continues to be a convenient place to look for savings. Too convenient as far as Gordon H. Russell is concerned.
Mr. Russell is the administrator of the Hi-Plains Hospital, Nursing Home and Clinic in Hale Center, Tex., one of hundreds of rural hospitals feeling the severe pinch of Federal cuts.
The private hospital, which serves several communities with a total population of about 20,000, was built in 1946 and operated profitably until 1983, when Congress changed the Medicare reimbursement formula to save money.
The problem, Mr. Russell said, was that under the new formula rural hospitals got less than urban hospitals but still had to compete in the same markets for staff and supplies. ''A year ago we were in critical condition and had to borrow to pay salaries,'' he said. ''We're fragile now, and we're holding our breath on what will happen this year with the budget talks in Washington.''
Many health policy experts say the Federal budget crunch has only accelerated a trend that was inevitable, the closing of rural hospitals that are simply too inefficient and unprofitable. But a senior Congressional budget aide who shares that view argues that it misses the point.
''The Federal Government made a decision at the end of World War II to subsidize the country,'' the aide said. ''Over the course of the 1980's, that decision has effectively been reversed.
''It may be the correct policy, but the shift has occurred not because lawmakers decided it was a good idea, but rather because they were backfitting policy to meet budget deficit demands.''
Those demands seem infinite. Donald F. Kettl, a professor of political science at the University of Wisconsin, said that although the savings and loan debacle has become the focal point for the cynicism and mistrust of Government, other big fiscal messes are on the way.
''I don't think the real economic, political and programmatic effects of a decade of deficit politics have come home to roost yet,'' he said. ''There are more monsters out there: the nuclear waste cleanup, the Medicare trust fund, F.H.A. and the unemployment insurance trust fund.''
One of the most far-reaching effects of the Federal budget crunch has been a shifting of the burden for many social welfare programs to the states. During the early years of the Reagan Administration, this was called ''New Federalism,'' an approach meant to give the states more control over the design and administration of their programs and premised on the notion that cutting Federal taxes would still leave the states some room to increase their own.
Many states did. But as the Federal Government's own budget problems have grown, forcing President Bush to abandon his no-new-taxes pledge, Washington has looked to higher Federal taxes on beer, wine, alcohol, cigarettes and gasoline - all of which have been traditional sources of revenue for state and local governments.
A leaked Administration proposal that calls for limits on deductions for state and local income taxes may never formally make it to the budget negotiating table, but the idea brought protests even from states that have little or no revenue from local income taxes as well as from those, like New York, that depend heavily on them.
''Congress reached its limit and discovered the states as a credit card,'' said one state budget official, referring both to the tax proposals and to Federal mandates for expansion of the Medicaid program, under which states share the costs. ''We're already in trouble out here, and the last thing we need is more help from our friends on the Potomac.''
 
Between Branches
A decade of futile efforts in Washington to bring down the deficit has also had more subtle effects on the Government, increasing the inherent strains between between Congress and the White House and undermining the internal balance of power in Congress, even fundamentally altering the way that Congress conducts its business.
''When the first thing you have to ask is what does it cost and where do you get the money, it totally distorts the policy process,'' said Robert Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, a nonpartisan economic research agency that Congress created in 1974 to act as a counterweight to the President's Office of Management and Budget.
''Congress doesn't do what it used to do, look at problems and try to fashion solutions,'' he said.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, refers to a conspiracy, a deliberate plot by President Reagan and his top economic advisers to blunt Congressional power by running up defense spending and cutting taxes so that the resulting deficit would ''strangle the beast.''
Professor Kettl, at the University of Wisconsin, said that while deficit politics may have initially given the White House the upper hand with Congress, the Presidency has also suffered.
''The President has lost his ability to announce any new initiative that costs money,'' Professor Kettl said. ''That's why you see these symbolic causes - the flag, abortion, family values.''
Mr. Moynihan agreed, lamenting especially the loss of American influence at a time of dramatic change in the world. ''They wanted to strangle the beast and they ended up paralyzing the Government,'' he said. ''At the moment in foreign policy we've waited for and worked toward for half a century, we're broke.''

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1667 words

HEADLINE: POWER GRAB;
Iraq Makes Its Bid to Run the Show in the Middle East

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR years now President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has been the bad boy of Arab politics, a classic bully who lived by the credo that crime pays and absolute crime pays absolutely. The Iraqi strongman was at it again last week, invading his neighbor Kuwait, holding up the whole country for its oil and gold, and then daring the world to do something about it.
The Iraqi heist set off alarm bells across the Arab world, in international financial markets and in the corridors of power from Washington to Moscow to Jerusalem. The shock was compounded by the fact that after all the velvet revolutions in Eastern Europe in 1989, the world had been lulled into thinking that such naked acts of aggression were a thing of the past. That was an illusion. Indeed, the Iraqi actions and the global reactions revealed many enduring truths about both international and Arab politics.
For the Arab world, the Iraqi blitzkrieg on Thursday was simply the latest version of the oldest power game in the Middle East: the struggle between Egypt and Mesopotamia, Iraq's ancient forebear, for regional domination. In this game a decisive winner would get all the countries in between. 
Because Iran, the traditional counterbalance to Baghdad in the Persian Gulf, had its strength sapped by the nearly decade-long war with Iraq, in the last two years Saddam Hussein has been relatively free to throw his weight around the neighborhood and begin competing again with Egypt for broader Arab leadership. President Hussein invaded Kuwait in order to steal enough money and oil resources to finance the panoply of big-ticket projects he wants to build to speed Iraq's recovery: steel mills, railroads, petrochemical plants.
But in the struggle between Baghdad and Cairo neither side ever seems to win decisively - at least for long - because of the natural tendency of all the states in between to band together and form a counterbalance. That realignment started last year when Syria began cozying up to Egypt, even making positive noises about peace with Israel, while Egypt itself, long shunned for its relations with Israel, was embraced anew by the Arab oil states just as Saddam Hussein's shadow began to darken their doorsteps.
This realignment offers intriguing possibilities for Washington. If ever there was a time when it might want to try to patch up its relations with Syria and Iran it is now, when they share an interest in restraining President Hussein; Administration officials say they have already communicated that sentiment to Damascus and Teheran.
But in this never-ending do-si-do of nations, there is more at stake than simply who dances with whom. What is at stake is who sets the agenda for the Arab world and for OPEC. If Iraq gets away with devouring Kuwait and intimidating all its neighbors, a climate of fear will be created in the Arab world that could make it impossible for Egypt to continue trying to promote Israeli-Palestinian negotiations. What Egyptian or Palestinian would risk defying the line laid down in Baghdad of unremitting hostility to Israel? And how could Saudi Arabia maintain its policy of keeping oil prices down so the West does not develop alternative energy sources, when Saddam Hussein, who wants prices to soar, will be sitting on King Fahd's doorstep with a loaded pistol aimed at his head?
For the Kuwaitis themselves, the Iraqi invasion brought to an end a double game they had been trying to play for years. Kuwait, like most other Gulf oil sheikdoms, was less a country than a family-owned oil company with a flag and a seat at the United Nations. No wonder that Iraq's initial fierce attack with tanks, artillery and air strikes suppressed Kuwaiti resistance so effectively that Baghdad was able to send in its reinforcements by bus.
Like its neighbors, Kuwait had survived by its wits, buying off an enemy here and shifting alliances there to stay ahead of the power curve. But it had always wanted it both ways. The Kuwaitis wanted the superpowers to hang around the Gulf to protect them from bullies like Saddam Hussein, but they always wanted them to hang around in someone else's backyard so their Arab nationalist credentials would not be tarnished by accusations of contracting with a colonial power for protection.
Throughout the 1980's, while the Iran-Iraq war raged, the United States literally begged the Kuwaitis and other Gulf states to put some teeth into their strategic relationships by granting the Americans basing or naval installations, even if only for maneuvers. Every time, they got a polite ''No thanks.'' Sure, the Kuwaitis whispered, they wanted American protection - but with no hands.
But in a wilderness of tigers like the Middle East, no one respects no-hands diplomacy. So it was probably only a matter of time before the Iraqi tiger, which has long coveted Kuwait and nibbled at it before, devoured the little Croesus. It was also no surprise that Kuwait's five allies in the Gulf Cooperation Council - lately dubbed by some Middle East analysts as the Gulf Capitulation Council - suddenly forgot that they had signed a mutual defense pact agreeing to defend any member that is attacked. Maybe next time.
Indeed, for the whole Arab world the invasion highlighted the degree to which the region has fallen behind the times. In an era when dictators have been ousted throughout Eastern Europe, just across the Mediterranean, the Arab world is still consumed by tribal feuds and dominated by the same class of leaders who have been in power in many cases since the 1960's. The region is innocent of glasnost or perestroika, velvet revolutions or democracy movements. History knocked on the Arab world in 1990, and nobody answered - nobody but Saddam Hussein.
For Israel, the invasion is a mixed blessing. Militarily speaking, Israeli officials are wishing Iraq and its Arab neighbors a long and healthy war. The longer the better. The more energy they expend on each other the less they will have left for Israel. Politically speaking, the Iraqi invasion is also good news for the right-wing Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, since it underscores his argument that the real source of instability in the region is not the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but rather the threat posed by aggressive, belligerent Arab states.
To be sure, Mr. Shamir has a point. The Middle East is a bad neighborhood, and the weak-kneed Arab response to the Iraqi invasion raises a legitimate point from the Israeli perspective: If they won't stand up for Kuwait, imagine what would happen with us? If Israel relinquishes land for a peace treaty, how long would that treaty be honored if some Arab tough guy like Saddam Hussein orders everyone to tear it up?
But this can also become an excuse for Israel to sit back and do nothing. The political danger now, argued Galia Golan, an Israeli expert on superpower involvement in the Middle East, is that the Shamir Government will use the invasion, and the diversion of attention it creates, to escape from making any hard choices on the Palestinian issue. ''Just because Iraq is dangerous does not change the fact that we have 1.7 million Palestinians living under our control,'' said Ms. Golan. ''That problem is not going to go away, simply because the world is looking in another direction.''
As for the United States and the Soviet Union, their joint response to the Iraqi invasion has demonstrated that in a post-cold war world they really have stopped competing in most regional conflicts. Ten years ago, the Soviets would undoubtedly have shielded their ally Iraq from world condemnation and economic sanctions. This time, instead, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze got together with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in Moscow and issued a joint condemnation of Iraq and called on all countries to cut off the aggressor's supply of arms.
This not only reflected attitudinal changes in the Kremlin, but also a sense of where Soviet economic interests lie. In the 1990's, neither superpower has an interest in promoting tribal ambitions that might interrupt the world's oil supplies. Even if the fighting in the Arabian Peninsula goes no further, the uncertainties are already raising prices at American gasoline pumps and threatening to interfere with Washington's efforts to avoid a recession. And a healthy Western economy is something even Mikhail S. Gorbachev needs if he is to attain his long-range goals of revitalizing his society through cooperation with the West. What Will Work? The bad news, though, is that the superpowers have joined hands about 10 years too late. If they had been able to cooperate a decade ago, when the two of them had a near-monopoly on the world arms trade, they might have been able to impose any solution they wanted.
But today, said Mark Heller of Tel Aviv University's Stategic Studies Center, the idea of a Soviet-American condominium in a multipolar world is obsolete, which is precisely why President Bush has not only turned to Moscow but to the European Community, NATO and the United Nations for help in building opposition to Iraq. But how long will they hold together?
''The idea of a Soviet arms cutoff to Iraq is an empty threat,'' Mr. Heller said. ''The same with economic sanctions. Too many other people are in the arms business today. Economic power has become too diffused as well. The Iraqis can get arms from China to Brazil, and after a few months half the world will be buying their oil. It is probably no accident that the United States and Soviet Union can only converge at a time when it is no longer meaningful.''
So the United States and the rest of the world are groping for the right response to Iraq. They will always be at a disadvantage, though, as long as they are not playing the game by the same rules as Saddam Hussein -which are no rules at all. One should never come to a hockey game prepared only to play by the rules of touch football. The Middle East is a hockey game - with no referee.

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 8; Page 8, Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1129 words

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
P.G.A. MUST GO BEYOND TOKEN CHANGE

BYLINE: By SAM LACY; Sam Lacy is the sports editor for the Afro-American Newspapers.

 BODY:
Once again racism has met its match: money.
And a segment of southern black leadership has retreated to embrace tokenism.
The P.G.A. Championship golf tournament will proceed this weekend under a facade of harmony because the host agreed to a pseudo-desegregation.
The Shoal Creek Country Club near Birmingham, Ala., accepted a black insurance executive, Louis Willie, as an honorary member on Tuesday, ending its tradition of ''No Blacks Allowed'' and thus quieting the furor raised by its racist policy. 
But acceptance came only after six powerful sponsors - I.B.M., American Honda, Toyota, Anheiser Busch, Lincoln Mercury and Spalding - pressured the P.G.A. of America, which runs the P.G.A., with withdrawal of their television advertising support.
And it should be noted that Willie's status for the weekend is ''honorary,'' a condition that can be terminated at will - possibly as early as Monday.
The fact that the P.G.A. of America scheduled its championship at a site where black membership is excluded actually came as no surprise. To blacks who follow golf, the surprise was that the P.G.A. had the audacity to claim it was not aware of the Shoal Creek policy of discrimination. Or that professional golf has a history of fielding its events in an atmosphere of exclusivity.
Augusta National, in the wake of the Shoal Creek episode, has announced a willingness to consider blacks as applicants for membership.
The National, home of the fabled Masters, maintained not only a ban on membership but on tournament entry by black players as well until 1976. That was the year Lee Elder waded through the tournament's maze of eligibility requirements and gained what many blacks believe to be a begrudging invitation.
It also was the year that the writer felt the retentive sting of bigotry at the Masters.
Armed with bona fide press credentials for the major events of baseball, football, boxing, plus Forest Hills and five Olympics, my organization, Afro-American Newspapers, requested similar courtesy to cover the Elder story at the Augusta National.
The late Clifford Roberts, self-styled Master of the Masters, extended ''sideline privileges'' with the stern warning that the holder would find the press tent ''off limits.''
There are hundreds of golf and country clubs throughout the nation that cling to a rigid ban on black participation. And, although they do not expect to be placed on the PGA schedule, these clubs reflect the attitude of Shoal Creek.
Moreover, Shoal Creek's earlier defense that it is difficult to find a black willing to pay the $35,000 initiation fee to join is ludicrous. For example, a similar explanation was used at the Salisbury Country Club in Midlothian, Va., near Richmond until 1977.
That was when a pro football hall of famer, Willie Lanier, applied for membership. At the time Lanier had just retired from an illustrious career as captain of the Kansas City Chiefs and was back in his native Richmond to accept a job as director of labor relations for the Phillip Morris Company. Salisbury turned him down. Concluding that he had not been in the area long enough to protest, Lanier urged Dr. Tom Wright, a longtime local physician, to apply for membership at the club.
Wright also was rejected, but the doctor immediately filed suit attacking the tax-exempt status of Salisbury.
The local court ruled in favor of the club, but that judgment was hastily reversed in the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals.
Both Lanier and Wright told this writer later that neither was interested in becoming a member; they simply wanted to establish the right of any black to join if he or she so desired.
Lanier today is vice president of the Wheat-First Securities Corp., which recently underwrote a $29 million bond issue to aid Morgan State University, Lanier's alma mater.
There is further evidence that black economics is not a plausible excuse for putting down black participation at many country clubs. In November 1988, a young black man named Charlie Vinson was in Ocala, Fla., to spend a weekend with a white friend at whose wedding he served as best man. His host, Don Delprete, is the son of a 20-year member of Ocala's Golden Hills Country Club.
As a gesture to his son, the father, Danny Delprete, made reservations two weeks in advance for Don's group to play 18 holes at Golden Hills in lieu of a bachelor party. But when Don and his friends showed up at the appointed tee time, the club pro said he had not been informed that ''this black guy'' would be among them. The rest could play but Vinson, was not welcome.
Vinson at the time was an Emmy Award winner, a five-time recipient of Tony Awards, a producer of ''The Cosby Show,'' ''Motown Returns,'' ''Benson,'' ''Christmas in Washington 1987'' and ''The Martin Luther King Special.''
It should be noted, though, that country clubs were not alone in their zeal to retain an all-white fraternity in golf. Cities in some areas helped to perpetuate the system.
The writer and many of his acquaintances encountered this reality early in life. While there was no attempt ever to gain membership in a country club, personal rejection came from various sources.
Public courses in the District of Columbia, Maryland and Virginia held firm to antiblack policies. In Washington, for instance, only a nine-hole course in West Potomac Park was available. That course and the Carroll Park course in Baltimore were equipped with sand greens, none of which were larger than the average rug in an inner-city home.
Moreover, at Carroll Park, a public course operated by the city in Baltimore, it wasn't until the mid-1950's that blacks were allowed to play more than one day in a week.
That ended under the threat of a lawsuit by the Afro-American Newspapers vice president, D. Arnett Murphy, and a group of his business and professional associates.
Under that threat golf and tennis facilities in Baltimore were thrown open, though with a measure of undisguised revulsion.
Finally, it is ironic that the P.G.A. now finds itself in a deep sweat when it has never before shown any sign of sensitivity regarding black protest. And it is obvious that its present concern is only brought about by the withdrawal of support by powerful corporate sponsorships and their money.
For years the P.G.A. was aloof to black disenchantment, issuing invitations to Gary Player, Harold Henning, David Black, John Fourie and others from South Africa, all of whom represent - even if they do not publicly espouse - the vicious apartheid system of government in a homeland they support with money won on American golf courses.
So, when one considers this continuing indifference to black concerns it is not hard for one writer to believe the P.G.A. deserves to squirm a little.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 5, 1990

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1, Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1611 words

HEADLINE: GOLF;
Golf Strikes Sensitive Nerve

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
The last time Louis J. Willie used his golf clubs, he played on a public course in Birmingham, Ala. Willie's most vivid memory of the day was having to tee the ball up on every shot to avoid breaking his clubs on rocks that dotted the course. That was in 1970. Twenty years later, as the result of a bizarre chain of events that has shaken the golf establishment, Willie is able to play the silklike greens and picture book fairways of the Shoal Creek Country Club in Shoal Creek, Ala.
Last week, club officials conferred honorary membership status on the 66-year-old businessman, making him the club's first black member. The appointment also temporarily ended a controversy that has engulfed Birmingham for the last three weeks and threatened to mar the P.G.A. Championship that begins at Shoal Creek on Thursday.
But while the club's move was an effective end run around Shoal Creek's immediate problems, the three-week episode has sparked protest and stirred debate within the black golfing community. 
From celebrity players like Michael Jordan to wealthy entrepreneurs and avid golfers with average incomes, the Shoal Creek incident opened several old wounds, pricked sensitive nerves and raised new, penetrating questions for many blacks about access and acceptance.
Ironically, Willie, who moved from Texas to Birmingham 33 years ago and heads the largest black-owned insurance company in Birmingham, said he accepted the membership to keep the peace.
''It's not embarassing to me at all to accept an honorary membership,'' said Willie, who joins 10 other honorary members at Shoal Creek. ''We defused an explosive situation in this city. Now the city is calm and peace is in the making.
''This doesn't have primary importance,'' he added. ''Joining a country club was never a high priority in my life. I'm 66 years old. My goal was never to join a country club. My main goal was to build a business, hire people, employ people, going to church saying prayers.''
Asked if he thought that the Shoal Creek move, forced by economic sanctions and another week of negative publicity, lacked a moral imperative, Willie said he thought that it did not. Birmingham stands to gain an estimated $30 million in revenues as a result of PGA-related business.
''It does have a moral ring to it,'' he said. ''Suppose they went ahead with the picketing and the pickets were met by violence and someone was killed. Isn't it moral to keep peace? Isn't it moral to keep people from dying?''
For others, Willie's appointment and much of the PGA's deference appeared precipitated by economics, not morality. Thus, the issue of whether substantial change is in the offing is not clear.
''That was totally a move to push some of the controversy away from the tournament,'' Jordan said Thursday in an interview with The Omaha World Herald. ''I think its going to be very interesting to see when the next official member, not honorary, but the next official member is going to be invited into that club.''
Jordan belongs to four country clubs: in Durham, N.C.; North Barrington, Ill., outside Chicago; San Diego, and Hilton Head, S.C. Each of the clubs he belongs to was established within the last two years.
''I've never had a problem getting in,'' he said. ''I guess that's one of the advantages of being who I am or being the projected person that I am. I've never tried to apply to all-men's clubs, all-Jewish clubs or anything like that. I've never even thought about it.
''But because of that whole incident,'' Jordan said, referring to Shoal Creek, ''I think it's something you have to look at and evaluate.''
While Jordan's stature allows him to play as a guest on some the nation's most exquisite courses it is interesting to note that the clubs to which he belongs are new counterparts of old established clubs in the same area whose policies have been questioned.
But for several black executives and athletes, Shoal Creek encapsules a continuing deep-rooted struggle for equal access to the nation's resources and pleasures.
''This is really not a sports issue,'' said Arthur Ashe, a former Wimbledon and United States Open tennis champion. ''It has very little to do with sports; sports is just a catalyst. The issue here is access. One of the last bastions of exclusion and nonacceptance of African Americans is about to capitulate.''
Ashe belongs to the semiprivate Doral Country Club in Florida, where he has been the tennis director for 20 years. While he has received offers from members of two clubs to pursue membership, Ashe said that status, reputation and income have not been tickets into elite, exclusionary clubs.
''If I would have lived in Birmingham, I would not be a member of Shoal Creek; I would not have been offered a membership,'' Ashe said.
He also disagreed with the notion that the country-club issue is more economic than ethnic.
''Hall Thompson let the cat out the bag,'' Ashe said, referring to the Shoal Creek founder.
''He said, 'Look, we don't discriminate against anyone except blacks.' A lot of clubs have Japanese members who are not even American citizens. You are favoring foreigners over native-born Americans who can afford it and have corporate credentials. It's got very little to do with economics.''
For several black professionals, country-club membership is no longer a luxury item. Golf and club membership are seen as essential tools of the corporate trade. The more elite, the better.
''It is an opportunity to conduct networking among people who are the movers and shakers in this society,'' said Donald Watkins, a civil and corporate attorney based in Birmingham.
Last week Watkins volunteered to be Shoal Creek's first black regular member and said that he was prepared to pay the $35,000 initiation fee.
''I viewed it as a business opportunity and a business investment,'' he said. He noted, however, that Shoal Creek was not a grass-roots issue in Birmingham.
''This was not a high-priority issue in the black community because it only affects a handful of blacks,'' he said. ''There are other pressing problems that the city has to deal with, like job opportunities and housing.''
Bobby Thomas said that he finds it difficult to empathize with well-heeled black business people who, he thinks, are involved in an elitist protest.
Thomas, 64, is a barber at Myrtle's His & Hers shop in Brooklyn and describes himself as an avid and serious golfer. He has played for more than 20 years and never belonged to a country club.
''I considered it once, but I figured it wasn't necessary,'' he said. ''I feel that golf is a recreation sport; it's an outlet. I don't feel discriminated against because I play with all people. If I go as a single, I'll team up with people of other ethnic groups and we just have fun.
''When you get to the point where being in the club is almost like politics, then you're not there just to relax and enjoy yourself. It's just an extension of the type of thing we're trying to eliminate. For me, it's recreation. I don't see color. I play the sport.''
Of course, for the pure golfer, there are advantages to playing courses at well-appointed country clubs and they have little to do with politics and making deals.
''By and large most municipal golf courses are designed, not so you can enjoy what you're doing, but so you can play and get off,'' said Eddie Payton, the head golf coach at Jackson State University and a former National Football League running back.
Payton, whose younger brother, Walter, is the N.F.L.'s leading career rusher, is a highly regarded amateur golfer and has played on many of the nation's exclusive courses with ideal facilities and conditions.
The lack of easy access to these country-club conditions, he said, adversely affects the development of young black golfers.
''Most of the college coaches that I know won't give a kid whose high school team plays at a municipal golf course a second look over a kid who plays in the country clubs because they figure their game is going to be more advanced,'' he said.
Robert Brown was raised in a poor section of High Point, N.C. Now he is founder and chief executive officer of B & C Associates in High Point. Brown is a member of the Pinehurst (N.C.) Country Club, the Pinehurst National Country Club and the Old Waverly Country CLub in Westpoint, Miss. For him, the lesson of Shoal Creek is not economics or opportunity but the stark emphasis placed on race.
''When I was growing up, it was hard for me to conceive that I would ever have enough money to get some expensive golf clubs and to buy expensive golf balls,'' he said. ''Now I probably have 10 sets of golf clubs, and I've got more balls than I'll ever know what to do with and I belong to three country clubs. That to me is the great thing about this country.
''But if a young black person is coming up now, has enough money, meets all the criteria, crosses all the T's and dots all the I's, and then somebody tells them that can't do this because they're black, that's going to cause animosity and great friction in this country and we don't need that.''
''If a group wants to be segregated, they should be, but you don't have the right to be a part of any kind of public institution,'' he added.
''I don't think they should get any kind of tax breaks and I don't want them to advertise any of these I.B.M. computers that I buy. I don't want to advertise for anything that I or anybody in this country who happens to be black or a woman can't be a part of. I abhor that and I intend to fight it with every fiber in me, and I think that most black people feel the same way. Even the ones who don't play golf.''
