HEADLINE: Study Says U.S. Needs to Attack Infant Mortality

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug 5.

 BODY:
A high-level Bush Administration study calls for spending about $500 million a year more to reduce the infant mortality rate in the United States, now higher than in 19 other countries, including Singapore and East Germany.
The report, which reminds the Administration of President Bush's campaign promise to ''invest in our children,'' was begun more than a year ago and appears to have been put on hold.
''A nation's destiny lies in its children,'' says a confidential draft of the report by the White House Task Force on Infant Mortality, which includes officials from nine Cabinet departments. It says Mr. Bush should ''build a fence of national urgency'' and raise the issue of infant mortality to the top of the public policy agenda because ''this country cannot afford its current infant mortality rate in economic or in human terms.'' 
 
Difficult Campaign Promise
The report said that merely through the application of existing knowledge, the United States could prevent 10,000 of the 40,000 infant deaths that occur in this country each year. The same techniques, including improved prenatal care, could also prevent vision and hearing loss, mental retardation and other handicaps that afflict 100,000 newborns each year, the panel said.
''The United States has not achieved its national goals for reducing infant mortality,'' said the study group, headed by Dr. James O. Mason, Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, who served as director of the Centers for Disease Control from 1983 to 1989. ''Unacceptable racial disparities and significant geographic inequities are still evident, and progress in reducing the rate of infant mortality has slowed significantly, especially among blacks.''
A copy of the report was obtained from an official involved in the study who supported the recommmendations and felt that they were being ignored. Others involved in the study said it had been shelved because it was an inconvenient reminder of Bush campaign promises that would be difficult to keep.
Alixe R. Glen, a deputy White House press secretary, said the study, begun in July 1989 by the task force for the President's Domestic Policy Council, was continuing and would probably be completed late this month or early next month.
Another Administration official said the report had been sent back to Dr. Mason's group for further work. ''There is nothing politically or intellectually wrong with it,'' the official said. ''But it's not ready for prime time.'' Blacks at Twice the Risk The draft report comes to light at a time when Congress and the Administration are considering cuts in a wide range of domestic programs, including those the report described as effective in reducing infant mortality and disability.
The draft noted that the infant mortality rate for blacks had ''consistently been about twice the white infant mortality rate.'' It said the disparity reflected ''the cumulative consequences of poverty from preceding generations.''
The task force said steps recommended in the report would save money in the long run but would increase costs to Federal and state governments in the short term.
''Early prenatal care has been shown to reduce the cost of medical services to both infants and children,'' the report said. Hospital care for low-birthweight babies costs $2 billion a year, it said, and ''each infant death represents an estimated $380,000 in lost productivity.'' Babies with birthweights of under 5.5 pounds account for nearly 60 percent of infant deaths.
 
Failing National Goals
The infant mortality rate measures the number of deaths in the first year of life for every 1,000 live births. In 1987, the last year for which final data are available, the overall rate for the United States was 10.1. The rate was 17.9 for blacks and 8.6 for whites.
More than a decade ago the Public Health Service declared a goal of reducing the nation's infant mortality rate to 9 by 1990, and it said no racial group should have a rate exceeding 12. Neither goal is likely to be achieved. Dr. Joel C. Kleinman, director of analysis at the National Center for Health Statistics, said the Government was projecting an infant mortality rate of 9.2 for the nation this year. For blacks, the projected rate is 16.6.
The tone of the report was reflected in its epigraph, from the Talmud: ''If we save but one life, we save the world.''
 
'A Very Sad Document'
The report recommends 18 specific steps costing a total of $480 million a year, or roughly one-tenth of 1 percent of the total spent annually on personal health care in the United States. The steps include expansion of Medicaid to cover 120,000 additional pregnant women and children in low-income families, an increase in Federal spending on prenatal care and a requirement for states to provide a uniform set of Medicaid benefits to pregnant women.
Parts of the White House study sound like reports from the Children's Defense Fund, a nonprofit group that lobbies for children. When shown a copy of the report, Sara Rosenbaum, program director of the fund, said: ''It's a very sad document. It confirms what we and others have been saying about the effectiveness of prenatal care and Federal programs. We could be saving 10,000 lives and sparing 100,000 infants from disability every year.''
The report quotes from a paper issued by the Bush campaign in October 1988: ''We must give our children a better start in the world. George Bush will see that quality health services so critical for improving maternal and infant health will be available to the pregnant women and young children in our nation.''
The panel said the Government could reduce infant mortality by expanding Federal programs to deter smoking, drinking and drug abuse during pregnancy.
 
Conference on Infant Health
In addition, it urges President Bush to convene a White House conference on children, with infant health as the major theme. ''Each state will be encouraged to hold a governor's conference on infant mortality before the White House conference,'' it said.
The study said employers should be encouraged or required to cover prenatal care if they offer health insurance to employees. ''Nearly nine million women of childbearing age have no health insurance,'' it said. ''One-fourth of all mothers either begin prenatal care after the first trimester or receive no prenatal care at all.''
States are required to offer Medicaid coverage to pregnant women and children under 6 years of age if the family income is no more than 33 percent over the Federal poverty level. The White House panel said the income limit should be set at 50 percent above the poverty level, which would add 70,000 women and 50,000 infants to the Medicaid rolls. For a family of four, the poverty level was $12,675 last year. The report said Japan had proved that ''with a national commitment and accessible health services it is possible to make substantial improvements in infant health.'' Japan's infant mortality rate was 20 percent higher than the United States' in 1960, but is now the lowest in the world, about half the American figure, the report said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Forces Evacuate 74 After Threats in Liberia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
A reinforced company of 225 United States Marines flew into Liberia today to evacuate Americans and foreign dependents, after a rebel leader threatened to start taking foreign prisoners.
State Department officials said that 74 people, almost all of them American Embassy officials and their dependents, were flown to a Marine vessel off the coast of Liberia.
But more than 300 Americans remain in Liberia, including some United States citizens who may be unable to reach the evacuation point at the embassy compound in Monrovia because of the fighting in the capital, State Department officials said.
 
A Dual Threat for Foreigners
In recent weeks, Americans and other foreign nationals were under threat not only because of the fighting between Government forces and rebels, but also due to clashes involving rival rebel factions. The bloody war has been stalemated in recent weeks, with President Samuel K. Doe's troops controlling only a small portion of central Monrovia. 
Relief workers, missionaries and diplomats say that at least 3,000 mostly unarmed civilians have been killed and many more wounded since rebels began the war to oust the President Doe last December. The Government and rebel leaders have predicted that many more are sure to die as fighting intensifies in the capital.
The American military operation appears to have been spurred by a threat from a rebel leader in Monrovia, Prince Johnson, to start arresting Americans and other foreigners to force foreign intervention.
Mr. Johnson, whose troops have occupied much of the city, including the diplomatic enclave at Mamba Point, where the American Embassy is situated, told reporters on Saturday that his roundup would begin on Monday, focusing first on American, British, Lebanese and Indian civilians. But he insisted they would not be harmed.
 
West African Nations to Meet
Although there appears to be no enthusiasum from Western governments to be drawn into Liberia's war, there are moves under way among a number of West African nations to intervene. The latest developments are expected to be discussed on Monday in Gambia, where leaders of the Economic Community of West African states called an emergency meeting to discuss a plan to send an intervention force to Liberia and to rescue foreign nationals and try to establish a cease-fire. [In Lagos, Nigeria, Reuters reported that Government officials said Nigeria was mobilizing a joint army, naval and airborne force with three other countries to secure a cease-fire. The force could move soon after receiving the backing of the Economic Community meeting.] President Bush ordered the evacuation after a meeting on Saturday at Camp David with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and General Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs.
 
Marines' Presence Indefinite
The White House notified Congress of the action at 4 A.M. and announced it several hours laters, saying that a reinforced rifle company of 225 Marines moved by helicopter from their ships off Liberia to the American Embassy compound. The company is to join the Marine Guard at the embassy and a total of 237 Marines are to remain indefinitely to guard the embassy and remaining staff, including the Ambassador, Peter De Vos. The United States plans to maintain a staff of 41 officials at the embassy.
''The Marines will remain in Liberia as long as necessary to insure the safety of U.S. citizens in that country,'' the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said.
''The Marines are there to protect lives,'' Mr. Fitzwater added. ''They are authorized to use whatever means are necessary to do that. And they are there in a battle situation. And we have notified the Congress to that effect.''
The Marines at the embassy are a small part of the 2,100 Marine Amphibious Ready Group deployed off Liberia on four ships, including the U.S.S. Saipan, an amphibious landing ship, and a destroyer.
Mr. Fitzwater said the United States had no intention of intervening militarily in the conflict.
 
Obstacles to Evacuation
The 74 evacuees airlifted to the Saipan, most of them American Embassy employees and their dependents, included 12 foreigners - 8 Liberians, 2 Italians, 1 Frenchman and a Canadian, a State Department spokesman said. The group was to be transported to Sierra Leone.
The Marines also evacuated two Americans from two American communications sites in Liberia that handle diplomatic and intelligence messages in Africa south of the Sahara. The sites were shut down. A State Department official said the Marines would continue the evacuation of remaining Americans and foreign diplomats and their dependents.
There is no telephone communication in Monrovia, and as a result, officials said, the United States does not know how many additional Americans may want to leave.
Those who want to be evacuated must reach the American Embassy compound. American officials said there was sporadic shooting on Saturday in the surrounding Mamba Point area.
''We cannot set down helicopter in people's back yards where we have people shooting weapons,'' a State Department official said.
The United States has previously offered to evacuate President Doe, hoping that such a move would lead to an end to the fighting. A State Department official said, however, that a request now from Mr. Doe for his evacuation would have to be re-evaluated in terms of the risk to American forces.
The rebels have accused Mr. Doe, who seized power in a bloody coup in 1980, of human rights abuses. Witnesses have said that Mr. Doe's troops were responsible for the massacre last Sunday of hundreds of civilians who had taken refuge in a Lutheran church in Monrovia.
The evacuation today, named Operation Sharp Edge, involved 17 aircraft, including 11 Sea Knight and Sea Stallion transport helicopters, 4 Cobra attack helicopters and 2 Harrier attack planes.
 
Praise From Lawmakers
Mr. Fitzwater said that the Marines did not encounter any fire during the evacuation.
But a spokesman for the other rebel faction, led by Charles Taylor, was quoted by The Associated Press as saying that his forces almost fired on a Marine helicopter by mistake.
The Marine action drew praise from lawmakers, including Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois.
''The President's action is a proper one, and I support his decision,'' said Mr. Simon, chairman of the Foreign Affairs subcommittee on African affairs.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
Experts Say Embargo May Work If Nations Maintain Commitment

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
With Japan joining the United States and Europe yesterday by agreeing to halt oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait, the industrialized world has begun an economic campaign against Baghdad that for the moment relies on an embargo but holds out the possible use of a naval blockade.
While economic embargoes have rarely succeeded, oil analysts and Middle East experts say the sanctions against Iraq could hobble its economy as long as Western unity and commitment to enforcing the embargo holds.
 
A Checkered History
The modern history of economic embargoes is checkered at best. The effectiveness of an embargo is sometimes blunted by a lack of international cooperation and enforcement, so that the target nation can still buy and sell in the global marketplace. And breaking sanctions against oil trade is often made easier by the fact that oil is a commodity, not branded or labeled for easy identification. 
But the embargo against Iraq is different in certain crucial respects, Middle East experts and oil analysts say. It has enlisted a larger measure of international support than previous sanction efforts and is aimed at a war-weakened economy whose income is almost solely derived from one product - oil - that is shipped abroad from a few easily monitored locations.
Still, the embargo plan appears to have broad international appeal. The United Nations Security Council is expected to approve a worldwide ban on oil purchases from Iraq and occupied Kuwait today and to prohibit all other trade and financial dealings with those countries. [Page A6.] ''Tracking and enforcing an embargo against Iraqi-controlled oil exports should not be a big problem,'' said Henry Schuler, director of the energy program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. ''The problem will be sustaining the commitment.''
 
A Test to Come
The real test of the West's commitment may well come if the embargo is successful. Iraq has been exporting about 2.6 million barrels of oil a day, while Kuwait ships about 1.2 million barrels. Together, they account for more than 20 percent of OPEC exports.
If the oil from Kuwait and Iraq is taken off the world market, energy prices will jump unless other producers increase their output. The nation most capable of filling the oil shortfall is Iraq's oil-rich neighbor, Saudi Arabia, which now produces 5.5 million barrels of oil a day. But, experts estimate, it could quickly increase its output by another 2 million barrels a day.
The Saudis, the experts agree, will be unlikely to pump more oil and risk antagonizing President Hussein without a guarantee that the West will come to Saudi Arabia's defense if it is attacked.
''For this embargo to work without driving up oil prices and slowing economic growth, the Saudis will have to produce more oil,'' said Joseph Stanislaw, managing director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, an oil consultant. ''The Saudis will only cooperate if the international consensus that has emerged in the past few days is backed up with Western - and specifically, American - military power.''
 
Different Restrictions
The boycott of oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait is also different in that previous economic embargoes tried mainly to restrict the flow of goods from many different countries to one nation, such as Rhodesia or South Africa. By contrast, the sanctions against Iraq are an attempt to put pressure on a nation by refusing to buy its main export.
Iraq's oil is shipped to the West by just three routes: a pipeline through Turkey to the Mediterranean; a pipeline across Saudi Arabia that runs to the Red Sea port of Yanbu, and loaded directly into tankers in the Persian Gulf. Kuwait's oil is exported via tankers in the gulf.
So if Turkey and Saudi Arabia, assured of Western military protection, shut down the pipelines across their territory, most of Iraq's economic lifeline would be gone. Even if they do not, the ship movements to and from the ports handling Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil in the Mediterranean, the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf can be monitored without too much trouble, according to oil experts, both by observation and tracking ship movements by Western military satellites.
A naval blockade would insure that Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil never reach foreign buyers. Should Washington and its allies try a naval blockade, the task would not be too daunting because the ''choke points'' are few and in comparatively narrow waterways, according to one shipping analyst.
 
Techniques of Disguise
Without a blockade, there are several techniques oil traders can use to disguise the identity of an oil shipment, including falsifying documents that show a tanker's identity, switching oil from one tanker to another and bribing port officials to allow oil from an embargoed nation to be unloaded. Concealing the origin of an oil shipment is made easier by the freewheeling nature of the international oil business. The ownership of a tankerload of oil can frequently change hands several times from the time it leaves its home port to the time it unloads weeks later, halfway round the world.
All these gambits have been employed since 1979 to sidestep the voluntary embargo, backed by the United Nations General Assembly, on oil shipments to South Africa to protest its apartheid policies. The oil embargo against South Africa has increased its oil bill, because it has paid millions in fees to middlemen to help Pretoria elude the sanctions. But the voluntary embargo did not stop oil from reaching South Africa.
Veterans of the South African oil trading curbs say the embargo against Iraq should be much more difficult to circumvent. ''This is a much more concerted international action than the restrictions on trade with Pretoria,'' said a Rotterdam oil trader, who asked not to be identified. ''It should be much easier to track shipments out of Iraq, especially if American military technology is being used, than it has been to monitor oil tankers from all over the world heading for South Africa.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Japan joined the United States and Europe in halting all oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait. Misoji Sakamoto, chief cabinet secretary of Japan, made the announcement yesterday in Tokyo. (Associated Press) (pg. A6)

LENGTH: 1458 words

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
BUSH, HINTING FORCE, DECLARES IRAQI ASSAULT 'WILL NOT STAND'; PROXY IN KUWAIT ISSUES THREAT

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Committing the United States to roll back Iraq's conquest of Kuwait, President Bush said today that he would not settle for anything less than a total Iraqi withdrawal and would not tolerate the establishment of a puppet regime in Kuwait.
In a forceful statement to reporters as he returned to the White House from Camp David, Md., Mr. Bush all but committed himself to use military force against Iraq if diplomatic efforts and economic sanctions fail to produce an Iraqi withdrawal.
Mr. Bush dispatched Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to Saudi Arabia tonight in hopes of obtaining permission to send United States armed forces there to deter an Iraqi attack on that country, Administration officials said.
 
'This Will Not Stand'
Visibly angry, Mr. Bush said: ''I view very seriously our determination to reverse this aggression. There are an awful lot of countries that are in total accord with what I've just said.'' 
''We will be working with them all for collective action,'' the President added. ''This will not stand. This will not stand, this aggression against Kuwait.''
Asked how he could prevent the installation of an Iraqi-sponsored government in Kuwait, the President shot back, ''Just wait, watch and learn.''
Mr. Bush said he had consulted by telephone over the weekend with other world leaders to line up support for international economic sanctions against Iraq. He said he would meet in Washington on Monday with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and with the Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Manfred Worner.
 
Cheney's Two Objectives
Mr. Cheney's trip, which is being made at Washington's initiative, has two primary objectives, Administration officials said. The first is to persaude the Saudis to allow the United States to use Saudi airstrips and naval installations as staging bases if Washington deems it necessary to respond to Iraq's military moves. In particular, Washington wants to be able to deploy fighter planes and bombers.
''When the need arises we want options available to us,'' a Pentagon official said.
Mr. Cheney is carrying a significant amount of information gained from intelligence reports to show the Saudis the full extent of the Iraqi threat and to demonstrate the importance of the United States' having ready access to Saudi military installations.
His second objective, the officials said, is to persuade the cautious Saudi leadership that President Bush is sincere when he says that the United States intends to confront President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. The Saudis fear that if they adopt an aggressive posture toward Iraq and are attacked by Baghdad, Washington will not come to their rescue.
To tighten the economic noose around Baghdad, Administration officials are trying to persuade Turkey and Saudi Arabia to close the Iraqi oil pipelines that traverse their countries and carry 90 percent of Iraq's crude oil to tankers for shipment abroad. Because virtually all of Iraq's Persian Gulf ports were put out of action by the Iran-Iraq war, these two pipelines are critical for the country's economic survival.
 
Iraqi Warning on Pipelines
Iraq has warned Turkey and Saudi Arabia against shutting down the pipelines, and Administration officials say these threats have proved effective so far. The officials said that if the Turks and Saudis decline to take such a step they will consider organizing an international naval blockade to prevent any tankers from picking up Iraqi oil piped through Turkey and Saudi Arabia and to prevent the export of oil from Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.
While the Bush Administration stepped up its anti-Iraqi oratory, it still seemed to be groping for a strategy that would induce President Hussein to withdraw the estimated 100,000 Iraqi troops in Kuwait.
Up to now, the Iraqi leader, an expert at brinksmanship, has shown no sign of being intimidated by the economic and diplomatic sanctions carried out by the West.
''Nobody is willing to accept anything less than total withdrawal of the Iraqi forces and no puppet regime,'' the President said. ''We've been down that road, and there will be no puppet regime that will be accepted by any countries that I'm familiar with. That signal is going out loud and clear to Iraq. And I will not discuss with you what my options are or might be, but they're wide open, I can assure you of that.''
Administration officials said intelligence reports indicated that Iraqi troops, rather than withdrawing from Kuwait as Baghdad asserted they did today, were digging in and building up their units along the border with Saudi Arabia.
''Iraq lied once again,'' Mr. Bush said. ''They said they were going to start moving out today and we have no evidence that they're moving out.''
The officials said that some 20,000 additional Iraqi troops were deployed along the Saudi border, augmenting the smaller expeditionary units that probed that area yesterday, in what could be preparation for an Iraqi strike at Saudi oilfields.
While an incursion into Saudi Arabia by Iraqi forces cannot be ruled out, American officials say the latest Iraqi deployments are more likely intended to make the West and the Arab world so concerned about defusing a potential threat to Saudi Arabia that they would be relieved to accept the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait.
 
Cabinet Formed in Kuwait
The Iraqi invasion force has replaced Kuwait's 250-year-old Sabah monarchy with a new Cabinet supposedly composed of nine Kuwaiti Army officers. Kuwaiti diplomats and other officials abroad contend that the cabinet is made up of Iraqis.
The Washington Post for Monday reported that President Bush had ordered Government agencies to begin a secret planning effort aimed at destabilizing and eventually toppling President Hussein. Efforts to reach United States intelligence officials to confirm The Post's account tonight were unsuccessful.
Administration officials are increasingly concerned about the unwillingess of Saudi Arabia and the other leading Arab countries to stand up to Mr. Hussein. Officials say they detect a strong tendency in the Arab world to try to appease Baghdad by letting it swallow Kuwait in hopes that this will spare Iraq's neighbors a similar fate. Privately, American officials are expressing contempt for most of the Arab leaders.
In the first public hint of such repugnance, Mr. Bush publicly chastized unnamed Arab leaders for their reluctance to condemn Mr. Hussein and to join in Western-initiated efforts to roll back his invasion.
Asked if he was disappointed by the way his friend King Hussein of Jordan abstained from an Arab League resolution denouncing the Iraqi invasion, Mr. Bush said: ''I want to see the Arab states join the rest of the world in condemning this outrage and doing what they can to get Saddam Hussein out. I am disappointed to find any comment by anyone that apologizes or appears to condone what's taken place.''
 
'A Very Serious Matter'
Apparently referring to King Hussein or to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Mr. Bush added: ''I was told by one leader that I respect enormously - I believe this was back on Friday - that they needed 48 hours to find what was called 'an Arab solution.' That obviously has failed. And of course I'm disappointed that the matter hasn't been resolved before now. This is a very serious matter.'' For now, the Administration's plan for dealing with the gulf crisis is focused on diplomatic pressure and economic sanctions. Working with the Western allies and the United Nations, it is trying not only to deprive Iraq of any economic benefits from occupying Kuwait, but also to punish it with an oil boycott and possibly broader economic sanctions now being considered by the United Nations Security Council.
These economic measures are being reinforced by an effort to isolate Iraq diplomatically and to prevent the Iraqi-installed government in Kuwait from being accorded any legitimacy within the Arab world or beyond. It is the Administration's hope that these diplomatic and economic moves will eventually induce a cash-starved Iraqi leader to withdraw.
Among the military options under review by the Administration, a multinational naval blockade would seem to be the most feasible and carry the least risk of widening the conflict. It also seems to enjoy the broadest support within the Administration at this time.
Far more controversial and dangerous would be any attempt by the United States, either alone or with its allies, to dispatch ground troops or fighter aircraft to Kuwait in an attempt to force the Iraqis out.
For now, Administration officials say, only an Iraqi incursion into Saudi Arabia would automatically bring direct American military intervention.

HEADLINE: With Care, U.S. Presses Kenyans To Open Their Political Process

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 5

 BODY:
A senior American official, in Kenya to patch up ruffled relations, has urged the Government to open up the political process but has been careful not to insist on multiparty democracy as the only prescription.
The four-day visit of the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Herman Cohen, which ended today, came after the Kenyan Government reacted angrily to statements by Washington and the American Ambassador here criticizing the detention of political opponents and advocating pluralism.
Mr. Cohen said after a meeting with President Daniel arap Moi that while the United States favors a multiparty system, ''Who are we to say it is good for everybody?'' Kenya's only legal party is the Kenya African National Union.
But Mr. Cohen made it clear that the United States expects a recently established party commission to come up with fundamental changes in the political system. 
 
Reaction to Detentions
Kenya is the largest recipient in sub-Saharan Africa of American economic and military aid, and Washington reacted to the detentions by freezing half of Kenya's $10 million military aid and a small amount of economic aid. The detentions, presaged by a statement by Mr. Moi that advocates of a multiparty state would be hunted down ''like rats,'' led to three days of rioting that left at least 20 people dead.
Three leading multiparty advocates, Kenneth Matiba, Charles Rubia and Raila Odinga, have been in jail without charges since early last month. Four detainees have been charged with trying to bring down the Government. Six more political opponents are said to be held without charges.
Mr. Cohen said he discussed the detentions with Mr. Moi but was not at liberty to say what the Government intended to do about the detainees. Mr. Moi must make that announcement, Mr. Cohen said.
American officials here have suggested that for Congress to release the frozen aid to Kenya, the detainees would have to be freed in the next month or so.
 
Support for Ambassador
There were also reports here that President Moi would ask the United States to recall its ambassador, Smith Hempstone, who has been outspoken about political reform. In his meeting with Mr. Moi, Mr. Cohen expressed support for Mr. Hempstone. Publicly, Mr. Cohen said, ''Ambassador Hempstone was expressing the truth when he said that the United States favors pluralistic democracy, individual rights and civil liberties.''
But unlike the ambassador, Mr. Cohen was not seen with any Government opponents. He appeared to have succeeded in his mission to placate the Government. Mr. Moi said today that relations were ''back to normal.''
American officials said in private meetings that Mr. Cohen tried to leave the impression that the future of Kenya's relationship with Washington was at stake. ''The country is at a crossroads,'' an American official said.
Officials said that Kenya, once considered a good example of an emerging democracy with relatively free elections, had backtracked and the Government needed to initiate change.
 
Pressure to Broaden System
President Moi has been under increasing pressure from church leaders and lawyers to broaden the one-party state, which has been in place since 1982. But unlike other one-party African leaders, Mr. Moi has staunchly resisted demands for a multiparty system and has instead said he would consider reforming the Kenya African National Union.
The new party commission, headed by the vice president, George Saitoti, has been holding hearings around the country to determine public opinion on how to change the party.
The hearings have been marked by loud criticism of election rigging and the abolition of secret ballot in primary elections. An Anglican bishop thought to be friendly with President Moi made a surprise attack on the political system at a hearing last week.
The bishop, Alexander Muge, said Parliament should be immediately dissolved and fresh elections held with a secret ballot. He said the president should be limited to two five-year terms, and in an effort to get at the pervasive corruption among politicians, he said candidates for public office should declare their wealth and how they got it.
A group of 54 lawyers made similar demands last week.

HEADLINE: Vietnam's Allies Faltering in Cambodia

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The new American policy on Cambodia has been warmly welcomed here, but it does not alter a domestic situation that, 11 months after the withdrawal of most Vietnamese troops, is slowly deteriorating.
Direct contact by Washington with Phnom Penh as well as Hanoi is a logical extension of the policy, announced on July 18 by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. The policy withdraws diplomatic support at the United Nations for an opposition coalition that included Khmer Rouge guerrillas.
In the first formal talks on Cambodia between the United States and Vietnam, scheduled to begin on Monday in New York, the Vietnamese will press for an expansion of the discussions to include a representative of the Phnom Penh Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, senior East European diplomats say. The Government is supported by Vietnam, which invaded Cambodia in 1979 and withdrew its troops last September. The talks are aimed at setting up a council to conduct elections for a new Cambodian government, ending the civil war involving the Hun Sen Government and the three factions, including the Khmer Rouge, opposed to it. 
At home, Mr. Hun Sen's Government is coping with a weakening economy, an inflation rate of some 200 percent a year, cuts in aid from Communist countries, political infighting and an increase in the Khmer Rouge's guerrilla war in the countryside, which has produced up to 130,000 displaced people in at least seven provinces.
 
A Year of New Challenges
Diplomats and relief workers say that Phnom Penh faces unprecedented challenges in the next year, and it is actively seeking both Western aid and recognition to restore confidence and replace declining Soviet-bloc support.
But at the same time, these challenges have caused the Government to tighten up internally, diplomats say, with an evident chastening of Mr. Hun Sen, who is also Foreign Minister, by older, senior party leaders more skeptical of the West, closer to Vietnam and more concerned about their own positions in a post-settlement government.
The most prominent of them is Chea Sim, 58 years old, who is president of the National Assembly and controls the Interior Ministry, which he used to head in the early 1980's. A former Buddhist monk, he is considered by diplomats to be a populist, nationalist and traditionalist, and he does not grant interviews to the Western press.
But these assorted developments do not yet represent a crisis, and no credible analyst or official here sees any imminent political or military collapse.
 
A Rickety Economy
The main concern, they say, is the economy, which the Khmer Rouge is trying to disrupt. Economic collapse could lead to the kind of panic that would quickly undermine an army that is still holding its own. The Khmer Rouge ruled the country from 1975 to 1978 and carried out a brutal reorganization of society that killed more than one million people.
While the level of popular concern in Phnom Penh and district capitals like Kompong Speu and Kompong Chhnang has increased, especially given inflation and the presence of refugees, life goes on as before.
Indeed, many urban Cambodians are making a great deal of money on free markets, and the amount of Thai and Singaporean goods for sale, from beer and clothing to medicine, spare parts and motorbikes, has been increasing dramatically over the last year.
One of the main problems for the Government, with so few trained specialists and a weak and widely abused taxation system, is to obtain even a modest share of the foreign exchange surging through the urban economy.
 
Coping With Inflation
The Cambodian currency, the riel, has gone from 190 to the dollar a year ago to 485 to the dollar now, and the price of rice has more than doubled in six months. While already low Government salaries went up 50 percent in January, inflation has made a mockery of the increase, and the number of commodities like rice, gasoline, clothing and cigarettes given to state employees for resale has been cut to only rice and gas.
As a result, state workers are more frequently absent to work second jobs or run private businesses, or are more corrupt. The result is a gradual lessening of the grip and impact of the national administration, which in the longer term, along with economic difficulties, can only help the Khmer Rouge.
''Frankly speaking, we don't know how to deal with the economic situation,'' Cham Prasith, a deputy prime minister in charge of the economy, said last week. ''We will have to face more and more difficulties. Our survival depends on the West.''
While the Khmer Rouge have been pushing out from their redoubts to hit soft targets closer to population centers, they avoid large scale battles.
 
Khmer Rouge Tactics
After failing to take Battambang and Sisophon, important provincial capitals in the northwest near their sanctuaries in Thailand, the Khmer Rouge have reinfiltrated their forces in the mountainous, heavily forested areas of provinces closer to Phnom Penh, like Kompong Speu, Kompong Cham, Kompong Chhnang and Kompong Thom.
Since the spring, they have intensified the well-known tactics of guerrilla war, designed to disrupt the economy and agriculture, destroy roads, bridges and trains, and undermine people's confidence in the local and national administration.
It thus remains a war of hit-and-run tactics, booby traps and mines. But since early June, in particular since the isolation of the Khmer Rouge at talks in Tokyo, the guerrillas have stepped up their activity in most provinces, moving farther from their traditional redoubts to attack closer to major district towns and cities.
This has caused the Government to pull back the more remote military district headquarters in Kompong Speu, Kompong Chhnang, Kompong Thom and Battambang provinces. With the headquarters have come thousands of civilians - some fleeing the fighting, others moved by the Government to try to deny the Khmer Rouge food, money and recruits.
 
People's Needs Are Unmet
These civilians, now in roadside shacks and huts, need food, medicine, clothing and farming utensils, which the Government and aid agencies here cannot supply in full.
But when Government troops mount campaigns even in these regions, the Khmer Rouge fall back or cross provincial borders, only to emerge again when the troops themselves return to headquarters.
Khmer Rouge commanders have said the increased fighting is to insure that they are not left out of any diplomatic solution and to pressure the Government to make more concessions.
For the moment, senior diplomats here believe the Khmer Rouge is incapable militarily of doing much more.
 
More Civilian Targets Hit
But since June, the Khmer Rouge seem to be hitting more civilian targets, including attacks in July on two trains in Kampot and Kompong Chhnang, in which more than 100 civilians were killed and others robbed and forced to carry ammunition and food.
The guerrillas are also seeding more rice fields with mines, burning more villages and seizing more cattle and rice.
''These tactics would seem to undermine their incremental efforts to rebuild any political credibility,'' a senior diplomat said. ''The evidence is still thin, but there may be a shift of tactics. Still, as they move farther from traditional strongholds, they are in areas where they have almost no political support.''
The current situation could go on for a long time, the diplomat said, barring a chain reaction of economic, psychological and military collapse.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eleven months after the withdrawal of the bulk of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge have steadily stepped up guerrilla warfare in the countryside. A Khmer Rouge family, above, after living for a decade in jungles near the Thai border, moved in June to territory seized by guerrillas. (Associated Press)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: CAMBODIA (98%); UNITED STATES (95%); VIET NAM (95%); VIETNAM (92%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (79%); 

CITY: PHNOM PENH, CAMBODIA (95%); HANOI, VIETNAM (92%);

LENGTH: 973 words

HEADLINE: Jerusalem Journal;
Getting By in Israel, or, How to Stretch a Shekel

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 5

 BODY:
If Israelis are hard on the outside and sweet on the inside, as local folk wisdom says, then a good part of their toughness probably comes from the constant struggle against a battered economy, where taxes are all-encompassing, prices are higher than in Manhattan, and meager salaries seldom stretch to the end of the month.
This is one of the world's most heavily taxed nations, with levels of up to 250 percent on imported goods, sales taxes of 16 percent on all purchases and a stiff tariff on all foreign travel. As a result, a four-door Subaru sedan costs the equivalent of $41,000, a standard 21-inch color television set, $1,245, a frost-free refrigerator, $1,600, and permission to leave the country, $125.
Yet the average combined salary for a two-income family of four is $16,800, or $1,400 a month. And that is before taxes that range quickly up to 48 percent. The same average family spends $1,650 a month on basic expenses, leaving a gap of at least $250. 
Mysteriously, despite all that, Israelis are devoted world travelers. And they buy extraordinarily expensive cars, VCR's and compact disk players at an impressive rate.
 
The Unreported Income
So how do they manage?
''If someone figures it out, please let me know,'' says Jay Kalish, a Jerusalem lawyer. Mr. Kalish, an American immigrant who runs his own business translating legal documents from Hebrew to English, and his wife, Judy, a part-time secretary, earn about $1,900 a month, quite a drop from what they earned in New York before moving here in 1987.
Largely for economic reasons, more than half the Americans who move to Israel give up and move back within the first two years. But families like the Kalishes that decide to stay have devised a broad variety of strategies for economic survival.
As in other countries, many people simply do not report a part of their income to the tax authorities - from plumbers or auto mechanics who give discounts if clients pay cash and do not ask for a receipt, to radio technicians who fix stereos at home or doctors who see patients in off-hours.
Prof. Reuben Gronaur of the Hebrew University economics department says that given the gap between the average salaries and the cost of living ''you have to infer that there is something wrong'' with the Government's income figures.
''The data on expenses is collected very carefully, but the data on income much less so because anyone can show a monthly salary slip without showing everything he earns,'' Mr. Gronaur said. Sweetening the Salary Avoiding taxes is not the only way Israelis have found to get by. Some of the more creative devices are for supplementing income.
In most of the public sector, which makes up 90 percent of the workforce, salaries are pathetically low. Doctors and nurses often earn $1,000 a month in state hospitals and teachers and educators earn as little as $800. To attract and keep employees, state institutions have to supplement basic salaries with ''extras.''
At the Government-run Israel Radio, for example, employees earn fixed salaries that rarely exceed $1,500 a month. Rather than increase the basic salary, which would violate wage freezes, the network, like most other employers, enhances income by reimbursing employees for transportation costs, auto insurance, phone bills, even meals eaten at work.
Employees are also paid for a fixed number of overtime hours, whether they have worked them or not. These extras can double a worker's income.
But for most people, augmented wages or tax evasion just bring the income in line with expenses. As a result, Israeli businessmen, merchants and consumers have come up with several unusual ways of stretching buying power.
Israeli banks routinely permit clients to overdraw their accounts by up to two times the amount of the client's monthly salary. Since nearly all Israelis have their salaries directly deposited into bank accounts, the bank is more or less guaranteed reimbursement.
As a result, hundreds of thousands of Israelis habitually and endlessly overdraw their bank accounts. Living in debt to the bank is commonplace, although not without penalty. If the overdraft is approved, which most are, interest on the debt hovers around 25 percent. But if the account holder doesn't have the bank's permission, interest rates can soar to about 45 percent a year.
 
On the Installment Plan
Merchants sell just about anything in installments. Furniture, applicances, clothes - even food - are often advertised by the monthly installment price without any mention of what the items would cost if paid for in full. To buy a new television set or toaster in 12 easy payments, all anyone has to do is hand over 12 signed, post-dated checks for each monthly installment.
The banks, the retailers and the customers all know that the checks are probably written on accounts that are perpetually overdrawn and are based on a guaranteed salary deposit that hardly meets basic living expenses. But that's the system, and everybody lives with it.
If they didn't, Israelis probably would not be able to cope with rises in the cost of living that easily outstrip salaries. Since 1986, the consumer price index has gone up 93 percent, while wages have risen by only 73 percent.
''Our expenses are the bare necessities for the most part,'' Mr. Kalish said. ''We spend on child care, heat in the winter, upkeep for the car. Food is an enormous expense, so instead of the supermarket we shop at the shuk,'' the local open market.
When it comes to putting money away for the future, Mr. Kalish said, ''At this point I can't see that it's possible.''
''It's frightening, but for some reason you get used to it,'' he added. ''The first time we saw a negative balance on our bank account, we turned ash gray, but all our friends just laughed and said 'Welcome!' ''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Israelis are among the most heavily taxed people on earth and many have a difficult time making ends meet. ''Our expenses are the bare necessities for the most part,'' said Jay Kalish, an American immigrant. He and his wife, Judy, shop at a shuk, a local open market with lower prices than the supermarket. (Micha Bar-Am/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1072 words

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
A President Puts Himself on the Spot

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Foreign policy, which lifted George Bush so high in the esteem of his fellow Americans, making him seem for months on end like the man with the infallible touch, now threatens to bring him low.
There is no doubt among those who are responsible for strategic political thinking in the White House and the Republican Party that the crisis in the Persian Gulf has the potential to cripple the President politically, just as double-digit inflation and the Iran hostage crisis, earlier products of the instability in the Middle East, fatally wounded President Jimmy Carter.
Aware that Mr. Carter and other Presidents had worsened their problems by seeming to temporize, Mr. Bush sought to project an image of boldness this afternoon by pledging that ''this will not stand, this agression against Kuwait.'' But in all but commiting himself to expelling Iraqi troops from the desert sheikdom, the President increased the stakes for himself. 
''The storm is mighty,'' a White House official said. ''The boat is small and the oars are short.''
 
Where Bush Is Strong
For the moment, to be sure, Americans are rallying around the President, as they did during the Panama invasion last December and as they always do in times of stress. Democratic politicians say the furthest thing from their minds is taking partisan profit from the situation.
Mr. Bush's reservoir of good will in the country, built up over 16 months in which he benefitted from changes in Eastern Europe, from Democratic disarray and from his successful management of a complex relationship with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, will stand him in good stead in the coming weeks.
Should Iraq invade Saudi Arabia, and should the United States spring to Saudi Arabia's defense, Mr. Bush could almost certainly count on solid backing from an electorate that is always slow to criticize Presidents at war. The same would be true if he used force to drive Iraqi units from Kuwait. But by drawing a line in the sand, he gives a hostage to fortune; failure would open him to criticism from Democrats and others. Had he not drawn the line he would have run the risk of seeming supine in the face of aggression, like Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of Great Britain in the 1930's. A Puppet for Baghdad? The Iraqi strategy, in the view of politicians, diplomats and Middle East scholars, is to remain in Kuwait, with troops or a puppet regime or both, and use it as the base for a long campaign of intimidation against Saudi Arabia and the small, weak oil-producing emirates to the southeast. If far less melodramatic than American combat involvement, that would be still be bad news indeed for Mr. Bush.
Unless successfully challenged through an embargo of improbable thoroughness, a naval blockade or another measure, like closing the two Iraqi oil pipelines, President Saddam Hussein could be in a position to dictate Saudi production levels. Then a ''country that has shown a ruthless hostility'' would have achieved, as former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today, ''a stranglehold on the world oil supply.'' And that could produce economic wreckage in the United States.
Higher oil prices tend to cut growth and accelerate inflation, which is hardly what the President, whose poll ratings for handling the domestic economy are lower than they are for his management of foreign affairs, wants as the 1990 Congressional and gubernatorial campaigns get under way.
A lengthy downturn, of course, could hurt the President himself as he seeks re-election in 1992. Now retail gasoline prices are leaping. More important perhaps, that phenomenon is being driven home by news organizations; in the Midwest this weekend, where several pivotal 1990 races are concentrated, local television news programs and local newspaper front pages have been dominated not by news from the Middle East but by pictures of service-station pylons with the new, higher numbers in place, accompanied by stories warning of much more to come.
 
Politics of the Pump
''Seems like we ought to be able to get ourselves out of this, those people over there dictating what happens here,'' said a man interviewed by a Cleveland television station on Saturday while pumping costlier gas into his car. The comment illustrates a central reality of the post-cold-war world.
Regional conflict has not been swept away by the rapprochement between Moscow and Washington; the superpowers find themselves less able to influence the course of events in areas where the fear of nuclear conflict used to act as a kind of damper.
Pressure to act would increase exponentially, of course, should anything happen to the 3,000 to 3,500 Americans believed to be in Kuwait, with which telephone communications have now been severed for almost 72 hours.
There are other problems. The tortuous negotiations on a domestic budget settlement, for example, have been based on a tacit understanding that some sort of energy tax would be necessary. The idea seems doomed at a moment when gasoline and fuel-oil prices are rising. Any sort of tax increase with recession threatening is likely to be considered economically and politically inadvisable, making it very hard to see how the cuts mandated by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings legislation will be possible to achieve.
 
Guns Gain on Butter
Last week's developments had a few positive implications for the President. They are likely to slow, though not to stop, the rush to cut military spending, something Mr. Bush and his aides had been unable to do previously. And the President, as an adoptive Texan, will no doubt be pleased that that state's long-suffering economy is likely to snap back, with its expensive oil better able to compete with more expensive oil from the gulf. But in global or even in national terms, those are relatively small considerations, and the overall picture is an ominous one for Mr. Bush.
The President will need all of his experience, all of his cool and all of his skill in rallying other nations to the cause to handle the diplomatic side of the crisis. He will need great political skills under stress, perhaps more than at any time since he stood on the verge of elimination from the 1988 Presidential contest in New Hampshire, to explain to the American public why, having spent tens of billions of tax dollars in the gulf in the last decade, American influence in the area is so limited.

HEADLINE: THE IRAQI INVASION;
Transcript of News Conference Remarks by Bush on Iraq Crisis

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription service:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Well, I just wanted to fill you all in on the diplomatic activity that is taking place, intensive diplomatic activity around the world. I've got to go in now; I'm getting another call from President Ozal of Turkey, with whom I have been in previous conversation. Yesterday, I talked to him. I talked this morning to Prime Minister Kaifu, and I applaud Japan's stance, cracking down on the imports from Iraq. I just hung up, up there in Camp David, talking with Prime Minister Mulroney. We're all in the same accord, he and President Mitterrand, with whom I've spoken, Chancellor Kohl, Margaret Thatcher. And I think the alliance, the NATO alliance, is thinking exactly the same way on this. I also talked yesterday to Kuwait's Emir and gave him certain assurances. 
What's emerging is nobody is -seems to be showing up as willing to accept anything less than total withdrawal from Iraq, from Kuwait of the Iraqi forces, and no puppet regime. We've been down that road, and there will be no puppet regime that will be accepted by any countries that I'm familiar with. And there seems to be a united front out there that says Iraq, having committed brutal, naked aggression, ought to get out and that the - this concept of their installing some puppet leaving behind will not be acceptable.
So, we're pushing forward on diplomacy. We've gotten - tomorrow I will meet here in Washington with the Secretary General of the United Nations - I mean, the Secretary General of NATO - and Margaret Thatcher will be coming in here tomorrow, and I will be continuing this diplomatic effort. And I'm sure you know of the meeting I had in Camp David with some of our top military people, and I will continue that kind of consultation as well.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Q. How are you going to - how are you going to keep the puppet government from being accepted and installed? And are you going to -
 
A. There is no intention on the part of any of these countries to accept a puppet government, and that signal is going out loud and clear to Iraq. And I will not discuss with you what my options are or might be, but they're wide open, I can assure you of that.
 
Q. The Saudi Arabians and the Turks, have they - have you talked to Saudi Arabia and the Turks about turning off the oil pipelines through their countries? And are they -
 
A. All options are open and there is a strong feeling on the part of the NATO countries to whom I've talked, Turkey being one of them, that we must have concerted, and I'd say -well, concerted action to isolate Iraq economically. And you can - you can just assume from there that those matters are being considered.
 
Q. Are the Saudis inclined to cut off the pipeline, Mr. President?
 
A. I can't tell you the state of play. I've discussed this with King Fahd and I - whether I'll be talking to him again today, I don't know. But I'm not going to characterize their position on this. Let them speak for themselves.
Yeah?
 
Q. Mr. President, what is the situation on the ground? Do the Iraqis appear to be dug in or are they readying -
 
A. Iraq lied once again. They said they were going to start moving out today and we have no evidence that they're moving out.
 
Q. Do we have evidence that there's 18 divisions, new divisions coming in -
 
A. I'm not going to discuss the intelligence situation on the ground right now, but I've not heard a figure of 18 new divisions going in.
 
Q. Have you given any -
 
A. Just a minute. Anne?
 
Q. Are Americans in danger in Kuwait or other areas down there? And can you -
 
A. I wouldn't want to say they're in danger, but I - you know how I feel about the protection of American life and willingness to do whatever is necessary to protect it. But I don't have the feeling that they're in imminent danger right now.
 
Q. And the people who are now in control in Kuwait are saying they may close some of the embassies in Kuwait City, that they will regard any reaction against them as - you should take care if you have your nationals in our country. Isn't that a threat?
 
A. I'm not trying to characterize threats. The threat is the vicious aggression against Kuwait. And that speaks for itself. And anything collaterally is just simply more indication that these are outlaws - international outlaws and renegades. And I want to see the United Nations move soon with Chapter 7 sanctions. And I want to see the rest of the world join us, as they are in overwhelming numbers, to isolate Saddam Hussein.
 
Q. Mr. President, how can you and other world leaders prevent the installation of what you've termed a puppet government?
 
A. Just wait. Watch and learn.
Yeah?
 
Q. Mr. President, have you, in fact, tried to reach Saddam Hussein since you're calling all these other people?
 
A. No. No, I have not.
 
Q. King Hussein has embraced him.
 
Q. Mr. President, have we asked the Saudi Arabians for the use of their military bases?
 
A. Hmm?
 
Q. Have we asked the Saudi Arabians -
 
A. I'm not going to discuss what I'm talking to the Saudis about. I'm not going to discuss anything to do about military options at all.
Yeah?
 
Q. Mr. President, have you talked to King Hussein of Jordan since he indicated his support -
 
A. I talked to him once and that's all.
 
Q. Are you disappointed in what he said?
 
Q. But he's embraced Saddam Hussein. He went to Baghdad and embraced -
 
A. What's your question? I can read.
 
Q. Are you disappointed in what King Hussein said -
 
A. I want to see the Arab states join the rest of the world in condemning this outrage and doing what they can to get Saddam Hussein out. Now, he was talking - King Hussein - about an Arab solution, but I am disappointed to find any comment by anyone that apologizes or appears to condone what's taken place.
 
Q. Is Secretary Cheney going to Saudi Arabia?
 
A. I'm not going to comment on anything that we're doing of that nature.
 
Q. Mr. President, are you disappointed in the failure of the Arab -other Arab nations to make more progress toward resolving the situation?
 
A. Well, I was told by one leader that I respect enormously - I believe this was back on Friday - that they needed 48 hours to find what was called an Arab solution. That obviously has failed. And of course I'm disappointed that the matter hasn't been resolved before now. This is a very serious matter.
I'll take one more and then I've got to go to work over here.
 
Q. Have you already taken steps to protect Americans over there? Have you moved -
 
A. I am not going to discuss what we're doing in terms of moving of forces, anything of that nature. But I view it very seriously, not just that, but any threat to any other countries as well, as I view very seriously our determination to reverse out this aggression. And please believe me, there are an awful lot of countries that are in total accord with what I've just said. And I salute them. They are staunch friends and allies. And we will be working with them all for collective action. This will not stand. This will not stand, this aggression against Kuwait.
I've got to go. I have to go to work. I've got to go to work.

LENGTH: 406 words

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
Thailand, the Next Tiger

BYLINE: By David C. Unger

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand

 BODY:
Economic development in Thailand is as visible as Bangkok's polluted air or the buildings that seem to spring up overnight. Less obvious but just as important is its political development, a steady consolidation of democratic institutions to match the economic gains. And there is an increasing sophistication and self-confidence in Thailand's foreign policies. 
Self-confidence seems to be the key. Thailand managed to avoid the European colonialism that engulfed most of its Southeast Asian neighbors. Now it faces the convulsive changes of urbanization and industrial capitalism with impressive aplomb.
The social costs of rapid change, like environmental degradation and a growing AIDS problem, are recognized and, to a limited degree, addressed by Government policies. But there is surprisingly little hand-wringing about the threat to traditional culture or the surge of foreign capital. Thailand, opinion leaders seem to believe, will absorb all the world has to offer and make it serve Thai purposes.
Thailand is headed for a third straight year of hurtling economic growth, after a 13.2 percent advance in 1988 and 12.2 percent in 1989. These rapid gains coincide with the Government of Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan, who, unlike most of his recent predecessors, is a democratically elected member of Parliament.
The Chatichai Government has been dominated by businessmen, and plagued by suspicions of ministerial corruption. Still, it remains highly popular.
The Government's main foreign-policy theme has been to turn war-plagued neighboring countries into peaceful markets. In Myanmar, once Burma, that has led to Thai complicity with the murderous military regime of the Slorc, the State Law and Order Restoration Council.
In Cambodia, Bangkok has advanced an imaginative peace diplomacy that helped wean Washington from its shameful indirect association with the Khmer Rouge. The common theme is that Thailand is capable of exercising regional leadership as it emerges from its earlier automatic deference to the wishes of Washington and Beijing.
There's the excitement of an emerging economic and political power in Bangkok these days, as it takes its place alongside the ''Asian tigers'' of Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan. The economic energy now surging through Thailand is frequently raw and crude. Yet Thais typically take in all these changes with a look of serenity and a knowing smile.

LENGTH: 479 words

HEADLINE: Khmer Rouge Poised to Gain From U.S. Policy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Since 1979, the United States has ostensibly pursued two policy goals toward Cambodia. First, to punish Vietnam for invading Pol Pot's Cambodia and installing the current Government in Phnom Penh; second, to prevent a Khmer Rouge return to power.
The United States has achieved the first at the expense of the second. It has given diplomatic recognition to the Khmer Rouge-dominated coalition at the United Nations, and covert lethal and overt nonlethal aid to that coalition and has imposed a devastating economic embargo on Cambodia. 
This shameful policy of aiding the architects of yesterday's genocide continued until July 18, when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d recognized after 10 months the Vietnamese troop withdrawal and announced that the United States would discuss with Vietnam how to stop the Khmer Rouge. But this long-overdue move could be too late.
The reason is that the Khmer Rouge have long prepared for it. Interviews with high-level defectors that one of us, Roger Normand, recently conducted in Cambodian refugee camps show that since 1988, Pol Pot's strategy has been to infiltrate thousands of cadres into villages throughout Cambodia. Through propaganda and outright terror, they plan to control any elections. The danger of their success is growing.
Meanwhile, Khieu Samphan, the Khmer Rouge negotiator, has been carrying out Pol Pot's instructions to use his veto power over the peace negotiations, and ''delay elections'' until Khmer cadres get a tight political and military grip on the countryside. Khieu Samphan will not agree to elections unless and until Pol Pot feels the country is ''ready.''
Yet according to Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the Administration continues to believe that elections in the context of ''a comprehensive settlement involving all factions is the best way - and probably the only way - of preventing the Khmer Rouge from returning to power'' (Op-Ed, July 26).
Such a settlement would play directly into Pol Pot's hands by granting his followers the two things they desperately need: more time and an internationally sanctioned mechanism by which to return to power.
Instead, the United States should encourage a new Cambodian coalition that excludes the Khmer Rouge by working with Vietnam to foster power sharing, and also condition further aid to the non-Communists on splitting from the Khmer Rouge.
While the hard core of the Khmer Rouge would continue to fight, they would do so from outside the Government. Faced by a unified, pluralistic Cambodia, a weakened Khmer Rouge could never again return their countrymen and women to the killing fields.
 
BEN KIERNAN
ROGER NORMAND
 New Haven, July 27, 1990
The writers are, respectively, associate professor of Southeast Asian history at Yale University and field work editor of The Harvard Human Rights Journal.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: CAMBODIA (97%); UNITED STATES (95%); VIET NAM (94%); SOUTH-EASTERN ASIA (79%); ASIA (79%);

HEADLINE: Buffalo's Economic Revival Owes Much to Albany Investment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 20 report on Buffalo's economic revival neglects the key role New York State has played in rebuilding the western New York economy. Six years ago, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo targeted the region - then suffering staggering unemployment and economic decline - for special state attention. He established the Western New York Economic Development Corporation, an Urban Development Corporation subsidiary, to channel state resources to job-generating projects and take a regional approach to long-range planning.
Since then, state investment in the region has been substantial, more than $100 million. Last year 28 percent of all state funds spent on economic development were spent in western New York, $39 million.
Pilot Field, for example, could not have been built without a $22 million state contribution. Dunlop Tire might have moved 1,500 jobs if the state had not created a $34 million incentive package. We have also funded high-tech research facilities at the University of Buffalo for earthquake studies and at Roswell Park Institute for cancer research. We have provided financing assistance to keep companies like Moog Inc., Harlequin Books and Freezer Queen Foods thriving and expanding in the Buffalo area.
We are working hard to sustain the resurgence, creating programs to help small businesses and starting to act on a plan for the Lake Erie shoreline. And not only western New York but also the rest of the state will benefit from the United States-Canada Free Trade Agreement.
We believe western New York can play a pivotal role in the global economy and are dedicated to providing help to the region.
 
VINCENT TESE
Director of Economic Development
 Albany, July 23, 1990

HEADLINE: Buffalo's Economic Revival Owes Much to Albany Investment;
Cultural Resources

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Buffalonians love admiring attention, such as your July 20 article on the Buffalo boom. Certainly, our proximity to our free-spending Canadian neighbor is not to be gainsaid in any analysis of our good fortune. And certainly our new baseball park, Pilot Field, where ballplayers perform on grass and fans can feel close to the action contributes to the positive way we feel about ourselves and to the perception of us by strangers.
But I was disappointed that you did not mention the State University of New York at Buffalo as a major employer and source of cultural and intellectual energy for Buffalo. Buffalo has a business life and a social life (yes, chicken wings are a favorite here), and it has an intellectual and cultural life as well.
Buffalo would be a very different place without the State University campus.
 
THOMAS PUTNAM
 Buffalo, July 25, 1990

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Reacting To Iraq

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
The Bush Administration, which was surprised by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, now faces two daunting tasks - to force an Iraqi withdrawal and a restoration of Kuwaiti sovereignty, and to move the United States substantially toward independence from Middle Eastern oil.
Neither task will be easy and the first may well be impossible. It demands the effort anyway - not least because the Iraqi invasion was an outrageous violation of international order and decency that neither the U.S. nor any other law-abiding nation can allow to stand unchallenged.
Practically speaking, moreover, if Saddam Hussein gets away with the seizure of Kuwait, his increased oil reserves and production capacity, together with the military threat he would pose to other oil-producing nations in the region, would give him virtual control of OPEC and world oil prices. 
The Arab nations, however, are already pondering that military threat, which means their unity in condemning Mr. Hussein will be hard to achieve. For him to withdraw and restore the Kuwaiti ruling family would require an arrogant man to admit a mistake and a defeat, and to suffer profound humiliation, in the world and before his own people. In a nation already suffering economic deprivation from the war with Iran, as well as Mr. Hussein's harsh dictatorship, he might not even survive a reversal in Kuwait. So he won't back down easily, if at all.
Calls will no doubt be heard for Western military action to force an Iraqi withdrawal. But that could destroy oil production capacity the West now needs. It could put Israel at risk from a ruthless leader who has already threatened to ''scorch'' it with poison gas and perhaps other deadly weapons. And it might well require a long and bloody land war, not just a quick application of relatively antiseptic air and sea power.
At least until Mr. Hussein tries something as nearly apocalyptic as an invasion of Saudi Arabia, military intervention is not an attractive option. Better by far to clamp tight and total economic sanctions on Iraq, including shutting off the oil pipelines through Turkey and Saudi Arabia on which Iraq depends. Mr. Bush apparently is considering that step, among others.
Agreement by European nations and Japan not to import Iraqi oil is a necessary beginning; so are the decisions by the Soviet Union and China not to sell more arms to Iraq. Mr. Hussein does not need more arms now, but it's useful to let him know there'll be none available in the future.
But squeezing Iraq economically is by no means a sure thing. Will the fearful and politically facile Saudis, for example, agree to such tough action as closing the pipeline? Will Arab leaders consider it the better part of valor to concede Kuwait to Mr. Hussein in return for his promises - for what little they would be worth - to leave them alone? How long will oil-hungry Western nations, or Japan, be willing to boycott Iraq? Can its imports really be withheld altogether, or blockaded?
For all these reasons, the Bush Administration's second task - increasing oil independence - is imperative, not just for the moment but for a future not dependent on imported oil.
Gas prices at the pump already are rising, and as things stand Mr. Hussein may push them higher - which means rising inflation and falling economic growth in this country. More immediately, bipartisan efforts for a $50 billion to $60 billion tax increase to reduce the Federal deficit probably are at an end. With oil prices threatening a recession, such a tax increase might make it certain. But by the same reasoning, a needed energy tax to cut consumption seems unlikely anytime soon.
Nevertheless, a start on greater energy independence can be made by conservation, and by the development of new energy sources. For only one example, if new cars were to achieve fuel efficiency of 65 miles per gallon by the mid-90's, which is technologically possible, all the 533 million autos expected to be on U.S. roads by the year 2000 would average 48 m.p.g. - and require 2.9 million fewer barrels of oil per day than did only 319 million cars in 1982.
Developing new energy sources is feasible, too, and actually might be aided by higher oil prices, which make some high-cost processes more competitive. Many possibilities exist - not, in my judgment, excluding re-examination of the potential for nuclear power. If reactors that do not breed weapons material and are safe enough to win public confidence -two big ifs - can be developed, that potential is too important to disregard.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED
