LENGTH: 1845 words

HEADLINE: Congressman Flake's Indictment: Good Works or Greed?

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
In southeast Queens, where the war against drugs and deterioration is a daily struggle, the white-steepled Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church is surrounded by a complex of tan brick buildings that some call Flakeville, in honor of the minister-turned-politician who built them.
For it is there that Representative Floyd H. Flake, one of 13 children of a Houston janitor, arrived 14 years ago to assemble a spiritual and secular empire that is the envy of many ministers across the city.
An energetic and charismatic preacher -with administrative skills honed in business school and academia - he built a private school for 480, an apartment complex for the elderly, renovations to broken-down stores, a home health care agency, a health clinic and social service center, a credit union and a congregation that has grown to 6,000 and doubles as a political field operation on Election Day.
But prosecutors now say that in the flush of his successes at the Allen A.M.E. Church, Mr. Flake turned from good works to greed to pay for an increasingly lavish life of fancy cars and clothing. 
 
Complaint About a Seduction
The complaints by an executive assistant, who said Mr. Flake had seduced her into an adulterous affair, stirred a former church trustee to come forward with allegations of fiscal improprieties. That in turn resulted in a 17-count Federal indictment last week, charging Mr. Flake and his wife with diverting thousands of dollars in church money to their own use.
Mr. Flake, in a statement, said his use of church money was proper. But even as the United States Attorney for the Eastern District, Andrew J. Maloney, announced the indictment, he went out of his way to praise Mr. Flake. ''In fairness to the Congressman,'' Mr. Maloney said, ''his church has done some outstanding work.''
The career of Mr. Flake is a story of uncommon idealism and ambition centered on a 155-year-old church, the oldest in Queens, in a largely black neighborhood of small single-family homes. The church, on the corner of Linden Boulevard and Merrick Boulevard in Jamaica, was at the center of a long-established black community. By the time Mr. Flake arrived as an idealistic 31-year-old college administrator in 1976, there were signs of abandonment and an encroachment of drugs and other social ills.
 
Janitor's Son Preaches at 15
Mr. Flake was born in Los Angeles, but grew up in Houston, where his father worked as a janitor at night to support his family.
Mr. Flake said he was totally caught up in church activities by age 10, and accepted the call to preach by age 15. When not leading youth activities at church, he said, he was selling black newspapers on his paper route.
The first member of his family to attend college, he graduated from Wilberforce University, an African Methodist Episcopal school in Xenia, Ohio, in 1967. He continued preaching while trying his hand at business, as a sales representative for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and a marketing analyst for Xerox.
After working as an associate dean at Lincoln University in Pennsylvania, the nation's oldest private, predominantly black college, Mr. Flake was recruited by Boston University to be the director of a black student center. He later served as the acting university chaplain. In his spare time, he took business courses at Northeastern University.
 
Door to Door to Koch
In his official biography, Mr. Flake says he was also dean of students at Boston University. But one former administrator at the school, Steven J. Trachtenberg, now president of George Washington University, said that while the job was offered, Mr. Flake turned it down. Instead he went to work at the Allen church.
At the church, working alone with a secretary, Mr. Flake set out to bring services to his neighborhood, going door to door at government offices, clipping public notices in newspapers and applying for grants.
''I would go downtown two or three times a week,'' he said. ''Even when there were no projects available I would still go back to say hello.''
He struck up a cordial relationship with former Mayor Edward I. Koch, at a time when the Mayor's relationship with many other black community leaders was growing more troubled. He became known in City Hall as one of Mr. Koch's favorite ministers and community leaders.
 
Financial and Spiritual Growth
The efforts paid off. The church's budget of $250,000 grew to $16.7 million, of which $9.7 million came from local and Federal government grants and programs. The church and its subsidiary corporations now have more than 700 employees, most of whom provide home health care services.
The spiritual life of the church surged as well. Mr. Flake, an imposing figure, 6 feet 1 inches tall, with closely trimmed hair and goatee, resplendent in royal blue robes, proved a popular and powerful orator. The congregation raised funds to build the Allen Christian School.
Membership in the church soared to 6,000 today from less than 1,500. Now the choir, more than a hundred strong, is seated first come first served, and three services are held each Sunday, the first, at 6:30 A.M., to meet the demand for seats. The church just spent $1 million for land for a new 2,500-seat sanctuary it hopes to build next year.
''He is a role model for the clergy,'' said the Rev. Carl Flemister, regional executive minister of the American Baptist Churches.
 
'He Is a Master Builder'
The Rev. Herbert Daughtry, pastor of the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn, said, ''He is a master builder.''
In 1986, after the district's longtime Congressman, Joseph P. Addabbo, died of cancer, Mr. Flake, at the urging, he says, of other local ministers, took on the regular Democratic clubs.
Running as an independent, he narrowly lost a special election to the Democrat, Assemblyman Alton R. Waldon Jr. But a few months later he came back to defeat Mr. Waldon in the Democratic primary and won a full term in the Sixth District.
Hundreds of congregants inundated polling places in the district - and many street corners between - for their beloved pastor.
 
'An Army in His Church'
''You always hear about ministers who can do things like this, but when they run against political clubs, it almost always turns out to be baloney,'' said Jerry Skurnik, a political consultant and former Koch aide. ''He had an army in his church working for him.''
While in Congress, Mr. Flake continues to run his church, a dual role that keeps him in perpetual motion, colleagues say, rushing back home several times a week after a full day in Washington to attend church or community events at night.
Mr. Flake has a moderately liberal voting record, but in his first two terms he has had little impact on legislation, and some constituents have begun to grouse that he has been spending too much time on church work.
''Most of the economic development work done by Representative Flake is done by his church,'' complained Nat Singleton, the head of the Association of Minority Enterprises in New York State and a former supporter. He said other neighborhood groups were not getting enough help.
Mr. Flake lives in a large three-story brick house, bought by the church for his use, with his wife, Margarett Elaine, who works for the church, and four children.
In addition to his Congressional salary, he reported earning $20,000 from the church. Motor vehicle records show that he owns a 1989 red Mercedes and previously owned a Lincoln and a BMW. Edwin Reed, an aide to Mr. Flake, said the Mercedes was actually owned by the church.
 
Willingness to Cut Corners
Even as his church empire grew, the events that led to Mr. Flake's indictment were quietly under way.
From the first, Mr. Flake showed a willingness to cut corners to get things done, sometimes for the church's benefit, sometimes, prosecutors say, for his own.
Church records provided by a lawyer for a former church trustee show that the church used $530,000 from a Federal loan for housing for the elderly to pay for parts of the Allen Christian School.
When the misuse of funds was discovered, and the church was ordered to repay the money, Mr. Flake persuaded officials in the regional Housing and Urban Development office to forgive the misspending. He argued that some of the elderly residents did volunteer work at the school.
The decision to forgive the error, rescinded last year by the agency, was made by same Federal housing officials later caught up in a scandal over political favoritism at the H.U.D. regional office. The church was ordered to repay the money.
 
Accused of Misusing Account
Later, according to prosecutors and church documents, Mr. Flake became more flagrant. He set up a private church bank account at his home, used to pay for transportation for residents of the housing complex to local shopping areas. Mr. Flake paid a local van company about $480 a month but billed the housing project $3,000 for the service, and diverted $75,200 to his own use, the authorities say.
The indictment also charges him with putting much of his basic salary into a church expense fund as a way of evading Federal income taxes on $66,700 of income.
The allegations might never had surfaced if not for the grievances of Mr. Flake's former executive assistant, Thelma Singleton-Scott.
Mrs. Scott, a congregant who was married with two children, was hired by Mr. Flake as his executive assistant in 1983. She said that they soon began an affair, an accusation Mr. Flake denied.
 
Accusation of Affair and Revenge
When she tried to break off the relationship a year later, she said, Mr. Flake dismissed her from her job, and when she complained, her name was stripped from the membership rolls of the church.
Mrs. Scott took her grievances against Mr. Flake to the church hierarchy, and demanded that he be dismissed. She took a lie-detector test, and secretly recorded conversations with Mr. Flake. Church officials backed Mr. Flake, but not before, Mrs. Scott's lawyers contend, she was offered a large settlement to drop her complaint. She later filed a suit charging, among other things, ministerial malpractice.
Mrs. Scott also consulted a lawyer, Robert H. Harris, who eventually took the evidence of financial malfeasance to the United States Attorney.
Mr. Harris said a former church trustee and retired Navy accountant, Elza W. Axon, called Mrs. Scott and said he had accumulated substantial evidence of financial improprieties by Mr. Flake. Mr. Harris turned the material over to Mr. Maloney.
While some officials and congregants in South Jamaica said Mr. Flake was the victim of a political or racial vendetta, the prevailing feeling following his indictment was sadness.
Mr. Flake said in an interview that the indictment was a ''difficult and traumatic'' moment for his family.
''They have a hard time understanding how you can put this much into something and have this as the end result,'' he said. ''They have seen me sacrifice them to perform for the church.''

HEADLINE: Man Accused of Stealing 25 Cabs

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
A Queens man has been charged with stealing 25 medallion taxis during the last month and using them to pick up fares to support his crack habit, the police said.
The suspect, Peter McGowan, 26 years old, of 30-42 80th Street in Jackson Heights, was arrested at his home at 2 P.M. Saturday and charged with two counts of second-degree robbery and four counts of grand larceny of an automobile. 
At the 108th Precinct station house, he was picked out of a lineup by several of the 25 drivers the police believe he stole the cabs from, said Sergeant Nicholas Vreeland, a police spokesman.
Sergeant Vreeland said Mr. McGowan was unemployed and drove the cabs around the city, picking up riders and keeping the fares, which he used to buy crack.
All 25 cabs were stolen from the drivers in Queens starting on July 4, Sgt. Vreeland said. ''He stole his first cab by simulating that he had a weapon in his pocket,'' Sergeant Vreeland said.
Using one cab, the sergeant said, Mr. McGowan posed as a taxi driver and then, pretending that he needed assistance with a flat tire, would wave down another cab driver. When the driver would leave his cab to help, Mr. McGowan would jump in the new cab and drive away, leaving the driver stranded with the old cab, the sergeant said. He stole his last cab on Saturday, the sergeant said.
An anonymous caller led the police to Mr. McGowan, Sergeant Vreeland said. Detectives in the 108th Precinct have not determined how much money Mr. McGowan made.

HEADLINE: 2 Companies, Big and Little, Clash Over Plan on Missiles

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
A proposal to convert aging nuclear missiles into cheap rockets for launching satellites has presented the Government with a difficult choice between conflicting goals: cashing in on the peace dividend and promoting American competitiveness in high-technology industries.
The Lockheed Corporation, the sole builder of submarine-launched ballistic missiles, wants to buy surplus Poseidon missiles being retired by the Navy, remove the warheads and use the missiles to carry small satellites for the space agency, the military and commercial customers. It says its plan could save taxpayers millions of dollars, providing income to the Navy while cutting its costs.
But Lockheed's plan would mean unwelcome competition for small companies that are just entering the commercial rocket business. One of them, the Orbital Sciences Corporation of Fairfax, Va., says it would undercut the Government's promise to spur commercial space technologies. 
''America won't be able to compete using 1970's technology in the 21st century,'' said Barbara Zadina, a spokeswoman for Orbital Sciences. She added that it would be unfair to make Orbital Sciences compete with a product made possible by what she called ''Government dumping,'' the cut-rate sale of used military hardware.
 
Government Is Torn
The young company, which has staked its future on the development of an innovative rocket for launching small satellites, may be on the verge of a commercial breakthrough with its Pegasus rocket. For the first time, the Pegasus this year proved itself able to carry a small satellite into space from under a high-flying airplane instead of from a launching pad on earth.
So far, Government officials remain torn between the conflicting goals, said Richard DalBello, director of the Commerce Department's Office of Space Commerce.
''One is loath, in the current budget conditions, to throw away assets that are already paid for,'' said Mr. DalBello. ''On the other hand, you don't want to hurt people like Orbital Sciences Corporation, who have spent real dollars, not government dollars.''
In June, Lockheed, Orbital Sciences and two other companies submitted bids to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for a contract to launch at least seven small scientific payloads into orbit, beginning in 1992. The competition is being conducted under new rules meant to spur the development of the commercial rocket industry after NASA, which used to launch all satellites for commercial and Government customers, dropped out of that business.
 
Global Telephone Potential
The space agency and the Air Force say they will need additional launchings of small satellites in the years ahead, and companies in the communications business are expected to demand hundreds of launchings of small satellites as well, for purposes like building global cellular telephone networks.
But that market could be served entirely by rockets built from surplus military missiles, analysts say. More than 350 Poseidons, including spares, could be scrapped under terms of the long-range missile treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union. Many land-based missiles might be scrapped as well.
Although all the missiles would need extensive modifications, and the costs of using them to carry satellites remain unknown, they clearly could be economically competitive with newly designed rockets built from scratch, industry officials said. The military missiles generally are not big enough to lift big satellites like those carried on the Space Shuttle or the Titan, Delta and Atlas classes of rockets.
The Navy has told NASA that it will allow contractors to buy its excess Poseidon missiles. But under pressure from Orbital Sciences, the Senate Armed Services Committee has questioned the idea.
 
Senators Exert Pressure
Senator John W. Warner of Virginia and Senator John McCain of Arizona, both Republicans, persuaded the committee to call for further study as part of its report on the 1991 military budget. In addition to its headquarters in Virginia, Orbital Sciences has a subsidiary in Arizona.
The committee report acknowledged that selling off the unneeded nuclear missiles ''is an appropriate use of such assets,'' since it would reduce launching costs and expand the nation's space launching capabilities.
But the committee added that it ''firmly believes that the impact of the release of significant numbers of excess Government ballistic missiles on the nascent commercial launch industry must be thoroughly understood and weighed before such release occurs.''
The committee urged the Defense Department not to release the missiles until the White House National Space Council, an inter-agency committee headed by Vice President Dan Quayle, had reviewed the idea.
Lockheed points out that Orbital Sciences itself has benefited from Government assistance. It launched its first test satellite under a contract to the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, from a specially equipped B-52 bomber operated by NASA.
Orbital Sciences argues that more benefit from the old missiles is not necessary, that the taxpayers have already collected enough of a dividend from their investment. ''The Poseidons have done their job, they have helped to win the cold war,'' said Ms. Zadina. ''The country has gotten its money's worth already, from deterrence of war.''

His mother teaches kindergarten at Public School 251 in Queens. His father was an elementary-school principal in Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Minor Blessing for Mexico, But Not Really a Windfall

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The sharp jump in oil prices after Iraq's seizure of Kuwait comes as a minor blessing for Mexico, a nation that enriched itself in the early 1980's by exporting high-priced oil but can no longer raise its production to benefit from a new windfall in prices.
Mexico might collect an extra $10 million a day in oil revenue from the higher prices. But it has invested so little in oil exploration in recent years that production has declined to about 2.5 million barrels a day, from a peak of nearly three million barrels a day in December 1982. About half of the production is sold domestically, and 1.2 million barrels are exported each day. 
''Maybe they can squeeze an extra 15,000 barrels a day from their wells, but that's minuscule,'' said George Baker, a Mexican oil industry expert at the Consortium for Research on Mexico, at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Pemex, the state oil company, cut capital spending from nearly $6 billion in 1981 to just over $1 billion today. ''Without new investment, the company sees a gradual decline,'' Mr. Baker said. Venezuela, by contrast, has roughly a million barrels a day in idle production capacity that could be used to increase sharply the 1.6 million barrels that it currently exports each day, most of it to the United States.
The United States, then, would turn to Venezuela rather than to Mexico if its oil supplies from the Mideast were restricted, said Philip K. Verleger Jr., an oil analyst at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. The United States imports more than eight million barrels of oil daily, getting from Mexico only 600,000 barrels, or 7 percent of the total.
Most of the output is purchased by four oil companies: Royal Dutch/Shell, ARCO, Chevron and Exxon. The rest of Mexico's exports go principally to Japan, which buys 150,000 barrels a day, and to Spain and Israel, which buy smaller amounts.
Whoever buys its crude oil, Mexico is unlikely to realize any benefit from the sharply higher prices if Iraq withdraws from Kuwait in the next week or so and world oil prices subside to their June levels.
One reason is that Mexico would need at least 18 months before exploration could begin to raise production levels, Mr. Baker said. And, second, the contracts Mexico signs with foreign purchasers of its oil fail to recognize a short-lived price spike.
Mexico sells nearly all of its oil under contracts that specify a single price for the oil shipped abroad in a given month. The single monthly price is the average of the daily prices in that month. A price increase would have to be sustained for a week or two for the monthly average to rise significantly.
 
Range of Prices
The prices of Mexico's three types of crude - Isthmus, Olmeca and Maya - ranged in June from about $9.35 a barrel to $14.57 a barrel. Since then, each of the prices has risen by about $8 a barrel, with much of the increase coming last week.
The various benefits of a higher oil price begin to show up for Mexico after a month or so, oil experts and economists say. At an extra $8 a barrel, revenue would rise by nearly $10 million a day and $3.6 billion a year. That would greatly reduce Mexico's merchandise trade deficit, which DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting agency, estimates at $3 billion for this year. The extra money would also ease the burden of interest payments on Mexico's $80 billion in foreign debt. And Pemex, which accounts for about $15 billion of the foreign debt, might begin to invest in exploration and production.
''Mexico should plow all this money back into oil,'' said Christopher Whalen, an international trade analyst in Washington. He and others contend, however, that even with higher oil revenues to insure repayment, foreign banks are not likely to renew lending to Pemex.
 
Fear of Pemex Debt
''People are scared of Pemex debt,'' Mr. Baker said. ''All the money that Pemex earned during the oil boom years really went to the central Government as general revenue.''
Nevertheless, Mexico might have the largest untapped oil reserves of any nation outside the Middle East and the Soviet Union, according to an estimate by a petroleum engineer for the United States Geological Survey. The engineer, Bernardo Grossling, said there might be as much as 730 billion barrels of undiscovered crude oil in the Gulf of Campeche and in the jungles along the Mexico-Guatemala border. Proven Mexican reserves now stand at 68 billion barrels.
What's more, the cost of recovering crude oil in Mexico averages less than $10 a barrel, even though a big percentage of the production is from offshore wells. The low production cost, less than half the outlay in the United States, should make Mexico a prime target for exploration. But foreign companies express reluctance to invest in drilling, in large part because Pemex has declined to give these companies a percentage of the revenue from any oil they discover.

HEADLINE: The Price of Confronting Iraq in the Oil Market;
Japanese Joining In Embargo Despite Impact on Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Japan said last night that it would join its allies in halting all purchases of oil from Iraq and Kuwait, cutting off an eighth of the country's entire supply of oil.
The action, which followed a three-day debate about whether Japan might doom its economic growth, effectively leaves Iraq with no large customers for its oil among leading industrial nations.
Japan imports virtually all of its oil, and Government officials said last night that the embargo, if prolonged, might be far more damaging than the twin oil shocks that sent the country into an economic tailspin in the 1970's.
Indeed, investors in the Tokyo stock market greeted the news with a wave of selling today. The 225-share Nikkei index plunged 1,058.29 points, or 3.59 percent, 28,472.09, in early afternoon trading. [Page D7.] Grudging Agreement Over the weekend, even Japan's politically powerful industrial giants grudgingly agreed that there was little choice but to follow the lead of the United States and the European Community, which announced similar embargoes after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Thursday. 
On Friday, Japan announced that it was freezing Kuwaiti assets here, which are variously estimated at $14 billion to $25 billion, mostly in stocks.
But an embargo of oil is politically a far more delicate issue, especially in a country that measures virtually every move by how it could affect the national economy. Some large companies in Japan still observe the longstanding Arab boycott of Israel, largely because they treasure the access to Middle Eastern oil.
Last year Japan imported more than half a million barrels of oil every day from Iraq and Kuwait, which were the country's eighth- and ninth-largest suppliers of oil. The United Arab Emirates was Japan's biggest supplier, providing more than 20 percent of its oil, with Saudi Arabia producing 17 percent and Indonesia about 14 percent.
 
No Improvement Seen
''As time goes on we expect that this may have a considerable impact on the life of the Japanese people, and a heavier impact on Japan than on some other countries,'' Makoto Watanabe, a former ambassador to Jordan who heads the Middle East and African Affairs section of Japan's Foreign Ministry, said last night. ''But the situation on the ground in Kuwait is not improving.''
As part of its announcement, Japan said last night that it would also embargo exports to Iraq and Kuwait, including light and heavy machinery. Last year exports to the two countries combined amounted to more than $1.1 billion. Japan is also freezing economic cooperation with Iraq. Saddam Hussein's Government already owes about $5 billion to Japan.
Despite the Government's fears, experts say that Japanese industry is in far better shape than at any time in its postwar history to cope with markedly higher oil prices and reductions in supply.
Since the Arab oil boycott in the 1970's Japan has built up an extensive petroleum reserve, which officials say will last the country 142 days. But more important, Japan's domestic industries have improved energy efficiency in recent years more than in any other industrial nation.
According to Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., $1,000 in goods and services requires half the amount of energy to produce in Japan that it did in the late 1970's. Over the same period of time, the United States also improved the energy efficiency of its industry, but by not nearly the same pace.
 
Reliance on OPEC Reduced
Moreover, at a time that the United States has grown more dependent on oil from members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Japan has reduced its reliance on OPEC. According to the Petroleum Association of Japan, about 86 percent of Japan's crude oil imports came from OPEC in 1980, but last year the figure was down to about 70 percent. In that time China and Mexico have become important suppliers.
''Right now the supply and demand situation is no problem,'' said Shigeki Koyama, the president of the Institute of Middle Eastern Economies, a Tokyo research organization that keeps a close watch on energy matters. ''Initially, in fact, big price increases in oil would probably hurt America more than Japan. But over time there could be slow damage to Japan's economy, of an extent that nobody knows.''
That realization was visible here all weekend as the Government wrestled with the question of whether it was willing to risk angering one of its biggest oil suppliers in the name of solidarity with its allies.
 
No Commitments Made
The debate began in earnest early Saturday morning in Tokyo, when President Bush called Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and asked him to join in the embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. So far the embargo is the chief tool for stepping up pressure on Iraq to leave Kuwait. But Mr. Kaifu made no commitments, other than to say that Japan would act after the United Nations Security Council decided on an embargo or other sanctions.
Cutting short a vacation in the Japanese mountains, Mr. Kaifu spent much of the weekend in Tokyo, meeting with Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama, Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and the Minister of International Trade and Industry, Kabun Muto.
An official said Mr. Kaifu was given several projections of what might happen to the Japanese economy, which is currently growing at 7 percent annually, if oil prices rose and Japan barred deliveries from Iraq and Kuwait, which together provide 11 to 12 percent of the country's oil. Officials refused to release those projections publicly.
 
Memory of the 1970's
What may have led to their hesitations was the memory of the 1970's. The 1973 oil shock led to a 29 percent inflation rate, taxi driver strikes, toilet paper shortages and riots by Osaka housewives who were angry over shortages of kerosene. Public hostility increased when Japan's Petroleum Association and 12 companies were indicted for creating a cartel to raise prices at the pump.
Japanese officials cited the chaos caused by the last oil shocks to explain the Government's slowness in acting. ''In '73, the oil shock was only a reduction of 5 percent,'' said Yukio Okamato, the head of the American desk of the Foreign Ministry here, who has been deeply involved in the negotiations with the United States. ''Now we are talking about a reduction of 12 percent. That is something we have to take note of.''
But Mr. Okamoto said he sensed ''a healthy evolution of national consciousness'' about the need to stand with the allies. In addition, he said, ''in the ensuing 17 years, the economy has become much more resilient.''

Iraq and the Oil Market
 Iraq's new proxy government in Kuwait threatened foreign governments that impose sanctions to take hostages or nationalize property. International

[D2.] Brazil's Government is wrestling with violent strikes, a sharp recession and threats by foreign creditors.  The seven leading women's magazines are re-examining their roles as tastes change. In 1979, the seven had a combined circulation of 45 million. By last year it was 37 million and falling. [D1.] Higher postal rates are giving new life to efforts to build nationwide private delivery networks that will put magazines, catalogues and advertising circulars at people's doors. HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President of US West Named to Chief's Post

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
US West Inc., the Colorado-based telecommunications holding company, has named Richard D. McCormick as its chief executive to succeed Jack A. MacAllister.
Mr. McCormick, who is 50 years old, has been president and chief operating officer. He will now be president and chief executive, and will not be replaced as chief operating officer. 
Mr. MacAllister, 63, was named to head U S West shortly after the breakup of the Bell System was announced in 1982. He will continue as chairman.
''In the size company we have and the issues facing us,'' Mr. McCormick said on Friday, ''we both felt that we should signal the change early so that I can handle the future-oriented issues and he can handle the ones that can be resolved fairly quickly.''
With legislation in Washington, regulation, court rulings, new technologies and markets well beyond the geographic home base, running a regional telecommunications company takes a variety of management skills. ''It's a very complicated industry,'' Mr. McCormick said. He is proud of the company's expansion internationally. ''We've had some real successes in developing our international ventures,'' he said. The company has cable operations in Britain and cellular ventures in Czechoslovakia and Hungary among its international activities.
Mr. MacAllister and Mr. McCormick have had similar careers. Mr. MacAllister began his career with the Bell System in 1950 as an installer-repairman in Council Bluffs, Iowa. Mr. McCormick, a graduate of Iowa State University with an electrical engineering degree, first went to work as an engineer with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in Kansas City, Mo., in 1961, moving to Northwestern Bell in 1969.
He worked in North and South Dakota and Minnesota before being named president of Northwestern Bell in 1982, a job that Mr. MacAllister held before him. Mr. McCormick, a native of Fort Dodge, Iowa, joined U S West in 1985 as executive vice president.
Mr. MacAllister said he planned to spend more time with his family and work on two of his interests, educational excellence and finding employment opportunities for the economically disadvantaged.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Plunge Again As Mideast Tensions Grow

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Volume was extremely low at 170 million shares for the morning session, about half the level of an active half-day. The trading was so thin that 15 percent of the stocks on the exchange did not open for trading, analysts said.
The analysts and traders described the thin volume as an indication not of panic but of extreme nervousness, which was driving most investors to the sidelines. The dominant theme in the market was uncertainty. 
''It was not so much a drop as a markdown,'' said Robert Alan Feldman, an economist here with Salomon Brothers Inc., the American securities house. ''Nobody is willing to buy in this atmosphere.''
A senior trader at a Japanese brokerage added: ''I can tell you for sure, there are no buyers. There isn't heavy selling, just no bids. Period.''
The market experienced another setback when interest rates spurted upward, in reaction to concerns that higher oil prices might cause inflation in Japan and in other industrialized nations. The yield on the Government's 10-year bonds jumped to 8 percent this morning, up from 7.70 percent a week ago.
The markets were tumultuous in spite of economists' perceptions that Japan would be less affected by an embargo on imports of Iraqi and Kuwait oil than the United States or other large oil-importing countries. Japan is believed to get from 10 percent to 15 percent of its oil from the countries.
On other markets, the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong plunged by 162.33 points, to finish the morning session at 3,194.62, and stock prices also fell in New Zealand and Thailand.
 
ISRAELI ISSUES PLUNGE
TEL AVIV, Aug. 5 (Reuters) - The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait sent Israeli stock prices tumbling today to their biggest one-day drop in seven years. Prices of blue-chip issues plunged 7.57 percent on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. The index, the market's main barometer, dropped by 19.65 points, to close at 240.03. Traders said it was the biggest one-day decline since 1983. Share prices fell 3.63 percent on Thursday, the previous trading day. Trading volume was a record $36 million on Sunday, compared with an average of $23 million in July.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Recession and Inflation Fears Rise

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The credit markets are expected to be whipsawed again this week by the powerful prospects of recession and inflation.
Recession fears were heightened last week by increasingly negative economic indicators, which were topped Friday by the Government's report of a sharp rise in unemployment last month.
The inflation fears were unleashed by the surge in oil prices that followed Iraq's seizure of Kuwait. The two countries are among the biggest oil exporters. In New York, the price of the American benchmark crude oil, West Texas Intermediate, soared to $24.50 a barrel Friday, from $20 the week before and $17 a month ago. 
 
Fall in Rates and Yields
Short-term interest rates and yields fell sharply during the week as investors moved out of the deteriorating stock market and into Treasury securities. Also pushing down the returns on short-term securities was the growing belief that a steadily weakening economy would soon cause the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates in order to avoid a recession.
Because Treasury bills and short-term notes would be immediately affected by lower interest rates, demand for bills was strong. The discount rate on 90-day bills, for example, fell to 7.33 percent last Friday from 7.54 percent the week before, and the yield on two-year notes dropped to 7.79 percent from 8 percent.
But fears that the Iraqi invasion and a possible disruption of oil supplies would lead to a burst of inflation weighed heavily on longer-term Treasury securities and high-grade corporate bonds.
 
8.55 Percent for Long Bond
The yield on the Treasury's benchmark 30-year long bonds rose to 8.55 percent, from 8.47 percent a week before. The long bond's yield would have been higher, save for the widespead belief that the Federal Reserve will soon have to lower rates to head off a recession.
''The Mideast situation that erupted in midweek turned the bond market completely around,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''After bond investors had been lured into thinking that the prospect of a recession would diminish, their hopes were dashed by the new specter of oil-fueled inflation.''
Now, Mr. Sullivan added, bond investors have to worry about the effects of higher oil prices, the reduced chances of cutting military spending and the Federal budget deficit, as well as a recession that will reduce tax revenues on the Federal, state and local levels. ''The prospect of stagflagtion is not very promising to the bond market,'' he said.
 
Gloom on Economy
Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the giant Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo, was even gloomier about the economy but more optimistic about the possibility of a reduction in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
''The July employment data served to erase any lingering doubts in the Street that the economy has deteriorated to the point that the Fed must now take action to prevent a recession from developing in the fourth quarter and then spreading into 1991,'' he said on Friday. ''Indeed, we had expected the Fed to announce a move to cut interest rates before this day was out.''
What heightened concerns about a recession, Mr. Braverman continued, was not so much the drop of 219,000 nonfarm jobs last month, but the loss of 439,00 jobs as measured by a Government survey of households.
''If a person is on someone's payroll even a few hours a week, that person is considered employed,'' Mr. Braverman said. ''But the household survey of employment is considered a far better yardstick of this key economic indicator.''
 
Increase in Hourly Wages
To make the latest employment figures even more upsetting to credit market investors, the Government's report also noted that hourly wages rose six-tenths of 1 percent in July, up from the five-tenths increase the month before.
Approval at the end of last week by the House and the Senate of emergency legislation providing the Treasury Department with $72 billion in additional borrowing authority through Oct. 2 permits the Treasury to hold its mid-quarter refunding auctions this week. The Treasury will auction a record $32.25 billion of debt, consisting of $11.5 billion of three-year notes tomorrow, $10.5 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.
Maria Fiorini Ramirez, who heads a investment consulting company bearing her name, said on Friday that, ''had the Fed moved to reduce interest rates today, it would have helped the Treasury in its record refunding auctions next week because many investors would once again be rushing to lock in yields before they declined further.''
As it is, Mrs. Ramirez said, ''most countries that once exported capital now need it themselves, including the Japanese and Germans.''
''In fact, the Japanese may not be as enthusiastic about next week's refunding as they have been,'' she said. ''In any case, we expect good demand for the three-year notes, with somewhat less interest in the seven-year. As for the new 30-year long bond, it could be attractive with a 8 5/8 percent coupon. But looking at the rate structure, we do not expect long-term rates to come down in the foreseeable future.''

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Coming to a Doorknob Near You: a Bag of Ads.

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The prospect of sharp increases in most postal rates next year has breathed new life into the effort to create a nationwide private delivery network that would compete with the United States Postal Service in distributing magazines, catalogues and advertising circulars.
As a result, newspaper companies - which have usually concentrated on distributing papers - must soon decide whether they will try to expand into a much more elaborate business or risk having such rivals as bulk mailers set up such a system to deliver advertising in their markets.
''If newspapers aren't in it, I believe they will have their lunch eaten,'' said Patrick J. Tracy, the general manager of the Commonwealth Printing Company, a subsidiary of Landmark Communications Inc., which owns newspapers in Norfolk and Roanoke, Va., and in Greensboro, N.C.
 
Fierce Competition
The stakes for newspapers are high. They have long faced fierce competition from the mail delivery of advertising circulars, and a private delivery service, charging less than the Postal Service, would only add to it. And in the current weak advertising climate, many newspapers are seeking ways to broaden their business. 
Stan Henry, the chairman of Alternate Postal Delivery Inc., one of the fledgling private delivery operations, is going from city to city to extol his vision: a hugely profitable new venture that would deliver magazines, catalogues and circulars and become what United Parcel Service is to the delivery of packages or Federal Express is to overnight letters.
''I'm not creating a business; I'm creating an industry,'' Mr. Henry said, though he conceded that his new industry was just beginning, with only a few operations in such markets as Buffalo, Omaha and Milwaukee.
Another company, Publishers Express Inc., was formed last year by nine communications companies, including The New York Times Company and Time Warner Inc. It has been experimenting with alternative ways to deliver magazines and circulars in the Atlanta area.
Mr. Henry said he was trying to organize a national network of locally owned delivery operations in the 95 largest markets over the next three or four years. And because most newspapers already have detailed listings and demographic data regarding the households in their markets, he considers them obvious candidates for joining Alternate Delivery's network.
But Mr. Henry said he was also negotiating with local entrepreneurs, cable television systems, weekly papers and bulk mailers, who might have similar household listings.
Landmark is among the first newspaper companies to sign a contract to deliver magazines, catalogues and circulars as part of Alternate Postal Delivery's network, which is based in Grand Rapids, Mich.
Under the system, the network signs contracts with publishers like the Hearst Corporation and retailers like the J. C. Penney Company to deliver national magazines and catalogues in certain ZIP codes where it has affiliate delivery operations.
In those areas, subscribers receive copies of Better Homes & Gardens or Popular Mechanics or more than a dozen other magazines in a plastic bag hung on their doorknobs rather than in their mailboxes.
Included in the bag are such ''ride along'' materials as catalogues, circulars, samples and other promotional materials that Alternate Delivery sells or are sold by the local operator, like Landmark.
 
More Precise Target
Providers of ride-along materials pay a premium price to be delivered with the magazine because their advertising reaches a more precise target. For instance, a hardware store might want its circular delivered with Better Homes & Gardens.
The magazine, on the other hand, would be charged less than the Postal Service's rate. Frank R. Heselton, an assistant Postmaster General, said the cost of mailing a typical magazine weighing about a pound would be about 37.4 cents in 1991 if the proposed rate increases were approved, compared with 29.7 cents now.
Alternate Postal Delivery pays Landmark about 15 cents a household to deliver each magazine, Mr. Tracy said. He then sells additional advertising worth an average of 30 cents a household to go in each bag. His average cost for handling and delivery is 24 cents a bag, giving him an average profit of 21 cents a bag, he said.
 
Talks With Newspapers
Mr. Henry said he was talking to such papers as The Washington Post, The Sacramento Bee, The San Jose Mercury, and The San Francisco Examiner and The Chronicle.
In each city, Mr. Henry requires the local deliverer to set up an operation to serve only a few ZIP codes for six months. If that works to everyone's satisfaction, it is expanded.
While Alternate Postal Delivery is concentrating mainly on building the nationwide house-to-house delivery operation, Publishers Express is focusing on refining the way the delivery packages are assembled.
Howard Rosen, the president of the company, said that when Publishers Express expanded into other markets, it could offer more sophisticated services than Alternate Delivery.
 
Different Versions of Time
For instance, he said, there are typically six different versions of Time magazine delivered in the Atlanta area, each with slightly different advertising tailored to a particular area or even subscriber.
While Publishers Express can deliver a particular Time to a particular house, the Alternate Postal Delivery system cannot.
Though Mr. Rosen and Mr. Henry said there were no plans to merge their operations, several people in the industry said each company complemented the other because Publishers Express had the processing ability while Alternate Delivery was establising the market-by-market distribution techniques.

PUB-DATE: August 7, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1295 words

HEADLINE: SECURITY COUNCIL VOTES 13 TO 0 TO BLOCK TRADE WITH BAGHDAD; FACING BOYCOTT, IRAQ SLOWS OIL: THE IRAQI INVASION;
PULLOUT DEMANDED

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council today registered its outrage over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait by ordering a far-reaching trade and financial boycott on Iraq and occupied Kuwait.
The sanctions, approved just five days after the Council condemned the invasion and demanded that Baghdad immediately withdraw its forces, prohibit all United Nations members from buying oil from either Iraq or occupied Kuwait or having virtually any other commercial or financial dealings with them. [Text of the resolution, page A9.] The embargo won the support of 13 of the Council's 15 members, including all five of the permanent members, which have veto power in the Council - Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. Yemen, the only Arab member, and Cuba abstained.
 
Third Use of Trade Sanctions
This is only the third time in United Nations history that the Council has sought to discipline a country defying its orders by imposing trade sanctions. 
The earlier actions involved Rhodesia in 1967, after its declaration of independence from Britain, and a ban on arms sales to South Africa.
The vote was welcomed by many participants as a sign that the Security Council was emerging from a long period of cold war paralysis and starting to exercise its responsibility under the Charter for enforcing peace and security around the globe.
 
Council Action Praised
Britain's representative, Sir Crispin Tickell, said the Council had ''faced its responsibilities'' and must now ''succeed where the League of Nations failed and the Security Council itself had faltered in the past.''
The United Nations has only limited means of enforcing compliance with today's sanctions, leaving its members to insure that the measures are respected.
The Security Council has powers to ask member states to use military force to insure compliance, although this provision of the Charter has only been used once, in 1950 during the Korean War.
Otherwise, the only practical means of enforcement are political pressure.
But the United States and the 12 European Community nations have already announced severe economic sanctions against Iraq that would fulfill the intent of the United Nations resolution.
 
Rare Unity Impresses Kuwaiti
''In my nine years of experience, I have not seen a cause attract such whole-hearted support,'' said Mohammed Abulhasan, representing the exiled Kuwaiti Government, shaking his head in wonder.
Just before the vote, the United Nations representatives of the established Kuwaiti Government and Iraq clashed in a bitter war of words when they addressed the Council.
Gesticulating and poking at the air with a pencil as he spoke, Mr. Abulhasan accused Iraq of lying when it promised that its troops would start withdrawing on Sunday, saying it is ''increasing and consolidating its military presence on our sacred land.''
He called Iraq's plans to form a new Kuwaiti army ''a cover for the occupying forces already there.''
But he said the resolution the Security Council was about to approve represents a ''historic shift in the Council's work'' and means ''the international community is imposing its will on a country which had flouted all international principles, standards and norms.''
 
Decorum Is Not Forgotten
But even Mr. Abulhasan could not bring himself to ignore completely the parliamentary decorum and the expressions of fraternity that pervade most debate here.
''We have had good relations with them. We loved them. We still love them,'' he said of the Iraqis. ''They are only following their Government's policy. I am sure they feel shame for the situation Bagdad has put them in.''
Iraq's representative, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, insisted that his Government has started to pull out its troops. But the sanctions plan, he said, will ''exacerbate tensions in the Gulf and impede the troop withdrawal.''
He called the embargo ''null and void'' because it was the work of the United States and signified that Washington was trying to use the United Nations to achieve its ''hegemonic aims'' in the gulf area, ''as if the Security Council is simply its Foreign Ministry.''
Mr. Anbari finished his remarks with an appeal to the Security Council ''to annul this resolution.''
 
U.S. Sees Lesson for Iraq
The United States representative, Thomas R. Pickering, said the sanctions plan would show Iraq that ''its disregard for international law will have crippling political and economic costs, including but not limited to arms cutoffs.''
''Our concerted resolve,'' he said, ''will demonstrate that the international community does not and will not accept Baghdad's preference for the use of force, coercion and intimidation.''
The Soviet Union reiterated that it condemns the invasion of Kuwait and supports the sanctions resolution against Baghdad.
The resolution commits the Security Council to ''bring the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq to an end and to restore the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Kuwait.''
Invoking its authority under Chapter 7 of the Charter, which gives it coercive powers to deter aggression, the resolution must now prohibit ''any activities by their nationals or in their territories which could promote or are calculated to promote the export or transshipment of any commodities or products from Iraq or Kuwait.''
 
'Sale or Supply' Forbidden
It also forbids the ''sale or supply, by their nationals or from their territories or using their flag vessels, of any products or commodities, including weapons or any other military equipment, whether or not originating in their territories.''
All investment in Iraq and Kuwait is banned as well as all payments and monetary transfers to these countries. The only exceptions to the embargo are medical supplies, famine relief and payments intended for strictly humanitarian purposes.
The Council says United Nations members must not recognize the provisional government that Iraq is seeking to install in Kuwait and also requires them to protect the foreign financial and other assets of the established Kuwaiti government.
Finally, it asks the United Nations Secretary General to report regularly on compliance with the sanctions and establishes a special committee of the Security Council to monitor the working of the embargo.
 
Substitute for Military Action
Aside from Cuba and Yemen, the resolution was supported by the Council's 10 rotating members, including Canada, Finland and Romania, representing the industrialized northern countries, Ethiopia, Ivory Coast and Zaire from Africa, the single Asian member, Malaysia, and Colombia, which with Cuba forms the Latin American contingent.
Britain and Finland said that the embargo was a substitute for military intervention in the dispute and should not be seen as a prelude to it.
But Mr. Pickering, said that ''by this resolution we declare to Iraq that we will use the means available to us provided by Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter'' to obtain the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait.
Chapter 7 provides both for economic sanctions and, where these do not work, the use of force against countries that defy the Security Council's orders.
Several diplomats speculated that the United States or other major powers may decide to blockade the pipeline terminals in Turkey and Saudi Arabia, through which most of Iraq's oil reaches the outside world, as well as Kuwait's oil port on the Gulf.
Taking one measure of the sense of urgency in the Security Council was Gilberto Schlittler, director of the Political Committee's Division of the Security Council and a 26-year veteran at the United Nations. ''This,'' he said, ''is the first time we have skipped lunch - certainly in the past 15 years.''

HEADLINE: SECURITY COUNCIL VOTES 13 TO 0 TO BLOCK TRADE WITH BAGHDAD; FACING BOYCOTT, IRAQ SLOWS OIL: THE IRAQI INVASION;
BLOCKADE IS HINTED

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
American and British officials said today they would be prepared to organize an international naval blockade of Iraq to insure enforcement of economic sanctions imposed on the country by the United Nations.
Bush Administration officials emphasized, however, that for now they would far prefer to enforce the sanctions by persuading Turkey and Saudi Arabia to close the Iraqi pipelines that run across their territories.
Closing the pipelines, which carry about 90 percent of Iraq's crude oil to market, would deprive Baghdad of its main source of foreign income.
 
Only if Sanctions Fail
Only if nonmilitary initiatives fail, and Iraq succeeds in maintaining trade despite the United Nations sanctions, will the Administration and allies like Britain and France opt for a blockade, Administration officials said.
The officials said that Washington had not sounded out the Soviet Government on participating in a naval quarantine of Iraq, which officials said could be organized under United Nations auspices or directed by Americans. 
Turkey receives oil and derives substanial revenue from the Iraqi pipeline. To persuade the Turks to close it, the United States has asked the exiled Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, to guarantee that he will compensate Turkey for any economic reversals, the officials said.
The Emir still controls the estimated $100 billion in Kuwaiti investments abroad, and Bush Administration officials said he seemed receptive to their idea.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is to visit Turkey on Wednesday, complementing a visit to Riyadh today by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Mr. Cheney is seeking Saudi Arabia's help in choking the Iraqi economy a as well as permission to use Saudi airfields in the event that Washington resorts to military intervention.
Washington's deputy ambassador to Iraq, Joseph C. Wilson, was summoned today by President Saddam Hussein in the first known contact between the Iraqi leader and an American official since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday. A senior Administration official said that Mr. Hussein showed ''no inclination'' to back down or to pull out of Kuwait soon.
President Bush and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who was in Washington for consultations, called for strict enforcement of the United Nations boycott and said they were discussing a number of plans to make it work.
With Mrs. Thatcher and the NATO Secretary General, Manfred Worner, at his side, President Bush said at the White House: ''We need to discuss full and total implementation of these sanctions, ruling out nothing at all. These sanctions must be enforced. I think the will of the nations around the world -not just the NATO countries, not just the E.C., not just one area or another -the will of the nations around the world will be to enforce these sanctions.''
 
'Encouraging Others'
Mr. Bush added: ''We'll leave the details of how we implement it to the future, but we'll begin working on that immediately. That's how we go about encouraging others to do that and what we ourselves should be doing.''
Asked about the possibility of a naval blockade to reinforce the United Nations sanctions, Mrs. Thatcher said the first priority was to insure that the trade sanctions work. But if Britain, the United States and the world community conclude that a blockade is essential for compliance with the sanctions, ''you would have to consider'' such a move, she said.
She pointed out that Britain has one ship stationed in the Persian Gulf and that two more frigates, one from Mombassa, Kenya, and the other from Malaysia, are to arrive in the Gulf by the weekend. France has dispatched a warship to the Arabian Sea.
''Those sanctions must be enforceable,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ''I cannot remember a time when we had the world so strongly together against an action as now.''
 
Seeking a Broad Coalition
The Administration is seeking to assemble as broad a coalition as possible against Iraq, both to isolate Baghdad and to insure that efforts to restore Kuwait's independence will not turn into a symbolic duel between the United States and Mr. Hussein. Such a confrontation might prompt many Arab countries to lean toward the Iraqi President.
All of the diplomatic and military moves by the Administration are aimed at punishing Iraq and at sending a signal to the frightened Arab states that they will not be alone if they stand up to Baghdad, officials said.
Without the support of Arab countries, it would be hard to sustain any meaningful economic sanctions or to pose a credible military deterrent.
''What we are trying to do now,'' one senior Administration official said, ''is maintain a strong international consensus, while we position ourselves to deal militarily with a possible overt threat by Iraq to the Saudis.
''We have to make sure everyone stays in line to maximize the pressure on Saddam,'' he said.
Mr. Bush received a telephone call on Sunday from King Hussein of Jordan, shortly after the President castigated Arab leaders who have refused to condemn the Iraqi invasion. Among those leaders is King Hussein.
 
Disillusioned by Jordan
United States officials described the President as deeply disillusioned with the King, whom Mr. Bush once counted among his close friends. The President reminded King Hussein that Jordan had asked for time to work out an ''Arab solution'' to the Iraqi crisis, but that all that this time had produced was waffling by certain Arab states, the officials said.
Mr. Baker is to travel to Turkey on Wednesday in a bid to win Ankara's approval for cutting off the Iraqi pipeline running through its territory and to seek Turkish cooperation in any military action to enforce a blockade or deter further Iraqi aggression.
Officials said Mr. Baker would assure Ankara that the West would not let Turkey suffer economically from participating in the boycott of Iraq. Mr. Bush today asked Mr. Worner, the NATO Secretary General, to urgethat all of the NATO allies notify Turkey of their willingness to stand behind the country if it is attacked by Iraq.
An Administration official said the message to Mr. Worner was that ''very few things'' could pose a greater threat to NATO than the the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait or a potential Iraqi push into Saudi territory.
''NATO has to be prepared to play a military role either collectively or through individual states,'' the official said.
Mr. Baker spoke this morning for a half-hour by telephone with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Administration officials said Mr. Baker was seeking assurances that the Soviets would support the Security Council resolution to impose a total economic boycott on Baghdad.
Mr. Shevardnadze told Mr. Baker that Moscow would support the resolution, officials said, and the two men discussed the safety of their citizens in Kuwait and Iraq.
 
Soviet Frigate in Gulf
The Soviet Union also has a frigate in the gulf region, press reports from the area indicate. United States officials said they had not decided whether they would be prepared to go as far as engaging in a joint military initiative with Moscow to enforce sanctions against Iraq.
Administration officials said that Vice President Dan Quayle was rearranging his schedule so he could spend time pressing Argentina and Brazil to join the Soviet, Chinese and Western arms embargo of Baghdad.
Mr. Quayle is planning to ask Venezuela, an OPEC member, to increase its oil output to help overcome any shortages that might result from losses of Kuwaiti and Iraqi production.
Because of his trip to Turkey, Mr. Baker postponed a meeting he had scheduled for later this week with Foreign Minister David Levy of Israel. Although the postponement was a matter of scheduling, Administration officials said they were not particularly eager to see the Israeli Foreign Minister in Washington at a time when the United States is trying to line up support in the Arab world.

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
Oil Prices Increase Sharply Again; World Financial Markets Tumble

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil prices rose sharply again yesterday and financial markets around the world plummeted as the international embargo against oil from Iraq and Kuwait appeared to be taking hold.
From Tokyo to Frankfurt to New York, investors drove the prices of stocks and bonds down abruptly on fears that with oil even more costly than expected a few days ago and supplies cut back, higher inflation and lower economic growth are more likely worldwide.
In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average fell by 93.31 points, or 3.3 percent, to 2,716.34, its biggest one-day decline since Oct. 13, 1989. Most other industrial nations import a larger share of their oil than the United States, and the market declines were even more dramatic elsewhere.
 
Drops in Japan and Europe
The Tokyo market fell 3.5 percent yesterday and plunged 4.6 percent in the morning session today. But the Japanese stocks rebounded somewhat in the afternoon and were off 2.15 an hour before the market closed. Frankfurt was down 5.4 percent yesterday and Paris dropped 5.1 percent. 
Interest rates worldwide rose yesterday because higher energy prices would increase inflation. That sent bond prices falling.
Governments and central banks throughout the world are beginning to weigh the implications for economic policy of the recent oil price increases. In Washington, for example, it now seems uncertain whether the Bush Administration and Congress will push for a sizable reduction in the budget deficit this year. With the economy already weak and higher energy prices likely to slow growth even more, any large cutbacks in Federal spending would almost insure a recession, economists say.
The impact of the embargo by the United States and its allies became apparent yesterday when Iraq sharply cut the flow of oil through pipelines across Turkey to the Mediterranean, after tankers that had been waiting to be loaded left empty, complying with the sanctions against Baghdad.
With the embargo starting to pinch, oil traders bid up the price of available supplies. In London, Brent crude reached $26.80 for September delivery, up $3 since Friday, and in New York, West Texas Intermediate reached $28.05, up $3.56 from Friday. Those two crudes set the price for hundreds of transactions involving oil all over the world, and both figures are up 75 percent since mid-June.
''People are scrambling like hell to get crude,'' said George Babikian, president of the ARCO Products Company.
Most companies had larger-than-usual inventories of crude oil before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait because of overproduction by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, but in the face of rising prices, many buyers were apparently deciding that it was better to buy now, at high prices, than later, when prices might be even higher or oil might not be available.
''The move is to make sure you've got enough crude to keep your system wet,'' Mr. Babikian said.
Nauman Barakat, first vice president of futures at Shearson Lehman, said: ''This is amazing. The market is up by $2 or $3 every day.''
 
Energy Agency to Meet
While oil companies scrambled, the International Energy Agency, which is based in Paris, announced that its members would meet there on Thursday to discuss whether to begin sharing oil supplies. The 21 member nations have an agreement to share supplies when an expected supply disruption threatens to cause a 7 percent shortfall to any of the countries. But a spokesman, Lionel Walsh, said yesterday that ''we do not expect it to be triggered at the moment.''
Motorists, meanwhile, continue to see the price of gasoline they buy rise. An American Automobile Association survey of 1,400 gasoline stations found that the price of unleaded regular had risen to $1.18 a gallon as of Sunday, from $1.07 on Wednesday.
Reacting to concerns about rising gas prices, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, urged oil companies to forgo ''anticipatory'' rises for gas and other products. ''It is not clear that all of the increases that have been reported at the consumer level are necessary,'' he said.
 
'Runaway War Profiteering'
Representative Frank Annunzio, an Illinois Democrat who heads a House subcommittee on financial institutions, said that oil companies were engaged in ''runaway war profiteering,'' and Senator Richard Bryan, a Nevada Democrat, said ''the big oil companies have gone on a feeding frenzy. Even though America has ample oil supplies on hand, these giants have decided to take us to the cleaners.''
The Governor of Michigan, James L. Blanchard, called on the United States Attorney General to investigate the ''dramatic and highly questionable increases in gasoline prices.''
The Attorney General of Massachusetts, writing on behalf of his counterparts in Maine, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Vermont, sent a letter to the antitrust division of the Justice Department in Washington asking for an investigation to determine ''whether American consumers are being unnecessarily harmed by anticompetitive conduct.''
James F. Rill, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, said the Justice Department would ''look closely for any indication that these increases may be the result of anti-competitive activity.''
For their part, the oil companies said they were setting prices in accord with the levels established on the commodity exchanges. But more increases seemed certain, as the wholesale price of unleaded fuel rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange by 9.34 cents a gallon, or 12.9 percent, closing at 81.52 cents. Pump prices include state and Federal taxes and a retail markup.
 
Speculation on Saudi Curb
With Iraq's oil exports through Turkey almost stopped, oil analysts speculated that the flow through Saudi Arabia might be the next to be interrupted. The line across Saudi Arabia runs from Iraq's Rumaila oilfield, just north of Kuwait, to Yanbu, the Saudi port on the Red Sea. The pipeline was originally built to assure that the Iran-Iraq war would not interrupt Iraqi exports through the Persian Gulf.
Another impediment to Iraqi exports was the wariness of tanker owners to load Iraqi crude, for fear of turning their ships into a kind of unwanted ''garbage barge.''
''There is certainly the possibility that you'd have nowhere to put it, you'd have to keep the oil until somebody would accept it,'' said an executive of an American company that operates tankers between the United States and the Persian Gulf. He insisted that his company not be identified.
Even if the oil were loaded now for a destination country that today would accept the oil, the situation might change by the time the oil got there, experts said.
 
Other Constraints Cited
In Washington, Philip K. Verleger Jr., a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics and a commodity expert, cited other constraints. Before oil is loaded on a tanker, he said, the buyer must generally obtain a letter of credit from a bank, promising the producing country the value of the cargo, which can be $50 million. ''No bank in any of the countries embargoing Iraq or Kuwait will give a letter of credit; that's the whole Western world,'' he added. ''A Brazilian bank might do it, but then you can't clear the letter through New York.''
The price run-up comes as crude supplies are substantially larger than usual for this time of year. ''The psychology may be more alarming than the actual structure of the market,'' said Robin West, the president of the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington-based consulting firm, who was one of several experts to point out that oil inventories are still quite high.
''If the market structure is recognized for what it really is, you may see prices begin to moderate,'' he said.

PUB-DATE: August 7, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
Iraqis Shut Pipeline to Turkey After Ships Sail Away Empty

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Apparently already feeling the effects of an American-orchestrated boycott, Iraq sharply reduced the flow of oil today through twin pipelines that cross southern Turkey and normally transport more than half its oil exports.
Oil officials in Baghdad, citing ''marketing difficulties'' in a message to their Turkish counterparts, entirely shut down one of the side-by-side pipelinesand reduced by nearly a third the flow through the other.
The effect was to cut Iraq's overall daily export of 2.7 million barrels by at least 40 percent.
 
Tankers Sail Away Empty
The twin pipelines stretch about 820 miles from the Kirkuk oilfields in northern Iraq to offshore terminals near Yumurtalik, a Turkish port in the northeastern Mediterranean. The pipelines can pump as much as 1.8 million barrels a day, but they are said to have been operating at less than capacity. 
According to Turkish officials and Western diplomats, several foreign-flagged tankers that were supposed to take on oil in the last few days sailed away empty after the United States, the European Community and Japan imposed an embargo on Iraq. There was no elaboration on the identity of the tankers.
Storage tank capacity at Yumurtalik is limited, and Turkish officials said Iraq had ordered the pipeline flow to be cut when it learned that there was no room to store more oil.
''If you haven't any place to sell the oil, you might as well shut the pipeline,'' Joseph Story, an oil specialist who heads Gulf Consulting Services outside Washington, said in a telephone interview.
There were diplomatic reports, which could not be independently confirmed, that trucks that usually deliver oil into Turkey from northern Iraq did not cross the border today.
Besides using the pipelines across Turkey, Iraq also sends oil, the mainstay of its economy, through a pipeline across Saudi Arabia to the Red Sea. There was no word if that facility would be affected as well.
 
Turkey Caught in the Middle
The Iraqi action came on a fast-paced day in the Persian Gulf crisis in which Turkey's potentially central role as both an Iraqi and a Western ally came into clearer focus.
Underscoring that point was an announcement in Washington that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would visit Ankara on Thursday for consultations with the Turkish leaders.
As part of the United States campaign for a full economic boycott of Iraq, which includes a possible shutdown of its oil pipelines across foreign territory, President Bush has telephoned President Turgut Ozal of Turkey three times since Friday.
The decision to send Mr. Baker here portended a new dimension to the American strategy, but it was not clear whether it meant new political or possibly even military components.
 
A Military Staging Area
If the United States is indeed laying the groundwork for military action against Iraq, its bases in Turkey, which is a member of NATO, would be logical staging areas for aircraft and troops.
But Turkish officials make clear that it would not be easy to persuade them to join a military operation against Iraq.
As it is, they have proceeded with extreme caution in deciding whether to join the West in economic sanctions out of concern about upsetting their unpredictable and dangerous neighbor, which supplies about half of Turkey's oil imports.
Some Turkish commentators have expressed irritation with the United States and the countries of Western Europe, which they accuse of repeatedly ignoring and slighting Turkey except when its help is needed.
''Our Western allies have basically always wanted the same thing from us - to protect their welfare, not ours,'' Gunes, a conservative daily, said in a commentary over the weekend.
 
'A Modern Adolf Hitler'
Turkey has joined the global condemnations of the invasion of Kuwait ordered by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and insists on a complete troop withdrawal. ''Obviously, we are faced with a modern Adolf Hitler,'' said a senior official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ''He's a madman, and we hope he will not be around after this episode.''
But the Turks were waiting for the United Nations Security Council to order sanctions before taking any measures of their own.
''You will not find us in the forefront,'' the senior official acknowledged, adding, as did others, that even if Turkey agreed on joining an economic blockade it would insist on assurances of help from to replace the Iraqi oil that is stands to lose.
So to some degree, Iraq's announcement that it was cutting the flow of oil across Turkey came as a relief to officials here. It eased pressure they were feeling from Washington to shut the facilities themselves, and it still left enough oil flowing for now to avoid an immediate economic crisis.
On Sunday, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Taha Yassin Ramadan, said during a visit here that he thought Turkey would remain neutral in the crisis. But Turks insisted today that their caution did not imply neutrality, and they again denounced the invasion.
Mr. Ramadan, who went to a meeting with Mr. Ozal dressed in a fatigue uniform with a pistol on his hip, cautioned later that a Turkish decision to close the pipelines ''would create mistrust'' between the countries.
