HEADLINE: Bhutto Is Dismissed in Pakistan After 20 Months

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto was dismissed today by the President of Pakistan, who accused her administration of corruption, nepotism and other acts ''in contravention of the Constitution and the law.''
A caretaker Government led by Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, a former member of Ms. Bhutto's party who had gone over to the parliamentary opposition, was sworn into office.
Hours later President Ghulam Ishaq Khan declared a state of emergency, citing a ''threat to the security of Pakistan by external aggression and internal disturbances.'' The emergency declaration gives him the power to make laws and to suspend civilian courts and individual rights.
Earlier, in a somber news conference in the room in the Presidential Palace where Ms. Bhutto took the oath of office as Prime Minister in a glittering ceremony 20 months ago, President Ishaq Khan said that the National Assembly, Pakistan's Parliament, ''had lost the confidence of the people.'' 
He said new elections would be held on Oct. 24. The Pakistani Constitution empowers the President to name and dismiss governments at his sole discretion if in his judgment the Government is unable to carry out its duties.
But Ms. Bhutto, the first woman to head a modern Islamic state, called the action ''illegal and unconstitutional.'' At a news conference tonight, she asserted that her opponents were trying to keep her from winning the next election, but that she believed she had the popular support to return to power.
She said her Pakistan Peoples Party may challenge the President in court, although the grounds for such a challenge were not specified.
''I don't feel betrayed by the President,'' she said. ''I believe there were other elements that wanted me out.''
Pakistan's top military officers were present at the swearing-in of the caretaker Government. Pakistanis assume that the ouster of Ms. Bhutto could not have taken place without the army's support, if not instigation. But Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, the army commander, said before the ceremony that the military had not been involved in politics recently and would remain out of government in the future.
Before Mrs. Bhutto won an election in 1988, Pakistan had been ruled by military governments for 25 of the 41 years since it became independent in 1947.
Among the uncertainties resulting from the surprise announcement today was the possibility of an eruption in Sind Province, Ms. Bhutto's home territory. Whether Sindhis loyal to her family will accept her ouster seems to hinge on how willing they are to give another government the opportunity to deal with the violence that has racked the province in recent years.
 
Questions on Policies
Mr. Jatoi, the new Prime Minister, is also a Sindhi, but he lost his seat in the province in the 1988 election. He later picked up a seat in neighboring Punjab province and took his place in the National Assembly under the banner of his small National Peoples Party, which he formed after breaking with Ms. Bhutto in 1986.
The dismissal of the Bhutto Government also raises a host of questions about Pakistan's policies on the civil strife in neighboring Afghanistan and in Kashmir, on which talks with India were due to be resumed this week. The President's action also means that Pakistan can avoid or at least postpone a divisive and potentially violent debate on the Islamization of the country's legal, educational and broadcasting systems. A bill supported by Muslim conservatives was scheduled to be introduced in Parliament this week.
Asked this evening after his swearing-in what his first priorities would be, Prime Minister Jatoi said only, ''Safeguarding the national interests.''
 
Focus on a Father-in-Law
In leveling corruption charges, the President alluded to numerous officials in Ms. Bhutto's circle, and especially to her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, and his father, Hakim Ali Zardari. Reports in the Pakistani press have said he has made a fortune on property deals while holding a high Government position.
A leading political commentator, Ghani Eirabie, said in an interview tonight that her father-in-law had long been regarded as a ''crook,'' and that Mrs. Bhutto's gravest mistake may have been agreeing to an arranged marriage with the wrong family.
Other accusations leveled by the President involve Ms. Bhutto's management of the national Government. The President said she had been involved in the paying of illegal ''inducements'' to buy parliamentary or other political support. He said she had ridiculed the national judiciary and the Senate and had ''wilfully undermined and impaired'' the workings of provincial governments.
 
Violence Cited
Mr. Ishaq Khan also held Mrs. Bhutto responsible for failing to protect Pakistanis from ''rural and urban violence'' and for allowing Sind province to sink into near civil war between families that trace their roots in the province for many generations, and those who arrived as, or are descended from, Muslims who immigrated to Pakistan with the partition of British India in 1947.
Unlike the practice in other democracies, Ms. Bhutto was dismissed without the benefit of an impartial inquiry or the right to fight a no-confidence motion in the national Parliament.
Ms. Bhutto, whose Pakistan Peoples Party took office in December 1988, enjoyed huge popular support and sympathy at the beginning. But she disappointed many of her early supporters.
Her rise to power at the age of 35 had been swift. The elections that swept her to office took place three months after the death in a plane crash of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who had led a military Government in Pakistan for eight years and who dominated a non-partisan but elected Parliament for the last two years of his life.
 
A Personal Crusade
The election of November 1988 was a personal crusade for Ms. Bhutto. General Zia had overthrown her father, Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, in 1977 after political violence against Mr. Bhutto's autocratic populist regime paralyzed the country. Two years later, President Zia refused to pardon Mr. Bhutto after he was convicted of complicity in a political murder.
Ms. Bhutto's father was hanged in 1979, despite pleas for clemency from world leaders. Years of house arrest, then exile, followed for her and her mother, Nusrat Bhutto.
One of Mrs. Bhutto's brothers, Mir Murtaza, fled to Kabul, where he formed a guerrilla organization to avenge his father's death, and was involved in a number of violent acts in Pakistan. He remains under criminal indictment here and has not been able to return to Pakistan, even since his sister became Prime Minister.
Ms. Bhutto, whom General Zia allowed to return to Pakistan in 1986, quickly took charge of the opposition to military rule, but alienated several older leaders of her father's party.
Her critics repeatedly note that she never held a job or political office before becoming Prime Minister of South Asia's second-largest nation. They say her lack of experience was a handicap not only in her political dealings but in making policy decisions involving the war in neighboring Afghanistan and the grave economic problems at home.
Ms. Bhutto, who had promised an era of improved civil and human rights after 11 years of military-dominated government, was unable to organize an efficient government or manage her party in Parliament. No major legislative programs were introduced.
Islamic ordinances demeaning to women were not repealed, nor were laws against child labor. Ms. Bhutto began to lose liberal support, but even critics argued to the end that almost any alternative to her would be worse.
Ms. Bhutto also squandered much of her initial energy in attempting to burnish her father's image despite many Pakistanis' qualms about his record, rather than building on her own substantial following and making a name for herself outside his shadow. She also spent a great deal of time in her early months attempting to dislodge an opposition-led Government in Pakistan's most prosperous and populous province, Punjab, led by Chief Minister Nawaz Sharif, who became her most outspoken rival.
 
U.S. Reaction to Ouster
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) - The State Department said today it regards Prime Minister Bhutto's dismissal from office as an internal matter, but Democrats in Congress called for sanctions against Pakistan.
''A constitutional change in government is an internal matter for the people in Pakistan to decide,'' said a State Department spokeswoman, Nancy Beck.
Two of the Democrats issuing statements, Senator Barbara Mikulski of Maryland, and Representative Robert Torricelli of New Jersey, urged the suspension of all economic and military aid to Pakistan under the law applying to the ouster of any democratically elected government by military coup or decree.

HEADLINE: Plan to Burn Dioxin Stirs Fear in Arkansas

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Ark.

 BODY:
Unless a small, determined band of residents have their way, this city of 29,000 people is about to become the site of the nation's largest incineration of dioxin.
Starting in mid-August, a state contractor plans to burn 28,500 barrels of toxic waste at an abandoned pesticide plant in the middle of a residential neighborhood where subdivisions run to the edge of the chain-link fence. The burning will go on 24 hours a day, seven days a week, for 7 to 10 months, until all the barrels are gone.
 
Health Effects in Dispute
Most of the barrels are full of chemicals like DDT, aldrin and dieldrin, wastes from more than three decades' production of pesticides and herbicides. About 2,800 contain dioxin, whose effects on human health are debated but whose toxicity is widely acknowledged: The town of Times Beach, Mo., was evacuated and abandoned after it was discovered that dioxin in waste oil had been sprayed on the streets. 
Opponents, saying Jacksonville's pesticide industry is responsible for a rash of cancers, stillbirths and miscarriages among residents, fear that the burning could release deadly chemicals and sow still more illness. But state and Federal health officials say they have found no evidence of illness that could be linked to the toxic waste. And the Environmental Protection Agency says the incinerator will reach such high temperatures - 2,200 degrees Fahrenheit - that it will destroy all but infinitesimal traces of the chemicals.
Nevertheless, what happens here will have an effect on how hundreds of other cities and towns deal with their highly toxic waste sites. ''There is a rush to burn all over the country now,'' said Hugh B. Kaufman, assistant to the director of the Hazardous Site Control Division at the United States Environmental Protection Agency. ''If the Jacksonville burn occurs, it's going to give more impetus to burning toxic waste on sites in populated areas, which is going to save the responsible parties a lot of money.''
 
'Go Get 'Em'
The last pesticide manufacturer in Jacksonville, the Vertac Chemical Corporation, stopped production in the early 1980's and closed for good in 1987. But on humid days here, the smell of pesticide still lingers in the air. The opponents of the incinerator, a few dozen fiercely committed residents who have the backing of Greenpeace and other national environmental groups, say the cancers, stillbirths and other health problems that have ravaged their families can be traced directly to the toxins produced and stored by Vertac and its predecessors, including the defoliant Agent Orange.
''Just before my mother died at 55 with a rare liver cancer, she said to me, 'How come everybody around this town dies early?' '' said Patty Frase, who herself had four miscarriages before moving away. ''She told me, 'Go get 'em.' And I am.''
Although incineration of toxic waste still stirs considerable scientific debate, the temporary incinerator in Jacksonville is one of the first in a wave of such projects. In the last two years alone, the Government has authorized the use of 60 temporary incinerators at toxic waste sites, said Paul Nadeau, acting director of E.P.A.'s Hazardous Site Control Division. These temporary incinerators, like the one in Jacksonville, are designed to be removed after the waste has been burned. Only a few of the 60 incinerators have been built so far.
The agency permits the use of these incinerators at the nation's 1,219 worst hazardous waste sites catalogued on the Superfund National Priorities List. About 400 municipalities are on the list; Jacksonville alone has three Superfund sites - the chemical plant and two city-owned landfills.
Aside from the temporary incinerators, waste disposal companies have proposed building permanent toxic waste incinerators in 25 cities, including Kansas City, Mo.; Memphis; Houston; Las Vegas, Nev.; Linden, N.J., and Model City, north of Niagara Falls, N.Y. These commercial incinerators would burn 750,000 tons of toxic waste a year, about double the capacity of existing commercial incinerators that burn toxic waste.
But Mr. Kaufman of the E.P.A.'s Hazardous Site Control Division, a frequent internal critic of the agency, said that if the Jacksonville plan was stopped, it would send a signal to the rest of the country ''that this is an unacceptable way of handling the problem.''
Opponents of the Jacksonville incinerator say the drums of waste should be stored in concrete bunkers while new disposal technologies are developed. They plan to file lawsuits to stop the incinerator as soon as it starts burning toxic waste. They demand an environmental impact study of the incinerator's effect on the community, buy-outs of several hundred homes that border the plant and other toxic waste sites in Jacksonville, and a comprehensive health survey of people living near the sites.
 
E.P.A. Insists It's Safe
The E.P.A. replies that incineration is safe and is the only legal way of disposing of dioxin. ''We are satisfied we have the technology to do the job,'' said Carl E. Edlund, chief of agency's Superfund Program for the Southern region. ''The E.P.A. has had ongoing investigations into incineration technology since the 70's. We have a high degree of confidence in it.''
But Mr. Kaufman said the agency's public pronouncements on incineration did not reflect the its internal concerns. Citing an April 1985 report by an E.P.A. scientific advisory board that was highly critical of incinerator safety regulations, Mr. Kaufman said there was no technology available, then or now, to keep constant track of the emissions from an incinerator's stack. Instead, incinerator performance is projected, based on initial test burns and the incinerator's general operating conditions.
As a result, incinerators may be just converting one hazardous substance into another, the panel said. ''By E.P.A.'s own admission,'' Mr. Kaufman said, ''its regulations on incinerators are lacking and don't do the job of protecting the environment and public health.''
Dioxin has been burned at two other sites in the United States, Gulfport, Miss., and Denny Farms, Mo., without apparent incident. But the quantities were small, and opponents say they give no indication of the scale of the incineration planned for Jacksonville.
 
The Dioxin Puzzle
The chemical is itself a mystery. In laboratory animals it causes cancer, birth defects and developmental defects, and it reduces immunity to a variety of diseases.
But there has been no documentation of these effects on people, even though dioxin has long been a focus of scientific and environmental inquiry - at the center, for example, of the long-running dispute over the possible effects of Agent Orange, the defoliant used in Vietnam. The only ailment dioxin is known to cause in humans is chloracne, a skin disease. The largest dioxin release in history, in an accident at a chemical plant in Seveso, Italy, in 1976, resulted in no deaths or permanent injuries.
Dr. Vernon N. Houk, an assistant surgeon general and director of the Center for Environmental Health and Injury Control at the Federal Centers for Disease Control, says a growing body of information indicates that people are not as susceptible to dioxin as animals.
 
Outrage Over an Article
Jacksonville is a highly transient community, dominated by the Little Rock Air Force Base, which contributes a third of the city's 29,000 population and most of the economic base.
In April, when Family Circle magazine named Jacksonville as one of 17 cities and towns that might be ''at risk from contamination,'' local leaders were outraged. ''The editors of Family Circle have been in the kitchen too long,'' Garrick Feldman, editor of The Sunday Leader, wrote in a front-page column, and the City Council passed a resolution of censure. The magazine responded in August with an article that focused on Jacksonville, titled ''Toxic Nightmare on Main Street.''
Officials here still support the incineration plan. ''People all over the state want a health study every time they find a dump or chemical plant in their neighborhood,'' said Dr. Thomas C. McChesney, a Jacksonville veterinarian who is the state's chief epidemiologist. He said none of public health statistics for Jacksonville were unusual. ''You can do the study for political reasons, but not for scientific reasons.''
Mayor Tommy Swaim said, ''I haven't asked for a health study, but I would not oppose one.''
But the opponents say their own medical histories are reason enough for a health study. ''I've been to too many hospitals, I've been to too many funerals and I've seen too much to think there isn't mass murder going on here,'' said Mozelle Bergschneider of People Against a Chemically Contaminated Environment, the local anti-incinerator group.
The opponents say they have a hard time getting officials to take any of their concerns seriously. Ms. Frase, the former Jacksonville resident who is a co-founder of the Environmental Congress of Arkansas, said she had ''begged and pleaded with the city to put up fences and warning signs'' at contaminated sites in public areas of Jacksonville; the signs she puts up, she added, are routinely removed. For example, dioxin has been found in the fish and sediment of Lake Dupree, a pond next to a baseball diamond in the city's Dupree Park. A sign near the lake says, ''Unauthorized persons keep out,'' and another has a no-fishing symbol.
Asked why the city does not put up fences or use more descriptive warnings, Mayor Swaim replied: ''If you put fences up, people would just climb over them. But if it makes people happy, I would put up a no-swimming sign.''

PUB-DATE: August 7, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 695 words

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
U.S. ACTS TO RAISE MIDEAST STRENGTH

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
The United States moved today to increase its naval forces in the Middle East for a possible blockade to enforce the United Nations trade sanctions against Iraq, and other Western officials indicated that they were prepared to join in such an action if it was necessary.
An American aircraft carrier battle group is scheduled to sail on Tuesday to join two others already in the region. The group's carrier, the Saratoga, will be accompanied by 2,100 Marines and the battleship Wisconsin, which is armed with cruise missiles.
Western European nations, meanwhile, have moved to increase their naval presence in the region. 
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said after meeting with President Bush today that Britain would consider taking part in a blockade if it was needed to enforce the U.N. sanctions.
Mrs. Thatcher said that Britain has one ship in the Persian Gulf and that two additional vessels would reach the gulf by Sunday. The two additional British frigates are steaming to the Gulf from South Africa and Malaysia.
 
France Increases Role
France is also increasing its naval presence in the gulf by sending a destroyer to join two frigates in the region. The French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, has said that Paris is ready to join in a blockade if it becomes necessary.
The United States already has eight ships in the Persian Gulf, not counting the three aircraft carrier battle groups being sent to the area.
The carrier Independence and six accompanying vessels are taking up position in the northern Arabian Sea, within striking range of Iraq. The carrier Eisenhower and six additional vessels are already deployed in the Eastern Mediterranean.
The Saratoga battle group is scheduled to leave Florida on Tuesday and will reach the Mediterranean in about 10 days. The Saratoga, the Wisconsin, and an accompanying force of Marines has been previously scheduled to leave this week to relieve the Eisenhower group. But with the crisis in the Gulf, those forces are unlikely to be withdrawn on schedule.
Pentagon officials said a group of F-111 fighter bombers, normally based in England, were in Turkey today participating in a previously scheduled NATO exercise. Although the aircraft, which were once used to bomb targets in Libya, were within striking distance of Iraq and Kuwait, Pentagon officials insisted their presence was coincidental and that they were not planned for use in any Middle East operation.
Naval analysts said that the blockade could be established in waters around three ports that ship Iraqi or Kuwaiti oil: Kuwait; Yanbu, Saudi Arabia, a Red Sea port, and Yumurtalik, near Ceyhan, Turkey, in the Eastern Mediterranean.
 
Checkpoints Established
Shipping companies, made aware of the sanctions, would be cleared through checkpoints established at the Strait of Hormuz, at the mouth of the Persian Gulf; in the Red Sea and at the Suez Canal and outside Turkish waters.
Oil tankers bound for terminal points of the Iraqi pipelines would be turned away. Other ships would be allowed to pass. Reconnaissance aircraft would insure that tankers traveled to their stated destination.
Shipping officials said that with the backing of the United States Navy, oil tanker owners would have little choice but to respect a United Nations-sanctioned blockade.
Some analysts believed it might never be necessary to brandish American military might. Ship owners and insurers would not risk coverage for ships that carried Iraqi or Kuwaiti oil, out of fear of having their assets seized, analysts said.
American intelligence reports suggest that Iraq may have acquired French-made Exocet anti-ship missiles from Kuwaiti arsenals. Exocet missiles were used by Argentina against British ships during the Falklands war.
But military analysts discounted the risk of Iraqi retaliation. The Iraqi Navy is puny, and would pose virtually no threat to the sizable American carrier groups.
Turkey and the Red Sea are ''not within the range'' of the more formidable Iraqi Air Force, according to Thomas McNaugher, a military specialist at the Brookings Institution here. ''The biggest need would be air screen in the Persian Gulf.''

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion: Reporter's Notebook;
The Guns of August Make a Dervish Bush Whirl Even Faster

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Maybe George Bush really believed that the world was becoming kinder and gentler.
Maybe, with his faith in personal diplomacy, he thought that his friendship with King Hussein of Jordan and his Administration's defense of President Saddam Hussein when Congress wanted to apply economic sanctions against the Iraqi Government in June, would be returned with some measure of loyalty. Or perhaps he forgot that August in Washington has a way of starting out in coma and ending up in crisis.
Whatever the reason, the President is facing his first post-cold war crisis in a mood that White House officials describe variously as mad, testy, peevish and, to use a favorite bit of Bush-speak, spleen-venting.
''This is one more piece of bad luck, bad timing,'' a senior White House official said. ''Things go your way for a while and then they start to go against you.'' With a sigh, he added, ''At least Congress is out of town.'' 
Just when Bush Administration officials were feeling so cocky that they thought they might just go for 100 percent in the public approval polls, the center could not hold.
The budget talks collapsed. The economy slowed. Because he had spent so much time courting Democrats and because he dropped his no-new-taxes pledge, the President has been hamstrung stumping for Republicans on the campaign trail. Even Millie, the First Dog, got sick after walking in some paint solvent outside the White House and then licking her paws.
And now, on top of all that, comes a melee in the Middle East, the diplomatic Bermuda Triangle for American Presidents. Suddenly, on the eve of his three-and-a-half week Kennebunkport vacation, the Administration is plunged into worries about military options, rising gas prices, dropping oil supplies and tricky Middle Eastern tribal politics.
Mr. Bush, who is usually circumspect and full of ambiguous diplomatic euphemisms, was visibly furious when he got off his helicopter on the White House lawn on Sunday afternoon, calling the Iraqis liars and snapping at reporters that they should ''watch and learn'' if they wanted to know his plans.
When Mr. Bush is annoyed, he does not sit and stew. He does not stay alone in the White House residence and listen to records and sip cocktails, as Richard M. Nixon liked to do, and he does not simply snooze through the chaos, as President Ronald Reagan did in August 1981, when he slept peacefully as Libyan MIG's and American F-14's clashed over the Mediterranean.
Mr. Bush, by contrast, becomes even more of a dervish.
He has dialed a dozen world leaders, had cascading meetings with his tight circle of foreign affairs advisers, and kept a revolving door going for the allies and other officials that the Administration is trying to enlist in the effort to isolate Iraq.
The President met this afternoon with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, his second talk with her in four days. In the middle of that meeting, Manfred Worner, the Secretary General of NATO, turned up breathless and joined their brief news conference. After more meetings and phone calls, the President dashed off to dinner at the White House with his confidant, Brian Mulroney, the Canadian Prime Minister.
 
On the Road With Bush
In the nooks and crannies of the crisis today, Mr. Bush sandwiched in an awards ceremony for the National Civic League's Cities Award Presentation, sat for a half-hour interview with a Sports Illustrated reporter, conferred with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, about a coup in Pakistan and put the finishing touches on a rescue mission by the Marines in Liberia. He also made a spur-of-the-moment visit to the hospital bedside of Lee Atwater, the ailing Republican Party chairman.
To cap the day, Mr. Bush's office released the President's headlong travel schedule for September: 13 events in 9 days on the road, including 10 fund-raisers in 6 cities from Tallahassee to San Francisco, a speech to the United Nations General Assembly, a U.N. children's event, and a dedication ceremony at Ellis Island in New York Harbor.
''Iraq is dominating the agenda but it's not replacing everything else,'' said one fatigued Presidential aide. ''This President is capable of doing eight things at a time.'' Under the circumstances, eight seemed a bit of an understatement.
 
The Law of Gravity
Official Washington's vacation schedules operate by Copernican rules: Everything revolves around the Boss.
So for months, everyone had been planning their vacations according to when President Bush was going to be out of town. Because Mr. Bush planned to spend most of August in Maine, his top advisers also planned holidays for the same time. And the aides to the top advisers to the President did the same, and the secretaries to the aides to the top advisers to the President followed suit.
So when war broke out in the Middle East, all the President's satellites were drawn to Washington by the gravity of the crisis.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was supposed to leave on vacation this Friday, as were his top aides, Margaret Tutwiler and Dennis Ross. Now all three are planning to leave for Ankara, Turkey, on Wednesday, where Mr. Baker will try to persuade the Turkish President to cut off the Iraqi oil pipeline that runs through his country.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had to postpone his holiday to stay at the Pentagon. Paul Wolfowitz, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, also switched his travel plans to head for Saudi Arabia to try to persuade the Saudis to cut off their pipeline from Iraq.
Reporters and officials in Washington, disappointed about their canceled vacations, used gallows humor to get through the day, asking each other ''How's your vacation going,'' and trading the capital's latest joke: What's the hottest movie in Kuwait this summer? Iraqnaphobia.
 
Scowcroft to the Fore
As national security adviser, Mr. Scowcroft has been both closer to the President and less dominant than many of his predecessors. He has often said that he deliberately takes a back seat to Mr. Baker, but this time it seemed that Mr. Scowcroft was calling the shots.
The retiring and retired Air Force general, who never seems to go home, was at home when the invasion began Wednesday night. Like other senior officials, he was caught by surprise. It is still not clear whether the problem was faulty intelligence or wishful thinking. He quickly returned to the White House, where he took up position in the situation room as the crisis developed and awakened the President at 5 A.M. Thursday, so that Mr. Bush could sign executive orders on sanctions against Iraq and freezing of Kuwaiti assets.
He has continued to take an uncommonly high profile role, setting up the President's schedules, staying at Mr. Bush's side as he met with allies, receiving foreign officials himself at the White House, writing inserts on the Middle East crisis for the President's speeches, helping set up talking points for phone calls to world leaders. Mr. Baker, meanwhile, has been less visible than usual, partly because he's been traveling.
Each international crisis also puts the spotlight on a different member of the scrupulously faceless staff members of the National Security Council. This time it is Richard N. Haass, the council's director for Near East and South Asian Affairs, who was the aide who rushed out onto the White House lawn on Sunday afternoon and thrust a secret memo into Mr. Bush's hand that seemed to spark the President's irritation at his news conference.
Mr. Haass, 39, is running the interagency group of ''grunt workers,'' as they call themselves, from the Departments of State, Justice, Defense, Treasury and the Central Intelligence Agency who toil below the top level of advisers.
''He seems pretty happy about it,'' an Administration official said of Mr. Haass's Andy Warhol moments of fame. ''After all, he's getting a lot of face time on national television.''
It is superior to Mr. Haass's last star turn, when he had second billing at a Washington book party for his tome ''Conflicts Unending,'' along with the authors of ''Command, Control, and the Common Defense,'' ''The National Security Constitution,'' and ''Allies in Crisis.''

The writer was William K. Stevens.

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
Hundreds of Westerners Rounded Up in Kuwait

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Iraqi soldiers rounded up hundreds of Westerners, including at least 28 American citizens, from hotels in Kuwait. It was not known what Iraq planned to do with them.
A defiant Iraq, meanwhile, staged air raid evacuation drills in Baghdad and other cities today and distributed tens of thousands of rifles to loyalists of the governing Baath Party in a display of readiness to resist any American military attack.
Iraqi occupation troops in Kuwait went through the luxury hotels that cater to foreign business people, rounding up American, British, German and other citizens of Western nations. Reports indicated that they were to be taken to Baghdad, but it was not clear for what purpose. The Iraqis had already moved 34 British soldiers, who had been training the Kuwaiti Army, to a hotel in Baghdad. 
 
Foreigners Outnumber Nationals
Flights from Kuwait have been suspended since the Iraqi invasion last week, and the Baghdad airport is also closed.
There are more than a million foreigners, including about 3,800 Americans, in Kuwait. These foreign residents make up roughly 60 percent of the population of Kuwait and hold most of the jobs in Kuwait. But many may have been away at the time of the invasion because August is traditionally a vacation period.
Americans, other Westerners and Japanese, work mostly in the oil industry and technical fields, Palestinians and Egyptians in the Government, in medicine and in schools, and Pakistanis, Sri Lankans and others from the Indian subcontinent in service and menial jobs. [A spokesman for American Telephone and Telegraph, Walter G. Murphy, said today that the company had been advised that one of its American employees had been taken into custody by Iraqi troops at a Kuwait hotel, but that about two dozen other A.T.&T. employees at another location had not been detained. Mr. Murphy declined to identify the employee who was detained.] 'This Is Unacceptable'
Kuwait's new provisional government, which is said to consist of Iraqi Army officers, threatened yesterday that it might respond to economic sanctions or military action by taking foreigners in Kuwait hostage or nationalizing foreign interests, saying it could not be expected ''to act honorably at a time when they are conspiring against us and other brothers in Iraq in an aggressive way.''
''If this is the threat it appears to be, then this is unacceptable,'' said a spokesman for the British Foreign Office, which called in the Iraqi ambassador in London to protest the roundup.
The Foreign Office spokesman said it knew of some 366 people who had been seized, most of them passengers on a British Airways flight that was caught at the Kuwait airport when Iraqi troops poured into the country on Thursday. The West German Foreign Ministry said its citizens were also being rounded up from hotels.
The British Foreign Office spokesman said, ''They are basically being taken by bus, we assume up to Iraq and Baghdad.''
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq summoned the senior American diplomat in Baghdad, Joseph Wilson, for a meeting in Baghdad that lasted several hours, the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said. She added that the United States ''viewed it as a very serious meeting.'' It was the first diplomatic contact between an American official and Mr. Hussein since the invasion.
 
Cheney in Saudi Arabia
The Iraqi moves came as the American Secretary of Defense, Dick Cheney, arrived in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, in an attempt to persuade the Saudis to confront Mr. Hussein, whose abrupt annexation of Iraq's tiny, oil-rich neighbor has left the Arab world stunned and in disarray.
The United States wants the Saudis to help in imposing economic sanctions on Iraq by closing the pipeline through the desert kingdom that carries much of Iraq's 2.7 million barrels a day in oil exports. Washington would also like permission to use Saudi territory as a staging area for military operations.
But so loath are the Saudis to annoy the Iraqis that tonight they issued an emphatic denial of reports that they had moved troops and tanks up to their own border with occupied Kuwait.
''All these reports are categorically untrue and if the kingdom had taken any such measure it would have announced it,'' an unnamed spokesman told the official Saudi Press Agency.
 
Silence From the Saudis
Saudi Arabia has been notably silent on the occupation of its neighbor Kuwait. Saudi Arabia and four other oil shiekdoms had a mutual-defense pact under the Gulf Cooperation Council under which an attack on one was supposed to be an attack on all.
The first public Saudi statement came on Sunday when it was announced that an emergency cabinet meeting had been called to discuss what were termed ''regrettable'' events.
The Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, was shuttling between Arab capitals on a private Iraqi jet tonight with a plan, apparently acceptable to Baghdad, that might conceivably provide a face-saving resolution.
Mr. Arafat flew into Alexandria this evening, for discussions with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. Mr. Arafat then left for Saudi Arabia and was to go to Baghdad later, according to the official Egyptian press agency, which also reported that a Saudi Arabian envoy had arrived in Egypt for talks with Mr. Mubarak.
Arabic press reports say the Palestinian plan, which is backed by Libya, calls for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops in return for ''supporting the Iraqi economy,'' which appears to mean a large payoff or a share of the Kuwaiti oilfields. Under the plan, free elections would be held in Kuwait to choose a new government. According to some reports, Iraq would continue to hold Bubiyan Island, a strategic mud flat long coveted by Iraq that controls access to the Shatt al Arab waterway and Iraq's two main ports at Basra and Umm Qasr.
Mr. Arafat was uncharacteristically taciturn, refusing to answer reporters' questions as he left Alexandria, saying only: ''It is better to be prudent when you want things done.''
 
Iraq Forces on Alert
President Mubarak's key political adviser, Osama al-Baz, said that ''the purpose of these contacts is to explore the available options in order to find a way out of the Iraqi-Kuwaiti crisis.''
In Baghdad, Iraq put its military forces on full alert, began drills lasting for hours in preparation for evacuating 4 million people from Baghdad and lesser numbers from other cities.
''Our great people, who were tested for their unlimited preparedness for sacrifice, are now fully prepared to deter those who dare to commit aggression against Iraq or Kuwait,'' the Ba'ath party newspaper al-Thawra said.
In Saudi Arabia and the gulf region there was a mood of deep foreboding today, and the leaders of the tiny desert countries grown fabulously rich on oil tried to keep a low profile. In Bahrain, the authorities expelled dozens of foreign journalists who had flown there to cover the crisis.
In Dubai, the largest of the United Arab Emirates, ceremonies to mark the anniversary of Sheik Zayed Bin Sultan al-Nahayan's accession to power were canceled. in deference to what were offically described as ''events in the region,'' and foreign laborers worked through the night to take down three million colored lights strung through the streets for the celebration.

It was unclear whether the scaffolding surrounding the building was put up to protect the hotel from anticipated attacks or for renovations. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: The Iraqi Invasion;
Cutting Budget Gap Now Discounted

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
With the American economy seemingly headed for recession and the exploding cost of imported oil about to push it over the edge, analysts widely agree that cutting the budget deficit this year no longer makes sense. But by the same token, they argue, the case for making a credible deal now on future deficit reduction is more compelling than ever.
The resulting psychological lift would make it far easier for the Federal Reserve to fight the economic downturn without touching off a self-fulfilling inflationary panic.
Under the threat of automatic budget cuts, White House and Congressional negotiators have been tugging delicately at the Gordian knot of deficit reduction since President Bush abandoned his no-tax stance. And in recent weeks negotiators seemed to be edging toward agreement on a combination of excise taxes on energy and income levies on the affluent. 
But from the beginning of the talks the prospect that higher taxes or lower spending would weaken an already anemic economy has tempered enthusiasm for deficit reduction. Last week's report of an unexpected surge in unemployment further increased fears of a recession in the making. And for many erstwhile deficit fighters, the run-up in oil prices since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait was the last straw.
 
Heavy Tax From Hussein
An extra penny extracted at the pump costs consumers about $2.5 billion annually. And with imports supplying half of American consumption, a $10-a-barrel increase would reduce domestic purchasing power by about $30 billion annually. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has thus already imposed a heavy tax on Americans, the argument goes; why tax them twice?
Why indeed, argues David Hale, an economist at Kemper Financial Services. What he calls a ''cyclical cul-de-sac'' has probably already deteriorated into an old-fashioned recession. And even a modest move toward fiscal constraint, magnified by consumer caution, could push it into deep decline.
Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, offers another reason for increased pessimism. The only bright spot in the economy in recent months, he notes, has been the growth in exports to the booming economies of West Germany and Japan. Higher prices for economies that remain heavily dependent on imported oil could easily divert foreign enthusiasm for buying American.
 
A Concern About Growth
Robert Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, is not quite ready to join the doom-and-gloom school. But he does acknowledge that ''a sustained oil price increase'' could bring growth to a halt. And he agrees with Mr. Hale that ''the case for changing the structural deficit is stronger than ever.''
It is not hard to see why. The immediate prospects for the American economy, most analysts say, turn on the monetary stance of the Federal Reserve Board and its chairman, Alan Greenspan. With production running well below capacity, the Fed might be expected to ease credit, encouraging businesses to invest and consumers to buy houses and cars. But in spite of encouragement from the Bush Administration, the Fed has been reluctant to loosen the money spigot. Inflation, Mr. Greenspan publicly argued, remained a greater threat to the economy than recession.
Last week's depressing unemployment statistics, coupled with the reduction in purchasing power associated with higher oil prices, might be expected to tilt the Fed toward easier money. But the higher energy prices also mean more inflation. Fed officials worry that accommodation of the oil shock - injecting cash into the financial system to replace the purchasing power lost to imports -would lead business and labor to conclude that the higher inflation would be tolerated indefinitely.
 
Double-Digit Inflation Recalled
Just such a change in expectations after the 1974-75 oil shock led to double-digit inflation. A decade of stable prices has probably reduced the public's inclination to make a snap decision that the inflation battle had been lost. And greater competition from imports has made it more problematic for unions and employers to pass higher wages and profit margins through to consumers.
But as Mr. Bergsten notes, the Fed's fear that the public could rapidly lose confidence in price stability may not be entirely unfounded. Never, after all, has the American economy ended a long period of prosperity with a $200 billion-plus budget deficit and its banking system in disarray.
That is why economists argue that a credible deal of future deficit reduction is so important. With such a deal, the Fed could assert with equal credibility that it was adjusting monetary policy to match the new fiscal discipline rather than merely accommodating oil-led inflation.
 
Stronger Dollar Expected
Richard Cooper, an economist at Harvard, points to a related benefit that would help smooth the Fed's way toward easier credit. A firm commitment to balance the budget in the future, he argues, would make the dollar a more attractive currency in which to hold wealth. And the resulting demand for dollars would offset the tendency of investors to shift into other currencies as American interest rates fell in response to monetary ease.
The unanswered question is whether any deal about future deficit reduction can be politically credible if it does not include a down payment this year. Mr. Bergsten is skeptical -so skeptical that he would even risk a small tax increase this year. At the very least, he suggests, the nuts and bolts of future deficit reduction must be spelled out in detail. That means agreement on which taxes are to be raised, which spending programs are to be cut, and by how much.
Paradoxically then, the threat of recession could add to the burdens of the budget negotiators rather than taking them off the political hook.

HEADLINE: Midland Journal;
No Champagne Gushers In Texas Over Oil Prices

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIDLAND, Tex., Aug. 6

 BODY:
Tripp Wommack, who has been buying and operating oil fields here for 10 years, scanned the buffet room at the Petroleum Club.
''See, no champagne corks popping,'' he said, digging into his blood-rare roast beef. ''Anyone who's out celebrating is a fool.''
Those who make their living directly or indirectly from oil in Midland - and that's almost everybody in this West Texas city - take pains to say that they are not nearly as happy about Iraq's invasion of Kuwait as they assume the rest of the country assumes they are. 
They are pleased, certainly, that after years of depression and modest recovery, the price of their primary product has nearly doubled in the past month, closing at $28.05 a barrel today. And they do not deny that it has been more fun to go to work since last Thursday than it has been in years. And they are not above a kind word for the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein. ''He may be a despot, but he's our despot,'' said Joe O'Neill, an independent oil operator.
But mostly, they are cautious. ''People here are snake-bit,'' Mr. Wommack said. ''They're superstitious. They know if they get too excited, they'll just feel stupid when it drops back down. And they're tired of feeling stupid.''
A decade ago, an invasion of Kuwait and the resulting increase in the price of oil would probably have brought unabashed celebration in Midland. Those were the giddy days of the oil boom, when each barrel sold for nearly $40 and there were more millionaires per capita in Midland than anywhere else in the country.
The price began to fall in the early 1980's, and by 1986 oil was selling for $8 or $9 a barrel. Banks failed, businesses closed, foreclosures soared. Midland learned it was not forever blessed. The initiation fee at the Petroleum Club was $7,500 five summers ago; now it is $2,500. Despite the discount, membership dropped by nearly one quarter.
The lesson learned by the city of about 90,000 people goes like this: rambunctious outsiders flocked here to take advantage of the boom, then left when their house of cards fell.
''A lot of people lost big,'' said Dennis Grub, whose drilling company was disbanded in 1986. ''They were doctors and lawyers and shoe salesmen who came from back East and didn't know what they were doing.''
The cautious old-timers say they are seeking stability rather than spectacular profits.
''You can't do business when prices are this unstable,'' said Henry Musselman, president of Musselman, Owen and King, oil and gas producers.
In effect, oil producers say, they want much the same outcome in the Persian Gulf as the rest of the country does. ''We're not out there rooting for Iraq,'' Mr. Musselman said. ''I would like to see Iraq retreat back to its own borders and leave the Kuwaitis alone.''
Midland, a land of cowboy boots and pickup trucks, the place where George Bush founded his oil company, prides itself on its patriotism. For that reason, too, these oilmen are insulted at the suggestion that they are secretly pulling for Iraq.
''A drastic increase would harm the nation,'' said Jack Blake, who has been in the oil business for 41 years and is now an independent producer. ''I love my country first and foremost. I'd hate to see it go into a recession because of a dictator.''
Not only do they fear for the country, they say, but they also fear for their carefully mended reputation. During the boom, they say, they were portrayed across the country as crass and cruel, spending their wealth with abandon and mocking those who were suffering the recession that was taking place elsewhere.
There is a lot of happiness in Midland, but it is carefully and deliberatly muted. It is reflected in the greetings Mr. Wommack received at lunch at the Petroleum Club this afternoon. ''How are you liking the oil business?'' he was asked by an acquaintance on the way into the dining room.
''It's been a long time since anyone asked me that,'' he said.
And it can be felt in the jokes between friends. Every Friday night, Mr. Grub meets the same group of geologists and oil engineers at the same bar for the same hour of unwinding. Last Friday, talk turned to the drilling company where Mr. Grub has been employed for four years and which is to be sold in 30 days.
The confidence of the old Midland comes through as Mr. Grub relates the toast made by a friend: ''If this keeps up, you can buy your own company.''
Then the caution of the new Midland steps in as Mr. Grub quickly adds: ''He was joking, really. Everyone laughed. We really don't expect this to keep up.''

HEADLINE: Congress Hails Its Bills on Housing As a Reversal of a Decade of Neglect

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
After a decade in which Federal housing programs stagnated or starved, Congress has passed bills that pledge significant amounts of new housing money, both to strengthen current programs and to create new ones.
Members of both parties and advocates for low-income housing are hailing the bills as a reversal of policy and an important step toward easing the nation's housing shortage.
They ''represent a significant break with the past that put housing on the back burner,'' said Representative Marge Roukema, the New Jersey Republican who is the ranking minority member of the House Subcommittee on Housing and Community Development.
Senator Alan Cranston, the California Democrat who is the chief author of the Senate bill, said, ''There is a recognition that after a decade of Federal abdication of responsibility in the housing realm, that we have to get back into the field.''
 
Increase Over Reagan Years
The House bill would provide 41 percent more money than the last budget of the Reagan Adminstration, according to an estimate by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The Senate bill would provide about 36 percent more. 
Although the Bush Administration has threatened to veto the House bill as it now exists, saying some programs are too generous, House and Senate negotiators have expressed confidence that they can reach a compromise that President Bush would sign.
Both bills propose new approaches to long-standing housing problems, emphasizing home ownership for the poor, offering increased money to nonprofit organizations and making it easier to link social services to housing.
The one-year $28.7 billion bill passed by the House would provide $5 billion more than the Administration requested; the Senate's $27.9 billion bill would provide $3.8 billion more than the Administration requested. Those amounts are limits, rather than sums actually approved for spending, which are almost certain to be less because of the budget deficit ''We don't have the money to do all that must be done,'' Mr. Cranston said. #220,000 More Households At full funding levels, both pieces of legislation are estimated to add 220,000 additional households to the 4.4 million now being assisted by the housing department. Some of the money in the House bill would be used to build housing. The Senate version discourages using the money for construction, instead it emphasizes assistance to rent existing homes.
Despite the spirit of congratulation that has accompanied the two bills' passage, they have significant differences, which promise a contentious meeting next month when a House-Senate conference committee will try to resolve the measures.
Both bills support Homeownership and Opportunity for People Everywhere, or HOPE, the proposal that is the centerpiece of the Administration's policy. The program would provide grants for low-income residents seeking to buy homes.
And both bills provide almost $1 billion more for three Federal programs: to modernize public housing, to provide grants to state and local governments for housing and economic development, and to supply low-income people with certificates that allow them to buy housing.
 
Different Approaches
But beyond that, the House and Senate take significantly different approaches toward creating new programs. The Senate has placed the bulk of its new program money into a $2 billion fund that would provide state and local governments with block grants to use largely as they see fit.
The House, by contrast, has divided about $1.1 billion in among three new major programs. One would subsidize mortgages for new homebuyers, another would subsidize developers building new rental housing, and a third would provide housing money to nonprofit corporations. In addition, the House has voted to spend $500 million to build 6,800 units of new public housing.
The bills also take strikingly different approaches to two other major housing issues. One is restructuring of a financially troubled Federal Housing Administration mortgage fund. The other is the prepayment of mortgages on government-subsidized buildings by developers who want to convert them to higher-rent properties. In the next decade, more than 300,000 units of low-income housing may become eligible for such conversions.
 
Administration Credited
In explaining the new housing emphasis, both Democrats and Republicans credit the Bush Administration with making it a higher priority than the Reagan one did. In addition, they say a climate for change was created by the suffering of many Americans, not only the homeless but also those of modest income who are paying more and more for housing.
While virtually all housing experts see the bills' passage as a turning point in policy, they disagree on which features are most significant. The Administration has emphasized the HOPE program, for which the Senate has allocated $240 million and the House $310 million.
Three different segments of the program would offer grants to low-income people seeking to buy public housing, foreclosed multifamily apartments, and federally owned single-family homes. The grants would be used to encourage residents of public housing to form their own coporations to manage, and later buy, public housing. The grants could be used to acquire, rehabilitate and learn how to manage the housing. The program would also provide grants to encourage business development in low-income areas.
Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp has spoken of the program in evangelical terms, calling it ''the most dramatic, far-reaching, incentive-oriented approach to fighting poverty in the last 25 years.'' He has argued that turning renters into homeowners will give poor people a greater stake in their neighborhoods and help reduce crime and welfare-dependency.
 
Shortage Exists
Some others see the HOPE proposals as a useful component of housing policy, but they say that concentrating on the transfer of ownership of existing housing will not increase the supply of low-income units.
''That's not bad stuff,'' said Barry Zigas, director of the National Low-Income Housing Coalition, but ''it doesn't do anything for the long-term supply.''
While other plans for new programs take very different forms in the House and Senate, they do articulate some common principles. Both, for instance, emphasize the role of nonprofit corporations in providing housing.
''This is a really significant step,'' said Cushing Dolbeare, director of the National Coalition for the Homeless. In the past, she said, Federal money has typically gone to entities based outside neighborhoods, like public housing authorities or private developers. But under these proposals ''the housing will be integrated into neighborhoods,'' she said.
A second principle in both bills is the recognition that some low-income residents have special needs that require social services. The bills provide housing preferences or special services for people with AIDS, the frail elderly, the homeless and children in danger of being put in foster care because of substandard housing.
High on the list of disagreements is the method of changing the Federal Housing Administration's single-family insurance fund, which is thought to be financially unsound.
The Senate has adopted the Administration's proposals to limit the amount of closing costs that buyers may finance and to charge higher premiums for those with low down-payments. The House version, backed by the mortgage-banking industry, rejected those proposals, saying they would exclude too many borrowers. Mr. Kemp has said the House version does not protect the fund and has recommended a veto.
The bills also differ significantly on the issue of developers buying out subsidized mortgages and converting projects into higher-priced housing. The Senate preserves a moratorium on the buyouts, now scheduled to expire in September, while the House offers financial incentives to developers to preserve the projects. The Administration has criticized several House programs because they include families who earn up to 115 percent of the area's median income, saying they are not the most needy. By contrast, 90 percent of the Senate block grants would go to households earning less than 50 percent of the median income, which is still above the poverty line.
''Two things have happened,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn. ''One, people agree that government has to become more involved in the housing area, but, two, that no one has a monopoly on truth as to how to do it.''

CORRECTION-DATE: August 8, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on Federal housing legislation misstated the difference in spending between the Senate proposal and the Bush Administration plan. According to estimates by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the $27.9 billion Senate version would provide $4.2 billion more than the White House version.

HEADLINE: A U.S. Strategy for the Gulf Crisis;
Coping with the Economic Consequences

 BODY:
President Bush has rallied the U.N. Security Council to vote a trade embargo against Iraq and Kuwait. This is the right response to Baghdad's heinous invasion, but it raises two troubling questions for the U.S.: Will the embargo block Iraqi oil exports? And will it throw the U.S. into a devastating recession?
There is cause for muted optimism on both scores. Iraq relies upon a single export, oil, whose shipment is easily monitored. The oil importing nations, if they cooperate, can make sure they buy only from non-Iraqi sources. 
The more successful the embargo, the worse the danger for the U.S. economy. The loss of oil from Iraq and Kuwait would drive up oil prices and throw a limp U.S. economy into recession. But Mr. Bush can mitigate this danger by marshaling Saudi support and releasing oil from large U.S. stockpiles. That way the embargo can cripple Iraq without crippling the U.S. too.
Iraqi oil is shipped through pipelines across Turkey and Saudi Arabia and in tankers through the Persian Gulf. The limited number of outlets makes the oil easy to track, and check. The proof may already be in hand. Even before the U.N. vote, the industrialized countries had announced an embargo. Iraq then suspended most of its oil shipments through Turkey apparently because it would be unable to find buyers.
Iraq and Kuwait sold between four and five billion barrels a day before the invasion. If that entire output is lost, the price of oil could, at worst, double. But even that scenario would be far less damaging to the U.S. economy than the quadrupling of oil prices in 1973-74 or their tripling in 1979. Inflation would rise by several percentage points; the unemployment rate might approach 8 percent from its present 5.5 percent. These are very serious but manageable consequences - especially when compared with the possible costs of inaction.
Mr. Bush has ways to lessen the economic harm. By providing military guarantees against Iraqi reprisal, he might be able to persuade Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates to step up production. If Venezuela also raises output, most of the shortfall could be offset.
And there is a powerful antidote within Mr. Bush's control: the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a 600-million-barrel stockpile created in the aftermath of the 1970's oil crises. Japan and Western Europe created similar stockpiles.
These reserves were established to smooth over a temporary crisis just like the one triggered by Iraq's invasion. The Western stockpiles are large enough to offset a sizable portion of the shortfall even if the crisis lasts as long as a year.
The loss of U.S. oil imports during the 1970's never exceeded 5 percent. The reason that such a modest supply shock caused havoc was that consumers panicked, and hoarded available oil. By immediately releasing oil from stockpiles, the West can calm jittery markets.
Western economies are less vulnerable to OPEC now than in the 70's. Energy use - compared with the size of Western economies - is lower and there are more supplies of natural gas and other non-oil energy sources. For these reasons, and because the price shock will be much smaller, the U.S. and its allies can withstand the embargo.
Only panic can turn this very difficult situation into a catastrophe. By addressing the nation now, explaining the price of inaction and the costs of his proposed actions, Mr. Bush has it in his power to prevent that and reassure the American people.

HEADLINE: Ill-Equipped for the Crises of the 90's

BYLINE: By Gary Hart; Gary Hart, former Senator from Colorado, was a founder of the Military Reform Caucus.

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
Nothing marked the euphoric and triumphant march of the Reagan Administration into Washington in 1981 more than two policies - a ''free market'' in oil (in lieu of energy independence) and a massive strategic weapons buildup. Last week, nine years and $1 trillion later, we found ourselves threatened by our dependence on Middle East oil and unable to mount a quick and effective military response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
We are now almost at the level of dependence on foreign oil imports -roughly 50 percent - that we were when OPEC embargoed our oil in 1973 and more than quadrupled its price by 1977. And by putting so many of our military eggs in the strategic nuclear basket in the 1980's, we are now virtually muscle-bound in dealing with regional conflicts of the sort we now face in Kuwait. 
One simple step, more than any other, could have assured our national energy security and the integrity of our foreign policy. That was a tax on imported oil, which a hardy few of us have advocated vigorously and insistently for more than a decade. Instead, the Reagan Administration chose to resume consumption and foreign dependence, and the U.S. is now hostage to the whims of Middle East politics.
Our dependence on imported oil casts doubt on our motives in defending the Persian Gulf. In the new international political order, which places more emphasis on democratic ideals than on superpower military strength, we are particularly vulnerable to such criticism. When the crisis has passed, people throughout the world will ask themselves, Was the U.S. truly interested in restoring order, re-establishing a lawful government or punishing outlaw behavior? Or was that excuse just a cynical cover for a desperate superpower addicted to someone else's oil?
Moreover, if we were determined to increase our dependence on foreign oil, then we should have prepared our military accordingly. Yet, like modern-day Bourbons, we learned nothing from the 1970's. Remember the Rapid Deployment Force (neither rapid, deployable nor a force) designed, after the fall of the Shah of Iran, to rescue ''our'' oil. From whom, the Russians?
Even if we can make a convincing case that the U.S. has a moral duty to police the Persian Gulf, we aren't prepared to do so. Not because we haven't spent the money - we certainly have done that in the past 10 years - but because we have spent the money wrongly.
Kuwait is a classic case of the limits of strategic weapons. No B-1 or Stealth bomber, no MX missile, no Trident submarine and missile, no cruise millsile can help us there. Not even Nimitz-class nuclear aircraft carriers. As the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Admiral William Crowe, has said, carrier-based air strikes will avail us little if we do not have land-based airstrips with which to supplement them.
Here the vaunted military buildup of the 1980's fails us. We are prepared for nuclear war with a disintegrating Soviet Union and unprepared for military action in Kuwait. We didn't use the period, as a few of us had argued that we should, to reform military structures, doctrines and weapons to anticipate the true threats of the 1990's and beyond: regional conflict, insurgency and terrorism.
Had we undertraken these reforms a decade ago, today we would have troops specifically trained in the flexible tactics necessary for localized conflict. They would be equipped with light, highly mobile weapons, transported by aircraft adopted to short runways and to ''roll-on, roll-off'' ships. Military leaders would be pursuing a doctrine of maneuver rather than firepower and attrition. All this would enable them to fight more effectively in a situation like Kuwait, if that becomes our policy.
Right now, for example, Iraqi military units are dispersing throughout the thin Kuwaiti population. If we tried traditional military approaches - air strikes and sea-based artillery fire - we would kill many Kuwaitis.
Given our present military capabilities, there are only two ways to force the Iraqis out of Kuwait. We can bring massive military force to bear against military targets in Iraq. That used to be called declaring war.
Or we can insert our own military forces into Kuwait and drive the Iraqis out. It would take weeks to assemble these forces, stage and equip them, and deliver them ashore. Loss of lives, including American lives, would be substantial.
Even given Saddam Hussein's fait accompli, there is no need and no justification for the U.S. to go it alone in the Middle East. If Iraq represents a threat to world peace or regional stability, then the international community is obliged to participate. The French, British, Italians and others can and should be involved in military blockades, sea and air interdiction and other political, economic and military sanctions.
The day is simply over for this nation to carry the Western burden. The true test of Presidential leadership in the 1990's is not willingness to send in the Marines but ability to mobilize and energize democratic unity.
The military and energy policies of the 1980's have been tested and found wanting. The long-view issue today is not what we will do with Saddam Hussein but what we will do to change these policies in anticipation of a new century.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Now or Later?

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Panicky officials at the U.S. Department of Agriculture are racing around to bank regulators to find Iraqi funds; unless they can seize and use offsetting assets, $2 billion in commodity credit guarantees will come out of taxpayers' pockets to pay for Mr. Bush's past appeasement of Saddam Hussein.
Of course, Kuwaitis lost much more. What a refreshingly simple motive for aggression: money.
Saddam did not snatch Kuwait to settle Sunni-Shiite scores, or to counter Zionism, or to provide his nation a place in the sun, or to advance some ideology. None of the usual reasons for recent wars - of religious or racial or ethnic hatreds, or geopolitics, or pro-anythingism - apply. 
This was a stickup. His reason for taking Kuwait was the same as Slick Willie Sutton's for hitting a bank: that's where the money was. Broke from his last war, with a million-man army to pay, Saddam grabbed the gold and oil, wiping out much of his debt by wiping out his creditor.
Who was to stop him? The Saudi King is spineless, and Syria and Egypt are unprepared for war; the Soviets might join an arms embargo for Western opinion's sake but they have as great a stake as Iraq in higher oil prices; and the Israelis have no dog in this fight. Turkey, if provoked, would be trouble.
Would the industrial powers act in unprecedented concert? A cutoff of arms sales means nothing, because Saddam has no money to buy more arms anyway; France, his biggest unpaid supplier, stopped shipments months ago. A boycott of Iraqi-Kuwaiti oil? That would only send the price up, and oil is fungible; in time, greed will find a way.
That leaves the superpower, the U.S. When Saddam poison-gassed 8,000 Kurds, Mr. Bush said nothing; when Saddam abused the U.S. banking system in the Lavoro affair, the Bush Attorney General dithered; when Saddam corruptly skimmed our grain credit to help pay for his Condor missile, the Bush Agriculture Secretary hastened to guarantee more grain loans, now in jeopardy.
Saddam probably figured the U.S. would (a) huff and puff about Kuwait, but limit response to economic boycott, and (b) re-declare a vital interest in oil and get the Saudis graciously to permit us to guarantee their sovereignty.
If that were our reaction, he would slip into a moderate phase. He would send out his lickspittle envoys, the King of Jordan and the boss of the P.L.O., to benumb his Arab brethren; he would pledge no further territorial demands, Hitler-style; he might even use his new leverage to spring the long-held hostages in Lebanon, and let out thousands of new Western hostages in Kuwait.
Mr. Bush's reaction, however -perhaps to compensate for the failure of appeasement - has been more severe. Although his first reaction was ''we're not discussing intervention,'' he soon stiffened: while preparing to base Air Force units in Saudi Arabia, he has announced that the conquest of Kuwait ''will not stand.''
That phrase, prepared for delivery and repeated, defines the U.S. insistence on a rollback, what diplomats like to call the status quo ante. Is the President serious? He must know that Saddam, having made his move, is not likely to humiliate himself by pulling out in the face of boycotts or long-distance threats.
If Mr. Bush is blustering during an international crisis, he will be the one who ''will not stand.'' If he is serious about not letting the conquest stand, as I believe he is, something internal or external will have to knock it over.
He hopes it can be induced short of war. U.N. sanctions, followed by a cutoff of the pipelines in Turkey and Saudi Arabia (perhaps covertly, to provide a fig leaf to those Governments) might lead to strangulation, economic collapse and a hoped-for coup in Baghdad.
If that won't work quickly, we have to ask ourselves why the stickup -what the hero of Halabja wants the big money for.
Poison gas is his local threat. Of direct concern to us: He is only four years away from production of nuclear bombs. His missiles now have sophisticated French guidance systems, and with time and money he will surely build intercontinental missiles.
Put yourself in the Oval Office in 1994. Saddam moves on Saudi Arabia. The U.S. warns him that means war. Saddam says fine, the first city he will take out is New York. You know he has the means and the will.
Bloodshed now is a terrible thing to contemplate. Nuclear war at a time of Saddam's choosing, against a sociopath already to blame for a million deaths, is worse.

PUB-DATE: August 7, 1990

SECTION: Section B; Page 5, Column 6; National Desk

HEADLINE: U.S. Rural Assistance Is Criticized in Study

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6

 BODY:
After a yearlong study, a nonprofit advocacy group has concluded that many rural Americans suffer needlessly from poverty and pollution because Federal programs to help them are poorly financed and poorly run.
The group, the Center for Community Change, said the people who run the Farmers Home Administration of the Agriculture Department lack the needed skills, and it criticized the Reagan Administration for cutting the agency's budget for rural development by nearly 70 percent. 
The report said that rural unemployment was one-third higher than in the cities; that a third more rural residents than urban residents were below the poverty line; that almost two million rural residents lived in substandard housing, usually lacking adequate plumbing, and that rural rates of maternal and infant mortality were higher than in urban areas and were rising faster.
Joe O'Neill, a spokesman for the Farmers Home Administration, said agency officials had not studied the report, but added, ''We're always pleased to get these kinds of studies.''
The report also criticized the Environmental Protection Agency, saying it had failed to provide rural areas enough help to meet water standards. Ninety-seven percent of the rural population relies on well water for drinking, the study said, even though a Federal survey has said two-thirds of wells are contaminated.
