HEADLINE: For More Drugs, First Test Is Abroad

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
PATIENT trials of new treatments, long a crown jewel of American medical science, are increasingly being conducted overseas, a number of prominent researchers say.
The researchers blame the fragmented American health care system, red tape, overzealous ethical concerns and financial constraints for making it increasingly cumbersome and costly to do studies in the United States and for driving the work abroad. At the same time, a flowering of clinical research in Europe has taken up the slack.
As trials shift overseas, experts worry that access to the newest therapies will be delayed for Americans, and they point to several drugs and devices widely used in Europe that are unavailable in the United States.
''Our trials are still very good, but these days there are less of them being done here and more in Europe,'' said Dr. Gerald P. Murphy, chief medical officer of the American Cancer Society. 
Dr. Thomas Chalmers, an expert on controlled clinical trials, said, ''Clinical trials that are large enough to give answers to important medical questions have certainly switched to Europe.
''The question to me is not how often Europeans are used as guinea pigs for Americans,'' he said, ''but how often Europeans are the lucky ones who get access to new and exciting medicines way before us. We ought to get the feeling that we are being deprived of the best opportunities.''
For a belief so widely proclaimed, the emigration of research is difficult to prove, since even the National Institutes of Health does not tally the numbers of clinical trials. And a few scientists even question its existence. But in interviews dispirited medical researchers said they and their colleagues now often travel to test their theories or collaborate with foreign researchers in studies in Europe, South America or Japan. As doctors, they increasingly look to European trials to decide how to treat patients.
Experts point to the rising foreign presence in the country's medical journals and at conferences to corroborate this view. And they all have a story to tell.
At the American College of Cardiology meeting last year, American doctors sat in rapt silence as Europeans described their studies involving drugs designed to break up clots in the coronary arteries to abort heart attacks in progress. American cardiologists had largely abandoned work on these thrombolytic medicines because they could not keep pace with the Europeans, said Dr. Anthony DeMaria, past president of the American College of Cardiology.
Two years ago, Dr. William O'Neill, chief of cardiology at the William Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, Mich., traveled to Germany to test a device to clean out clogged coronary arteries to avoid the delays and expense of trials in the United States.
''Most of the evidence is qualitative, but I think on the basis of my observation that the hunch that research is leaving the country is on target,'' said Renee Fox, a sociologist at the University of Pennsylvania who has been a student of the field since shortly after World War II. ''I don't want to get into hand wringing, but I think we should be worried about why it's happening.''
In more than a dozen interviews, Americans who had done research in Europe often denied consciously bypassing the constraints in this country. But all were conspicuously quick to take advantage of an open door.
''When there's a collaboration, the research tends to be done overseas,'' said Dr. Robert D. Rosenberg, a professor at both Harvard Medical School and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who said that a growing portion of his work was done with foreign doctors. He recently published a study in which Dutch volunteers were injected with a protein implicated in clotting abnormalities and is involved in research in England on predicting heart attacks.
Drug companies, too, are taking a growing number of trials out of the country. Foreign pharmaceutical trials got a shot in the arm in the mid-1980's when the Food and Drug Administration decided to accept some foreign data in support of new drug applications, although the agency still requires at least one United States study for final approval. Reasons to Leave Researchers Cite Rigorous Rules Researchers cite several factors for the trend:
* The vigorous regulation of research by the Government and universities, so that preparing a study involves reams of paperwork and rounds of committee meetings, which are time-consuming and costly.
* An outspoken and, some say, overzealous national attitude about patient rights, which many experts feel has led patients to regard trials with unneccesary suspicion and made it difficult to recruit volunteers.
* A fragmented private health care system, which provides no incentive for doctors to refer patients to clinical trials and has poor mechanisms for financing them.
''There are so many obstacles that a number of people either give up or just throw up their hands and go elsewhere,'' said Dr. Charles Lieber, a psychiatrist at the Bronx Veterans Affairs Hospital who recently published a study on alcohol metabolism in women in Italy. ''I've been doing clinical research for 32 years and its gotten harder and harder. It still can be done but at a cost in frustrations and dollars.'' Dr. Lieber says he took his project abroad because the Veterans Affairs Hospital had few female patients and one of the Italian collaborators had been a student in his laboratory.
Although experts generally acknowledge the relative difficulty of doing research in the United States, some defend the obstacles as legitimate. ''We may be a little ahead in the amount of bureaucracy,'' said Dr. Curtis Meinert of Johns Hopkins University, an expert on clinical trials. ''But a lot of those procedures are there for good ethical and scientific and legal reasons.''
But all seem to agree that the departing research is, in general, not morally suspect. ''Just because it's cheaper or easier to do something in another country doesn't mean that a big moral issue is being compromised,'' said Mike Shaffer, a spokesman for the Food and Drug Administration. Researchers point out that the majority of the lost work has gone to nations that have their own mechanisms for protecting patients.
In the world of research, where hard data reign, the magnitude of the migration - even its existence - has been difficult to gauge. ''I agree there's such a perception but I'm not sure that it's true or even where to find data to prove it,'' said Dr. Meinert, who nonetheless said he believed there was a ''building crisis'' in clinical research.
In fact, the financing of clinical trials by the National Institutes of Health has gone up about 40 percent in constant dollars in the last decade, to $495 million in 1989. But researchers say the cost of doing clinical trials in the United States has far outpaced inflation and that in some of the institutes constant dollar spending is down.
Earlier this year in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Thomas Stossel tried to get a handle on the situation indirectly by tracking foreign publications in several prestigious medical journals over the previous decade. He discovered that the number of foreign papers increased two- to threefold and the number from the United States decreased in tandem.
Such findings have evoked the usual debates about the power and significance of data. There have been some skeptics: Dr. Vincent DeVita, former chief of the National Cancer Institute, called the widespread impression that research is emigrating ''an illusion created by Europe's new strength.''
Dr. Bert Spilker, a research executive at the Burroughs Wellcome Company, said, ''Yes, we're doing more abroad, but I don't think the data mean that the U.S. is falling down but that Europe is catching up.'' But many American researchers clearly feel that they are slipping. Overzealous Ethics Regulations Add Time to Studies These researchers protest that intense regulation, makes it cumbersome to conduct their work in the United States and expedient to take it elsewhere. In order to undertake a study of a new drug, for example, a researcher must often submit extensive proposals to the government, his university, and the F.D.A. before enrolling patients. The process can take months or years. ''By the mid-80's I had all this animal data, and I was convinced we could proceed with testing in patients,'' said Dr. O'Neill, explaining why he took his device for reaming heart arteries overseas. ''That was impossible here. The preclinical evaluation it had to go through was unbelievably elaborate and expensive.'' In West Germany, he said, he simply needed permission from the hospital, which was quickly obtained. The F.D.A. subsequently approved the device for use in the United States.
Officials at the Food and Drug Administration are accustomed to the complaints. ''In this country there is an overriding concern for the safety of the patient, and some feel it's excessive,'' Mr. Shaffer said. But, now that the F.D.A. accepts foreign data, he says there is sometimes a new outlet for the frustration. He said the agency's decision to accept such data was controversial and compared it to a court deciding how to regard evidence that was compelling but illegally collected.
Scientists also feel that overzealous ethical review boards and, in particular, informed consent rules have driven science away.
In the mid-80's, Dr. Richard Peto, a well-known epidemiologist at Oxford University, approached American cardiologists to enlist patients for a study of the drug streptokinase as a treatment for heart attacks. Although the Americans were enthusiastic, in the time that British doctors referred 6,000 patients, only 400 entered from the other side of the Atlantic. He holds consent procedures largely to blame.
''The American documents were three pages of legalistic junk,'' Dr. Peto said, who had written a single page consent form for British use. ''That's not the sort of thing you want to push under someone's nose as he's having a heart attack, terrified, with chest pain, on morphine. You want to tell him about the trial, but you want to be humane.'' Although countries in Europe require that researchers discuss a study with potential subjects, the requirement is far less formalized.
Equally important, experts say the fragmented system of health care in the United States is poorly suited to organizing large patient trials. When Dr. Tord Naessen wanted to study the effect of hormone replacement on postmenopausal women in Sweden, he had easy access to the health records of all 23,246 women in the Uppsala health district who had been prescribed the medications. In the United States, that information would have been locked away in thousands of individual offices.
Many cardiologists blame fragmentation for the relatively poor showing of American scientists in heart research. In this country, only about 10 percent of heart attack victims are treated at academic hospitals where studies take place. In Europe that number is probably over 60 percent, Dr. DeMaria said.
The American method of financing health care creates further disincentives since insurers, including Medicare and Medicaid, often do not pay for services rendered as part of a trial even if they prove beneficial.
If, for example, a study requires a patient to stay in the hospital an extra day for a liver biopsy to monitor a new treatment, most insurance will not pay for the hospital bed, the operating room time or the doctors' fees; private hospitals and doctors usually write off the costs.
Clinical researchers say the National Institutes of Health has got to address the financing dilemmas peculiar to patient trials in the United States. Many Consequences Trend Could Affect Jobs and Patients In the face of the migration, experts fear for the health of the clinical research community. ''The Europeans are developing a large coterie of scientists who are good at clinical research, while our skills are going to atrophy,'' Dr. Rosenberg said. The experts say that the repercussions will be felt by patients and businesses as well.
Already, new drugs and devices are often used in Europe long before they can be in the United States. A promising new class of drugs to treat prostate cancer, called antiandrogens, is widely available in clinical trials in Europe, but not in the United States, said Dr. Murphy. Cardiac stents, tiny tubes that hold open coronary arteries on the verge of closing, were tested in Europe beginning in 1985 and are widely used now, said Dr. DeMaria. They are scheduled for trials here this fall.
Researchers predict that if clinical research becomes too cumbersome in the United States, biomedical firms may be tempted to take their manufacturing elsewhere so that early testing may be done speedily and without heavy regulatory constraints. Dr. O'Neill said his work in Germany was delayed by a year while he waited for an F.D.A. license to export the device, which was manufactured in the United States.
In some other countries, things can move very fast. It took 12 months to do preliminary human testing of a chemical to enhance ultrasound exams in the United States, said Mr. David Pritchard of Molecular Biosystems of San Diego. ''Our Japanese collaborator completed the same testing in less than a day,'' he said. ''He commandered a medical center and lined up volunteers, one after another, and said to each one, 'Congratulations, you are going to be in my clinical trial.' ''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
 
Markets
Oil prices rose sharply again and financial markets tumbled around the world as the international embargo against oil from Iraq and Kuwait appeared to be taking hold. From Tokyo to Frankfurt to New York, investors drove the prices of stocks and bonds down abruptly on fears that with oil even more costly than expected a few days ago and supplies cut back, higher inflation and lower economic growth are more likely worldwide. [Page A1.]
In the U.S., stocks fell sharply, with the Dow suffering its biggest one-day loss since Oct. 13, 1989. After a 54-point fall on Friday, the Dow lost 93.31 points, or 3.3 percent, to close at 2,716.34. [D1.] 
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds took their worst battering since just before the 1987 stock crash, although bargain hunters prevented the interest rate on the benchmark 30-year bond from going higher than its May level. [D14.]
The dollar lost more ground against all primary foreign currencies except the yen amid speculation that recent signs of economic weakness will lead to lower U.S. interest rates. [D16.] The dollar, a longtime haven for investors in times of military and political crisis, has been all but shunned since Iraq invaded Kuwait. The ''flight to quality'' now is to the German mark. [D4.]
Gold futures prices rose, reflecting continuing fears that the soaring price of crude oil will lead to higher inflation. [D16.]
 
 
 
The Economy
Cutting the budget deficit this year no longer makes sense, analysts agree, with the economy seemingly headed for recession and the exploding cost of imported oil about to push it over the edge. But by the same token, the case for making a credible deal now on future deficit reduction is more compelling than ever. [A10.]
The Mideast turmoil has quickly hit the airline passenger, with higher oil prices already translating to higher air fares. [D1.]
Mortgage rates have increased quickly, as oil takes its toll. Last week rates hovered just above 10 percent, but they have soared more than a quarter-point in the last few days. [D1.]
After hearing James M. Fail acknowledge that he made incorrect disclosures to Federal regulators in 1988 when he purchased 15 insolvent savings and loans, members of a Senate panel said they were seriously troubled by the deal's inadequate disclosures and questionable financial arrangements. [D1.]
The productivity of American workers improved for the first time in six quarters, climbing in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, the Labor Department said. [D4.]
 
 
 
Companies
Businessland stunned Wall Street by posting losses for the quarter and the year far in excess of analysts' estimates. The stock lost more than half its value. [D2.]
A major effort to develop superconducting computers that can operate a million times faster than today's fastest machines should be undertaken by the U.S., a national panel recommends. [D2.]
In an attempt to put pressure on Manville, a Federal judge said the company's senior executives had not been cooperative in helping to bail out the trust to assist victims of asbestos. [D20.]
General Dynamics said it would consolidate two California military-related divisions that will result in 1,500 to 2,000 layoffs by the end of 1991. [D3.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
The head of Compaq's global operations discusses his strategy for maintaining high growth in Europe. Talking Business. [D2.]
The stock market is undergoing a series of stresses with no direct parallels in the recent past. And all this comes as traders are trying to cope with a new rule that many do not fully understand. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
Camel's offbeat ''Old Joe'' campaign is proving effective, even after many critics saw a blatant attempt to appeal to children. Kim Foltz: Advertising. [D17.]

HEADLINE: Banks Are Prodded to Offer Better Service in Poor Areas

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Responding to pressure from Congress and community groups, Federal regulators have withheld approval for some bank mergers in recent months until the companies agreed to improve service to poor neighborhoods.
The tougher regulatory stance has caused many banks to increase their lending programs for the poor, while forcing others to drop acquisitions that they thought would not be approved because of their record of serving poor neighborhoods.
When it agreed to bail out the savings industry last year, Congress insisted that banks start complying with a 1977 law that requires Federally insured financial institutions to serve their entire communities, including poor neighborhoods. It passed an amendment strengthening the law to give banks a greater incentive to comply.
And community groups have kept up pressure on banks, seeking more low-interest loans for housing rehabilitation, low-cost checking and other services. 
The delays in the approval of acquisitions can be extremely costly to banks because growth through mergers is an important competitive tool. American banks are under siege from foreign competition, notably the huge Japanese banks that have entered the United States.
As a result, many banks have increased their lending programs for the poor. The Center for Community Change, a Washington research institute, estimates that from 1977 to 1988, financial institutions pledged more than $5 billion to programs for low-income people. There has been a spate of new pledges to such programs in the last two years.
Last week, after nine months, the Federal Reserve Board approved the Citizens and Southern Corporation's acquisition of Sovran Financial, which it had held up because of Sovran's community service record. The merger, which will create the nation's 14th-largest bank with assets of about $48.7 billion, was approved partly because Sovran agreed to lend $25 million over five years to businesses owned by members of minority groups in the Washington area and to lend $10 million to low- and middle-income housing.
The purchase of Florida National Bank by the First Union Corporation in North Carolina was also approved after delays caused by First Union's record in its poor communities. It was finally approved after First Union expanded its programs to these communities and joined a consortium of three banks that committed $100 million in loans to businesses owned by members of minority groups. It has also announced a home mortgage program with low interest rates for low-income people.
The Federal Reserve has warned the Security Pacific Bank in Los Angeles that its proposed acquisition of 20 percent of Mitsui Manufacturing Bank will not be approved until Mitsui's community investment record is reviewed and found to be satisfactory.
A few deals, including the Harris Trust and Savings Bank's acquisition of Frankfort Bancshares Inc. in the Chicago area, were scrapped when the banks decided they could not gain approval. The Harris deal was curtailed, in part, because of its record of investing in poor neighborhoods.
Providing low-cost services for poor neighborhoods is not the most efficient way for banks to use their capital. But their profitability should not be adversely affected because little money is involved relative to a bank's size and because default rates on these types of loans are generally lower than the national averages for consumer loans. But small banks in particular say they do not have the resources to comply with the law. ''One of our major concerns is the increased burden that this is placing on the banks,'' said Virginia Stafford, a spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association.
 
A Recent Success
Sister Barbara Busch, a Roman Catholic nun in Cincinnati, says she has tried over the last eight years to get local banks to lend money for the rehabilitation of decaying housing in the city. She said she has had success only recently, and credits both an amendment to the 1977 law that opens the traditionally secretive bank review process to public scrutiny and a new city ordinance that forces banks to provide data showing where they make retail and commercial loans in Cincinnati.
''It wasn't until we started working with the city ordinance that they responded,'' she said.
Since Congress passed the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, bank regulators including the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and the Comptroller of the Currency have conducted ''C.R.A. reviews'' as part of their routine bank examinations to make sure Federally insured financial institutions are adequately serving their communities.
 
Reluctant Examiners
But until recently, these reviews have been cursory and examiners have been reluctant to give banks a failing grade.
''Up to now most of the institutions - over 95 percent - were not complying with the C.R.A. laws,'' said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs.
But several factors have made examiners tougher on banks. Community groups in recent years have regularly filed protest letters with regulatory agencies urging them to take action against institutions that seemed to be avoiding poor neighborhoods.
There have also been rumblings in Washington over the last two years for more vigorous enforcement of the act. In the wake of the savings crisis and public outcry for stricter banking regulation, Congress passed an amendment to strengthen the law last year. Tacked onto the savings and loan bailout legislation, the amendment requires banks to make their community investment records and examination files available to the public for all reviews conducted after the beginning of last month.
 
Threat of Publicity
Because of the threat of a negative publicity campaign waged by a community group armed with bank records, regulators are expected to be less tempted to give every bank a passing grade, and acquisition-minded banks may be more inclined to increase their involvement in poor neighborhoods.
In an attempt to prove to Congress that a harsh new rule was unnecessary, regulators had begun sending signals to banks that they would be more disciplined in their reviews and tougher on violators of the 1977 law even before the amendment passed.
In response, banks began to form groups to make investments in low-income communities, low-interest mortgages available to low-income people and to help finance the construction and rehabilitation of lower-priced housing.
''There are a lot of banks taking this seriously right now that really did not take it very seriously before,'' said Donald A. Mullane, an executive vice president of the BankAmerica Corporation and head of the California Bankers Association.
 
A Fundamental Problem
But some community groups worry that the banks will not follow through on their commitments. ''The process of getting these organizations capitalized and running has taken longer than it should have,'' said Willie Jones, director of the Community Investment Coalition in Boston. ''The fundamental problem is that the banks don't know how to do business in these neighborhoods.''
The coalition is working with a group of 14 Boston banks that last year pledged $500 million in credit to disadvantaged neighborhoods in Massachusetts.
Community groups also emphasize that banks agreed to many of the pledges only after they had filed complaints with regulators protesting the institutions' lending practices.
In many instances, community groups say, banks have been unwilling to make loans at rates low-income people can afford or to adjust their underwriting standards so they can qualify. Some bankers are unwilling to accept things like applicants' reliable history of paying utility bills in lieu of more standard credit records to make low-interest loans in poor neighborhoods.
''There is something like $5 billion or $6 billion in pledges outstanding, but 80 percent aren't available because the rates or the terms or the structure is not sufficiently flexible,'' said Reed Morgan, director of the Community Reinvestment Institute in San Francisco, a research organization that assists community groups.
Despite their criticism, community groups nationwide see the amendment to the 1977 Act as a new arrow in their quiver.
''This is the most significant development for freeing up money for low-income housing and small businesses since the passage of the original legislation,'' said Jane Uebelhoer, legislative director of Acorn, a grassroots group that focuses on low-income housing and other problems of poor communities.

HEADLINE: OIL SURGE: CONSUMERS ALREADY TAKING A BEATING;
Air Fares Climbing as Fuel Costs Rise

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
The economic fallout from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has quickly filtered to the airline passenger, with higher oil prices already translating into higher air fares. Two airlines will add surcharges or raise fares on Thursday to offset their higher fuel costs, and several others are considering a similar move.
A least one consumer group has objected to the increases, calling them premature. But the airlines, which consume 41 million gallons of jet fuel a day, insist that the extra charges are needed to stem the sudden cash drain. But even with the fare increases, some anlysts said, the airlines may not be able to recoup all the added expense, as some passengers may balk at paying higher fares. 
Meanwhile, airline stocks tumbled yesterday, as concern grew about the higher fuel costs and a possible recession. After labor, fuel is an airline's largest expense, accounting for 15 to 20 percent of a carrier's operating budget.
To recover the billions of dollars in added fuel costs, the airlines will have to raise fares as much as 12 percent, said George James, chairman of Airline Economics, a consulting firm based in Washington. ''It's either higher fares or significant losses over the next year,'' he said.
The rising fuel prices deal another blow to an industry that is already reeling from a summer with more empty seats than airline executives had anticipated. The industry is more vulnerable than most to even the slightest economic downturn.
 
Northwest Plans Surcharge
Northwest Airlines said last week that it would add an $8 fuel surcharge on all its domestic flights beginning Thursday, and yesterday Pan American World Airways said it would increase fares 10 percent on its domestic flights starting Thursday and on its international flights starting Aug. 15.
The move, which is Pan Am's largest fuel-related fare increase since the Arab oil embargo of 1973, is the result of costs that are up significantly in the last few days, said Jeff Kriendler, a Pan Am spokesman. The airline, which has been struggling for years, is forced to buy much of its fuel overseas because of its many international flights. Prices are generally higher abroad than in the United States.
''We are as much victims of what is going on in the Middle East as the consumer at the gas pump,'' said Robert Gibbons, a spokesman for Northwest. In the two days after the Iraqi invasion, the airline's fuel costs rose 8 cents a gallon, he said.
Spokesmen for Continental, American, Delta and USAir said the airlines had not yet decided on whether to add a surcharge or raise fares. A spokeswoman for United Airlines had no comment.
 
Consumers Critical
One consumer group said any fare rises or fuel surcharges was premature. ''It seems awfully early to talk about a 10 percent increase,'' said Richard Livingston, chairman of the Airline Passengers Association of North America, a consumer group based in Washington. ''Why not wait to see where the price levels out?''
Some airlines said it was too early to make a decision. ''We're waiting until a clear picture emerges,'' said Susan Young, a spokeswoman for USAir, in statement echoed by many airlines. ''The market is too volatile.'' she said.
The price of crude oil rose to $28.05 a barrel yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. A few weeks ago, crude was trading at about $16 a barrel. Most airlines have 30-day contracts with fuel suppliers that afford the carriers only limited protection against price fluctuations.
The industry's appetite for fuel is enormous. It consumes 15 billion gallons of fuel each year. For every $1 increase in crude oil prices, jet fuel increases 3 cents a gallon and the industry has to swallow $450 million in added annual fuel costs. A $5 increase in crude means another $2.25 billion in costs for the industry.
Jet fuel sold for an average of 57.8 cents in June, down sharply from January when a heating oil shortage forced the price up to an average of 78.3 cents a gallon. Some airlines set fuel surcharges at the time but dropped them once the price fell again.
Nearly every airline stock fell yesterday. AMR, parent company of American Airlines, fell $4.375, to $50.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. UAL stock, already battered by a union-led takeover attempt that is losing investor confidence, fell $12.50, to $110. Pan Am, the only airline to announce an across-the-board fare increase yesterday, was also the only carrier to gain ground - rising 12 1/2 cents, to $2.125.
